description: International A3-12

title: Schools Are Failing to Serve Homeless Children, Messinger Asserts
description: Calling current policies ''a prescription for chaos,'' City Councilwoman Ruth W. Messinger criticized the Board of Education yesterday for what she asserted was its failure to deal with the problems of homeless children living in hotels.

title: Mets Cut Deficit to 3 1/2 Games
description: With Dwight Gooden on the mound and Keith Hernandez and Howard Johnson hitting the long ones, the Mets completed a three-game sweep of the San Diego Padres tonight and moved another game closer to first place.

title: American to Raise Maxsavers and Tighten Rules
description: American Airlines, in an attempt to regain its role as the industry price leader, announced yesterday that it would raise its Maxsaver fares by $10 each way and increase the advance purchase requirement to 14 days, from seven.

title: Boycotting Guns and Butter
description: By staying away from the current U.N. conference on disarmament and development the United States escapes some simplistic oratory, silly Soviet propaganda and requests to commit funds it can't commit. It also throws away a chance to learn and to lead on critical issues, and moves further down the regrettable path of thwarting rather than encouraging international cooperation.

title: Jewish Tale By Babel Is Found
description: A previously unknown short story by Isaac Babel has been discovered in a Moscow archive and published in a Jewish literary magazine, the official Tass press agency has reported.

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Giants Cancel Reasons Talk
description: Gary Reasons, the Giants' linebacker, and his agent, Leonard Roth, had been scheduled to hold contract talks with the club this morning in an effort to end his holdout. But the team canceled the meeting when it found out that Reasons had planned a news conference for the afternoon.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Protesters, Angered by Injury, Return to Arms Site
description: Protesters today returned to a naval weapons transfer point where a train severed the leg of an antiwar demonstrator Tuesday. Two trains scheduled to leave the station were halted as a result of the renewed demonstrations, according to protest leaders, although this could not be confirmed independently.

title: Let's Not Back the Killers in Mozambique
description: To the Editor:

title: NUNN SEEKS ARMS-TALKS RECORDS
description: Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, has asked President Reagan to collect six years of records from negotiations on medium-range nuclear missiles, warning that he would ask for the entire history of the Geneva talks if the United States and Soviet Union concluded a treaty eliminating those weapons.

title: NEW RULES ON RETIREMENT. . . AND NEW CAREERS TO CONTEMPLATE
description: Not all diplomats are going to wait 20 years to see if they will be forced to retire from the Foreign Service. Some choose to leave early, having seen it coming. Others elect to leave at mid-career for a range of other reasons. Following is a sampling of second careers:

title: Jazz: Don Cherry
description: DON CHERRY'S musical life has been rich in variety and adventure, often played out in exotic locales. He has learned from encounters with remarkable men, including Ornette Coleman, the Indian vocalist Pandit Pran Naph, the South African pianist Abdullah Ibrahim and the West African, Moroccan and American Indian musicians who taught him indigenous instruments and tribal lore. He has been a key member of several significant bands - the original Ornette Coleman Quartet, Old and New Dreams, the multicultural trio Codona. One thing Mr. Cherry hasn't got around to yet is leading a regular, working combo of his own.

title: Advertising; At Last, 'Mr. Paul' Is Found
description: WHAT would you do if your customers professed to love your product, but your market share was no greater than those of your two major competitors?

title: S.E.C. Plea On Loophole
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked Congress today to close a loophole that allows corporate debt guaranteed by commercial banks to be exempt from registration under Federal securities laws.

title: DeMars to Resign
description: Bill DeMars, the batting coach for the Cincinnati Reds, has announced he will not return to the team's coaching staff next season. DeMars, who was picked for the job by Manager Pete Rose, was angered this week when Tony Perez, the first-base coach, was instructed by Bill Bergesch, the general manager, to help instruct hitters.

title: Talking Deals; Big Partners In Technology
description: EVEN a company that specializes in navigation can have trouble finding a quick way to complete a technology-transfer deal. Etak Inc. needed a year and a half of meetings, demonstrations and negotiations to nail down a technology agreement with Blaupunkt-Werke G.m.b.H., the West German maker of audio equipment. Nine more months passed before Etak was allowed to announce the deal last week, and it will take years to find out if the risks involved were worth it.

title: It's Harvest Time for Urban Gardeners
description: THE buzzing bees might not drown out the fire engine sirens on the street, but Franz Supper and Patrick Corrigan don't care. It's harvest time in the city and like other community gardeners the two men are busy gathering the vegetables, herbs and flowers that they and several dozen neighbors have nurtured all summer.

title: Bork On Free Speech
description: In large areas of constitutional law, Judge Robert Bork is a committed radical. He wants to tear up settled understandings of the Constitution, root and branch.

title: FAT YEARS AND LEAN YEARS
description: The Mayor of New York has fallen off the wagon, toppled by a chocolate cake. After his recent stroke, his doctors urged him to diet; good intentions appear to have lasted about 17 days. The wonder is that his diet held on that long.

title: Japan Permit to Barclays
description: The securities arm of Barclays Bank P.L.C. said it had received a license from the Japanese Government to begin trading securities in Tokyo later this month. The British Government had threatened in March to revoke licenses of Japanese banks and insurance companies doing business in the City, London's financial district, if British firms were not given equal access in Japan.

title: Tennis Encouragement
description: The United States Tennis Association is moving to attract more people to tennis and to develop young players of championship caliber.

title: P.L.O. Accepts Plan on Peace
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has accepted a plan for ending the violence around refugee districts in Lebanon.

title: U.S. Wood Exports Rise
description: American exports of wood products were valued at nearly $1.8 billion in the first six months of this year, up 24 percent from the first half of 1986, according to the latest Agriculture Department figures. Japan continued to be the leading buyer of American wood products, accounting for almost $747 million, up 28 percent from a year earlier, the department's Foreign Agricultural Service reported. ''The continued competitiveness of the U.S. dollar and the general reductions in tariff rates for wood products in some Pacific Rim countries have helped spur positive gains in trading activity for all major wood commodities,'' the agency said.

title: European Output Up
description: Industrial production in the European Community rose slightly in May, the trade bloc said today. Its index (based on 100 in 1980) stood at 106.7 in May, up from 106 in April.

title: Jerome Reinstein Dies; A State Judge in Bronx
description: Jerome L. Reinstein, an acting State Supreme Court justice who was to preside over the trial of Larry Davis next week on charges of killing four Bronx drug dealers, died Monday after collapsing in the Bronx County Courthouse. He was 59 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Resorts International to Sell 774 Acres
description: Resorts International, Atlantic City's first casino operator and largest private landholder, is offering to sell hundreds of acres of land all over town.

title: Spanish Royalty to Visit U.S.
description: King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia will visit the United States from Sept. 27 to Oct. 4, the Foreign Ministry said today. A statement said the royal couple would lunch with President Reagan in Washington, then go on to visit Texas, New Mexico and California.

title: U.S. Acquisitions For BICC and Lee
description: P.L.C., a cable maker, and Lee International P.L.C., a film and television services group, said they had joined the growing list of British companies making American acquisitions.

title: Yugoslav Bankruptcies
description: At least 5,000 Yugoslav workers are jobless as a result of bankruptcies under a tough new law aimed at weeding out money-losing companies, the official news agency Tanjug said today. It said Yugoslavia's poorest republic, Montenegro, was the first to implement the law, which went into effect July 1.

title: Progress Is Reported By Ford and Union In Talks on Contract
description: Executives of both the United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company said today that progress was being made in their negotiations for a contract to replace the one that expires Sept 14.

title: Cash Upset by Lundgren
description: There were only a handful of fans remaining at the National Tennis Center to see if the Wimbledon champion would survive the first round of the United States Open. It was not the kind of reception that Pat Cash might have expected, but not half as bad as the one he received from Peter Lundgren of Sweden. On a damp night when many of the fans began leaving for home as the match unfolded, Cash was upset by Lundgren, 6-4, 4-6, 6-4, 6-4, in the first major upset of the tournament.

title: Zany Depression-Era Fad
description: EVER since he was a teen-ager putting balls into the Campbell's soup cans he had sunk in his parents' backyard, John Margolies has been enamored of miniature golf. A much-traveled scout of vernacular architecture along America's roadsides, he has recently focused on the sport that became a national passion during the Depression. The result is ''Miniature Golf,'' a book with color photographs by Mr. Margolies, text by Maria Reidelbach and Nina Garfinkel, and a cover of Astroturf. It is published by Abbeville Press ($19.95). Mr. Margolies's pictures chronicle the fantastic architecture of such endearing courses as Putt-Putt Golf, Rinky-Dink Golf, Moby-Dick Golf, Tom Thumb Golf and Goofy Golf, with their holes and hazards of dragons, cows, pagodas, windmills, castles, Buddhas and sphinxes.

title: 10th-Grader Goes to School at the Open
description: Once inside the gates at the National Tennis Center, one never has a very long walk to the nearest location where something can be bought or sold. The purchase that Michael Chang seeks to make, however, cannot be found anywhere near the footlong hot dogs at the United States Open, or the bottled water, or the rows of stands with the overpriced shoes and shirts and racquets and shorts.

title: Japan Loss In Bonds Stirs Fear
description: A Japanese chemical company yesterday announced large losses from speculation in the Japanese bond market, news that sent a tremor through financial markets around the world.

title: D.I.A. Denies
description: To the Editor:

title: A Prisoner With AIDS Virus Is Isolated After Bite Incident
description: A prison inmate who tested positive for AIDS was placed in segregation pending a decision on charges stemming from a fight with a guard he is said to have bitten on the hand, officials said.

title: Texas to Appeal
description: The University of Texas has decided to appeal an N.C.A.A. decision declaring the football and track star James Lott ineligible. Lott, a senior defensive back and high jumper, was declared ineligible by the school several weeks ago on grounds he had accepted $800 from the sports agent Lloyd Bloom in September 1986. The N.C.A.A. concurred with the Texas action, but gave the school the right to appeal, which it initially declined. Last week, the N.C.A.A. restored the eligibility of Teryl Austin, a football player at Pitt, who agreed to repay money received from Bloom and his associate, Norby Walters. Austin will be suspended for the first two games of the season. DeLoss Dodds, the Texas athletic director, noted the Austin matter in announcing the appeal on Lott. He said that Lott has made arrangements to replay the loan.

title: Godot Isn't Coming
description: Senator Sam Nunn's decision not to run for President leaves Democrats facing the hard reality that what they see - seven relatively unexciting prospects and the possibility of an eighth - is what they'll get in the choice of a Presidential candidate.

title: From Air and Sea, Iran-Iraq 'Tanker War' Heats Up
description: Iraqi warplanes and Iranian naval vessels hit eight ships in about 36 hours in the Persian Gulf in the most concentrated assault on shipping since the Iran-Iraq war began in 1980, according to reports from the region today and Wednesday.

title: Publisher Is Restored in Santa Fe
description: The former owner of a Santa Fe newspaper has resumed management of it after winning a nine-year-old lawsuit.

title: Students Welcome Returning Principal
description: A high-school principal who was suspended last year for making a student disrobe as a punishment returned to his job this week to the applause of students.

title: Lease Finance Signs 9 Airlines
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation said today that it had signed lease agreements worth more than $1 billion with nine airlines.

title: No Big Macs for Saugatuck
description: In the quaint little town of Saugatuck on the Lake Michigan shore, there will be no Big Macs or Chicken McNuggets.

title: The Editorial Notebook: The Other AIDS Epidemic:; A Contagion of Fear Takes Ugly Turns
description: ''They don't need to get an education, because according to statistics I've seen, they only have but five years to live.'' That's a local comment from Arcadia, the Florida town that ostracized the Ray family, whose three boys have been exposed to the AIDS virus. In Pleasant Valley, Pa., parents yesterday demanded mandatory testing of all schoolchildren and segregation of those with AIDS, after the state education secretary ruled that a 6-year-old with the virus must be educated in regular classes. Washington has still not got through the message that the AIDS virus is not spread in the classroom.

title: NATIONAL TECHNICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $163,000 for the quarter and $276,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after a tax credit of $27,000 for both periods and losses from discontinued operations of $564,000 for the quarter and $722,000 for the 6 months.

title: Whitehead Legal Bills Disputed
description: Mary Beth Whitehead should not have to pay the legal fees of Baby M's court-appointed guardian because the attorney was biased in the custody dispute, Mrs. Whitehead's attorney says.

title: High-Tech Job Growth
description: San Jose, Calif., added the most high-technology jobs of any metropolitan area from the end of 1980 through 1986, according to a new survey. Boston ranked second and Los Angeles third. San Jose added 50,000 such jobs in the six-year period, for an annual growth rate of 4.5 percent, reported the Grubb & Ellis Company, a San Francisco real estate services firm.

title: Britain to Extradite 26 Fans for Riot Trial
description: After two years of police work and legal debate, the British Government announced today that 26 British soccer fans would be extradited to Belgium to face charges resulting from the 1985 Heysel Stadium riot in which 39 people were killed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1987
description: Markets

title: ANTI-SANDINISTAS ASKING TV LICENSES
description: Two groups of Nicaraguans say they will seek licenses to operate non-Sandinista television stations under provisions of the new Central American peace accord.

title: Iowans Look at Campaigners And Caution: Caveat Vendor
description: Robert O. Lossner, head of a printing company here, has adopted a stern rule about doing business with Presidential campaigns: He doesn't.

title: Bork Backers Flood Senate With Mail
description: President Reagan has called Judge Robert H. Bork a ''fair-minded'' man of ''detachment and statesmanship,'' but mail pouring into Congressional offices suggests that some of the President's conservative supporters have a much more pointed role in mind for the Supreme Court nominee.

title: Bridge: A Fine, New Book by Kantar Lays Out Play-Defense Pairs
description: Those who like to solve at leisure the difficult problems in play and defense that crop up at the card table should cover the East-West cards in the diagramed deal and plan the play in three no-trump.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I regret what happened. I saw no other possibility to achieve my goal. It was not hooliganism.'' - Mathias Rust, who flew a small plane to Red Square. [ A12:1. ]

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
Litton Profit Increases 18%
description: Litton Industries said today that fourth-quarter earnings rose 18 percent, to $35.4 million, or $1.33 a share, from $30 million, or $1.07 a share, a year ago. Revenues in the quarter ended July 31 rose 7.9 percent, to $1.23 billion, from $1.14 billion.

title: U.S. Loses, 3-2
description: Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins scored three goals to give Team Canada a 3-2 victory over Team USA in a Canada Cup game tonight. Lemieux tied the score with a slapshot at 5 minutes 27 seconds of the second period and put Canada ahead by 2-1 with a power-play goal with :03 left in the period.

title: Lorne Greene Reported In Serious Condition
description: Lorne Greene, the actor who for 14 years played Ben Cartwright, the white-haired patriarch on television's ''Bonanza'' series, is responding to treatment for pneumonia developed after ulcer surgery, a spokesman at St. John's Hospital has said.

title: Article 294587 -- No Title
description: Families of the crew of the ill-fated Challenger space shuttle today announced the selection of a president and a grant of $1 million that will help them build a center for teaching America's youth about space.

title: Conflicting Reports On Status of Waite
description: Confusion about the fate of Terry Waite, the Anglican Church envoy who was kidnapped in Beirut last January while on his fifth mission to free other foreign hostages, deepened yesterday because of conflicting reports - one that he would soon be released, the other that he appears to have died.

title: SHEARSON IN ASIA
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said it was adding $85 million in capital to its Tokyo securities operations to support further growth in Asia. The infusion will lift the capital in Shearson's Tokyo operation to slightly more than $100 million, the company said. Shearson's move exemplifies the trend toward globalization in the securities markets.

title: Dallas Minister, Under Cloud, Gives Up Church Credentials
description: A Methodist minister whose wife was choked nearly to death in April surrendered his church credentials today, citing increasing stress from the attack and the investigation into it by the authorities.

title: U.S. Bank In Squeeze On Libya
description: A London court ruled yesterday that the Bankers Trust Company must pay $292 million to the Libyan Arab Foreign Bank. The money consists of deposits that were ordered frozen by President Reagan in 1986.

title: Boston Journal; A Busy Season For Trucks, Beds And Tuneups
description: The Arthur Fiedler Footbridge over Storrow Drive (clearance 10' 0'') attracts students' U-Haul trucks like a candle draws moths. And the beginning of fall semester is suicide season.

title: Getting A Start
description: A MAJORITY of the city's community gardens are on city-owned land, according to Jane Weissman, director of Operation GreenThumb.

title: Members of AIDS Panel Say Politics Will Not Taint Their Report
description: Members of President Reagan's Commission on AIDS, completing a two-day visit to New York City, said yesterday that politics would play no part in the recommendations they will offer the President when they finish gathering facts about the AIDS epidemic.

title: MOTT'S SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Just a Tenant
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain's New Chief At Merger Agency
description: Sydney Lipworth, deputy chairman of Allied Dunbar Assurance P.L.C., has been named chairman of Britain's Monopolies and Mergers Commission, the Government agency that monitors the effect of mergers on industrial competition.

title: NEW RULES ON RETIREMENT . . .
description: A career as a diplomat with the Foreign Service, a proud institution that traces its origins to Benjamin Franklin, can no longer be viewed as a lifetime vocation.

title: No Lack of Regulation In Farm Credit System
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Talks Last 4 1/2 Hours
description: The leaders of the National Football League's management and the players' union met yesterday for four and a half hours - their first negotiations since Aug. 14 - in an effort to replace the contract that expired last Monday.

title: Air Emergency at Tampa
description: An American Airlines 727 made an emergency landing at Tampa International Airport this afternoon after the pilot reported an engine fire. The 31 passengers and 6 crew members of Flight 907, flying to Tampa from Nashville, were evacuated by emergency chute, and no injuries were reported.

title: CONSOLIDATED FIBRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $79,000 for the quarter and $484,000 for the year. c-Net loss The results for the year-ago periods include a pre-tax charge of $6 million associated with the restructuring of its paper business.

title: Candiotti Loses, 2-1, In 1-Hitter of Tigers
description: Tom Candiotti of the Cleveland Indians pitched seven-and-two-thirds innings of no-hit ball until Matt Nokes singled for the Detroit Tigers' only hit tonight, but he lost the game, 2-1.

title: For Ugandan, a Pledge of Order and Accusations of Abuse, Too
description: When Yoweri Museveni was sworn in as President of Uganda 18 months ago, he promised to bring law and order back to a nation that had endured years of nightmarish violence, repression and bloodshed.

title: Critic's Notebook; How Good Is Jackson's 'Bad'?
description: COMMERCIALLY, it's so far, so good for ''Bad,'' Michael Jackson's sequel to ''Thriller.'' Radio stations are reporting a surge of requests, particularly for the title song. ''It's a heavy-reaction record,'' said Andy Dean, music director of WPLJ-FM in New York City. ''It's living up to the hype, and it looks like a No. 1 record to me.'' The CBS television special on Monday, ''Michael Jackson - The Magic Returns,'' dominated the ratings for its half-hour time slot.

title: INSIDE
description: Test Blasts Shake Steppes

title: Insect-Resistant Plant Reported
description: A Belgian company said it had made an important scientific breakthrough by altering plants genetically so they became poisonous to insects. Plant Genetic Systems of Ghent said its technique could result in a big reduction in the spraying of farm crops with insecticides.

title: Giving a Shape To Sentimental Attachments
description: PATRICIA FUNT, left, sells European decorative objects that date from the mid-1800's to the 1930's. From brass fire screens shaped like silhouettes of women to iron banks that resemble bureaus, ''I search for objects that are not just functional but odd, because people like to buy things that have a sentimental attachment,'' she said.

title: A Moscow Show Brings Chagall 'Back Home'
description: After decades of purposeful neglect, the art of Marc Chagall is receiving a full-scale exhibition in his native land. More than 250 paintings, prints and drawings by the artist, drawn from private collections and from Soviet museum storerooms, are in a show that opened here today at the Pushkin Museum. The exhibition marks the centenary of Chagall's birth.

title: Closed Airport in Flushing Picked For 10-Acre Full-Service Heliport
description: Plans to open a 10-acre heliport at the now-closed Flushing Airport in northern Queens were announced yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Capote 4th as Belmont Opens
description: A change of scenery from Saratoga to Belmont Park yesterday could not change the sputtering fortunes of the D. Wayne Lukas Stable. Capote, last year's champion 2-year-old, finished a dull fourth at odds of 1-2 in an allowance race and then the entry of Without Feathers and Fiesta Gal finished second and fifth at the same short odds in the featured Gazelle Handicap.

title: Court Puts a Snag in Cup Sail
description: Legal action by a New Zealand millionaire who wants to mount an unorthodox challenge for the America's Cup next year has blown into turmoil preparations by the San Diego Yacht Club to defend sailing's most prestigious prize.

title: Yields Rise At Banks
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were generally higher for the week ended yesterday.

title: HARD ROCK CAFE PLC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The U.S. dollar amounts have been converted from U.K. pound sterling at the June 30 exchange rate of 1 pound equals $1.6128. The share earnings represent American Depositary Share and each ADS represents 5 ordinary or class A shares.

title: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest year net includes a pre- tax special charge of $1,272,000 to increase allowance for doubtful accounts and contracts.

title: Of Volcker's Laundry And Fiscal Restraint
description: As chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker was a man of great power. Picture him, then, carrying his dirty laundry in a suitcase every week or so to his daughter's home in Virginia.

title: Taiwan Stocks Continue Surge
description: Stock market fever is sweeping Taiwan as share prices continue their record climb. The index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose 77.13 points today, to 3,291.43.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-After tax credits of $52,000 for the quarter and $716,000 for the year. c-After a tax credit of $1,320,000. d-After a tax credit of $3,346,000 and a gain on the extinguishment of debt of $3,501,000. The latest year results include charges of $56,826,000 in the second quarter from the company's refocusing of its product and marketing strategy, a major restructuring of U.S. operations and a minor streamlining of the company's international network. The prior year results include credits of about $6.8 million from lower-than-expected reductions in force and a favorable settlement with the vendor, net of other normal adjustment. The prior year results also include a loss of about $4.3 million from the disposition of a minority interest held by Datapoint, and credits of about $3 million from the settlement and curtailment of pension obligations in accordance with provisions of the federal accounting standards rule No. 88.

title: Drive Is On to Make 'Dry' Town 'Damp'
description: Ever since Prohibition ended, this rural hideaway has been a bring-your-own-bottle town. Because the sale of alcoholic beverages is banned here, diners arrive in restaurants with their Bordeaux in brown paper bags. Residents restocking their liquor cabinets journey to nearby Westport and Ridgefield.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alberto-Culver Co., Melrose Park, Ill., a maker of beauty and hair products, said it had begun seeking consents from Lamaur Inc. shareholders for a special shareholders meeting in order to remove Lamaur's board and elect its own nominees.

title: CUC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax loss carryforward of $1,197,000.

title: Old Scourge Loses Ground In West Africa
description: In the dusty mud brick villages around here, the medieval sight of a small child leading blind men linked by poles is becoming increasingly rare.

title: Market Place; Is This a Pause In Bull Market?
description: WHAT are the stock market's technicians saying about the Dow Jones industrial average's ragged retreat from the record 2,722.42 set on Aug. 25? For the most part, their work indicates that stock prices rose too far too fast - the Dow had hovered at 2,220 in late May -and were poised for a pullback of fairly limited proportions.

title: The Mild Deception of Distressing Wood
description: LEAD: The term ''distressing'' used in connection with furniture means the endeavor to create the look of wear or long use. To the unenlightened, however, it might conjure images of instant deception: furniture treated with such things as ice picks, chains, hammers, rocks inside socks, burning cigarettes and even a blowtorch, all to imitate the ravages of time.

title: AMPLICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Computers Introduced At A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday introduced a desktop computer and a minicomputer that offer significant advances in technology at a competitive price.

title: U.S. Envoy Returns to Syria After Absence of 10 Months
description: The American Ambassador to Syria returned to Damascus today after a 10-month absence caused by Syria's reported involvement in a London bomb plot.

title: Choices For High Rollers
description: ATTENTION, travelers: If you are a high roller, or yearn to be, here's a brief guide to some amenities you won't want to miss.

title: After-Class Isolation Called Top Pupil Problem
description: A majority of teachers in a survey of parents and teachers say the major reason children have difficulty in school is their isolation and lack of supervision after school.

title: Executing the Potato Play
description: In a minor league baseball game in Williamsport, Pa., the other night, the catcher threw a potato wildly in an apparent attempt to pick a runner off third base.

title: EQUITEC FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Japan's Needless Whaling
description: LEAD: In mid-October, the largest remaining fleet of commercial whaling ships operating on the world's oceans is scheduled to set out from its home port in Japan, bound for the waters of Antarctica. Its goal is to kill 875 whales, ostensibly in the name of scientific research.

title: Regency Theater Is Closed Abruptly
description: The Regency Theater's last picture show didn't happen last night.

title: A Rolling Boil
description: To The Home Section:

title: Ohio Edison Offers $385 Million Issue
description: The Ohio Edison Company is offering a total of $385 million in bonds, in a two-part financing through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Labor Suit Widens Drive on Secrecy Pledge
description: A labor union representing Federal employees has filed a lawsuit to broaden a legal challenge to the Reagan Administration's use of secrecy pledges governing classified information.

title: Pitt Routs B.Y.U
description: Sal Genilla passed for two touchdowns and Craig Heyward, the tailback, threw for another and rushed for 132 yards on 33 carries as Pitt defeated Brigham Young, 27-17, in the season-opener for both teams tonight.

title: Arbitrage Reins Urged For Investment Firms
description: A study of the risk arbitrage business suggests the Government may need to prohibit investment banking firms that arrange corporate takeovers from speculating in takeover stocks, Senator William Proxmire said yesterday.

title: Advertising; New Education Guide For Veterans
description: College-bound soldiers can now consult a new guide to be issued in January by School Guide Publications of New Rochelle, N.Y., in conjunction with the Department of the Army. Called Army Continuing Education, it will have an initial circulation of 100,000.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Fluor Corp., Irvine, Calif., a worldwide engineering, construction, procurement and project management concern, appointed Denis P. Kalscheur treasurer and vice president.

title: DOW BARELY STAYS ABOVE 2,600 LEVEL
description: The stock market sagged again yesterday, but a late rally trimmed earlier sharp losses.

title: BLENDER'S ON THE BLINK; WHERE TO GET IT FIXED?
description: THE toaster won't pop up. The iron doesn't get hot. The coffee mill won't grind. And your warranty has run out. What do you do - throw it out? Not necessarily. You might be able to have it fixed at a repair shop.

title: Voting and Frittering
description: No matter what constituents think, legislators do take their attendance records seriously. For example, Senate rules provide 15 minutes for a roll-call, ample time for all 100 senators to reach the floor and cast their votes. But it is a rare Senate roll-call that takes only 15 minutes; rather than shut out any senator who might possibly be on his way, the leadership routinely permits the voting to go on for half an hour or even 45 minutes. A considerable part of the day is often frittered away in this manner.

title: Italian TV to Broadcast A Concert by Madonna
description: The first of two Italian concerts by Madonna will be telecast live in several countries by Italy's state-run RAI television network.

title: Rangers Sign Maloney
description: The Rangers announced yesterday the signing of Don Maloney, the 28-year-old left wing, to a contract for next season. Maloney, who has been with the Rangers since 1978, ranks ninth on the club's career point list with 456, 12th in goals with 179 and ninth in assists with 277. Last season he had 19 goals and 38 assists in 72 games.

title: Yellow Rain Falls
description: As every reader of Washington memoirs knows, Government has two castes: bureaucrats who endlessly churn out red tape, and political appointees who daringly cut through it. The case of yellow rain, set out in the fall issue of Foreign Policy, demolishes this myth. It proves how embarrassingly astray political appointees can go when they ignore routine procedure.

title: Javelin Thrower Barred
description: Sue Howland, an Australian javelin thrower, has been barred from the world track and field championships after testing positive for ''a drug in the steroid group'' at a British meet earlier this summer, officials said today.

title: GALOOB LICENSING DEAL
description: Lewis Galoob Toys Inc. said that it had acquried worldwide licensing rights to make toys and games featuring the Garbage Pail Kids and the Garbage Gang.

title: Tennis Just a Game to Bassett
description: She can still draw a crowd, grown men with telephoto lenses and adolescent boys who lean onto the railings around the court and whisper encouragement as she passes.

title: Gondrezick Gets Probation
description: Grant Gondrezick, the Phoenix Suns' guard who was one of 13 defendants in a drug-conspiracy case, pleaded guilty to a reduced charge yesterday and was sentenced to three years' probation.

title: A Snag Delays Search for City Schools Chancellor
description: The New York City Board of Education, which had planned to form a panel by yesterday to help it find a new schools chancellor, ''will probably not have the names until Friday,'' the board's president said.

title: Last-Place Pirates Improve by Trading
description: In 1976, Charlie Finley tried to sell off some of the Oakland A's biggest stars - Vida Blue to the Yankees for $1.5 million, Rollie Fingers and Joe Rudi to the Boston Red Sox for $1 million each. Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, prohibited the sales.

title: Jewish Leader Protests Choice of Israel Consul
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, a member of Israel's Parliament and a founder of the Jewish Defense League, staged a peaceful protest here Tuesday against the appointment of Mohammed Massarwa, an Arab, as Israel's new Consul General.

title: On Mammograms
description: To The Home Section:

title: Auto Agency Bribery Charged
description: An inspector's aide with the State Motor Vehicle Department has been charged with taking bribes to pass vehicles with defective equipment, the state police said today. The aide, Christopher Chambers, 31 years old, of Bridgeport was charged Tuesday at the agency's office in Bridgeport, where he has worked for about nine years. He was released on a written promise to appear in Superior Court.

title: Cannon Out of Prison
description: Billy Cannon, the 1959 Heisman Trophy winner who was convicted in 1983 of heading a group of counterfeiters in Baton Rouge, La., has been released from Federal prison and has reopened his dental practice in Baton Rouge.

title: REBUKE SUGGESTED FOR GENE SCIENTIST
description: A review committee at Montana State University said today that an experiment involving genetically altered bacteria was in violation of Federal regulations and recommended that the scientist who conducted the test be reprimanded by the president of the university.

title: Arms Dealer Is Cited By Court in Iran Case
description: Albert Hakim, the Iranian-born arms dealer who helped arranged American arms sales to Iran, has been cited for contempt of court for refusing to comply with a subpoena issued by the grand jury in the Iran-contra affair, and is appealing the citation, people familiar with the case said today.

title: Bond Prices Continue Sharp Fall
description: Bond prices plunged again yesterday in waves of nervous, heavy selling. As in recent days, no single event could be isolated as the root cause of the selloff, although analysts agreed that a sharp overnight drop in the Japanese bond market was a catalyst.

title: The 'Windfall' Tax Should Blow Away
description: LEAD: When the Senate amended its version of the pending trade bill to repeal the windfall profits tax, it took a long overdue step toward abolition of a perverse piece of legislation. This misnamed, counterproductive tax has already extracted more billions of dollars from American oil consumers than it has produced in revenues.

title: INVESTORS SAVINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $10,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $148,000 for the year.

title: Abortion Foe Gets 7 Years For Bombings
description: A 37-year-old fireworks expert was sentenced yesterday to seven years in prison for his role in the bombing of abortion clinics in New York City.

title: Chicago Merc and Reuters Set Link
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Reuters agreed yesterday to establish a global electronic trading system.

title: U.S. Team Joins Russians in Monitoring Explosion
description: The steppes of Central Asia shook twice today as a total of 30 tons of high explosives was set off to test whether teams of American and Soviet scientists, up to 400 miles away, could detect relatively small explosions.

title: Up in Arms
description: To The Home Section:

title: KEY RATES
General Cinema
description: The General Cinema Corporation said it had paid $39 million for 500,000 more shares of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., increasing its interest in the retailer to 49.9 percent, from more than 48 percent. The purchase was General Cinema's last opportunity to maximize its interest in Neiman-Marcus Group Inc., a specialty store company that was spun off from Carter Hawley last week. Shareholders of Carter Hawley, based in Los Angeles, are to receive stock in the new company under a previously announced restructuring. With its new stock purchase, General Cinema, based in Chestnut Hill, Mass., stands to increase its ownership in Neiman-Marcus to 60 percent.

title: The Matter of Killing
description: To The Home Section:

title: Disclosure By Hunts
description: Two bankrupt companies controlled by the Hunt brothers filed a consolidated disclosure statement today in Federal bankruptcy court, completing the financial picture of the Hunts' major holdings.

title: Some Midwest Farms Prospering
description: Southeastern Minnesota has hardly been immune from the hard times that have hit the Farm Belt. But, as farmers in this region demonstrate, not everyone is suffering.

title: Yanks Win on Pinch-Hit
description: Jerry Royster was still just a member of the supporting cast when all the histrionics were taking place last night. He sat passively on the bench for nine innings as pitchers withstood inspections, gloves were checked and baseballs were removed for post-game examination.

title: Fairchild to Sell 2 Subsidiaries
description: Fairchild Industries, a diversified military contractor, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its aircraft operations to an investor group headed by senior management. The company also said it had agreed to sell a subsidiary that makes building products to Pacific Precision Metals Inc., a company formed by Fairchild employees.

title: U.N. CHIEF RECEIVES BACKING FOR TRIP TO IRAN AND IRAQ
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar received the backing today of the five permanent members of the Security Council to begin a Persian Gulf peace mission next week, senior United Nations officials said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: New York Offers A New Collider Site
description: The Cuomo administration, without public announcement, has offered the Federal Government a fourth site as a possible location for the $4.4 billion ''supercollider,'' state officials said yesterday.

title: BEARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $1,026,000 for the quarter and $1,113,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss The latest second quarter results include a pre-tax gain of $13,490,000 from the sale and issuance of Uspci Inc. stock.

title: Maputo Journal; Now a Little Weary of Marxism's Heroic Slogans
description: The streets of this African capital are named after Mao, Marx, Ho Chi Minh and other revolutionary heroes, and there are slogans on peeling stucco walls proclaiming the triumphs of the revolution and the role of the ruling party here, Frelimo, as the vanguard.

title: A.D. MOMIGLIANO, HISTORIAN AND CLASSICS PROFESSOR, DIES
description: Arnaldo Dante Momigliano, an Italian historian and internationally renowned professor of classics, who received a MacArthur Foundation fellowship last spring, died Tuesday at Central Middlesex Hospital in London. He was 78 years old.

title: Rock: John Hiatt at the Bottom Line
description: FOR more than a decade, John Hiatt has been searching for the style and the voice that will put across his crafty songs. Now, with his new album, ''Bring the Family,'' he is on the verge of finding it: a lean, bluesy guitar band that puts the steadfast chug of Memphis soul and the twang of rockabilly behind Mr. Hiatt's feral baritone.

title: Voting and Running
description: Running for President while serving in Congress can take a heavy toll on attendance records. Statistics compiled by Legi-Slate, a Congressional data bank, show that with one exception senators and representatives seeking the White House have missed more votes than any of their less overtly ambitious colleagues.

title: Photo of strap restrain system being tested by the New York City Police Department for restraining emotionally disturbed or violent people; Police Try Strap to Restrain Suspects
description: The New York City Police Department is experimenting with a new device designed to restrain emotionally disturbed or violent people while they are being transported in patrol cars.

title: Aquino Cabinet Backs Pay Raise Sought by Military
description: The Cabinet agreed today to sponsor legislation raising the pay of soldiers after hearing a plea from the Chief of Staff that they address the grievances of a restive military.

title: New Breed of Sergeants: Less Spit, More Polish
description: In a far corner of this sprawling post, the new Sergeants Major Academy will open in November, a symbol of a resurgence in the authority and responsibility of the noncommissioned officer corps in the Army.

title: Jazz: Charles Gayle
description: THE challenge of free jazz is to create coherent, compelling music without such obvious devices as melody, recurring chord sequences or a steady beat. It's a challenge that has defeated many a virtuoso since the free-jazz heyday of the 1960's. But Charles Gayle, a tenor saxophonist, is carving out a free jazz that is muscular, impassioned, clearly structured and wonderfully volatile.

title: BCI Ready to Sell The Last of Beatrice
description: The BCI Holdings Corporation, which took the Beatrice Companies private last year and has been selling off parts of it since then, said today that it had retained the First Boston Corporation to help with the possible sale of the company's only remaining division.

title: HERS
description: A WOMAN walks up Madison Avenue. She's wearing one of the new short skirts - one of the ones that, after recovering from the wafts of Poison, Obsession and Giorgio, you see in all the magazines now. It's higher than the Dow Jones. If she bent over, she'd be fined for exposure. A man passes her on the street. He stops, turns, stares at the legs. I stare at him staring at them. What is it about women's legs anyhow? What do they tell men about us? What do they know about our legs that we don't? Why is it the ones who are all covered up do all the staring?

title: Strikers Assert NBC Walked Out on Talks
description: The union on strike against NBC accused the network yesterday of ''walking out'' of contract negotiations with a Federal mediator. The network, in turn, said that the negotiations had been recessed at the suggestion of the mediator.

title: Local Graft, and Tart Tongue, Are Bruising Capital's Mayor
description: Marion S. Barry Jr., who learned long ago to accept criticism as among the vicissitudes of public life, is under attack as never before, and some fellow Democrats have started speculating that he might be forced from the Mayor's office here.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Changes Will Be Needed for New School Chancellor to Succeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Group Drops Lawsuit Over Reburial of Ancestors
description: A Chumash Indian group is dropping its lawsuit against two rival groups and several government agencies over reburial of its ancestors, attorneys say.

title: AIRLINES ORDERED TO DISCLOSE DATA ON FLIGHT DELAYS
description: People planning airplane trips will soon be able to learn how often the flights they are considering arrive on time, under a ruling made today by Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-After a gain of $321,000 for the quarter and a loss of $308,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations, and a loss of $1,536,000 from disposal of discontinued operations for the both periods. The latest periods include pre-tax charges of $36,966,000 for the quarter and $41,269,000 for the 6 months for costs associated with stock incentive, severance and early retirement programs resulting from the leveraged buyout, as well as legal and advisory fees related to the Dart Group Corp.'s proposal to acquire Supermarkets General. The company also said the latest periods' results include pre-tax LIFO charges of $2.6 million for the quarter and $5.3 million for the 6 months, compared with year-ago results of $1.2 million for the quarter and $2.4 million for the 6 months.

title: Police Captain Faces Fraud Charges
description: A 35-year-old New York City police captain was arrested yesterday on charges of falsifying financial statements in order to qualify for an apartment in a city-financed, oceanfront housing development in Rockaway, Queens, the authorities said.

title: Dart Group Wants Southland Chain
description: The Dart Group Corporation has offered to buy the 467-store Chief Auto Parts chain from the Southland Corporation, a Dart spokesman said. But Dart is one of ''dozens and dozens'' of parties interested in six operations being sold by Southland to finance a $4.6 billion leveraged buyout by the controlling Thompson family, said Markeeta McNatt, a Southland spokeswoman.

title: Harry W. Baehr, 79; An Ex-Editorial Writer
description: Harry W. Baehr, the former chief editorial writer for The New York Herald Tribune, died of an apparent heart attack Wednesday in his apartment in Brooklyn Heights. He was 79 years old.

title: Don Cherry
description: Don Cherry, a trumpeter, is leading a quartet with Carlos Ward on alto saxophone, Cameron Brown on bass and Ed Blackwell on drums tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: TRW Settles U.S. Dispute
description: TRW Inc. pleaded guilty today to charges that a Denver subsidiary of the military contractor had overcharged the Pentagon by about $2.6 million.

title: ERO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in March.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PASSION BY DESIGN: The Art and Times of Tamara de Lempicka. By Baroness Kizette de Lempicka-Foxhall as told to Charles Phillips. Illustrated. 191 pages. Abbeville Press. $29.95

title: Lawyer for Hakim Is Seeking To Bar Handing Over Papers
description: Albert Hakim, the Iranian-American businessman, is a target of the Iran-Contra grand jury's investigation and would incriminate himself if compelled to produce records of purported covert arms deals, his attorney told an appeals court today.

title: EXCELAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $190,000 for the quarter and $310,000 for the 6 months.

title: Antitrust Official Takes Aim at Organized Crime
description: The new chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division, Charles Rule, said today that he would expand antitrust prosecutions using legislation such as the Federal racketeering statute.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Sindelar First-Round Leader: Joey Sindelar played the final 10 holes in seven under par yesterday and finished with a six-under-par 65 to take a one-stroke lead after the first round of the B.C. Open in Endicott, N.Y. Jay Delsing was second at 66 and Antonio Cerda was third, another stroke back, over the En-Joie Golf Club course. ''The last 10 holes, seven under, that will certainly turn you around and get it going in the right direction,'' said Sindelar, a native of nearby Horseheads, N.Y.(AP) Dog Show Great Dane Is Best: A 4-year-old Great Dane, Ch. Sheenwater Gamble on Me, owned by Sally Chandler and Chris O'Connell, was named best of 1,343 dogs yesterday at the 47th all-breed show of the Rockland County Kennel Club on the grounds of Rockland Community College in Suffern, N.Y. Boxing Jackson Wins on Knockout: Tyrone Jackson of Harlem knocked out Wilmer Ruiz of Tyler, Tex., at 37 seconds of the sixth round of a scheduled 12-rounder to retain his Continental Americas super featherweight championship last night at Felt Forum. Jackson, (25-1 with 20 knockouts) sent Ruiz (16-4) to the canvas with an overhand right to the head, and Referee John LoBianco counted him out. Football Lions Rout Eagles: Chuck Long threw two touchdown passes and Detroit intercepted two passes and had seven sacks as the Lions buried the Philadelphia Eagles, 36-3, last night in the final National Football League exhibition game for both teams. The game was played at Philadelphia.

title: Jazz: Sonny Greenwich
description: SONNY GREENWICH, a Canadian guitarist who dropped out of sight after making a reputation in the 1960's, marked his reemergence with a Greenwich Village Jazz Festival showcase Wednesday afternoon at Sweet Basil. Mr. Greenwich now lives in Montreal and has just released an album for Justin Time Records. The Sweet Basil sets by Mr. Greenwich's quartet were also recorded.

title: 3 Compete for Arms-Control Post
description: Administration officials said today that three candidates were being considered to succeed Kenneth L. Adelman as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency when he leaves the post next month.

title: A Test on AIDS For the Candidates
description: LEAD: Health care workers who distance themselves from AIDS are attracting attention. Politicians, particularly Presidential candidates, who do so attract much less attention. But political leaders' neglect of the problem is as damaging to national security as health workers' is to patients.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The year-ago third quarter and 9 months include a $461,000 gain on the sale of real estate.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Tuesday about a straw poll at the Century Association on the admission of women carried a headline that oversimplified the finding of the poll. As the article pointed out, a majority of the members said they would favor the admission of women if - a condition specified in the poll question - a city law forbidding discrimination in public accommodations were upheld as constitutional.

title: Film: 'Blood Diner'
description: THE only question worth asking about ''Blood Diner'' is:

title: Rape Suspect Held in Town After Fingerprinting Inquiry
description: A man was charged today with raping two elderly women in this small steel town, where the police had asked black men for their fingerprints to help their four-year-old investigation.

title: Odetta at Speakeasy
description: Odetta will sing blues and folk songs tomorrow at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670). Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; admission is $10 with a two-drink minimum.

title: Truth About the Goldenrod
description: Anyone who thinks a goldenrod is a goldenrod should take a second look as the flowers are starting their big bright show. There are about 10 dozen kinds in the U.S. The flowers of some grow in plumes, others like wands, while still others are flattopped. There is early goldenrod and late goldenrod, rough-leaved and lance-leaved. Alpine goldenrod likes high places; seaside goldenrod prefers the shore, and pine barren goldenrod is very particular about its habitat. Gray goldenrod has grayish stems. Silverrod has white flowers and sweet goldenrod has leaves that can be brewed into a pleasant, anise-flavored tea.

title: Country Fair Becomes Land of the Lava Lamp
description: It is country fair season, but it has been almost six years since anyone has seen a Ferris wheel, a 320-pound squash or an ox pull here in this fast-growing western Connecticut city.

title: Florida Sets Tax Debate
description: Bowing to pressure from lawmakers and business interests, Florida's Governor today scheduled a special legislative session to decide the future of the state's tax on advertising and other services.

title: EVANS & SUTHERLAND COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today: Sept. 4, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Iran-Contra Panel Got Out the Wrong Facts
description: To the Editor:

title: Listening Spots for Concertless Weekend
description: Once upon a time, musical life was divided between ''the season,'' which ran from mid-autumn to early spring, and ''the off-season,'' which took up the rest. The off-season no longer exists - now there is ''the summer season,'' very busy and full - but anachronistic gaps linger in the schedule to remind us that music used to rest periodically to recharge its batteries. This weekend is not quite ''off'' - the New York City Opera's ''Desert Song'' is playing and there are things to hear at some of the holiday festivals - but the fact remains that there does not appear to be a single classical-music event scheduled in any Manhattan concert hall today through Monday.

title: PEP BOYS-MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: Living Colour
description: Living Colour, a band led by Vernon Reid on guitar, will perform tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). The Greg Trooper band and the Silos will also perform, on a bill that begins at 11 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: Meadow Gold Dairy Moves to Tracy-Locke
description: Meadow Gold, a Houston dairy that was acquired by Borden Inc. dairy last November, has shifted its $4.5 million budget to Tracy-Locke of Dallas in an effort to consolidate advertising. Borden has been doing business at the agency since 1981.

title: Pressure On Fed for Rate Rise
description: The dollar's decline and new economic strength, both of which awaken fears of inflation, are putting pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, economists said today.

title: Kemp Campaign Aide Ousted for Racial Slurs
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp's Presidential campaign today dismissed an honorary county chairman who had refused to apologize for his racial slurs.

title: COOPER DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an $11,419,000 gain on the sale of Cooper Technicon Inc.'s blood bank and immunochemical product line and an extraordinary charge of $4,711,000 for the expensing of a portion of Technicon's unamortized debt issuance costs. The results for the latest quarter and 9 months include those of 2 months and 8 months, respectively, of Cooper Technicon Inc., its previously voting majority-owned affiliate, but that future results of Technicon would not be included in the company's results on a consolidated basis. The results of Cooper Technicon included in the latest periods are for the Nov. 1, 1986 to June 30, 1987 period.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 396 money market mutual funds increased $258.2 million, to $244.51 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 103 institutional funds were down $531.1 million, to $66.13 billion. The 200 general purpose funds rose $1.15 billion, to $70.36 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds fell $361.7 million, to $108.01 billion.

title: 2 Mob Figures Slain by Gunman in Brooklyn
description: Two men described by the police as members of the Colombo organized-crime family were slain in Brooklyn yesterday by one or two gunmen who strode up to them on a quiet sidewalk, opened fire, leaped into a car driven by an accomplice and sped away.

title: Duquesne Ban Ends
description: Duquesne University, which was reprimanded last year for failing to field the required number of Division I sports teams, has been taken off probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Duquesne's athletic program is in full compliance with N.C.A.A. requirements, the acting university president, Rolando Bonachea, said yesterday. To maintain Division I status, a college must sponsor eight men's varsity sports teams and six women's teams. Duquesne failed to field the required number of competitors in men's and women's swimming during the 1985-86 academic year, leading to the probation.

title: A Split at LJN Toys
description: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos and LJN Toys Ltd. have agreed to end their yearlong relationship. The client spends about $5 million in TV and print advertising, mainly to promote two of its toys, Video Art and Gotcha, a gun that shoots colored pellets. LJN said that its advertising for this year is set and may use agencies on a project basis in the future.

title: Tirez Tirez
description: Tirez Tirez, a rock band led by Mikel Rouse, will perform tonight at 9 and 11 at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055); the duo of Angel Dean and Tony Maimone will open. Admission is $5.

title: PREDICTED DECAY OF ELEMENT SEEN
description: Scientists in California have reported the first direct observation of an extremely rare form of radioactivity that was hitherto known only as a theoretical prediction.

title: Saxes at Carlos 1
description: The World Saxophone Quartet -Julius Hemphill, David Murray, Oliver Lake and Hamiet Bluiett - will perform tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: When Koch Calls for His Bowl
description: In one of those throwaway lines for which he is famous, Mayor Koch said Tuesday that the diet he is supposed to be on would have to wait until after he had some coconut daiquiris this weekend. Not just any coconut daiquiris, but those made by his old friend David Margolis.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Antoinette Castelli, 58, Dies; President of Graphics Gallery
description: Antoinette Faissex du Bost Castelli, the president of Castelli Graphics Gallery in Manhattan, died of a hemorrhage yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital, where she was being treated for cancer. She was 58 years old.

title: Crude Oil Edges Lower As a Balance Is Struck
description: Crude oil futures closed slightly lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as prices stabilized at levels seen a week ago.

title: George Mikes, 75; Wrote Gentle Satires And Serious Works
description: George Mikes, a Hungarian-born writer who wrote gentle satires on the foibles of nations, typified by ''How to Be an Alien,'' has died at the age of 75, his family said today.

title: BELL, W & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-After a writeoff of $6.6 million for discontinuance of the company's Houston-based operations. The latest fourth quarter loss is primarily attributable to the curtailment of Houston operations.

title: Sometimes a Resignation Is Only a Resignation
description: To the Editor:

title: Cash's Early Departure Is No Surprise at Open
description: There were a lot of nods and knowing glances around the National Tennis Center yesterday. Everyone from Arthur Ashe to the vendor hawking Italian ices had apparently anticipated the quick and unceremonious demise of Pat Cash, the Wimbledon champion, who was eliminated by Peter Lundgren of Sweden shortly before 1 A.M. yesterday in the first round of the United States Open.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
Koch and U.S. Trade Blame on Amnesty Turnout
description: Mayor Koch and Federal immigration officials traded accusations yesterday over why relatively few illegal aliens in New York City have applied for amnesty under the new immigration law.

title: CENTURY COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income There were no share earnings in the year-ago quarter after provisions for dividend requirements on preferred stock.

title: In Korea Strike, Tension but Hope of Harmony
description: The tennis courts at the Hyundai executive apartment compound were empty today, and so was the adjoining company-owned hotel, a comfortable place with faint delusions of grandeur.

Commissars and Cavaliers
description: The fictional Agent 007 zooms around the Alps in an exotic armored Aston Martin. A real 007 pokes around Manhattan in a Dodge.

title: Dollar Closes Mixed; Precious Metals Drop
description: The dollar turned in a mixed performance yesterday, firming against the Japanese yen but setting new three-month lows against the West German mark in active trading dominated by rumors.

title: Biaggi 'Arrangement' Heard on Tape
description: In a secretly recorded telephone conversation played in court yesterday, Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, was heard making arrangements for a 1985 Florida vacation for Representative Mario Biaggi and a companion and to have the bill paid by a printing company controlled by Mr. Esposito.

title: Bridge: Losers in Final, by 8 Points, Had Much to Dream About
description: When a major match is won, and lost, by a small margin the losers have plenty to keep them awake at night.

title: FIVE-PART LOOK AT DANCE STYLES, ON 13
description: CHANNEL 13 has found still some more series on film and dance, but this new batch approaches the subjects from unusual angles. The five-part ''Rhythms of Earth,'' getting under way tomorrow at 5:30 P.M., offers an anthropological study of dance styles. ''What Do Those Old Films Mean?,'' beginning tomorrow night at 10 on the ''Film on Film'' series, goes in for a sociological approach, trying, in the words of a news release, to ''look at certain moments of contemporary history when cinema and society shed light on each other.''

title: About Real Estate; A 40-Story Tower Jolts East End Ave.
description: East End Avenue, that secluded 13-block enclave near the East River between 79th and 92d Streets, has long maintained a reputation for elegance and stability. Occupying an extreme easterly site, East End is not a route to anywhere and is unusually quiet for a Manhattan thoroughfare.

title: 2 Towns Fight Over Past and Future
description: Salem and Bridgeton, two small county seats in southern New Jersey with a strong interest in their Swedish past and their tourism future, met in legal combat here today.

title: Caesars Bid Is Weighed
description: Martin T. Sosnoff, the investor who put Caesars World Inc. into play earlier this year, said yesterday that he was still interested in acquiring the casino operator and had made another bid for the company the day after New Jersey's Casino Control Commission rejected Caesar's proposed recapitalization plan.

title: Tigers Defeat Indians
description: Walt Terrell continued his success at Tiger Stadium, and Lou Whitaker and Kirk Gibson hit home runs tonight as the Detroit Tigers beat the Cleveland Indians, 3-1.

title: East German Escapes
description: An East German man climbed over a border wall and swam across a river to West Germany, raising to seven the number of escapes this week, the police said today. The 32-year-old man crossed the frontier Wednesday night near Hof, in northeastern Bavaria.

title: IMMUCELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dresden Journal; A Task of Communism: Building a Glorious Past
description: It is a haunting sight, the charred skeletons of Dresden's once-splendid center.

title: Hudson Valley
description: An old-fashioned country fair and a ''Civil War Weekend'' as well as an Irish and an Indian festival are among the holiday events in the Hudson Valley this weekend.

title: 3 Exchanges Fight Bank
description: The world's three largest futures and options exchanges have asked a Federal court here to nullify a decision allowing the Security Pacific National Bank to create an automated marketplace for trading in Government security options.

description: The Economy

title: Eichelberger in the Park
description: Wigstock '87, an outdoor festival of music and performance art, will take place Monday from 2 to 8 P.M. at Tompkins Square Park, Avenue A and Seventh Street. The festival -the third sponsored by the Pyramid Cocktail Lounge - will feature the performers Ethyl Eichelberger and Joey Arias, and the groups Kooky Kabuki and Dean and the Weenies. Admission is free. Rain date, Sept. 13. Information: 219-8833.

Ashton-Tate Ships Macintosh dBase
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation said it has begun shipping the long-awaited dBase Mac program, a version of its industry-standard data base management software for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh. This is Ashton-Tate's first product for the Macintosh and the first truly powerful data base program for that popular computer, although releases from competitors are imminent.

title: HALMI, ROBERT INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
Puckett Bat Displayed
description: And on the subject of bats, the one used by Kirby Puckett, the Minnesota Twins outfielder, to make 10 hits in two games against Milwaukee last Saturday and Sunday has been sent to the Baseball Hall of Fame to be part of a 1987 highlights exhibition. ''It was broken, but it's probably the only way I'll get there,'' Puckett said before the game Wednesday against Boston. Puckett broke the bat on his final turn at bat Tuesday. Attempting to tie the major league record of 13 hits in 3 consecutive games, Puckett hit a soft grounder to short.

title: Space Program Lauded
description: The Advertising Council started a national public-service advertising campaign this week on behalf of the United States Space Foundation. It includes a series of 17 television spots featuring national figures and celebrities and is intended to portray the benefits of the space program. The campaign, created by the Campbell-Ewald Company, is expected to generate more than $25 million a year in donated time and space from print and broadcast media.

title: HOLIDAY MONDAY
description: Monday is Labor Day, and closings vary. Following are holiday schedules: NEW YORK Parade: Starts at 11 A.M. on Fifth Avenue at 44th Street, moving north to 86th Street, then east to Third Avenue. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No collection or street sweeping. Governmental offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed; special and express mail only. Banks: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways, buses, and Long Island Railroad on holiday schedules. On the No. 7 line, subways will run every four minutes to the Shea Stadium stop. L.I.R.R. trains to Shea Stadium will run every half hour on the Port Washington line. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Sanitation: Local option. Governmental offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed; special and express mail only. Banks: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on holiday schedule, except shore express from New York, Newark, Hoboken and Bergen County. CONNECTICUT Sanitation: No collection. Governmental offices: Federal, state, and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed; special and express mail only. Banks: Closed. Transportation: Metro-North on holiday schedule. Schools: Closed.

title: Libyan Gain in Chad Dashes Hopes for Peace
description: An unexpected Libyan military victory in Chad has dashed hopes that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi had given up his territorial ambitions there, according to American officials and military analysts.

description: b-After a gain of $2,523,000 from life insurance proceeds resulting from the death of John Cade, founder and chairman.

title: A Filipino General's Problem: After a Mutiny, Who's Loyal?
description: Gen. Eduardo Taduran sits in the office where he was confined by his own troops during last week's uprising and wonders who among his soldiers is loyal to him.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bill Giles, president of the Phillies, reversed an earlier decision and said he would not withhold Kevin Gross's salary during a 10-day suspension for putting sandpaper in his glove during a game against the Cubs. The suspension went into effect this week after Gross lost an appeal. . . . Billy Williams will manage one of the Chicago Cubs' two teams in the Arizona instructional league this fall, the team announced. Williams, who was recently inducted into baseball's Hall of Fame, is a hitting instructor for the Cubs. . . . George Gervin, who retired as a player last season, will join the San Antonio Spurs this year as a member of the staff, the team announced. . . . Andre Dawson of the Chicago Cubs, with 15 home runs and a .309 batting average, was named the player of the month in August in the National League, and Doug Drabek of the Pittsburgh Pirates, who went 5-0 with a shutout and 2.79 earned run average, was named the pitcher of the month.

title: Zenith to Sell Tubes in Japan
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said C. Itoh & Company, the Japanese trading concern, had agreed to distribute its high-resolution picture tube in Asia.

description: To the Editor:

title: Catskill Auction to Benefit Fly Fishing
description: If you are a collector of fishing rods and reels and other angling equipage, you might wish to attend an auction next Friday in Roscoe, N.Y., that is being held for the benefit of the Catskill Fly Fishing Center.

title: Too Few Answers About the Stark
description: LEAD: As the naval buildup continues in the Persian Gulf, questions about the Stark tragedy are assuming ever-greater significance. So far, much of the blame has been shouldered by the ship's officers, who have been accused of errors of judgment and poor readiness. But it appears that other factors - including faulty equipment and perhaps flawed intelligence -contributed to the warship's vulnerability, raising questions about the safety of other warships in the region.

title: HUNTER-MELNOR reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2

title: Red Staff Disgruntled
description: An apparent rift has developed between Marge Schott, owner of the Cincinnati Reds, and leaders of the team's baseball operations, including the manager, Pete Rose. The batting coach, Billy DeMars, who has told the Reds he is leaving, is said to be the first victim, but not the last. The first-base coach, Tony Perez, has replaced DeMars, whom Rose picked in 1985. ''It didn't come from me,'' said Rose, when asked who had first suggested that Perez take over at least part of the batting coach job. DeMars, who is reportedly paid about $80,000 a year as one of the major leagues' best-paid hitting coaches, announced last weekend he was leaving when the season ends after Bill Bergesch, the general manager, asked Perez to help work with some of the team's hitters. Bergesch said that he had approached DeMars about giving up some of his role to Perez. ''At that point, he didn't feel that they both should be working with hitters, so he just said let Tony do it,'' Bergesch said.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Martinho Da Vila, S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street (243-4940). Martinho Da Vila, the renowned Brazilian samba master, kicks off a monthlong World Music Festival celebrating S.O.B.'s fifth anniversary with a three-night engagement beginning this evening. Mr. Da Vila started his career in 1957, at the age of 19, by composing the popular samba ''Carlos Gomes.'' In 1969, he recorded the first of 19 highly successful albums, during the course of which he perfected the intimate lyrical style of samba known as ''partido alto.'' The music on his newest album, ''Batuqueiro,'' is a deliciously festive exploration of different styles of Brazilian party music. Show times are 10:30 P.M. and 12:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow and at 10 P.M. and midnight on Sunday. Tickets are $16.50 through Ticketron and $18.50 at the door. Information: 243-4940 The Brandos, CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4452). The Brandos, a rising young rock quartet, make sturdy, grim-spirited guitar-based rock in the mold of Creedence Clearwater Revival. Their song ''Walk on the Water'' is included on their debut album, ''Honor Among Thieves'' (Relativity). Among other downbeat subjects, the band's songs deal with wife-beating (''A Matter of Survival''), the horrors of war (''Gettysburg''), poverty and theft (''Honor Among Thieves''), and killers on the loose (''Nothing to Fear''). The group's lead singer, guitarist and chief songwriter, Dave Kinkaid, has an appropriately gritty snarl, and the arrangements are taut and gleaming. The Brandos are headlining a four-act bill that includes J. J. Jumpers, Rude Buddha and Mercy Land. Show time is tomorrow at 10:30 P.M., and tickets are $7. Information: 982-4052. John Abercrombie Trio and Azimuth, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 27th Street (533-7902). A guitar lyricist whose style retains an echo of the blues, John Abercrombie is leading a trio that includes Marc Johnson, a bassist, and Peter Erskine, a drummer. Long, liquid guitar lines and gently shaded dynamics make for luxuriantly cerebral jazz. Azimuth (Norma Winstone, vocalist; Kenny Wheeler, trumpeter and fluegelhornist, and John Taylor, pianist) offers moody, impressionistic set pieces that have the meandering flow of pleasant daydreams. Show times tonight and tomorrow are at 8, 10 and midnight and on Sunday at 8 and 10 P.M. There is a $12.50 music charge and a $7.50 minimum. Pop Album of the Week: Susannah McCorkle: ''Dream'' (Pausa). Susannah McCorkle, the silky-voiced pop-jazz singer whose lingering phrases recall Billie Holiday, is the rare saloon singer whose ear is equally well attuned to pre-rock standards and contemporary songs. The title song of her latest album is the Johnny Mercer standard, treated here to a wistfully languid pop-jazz interpretation. The record's most revelatory performance is of Paul Simon's ''Train in the Distance,'' which Ms. McCorkle reveals to be a natural jazz ballad, delivering its ''grass-is-always-greener'' philosophy in sly, looping vocal lines. Other high points are a deeply torchy ''Just for a Thrill'' and Leiber and Stoller's little-known slice of American nostalgia ''Longings for a Simpler Time.'' The album personnel include Ben Aronovo, a pianist; Steve LaSpina, a bassist; Joe Cocuzzo, a drummer; Gene Bertoncini, a guitarist, and Frank Wess, a tenor saxophonist.

ART: EXXON SHOW AT THE GUGGENHEIM
description: THE Guggenheim Museum's nine-year-old series of exhibitions devoted to the work of emerging artists and sponsored by the Exxon Corporation has come, at least momentarily, to a close. According to the museum, the series' cancellation is part of across-the-board cutbacks in Exxon's arts support that stem from the faltering oil market. Initiated in 1978 and continuing at a nearly annual rate until last fall, the ''Exxon Nationals'' and ''Exxon Internationals,'' as they were called, introduced 85 artists from five different countries. Four of the eight exhibitions - in 1978, 1981, 1983 and 1985 - were devoted to American artists.
