title: Hatcher Suspended
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, president of the National League, issued a 10-day suspension to Billy Hatcher of the Houston Astros yesterday for using an altered bat. Hatcher was not available for comment, but Dick Wagner, the general manager, said Hatcher had told him he would not appeal the suspension, which took effect immediately. Manager Hal Lanier of the Astros was fined an undisclosed sum because Giamatti holds that a manager is responsible for illegal equipment used by his players. Hatcher was ejected from the game against the Chicago Cubs Tuesday after his bat splintered, revealing cork in the center. Hatcher, the team's leading hitter, will miss eight games, including a crucial three-game series beginning Monday against the division-leading San Francisco Giants. Kevin Gross of the Philadelphia Phillies and Joe Niekro of the American League Minnesota Twins were suspended earlier this season for 10 days after sandpaper was discovered in their possession. Meanwhile, both major leagues have rejected a Texas firm's pitch to use its high-tech scanning equipment to check for cork, rubber and other foreign substances in baseball bats. The offer came from Scientific Management Systems Inc., an Austin firm that uses computer industrial tomography to check jet engine turbines, automobile engine blocks, space shuttle parts and other equipment. The system is an X-ray-like process that produces an inside look at an item without damaging it. Jim Kay, the company's vice president, said the process is better than medical X-rays, such as the ones used by the leagues, for bat checking. The company offered to check suspected bats at no charge.

title: Dining Out Guide; Labor Day Weekend
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BRIDGE CAFE, #279 Water Street (227-3344) - *(Jan. 27, 1984) Choosing a restaurant on a holiday weekend poses some difficulties, but this one -situated at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge, not far from the South Street Seaport - is open for lunch and dinner throughout. You might start with chicken quenelles with shrimp fume; sea scallops in puff pastry with fresh mint and tarragon, or soft-shell crabs - with scallion butter - which can be ordered either as an appetizer or entree. Main dishes include roast duck with green peppercorn sauce; pan-fried brook trout with white wine, saffron and chives, and cold poached halibut with mustard, orange and fresh coriander dressing. Dinner entrees $11.50 to $15.95. Fridays, 11:45 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 6 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays, noon to 3:30 P.M. and 6 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, noon to 3:30 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M.; Labor Day, 11:45 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 6 P.M. to midnight. DOCKS, #2427 Broadway, near 90th Street (724-5588) - *(Feb. 6, 1987) This sparkling black-and-white tiled fish house on upper Broadway might answer your needs this holiday weekend. It is an ambitious place that offers an ever-changing assortment of fish - from fresh tuna and mako shark to jackfish and Mediterranean rouget - as well as a broad sampling of clams and oysters. Recommended dishes are light and crisp calamari rings with a smoky cumin-laced hot sauce; steamed giant New Zealand mussels in a saffron cream broth; grilled Norwegian salmon, and the special bouillabaisse-type dishes that are sometimes featured. Dinner entrees $8 to $18. Fridays and Saturdays, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5 P.M. to 1 A.M.; Sundays, 10:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M.; Labor Day, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight. PETALUMA, #1356 First Avenue, at 73d Street (772-8800) - *(May 3, 1985) This expansive multitiered peach-colored restaurant with a long bar and open kitchen is a convivial East Side dining spot. Appetizer options include smoked tuna with marinated artichokes; antipasto, and a combination of fried mozzarella with fried zucchini. For a main course, you might select a pasta of gnocchi with a creamy tomato sauce; grilled swordfish with tomatoes and capers; grilled red snapper with fresh herbs, or veal chop sauteed with fresh sage. Dinner entrees $12 to $20. Fridays and Saturdays, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to midnight; Sundays and Labor Day, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5:30 to 11 P.M. PIG HEAVEN, #1540 Second Avenue, at 80th Street (744-4333) - **(Dec. 28, 1984) The whimsy of the barnyard motif, from the giant wooden piglet holding a menu card at the front door to the frieze of pigs all around the dining room, belies the seriousness and authenticity of the Chinese food offered here. You might start with dumplings, fried, boiled or steamed; cold hacked chicken in a combination of sesame paste and hot oil, or sesame-flavored scallion pancakes. Good main-dish selections are the Cantonese-style suckling pig with its brittle skin and juicy meat; minced pork sauteed with corn, bell peppers and pine nuts; whole braised carp with hot bean sauce, and braised red snapper with whole garlic cloves. Entrees $10 to $15. Fridays through Sundays and Labor Day, noon to midnight. QUATORZE, #240 West 14th Street (206-7006) - **(Sept. 28, 1984) The shiny red enameled entrance to Quatorze casts a welcoming glow, which extends past the marble-topped bar and old-fashioned tiled floor to the dining room with its red banquettes and bold posters and prints. First course options include oysters, available by the piece, in an invigorating mignonette sauce; smoked chicken breast with horseradish cream, and a salad of chicory with smoked bacon and croutons in hot vinaigrette. Fish dishes are prepared with finesse and you might order flounder fillet grilled or meuniere, or salmon in a creamy sauce choron. Another good main-dish option is the calf's liver in a shallot sauce with balsamic vinegar. Entrees $15 to $22.50. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays, 6 P.M. to midnight; Sundays and Labor Day, 5 to 11 P.M. WATER CLUB, East River at 30th Street (683-3333) - *(July 19, 1985) Dining while enjoying the panoramic view of Queens and Manhattan on this glass-enclosed barge might brighten your holiday weekend. On deck, the al fresco bar serves a light grill menu from noon to midnight on Labor Day. The three-tiered main dining room is wrapped in glass, offering views from every table. Starters are icy and glistening fresh oysters and clams; smoked fish with blinis and caviar, or one of the half-dozen or more specials. Main dishes include some of the best crab cakes in town, golden brown disks loaded with well-seasoned crabmeat; tuna steak in a soy-based sauce; prime ribs of beef, and steamed or grilled Maine lobsters. Dinner entrees $18 to $36. Fridays, 11:30 A.M. to 2:45 P.M. and 6 to 11:45 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11:30 A.M to 3 P.M. and 6 to 11:45 P.M.; Labor Day, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 to 11:30 P.M. What the stars mean, page C18.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: El Gran Combo, the 12th New York Salsa Festival, Madison Square Garden (563-8300). Puerto Rico's most dependably incendiary salsa band is sleek, well-rehearsed, still energetic and vital after 25 years. In addition to El Gran Combo, the New York Salsa Festival's major concert extravaganza this year will also feature some of the music's virtuoso vocalists -Celia Cruz, Cheo Feliciano, Hector La Voe and Oscar D'Leon - plus the grand master of the timbales, Tito Puente. Tickets for the concert, which begins tomorrow at 8 P.M., are $15, $20 and $25 at the Madison Square Garden box office, or through Ticketron (399-4444). Pheeroan Ak Laff, Visiones, 125 Macdougal Street (673-5576). Pheeroan Ak Laff is so many band leaders' drummer of choice, he's likely to turn up almost anywhere. He is fastidious, a percussive perfectionist who plays with crisp, pinpoint definition and always goes for the groove. His own band, with John Stubblefield, a formidable tenor saxophonist, is playing tonight at Visiones, a Spanish restaurant and an increasingly important live-music venue in the Village. Sets are around 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1:15 A.M. There is a $7 minimum in the dining room, or a one-drink minimum at the bar. Johnny Copeland, Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Records haven't begun to capture the electricity and gritty authenticity this Texas blues-and-soul man projects in a club. Johnny Copeland plays sharp, biting guitar, and sings about hard knocks and hoping against hope in a voice that sounds like it could shear steel. He knows how to pace a show, building excitement, grabbing the audience by the collar and gradually tightening his grip. He isn't so much an entertainer as an experience. Shows are around 9:30 and midnight tonight and tomorrow night. There is a $10 cover charge and a $5 minimum. Jazz Album of the Week: ''Shades,'' Andrew Hill Trio and Quartet (Soul Note-Polygram Special Imports). The music on this exemplary new album from the elusive pianist Andrew Hill is deeply felt. It's also been painstakingly crafted and carefully programmed to provide a kaleidoscopic and uncommonly satisfying listening experience. The subject is jazz as language. On the first side, four tightly (if eccentrically) structured compositions explore some of the ways the music can express ideas through metaphor. ''Tripping'' is a painterly study of shape, flow, color and nuance; ''Ball Square,'' presented as a series of conversational gambits between Mr. Hill's piano and Ben Riley's thoughtfully melodic drumming, is a composition about cycles, and cycles within cycles. The album's second side consists of two long, relaxed quartet performances, with Clifford Jordan's supple tenor saxophone sinuously winding its way through Mr. Hill's dapplings of light and shade. Here jazz itself is the metaphor, and playing well is its own reward.

Watching dance and examining sculptures placed around the site, however, one feels surrounded by the lush green grass, weeds and trees that grow over the abandoned hillocks and flat, sandy places. And on Wednesday, Yvonne Meier performed a dance that seemed perfect for the spot, a brief and equally abandoned solo that seemed to blow across the site and then off again, like some exotic throwaway scrap fluttering across an urban landscape.

The bat was confiscated Wednesday night during the game against the Montreal Expos in San Francisco. Maldonado's bat also passed an X-ray exam last month when it was confiscated at the request of Dave Johnson, the Mets' manager.

The venture is in partnership with Bruno's Inc., a food retailer based in Birmingham, Ala. K Mart said the agreement gives it a 51 percent interest in the partnership, which hopes to open stores of about 225,000 square feet in major metropolitan areas. The first stores are scheduled to open next year. K Mart is the second-biggest retailer in the world, with 1986 sales of $23.8 billion. Bruno's operates 111 food stores in five Southern states, generating annual sales of more than $1 billion.

description: I WAS never able to understand why January first was celebrated as the New Year, when everyone knows that the old year limps into memory during those final days of August and that the ''for real'' New Year begins the day after Labor Day. September heralds the new season, but it is more than just the season that we anticipate. We shop for new clothes, we buy our kids new pencils and notebooks and erasers, we rework our social calendar to conform to indoor living, we get invited to closings and openings. A closing affair at the club or the summer colony or the neighborhood block party. An opening meeting of the Parent-Teacher Association or the planning committee for a favorite organization. We close the book on barbecues and clam bakes, on shared houses at the beach, on slipping into the car unencumbered by layers of outer clothing.

description: FOR unexplained reasons, Mike Rozier, the running back of the Houston Oilers, missed practice Friday and did not go with the team to Dallas for last night's game against the Cowboys. Coach Jerry Glanville told Rozier he would meet with the player today. Rozier missed the team's first exhibition game, against the Chiefs, when he overslept at the team's hotel and arrived at the stadium at game time.

title: NOT THE SAME OLD RICE
description: RICE USED TO BE BORING. But after thousands of years as a dietary staple, it has become fashionable. Educated cooks are no longer asking simply for rice, but for a specific variety of this grain. American adaptations of long-grain basmati rice, such as Texmati, Konriko Wild Pecan and Wehani, as well as the short, oval-shaped arborio rice, are becoming as much in demand as pasta varieties were a few years ago. As a complex carbohydrate, rice is low in cholesterol and an excellent source of sustained energy.

title: Johnson Suspended
description: THE National Basketball Association has suspended Eddie Johnson, a Seattle SuperSonics guard, for failing to follow through on drug counseling. The 31-year-old Johnson was arrested in Atlanta, his hometown, last Wednesday on charges of writing bad checks and theft of services, according to the Atlanta police.

title: DATA BANK: September 6, 1987
NASA's Staggering Bill For Getting Off the Ground
description: AMONG the thousands of spectators who lined deserted Highway 83 in northeastern Utah last week to watch the successful test firing of the space shuttle's revamped booster rockets were most of NASA's top officials, eager to proclaim the space program back on its feet. ''It was four years ago today that I went up on STS-8,'' said Adm. Richard H. Truly, the agency's associate administrator for space flight, using NASA's lingo for the eighth shuttle mission. ''That seems like a long, long time ago.''

title: Beth Isaacs Is Wed

The Rev. Charles White officiated at St. Helen's Roman Catholic Church in Howard Beach, Queens. The bride, a graduate of Cornell University, is a gift buyer for Eastern Lobby Shops, a division of Restaurant Associates Industries in New York. title: 'The Candles of Your Eyes'
description: JAMES PURDY has always been celebrated for his ''voice'' - the unpredictable but unmistakable sentences, at once plain-spoken and eccentric, that spin from his narrators no matter who they are or what kind of tales they're telling. Listening to Mr. Purdy's autodidacts, semiliterates, social climbers and outcasts, the reader, however charmed, always knows a bit more than they do and is kept at a bit of a distance. Mr. Purdy's stories have the self-conscious attractions of a ventriloquist's show.

title: Portugal Train Crash Kills 5
description: Two passenger trains collided Friday in a popular resort region of southern Portugal, killing 5 people and injuring 29, officials said. One of the dead was identified as a 52-year-old Portuguese man. The identities of the other victims were not known. An American woman, identified as Kerrie Ann Guidroz, 22 years old, suffered minor injuries. One train struck a car that had stalled at a crossing then struck a second train that was coming to its aid. All the dead and injured were on the second train. Of the 10 passengers who were seriously injured none were foreigners, the authorities said.

So moisturizers have evolved, acquiring more scientific names, jazzier packaging and more ambitious functions.

title: Poland Sentences 2 Danes

title: East Germany Moves West

His trip to West Germany coincides with - and reinforces - Mikhail Gorbachev's effort to build new bridges between the Soviet bloc and Western Europe. title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MOURNFUL DEMEANOUR OF LIEUTENANT BORUVKA. By Josef Skvorecky. Translated by Rosemary Kavan, Kaca Polackova and George Theiner. (Norton, $15.95.) Lieutenant Boruvka, the detective of the doleful countenance, takes a warm and nurturing approach to crime-solving. Unlike his eager-beaver assistant, Sergeant Malek, who is infatuated with the latest scientific techniques, this Czechoslovak police officer relies on good old-fashioned observation and deduction, supplemented by an understanding of the human heart. He is too sensitive to fire a gun. He doesn't like the death penalty. Upon solving a crime, he always experiences a profound sadness. Readers of Mr. Skvorecky's epic, freewheeling political novel, ''The Engineer of Human Souls,'' will find no comparable sustenance in these 12 linked detective stories written before the author immigrated to Canada in 1968 from his native Czechoslovakia. Boruvka exhibits a bit too much of the bogus humanism associated with the Socialist Realist school - even though Mr. Skvorecky tries to round out his hero by having him botch a case, and, while married, fall in love with a female subordinate. These tales reveal little flair for mystery writing, relying on intricate plots that annoy rather than challenge. One puzzle requires that we decipher musical notation - hardly fair. Intermittent pleasures come from such witty touches as the character who takes umbrage at not being suspected and protests, ''You don't regard me as a man, sir?'' But on the whole this first of four scheduled Boruvka collections amounts to no more than a hobby of the author. The less than idiomatic translation (one character refers to Boruvka as a ''disbelieving Thomas'') doesn't help.

description: Any doubts about Mayor Koch's being his old self after his minor stroke vanished last week as he lashed out at every target within tongue's reach.

Developers Alarmed by Rezoning 'Trend'

title: Focus Is on Americana In This Season's Shows
description: AMERICANA, ANTIQUITIES and Asian art - with generous doses of ancient and tribal jewelry and a dash of French elegance - dominate in the antiques exhibitions to be presented at museums and galleries over the next several months.

title: Buying High
description: To the Editor: ''When You Buy High and Sell Low'' (Investing, Aug. 16), by John C. Boland, casts a shadow on over-the-counter stocks and full-service wire houses that deal in these stocks. As director of retail equity trading at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., I would like to respond to certain claims made in the article.

title: YOUTH AND AFFLUENCE
description: I found Daniel Menaker's article interesting, but disheartening. Stories detailing the excesses lavished upon our youth bring to mind also the children of this nation's homeless, living in shelters or welfare hotels.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A Conference Will Celebrate American Coinage
description: LEAD: THE American Numismatic Society will hold its fourth annual Coinage of the Americas Conference Sept. 26 and 27 at the A.N.S. Museum in New York City.

title: YOUNG CELLIST SCALES CLASSICAL HEIGHTS
description: LEAD: There were times, after being named a finalist in the 1982 Tchaikovsky International Competition, that cellist Alvin McCall wondered ''if maybe I got to the finals because I was black -- or, yeah, maybe because I played well.'' Lately, Mr. McCall who will be one of the featured cellists Saturday at the Friends of the Arts annual Beethoven Festival in Oyster Bay wonders less.

title: Campaign in Argentina Ends on Violent Note
description: A basically peaceful electoral campaign for part of the Argentine Congress, provincial governors and local officials ended with violence this week.

title: Walton Uncertain Of Team's Prospects
description: As Joe Walton goes into his fifth season, he brings the only winning record belonging to a Jets head coach, 35-29, along with playoff appearances the last two seasons. He has succeeded by constantly rearranging the personnel, the coaches and even his relationship with the front office.

description: ON a hill on 66 wooded acres along the Hudson River in North Tarrytown, the first on-site corporate-sponsored day-care center in Westchester is to open its doors early next spring.

title:
GARDENING;
When It's Windy. . .
description: LEAD: MY first encounter with wind came two years ago when I moved from my home in Connecticut to an apartment. The location seemed choice - open country and low buildings set among lawns. There was space for a garden and always a fresh breeze.

description: From time to time, certain articles receive a particularly strong response from readers. description: Sandinista leaders began warning their supporters this week to prepare for major political changes in Nicaragua soon because of the regional peace plan adopted last month.

title: Air Travelers Warming To Idea of Smoking Ban
description: Amid indications that air travelers now favor forbidding smoking on many flights, one major international carrier has announced plans to extend an experimental smoking ban that most of its passengers have greeted with approval.

title: A Vatican Stake In Talks With Jews
description: POPE JOHN PAUL II interrupted his vacation last week to meet with nine leaders of world Jewry at his summer residence outside Rome. It was crucial, the Catholics and Jews at the meeting agreed, to resolve recent tensions between the two faiths before the Pope arrives this week for a 10-day visit to the United States.

title: Kuwait Expels Iran Envoys After Attack
description: Kuwait said today that it was expelling five Iranian diplomats as tension mounted between the two Persian Gulf countries over Iranian missiles fired at Kuwait.

title: Bicyclist Says Officers Beat Him As They Held Him in Traffic Case
description: The police are investigating a Queens man's charge that two officers beat him Friday as they arrested him for riding his bicycle against rush-hour traffic in mid-Manhattan.

title: L. I. Laughlin 3d And Miss Clifford To Marry Nov. 7
description: The engagement of Sarah Clifford to Ledlie Irwin Laughlin 3d, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Laughlin Jr. of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Rowland Clifford of Cornwall, Vt. The couple plan to marry Nov. 7.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sanctuaries In the Sea Off Georgia
description: The Sapelo Queen, a trawler converted to passenger ferry use, winds through tidal creeks and moves into Doboy Sound on its way to an island in the middle of 100 miles of solitude. A score of riders, some scientists and naturalists, others vacationing couples and families, line the boat's railings.

title: Comparing Two Communist Paths to 'Reform'
description: THE Russians went to Beijing this summer to see for themselves the changes wrought by China's leader Deng Xiaoping. Among other things, the delegation of Soviet party officials toured a revitalized petrochemical plant and visited a village where peasants believe that getting rich is glorious.

The stamp will be issued in Philadelphia where the Constitution was signed. The new stamp's release will be one of several events scheduled across the country on that date.

title: Wedding Planned by Ellen Gallagher
description: Ellen Marie Gallagher, a health-care consultant with Coopers & Lybrand in Washington, and John Charles Parsons Jr., a professional accounting fellow in the office of the chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington, plan to be married next month. Ms. Gallagher is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip G. Gallagher of Weston, Mass., who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Parsons of Natick, Mass.

title: Libertarians Pick Ex-Congressman in '88 Bid
description: Former Representative Ron Paul of Texas was nominated today as the Libertarian Party's candidate for President. His closest rival in the vote at the party's national convention here was Russell Means, the Indian leader from South Dakota.

title: U.S. Denies a Report Of Meeting With Iran
description: A State Department official tonight described as ''completely inaccurate'' a British newspaper report asserting that American and Iranian Government officials met secretly in Swtizerland last week to discuss the Persian Gulf.

title: Britain Charges 3 in Plot
description: Two men and a woman, as yet unidentified, were charged today with conspiracy to kill Tom King, the British Cabinet Secretary for Northern Ireland, six days after they were arrested near his country home in Wiltshire, England.

title: John Huston: Spinner of Late-Night Tales
description: JOHN HUSTON'S CAREER WAS AS long-lived and shapely as his movies - and as full of exuberant spirits. His most memorable films, even the autumnally sad ones, from ''The Treasure of Sierra Madre'' (1947) to ''Wise Blood'' (1979), leave one experiencing the kind of exhilaration that only comes from being witness to craftsmanship in the service of an original, seriously amused mind.

title: 9 Firemen Missing in Spain
description: A burning seven-story department store in the center of Madrid collapsed before dawn today, and nine firemen were missing under piles of concrete, officials said. More than 1,000 people dug through rubble looking for them. The top floors gave way as 200 firefighters put out the blaze, which began Friday night. The Civil Governor, Ana Tutor, said there was a small possibility that the men could be rescued alive.

title: POSTINGS: City-Within-a-City; St. George Seaport

description: THE New York Public Library will unveil its latest reclamation on Sept. 22: a marble-walled room with pillars of cast iron and steel and a spectacular skylit dome - much unlike the rest of the landmark Beaux Arts building.

title: It's Time for FM Radio To Make Some Waves

The ''pirate'' disk jockeys declared rock radio in New York ''stale and stagnant.'' The bad news is that they were right.

title: Shaking Billions From Beatrice
description: HENRY KRAVIS was in the middle of a safari in the Kenyan bush two years ago when he decided to call his office in New York. Once he got through, he received news of a far more interesting hunt: His partner, George Roberts, told him that the board of the Beatrice Companies had just forced out the chairman, James L. Dutt.

description: In ''Safe Sex,'' her nostagic reminiscence of her childhood dilemma about making babies [ Opinion page, Aug. 9 ] Mildred Wohlforth confessed, ''I didn't have my curiosity satisfied until I went to college and my freshman roommate enlightened me.''

title: MOVIES

MCA Home Video. 92 minutes. $24.95. This film, which brought together Ally Sheedy, Molly Ringwald and the cohort of other young actors known as the ''brat pack,'' is a talky tale of adolescent angst set in a high-school library during a Saturday detention period. At the outset, one of the young heroes all but sums up the plot, saying: ''A brain, an athlete, a basket case, a princess and a criminal - that's the way we saw each other at 7 o'clock this morning. We were brainwashed.''

title: Headliners; Grounded in Moscow
description: Mathias Rust, a 19-year-old West German, thoroughly embarrassed Soviet air defense forces three months ago when he made an unauthorized - and unchallenged -flight over 500 miles of Soviet territory in a small plane, buzzed Red Square and then landed near the Kremlin. At his trial in Moscow last week, Mr. Rust said that his mission was one of peace and that he had hoped it would lead to an audience with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Rust admitted that he had illegally crossed the Soviet border and violated international flight regulations, but denied a third charge, malicious hooliganism. The court found him guilty on that count, too, saying he was motivated by ''adventurism'' and a desire for ''self-advertisement.''

title: A French Playground for Fall
description: The broad, flat beaches of France's new Mediterranean resorts sparkle along a nearly continuous strip of sand stretching west from the Rhone and curving down toward the Pyrenees. In July and August sunseekers form a nearly unbroken strip along this coast, proving beyond a doubt that the French Government's 24-year-old project for development of the Languedoc-Roussillon coastline is a booming success.

description: The leader of the failed military rebellion, in his first public statement since the Aug. 28 uprising, called on Filipinos today to support him in his struggle against the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ELVIS WORLD. By Jane and Michael Stern. (Knopf, $35.) Considering the complex ironies of the Elvis legend - the hillbilly who became ''the King'' - it's surprising so few intellectuals have tried to figure out what it all means. Now Jane and Michael Stern begin to fill this gap with a wonderful little gold mine of Americana called ''Elvis World.'' Cleverly disguised as a coffeetable book, it is actually an illustrated essay defining the elements of the Elvis mythology. ''Elvis has always been an issue way beyond his art,'' the Sterns tell us, and take us on a tour of the fantastic Presley universe - the homes, the shrines (''any place he shopped, ate, bought cars or guns or diamond rings''), the awful movies, the fans who keep his cult stronger than ever 10 years after his death. With Flaubertian precision they pile on the details (''to understand the Elvis mystique, you must know details''): the famous sneer that so threatened American morality in the 1950's, the hideous lamps he collected, the contents of his pantry (food looms large in the Elvis legend). The key to Elvis's power seems to be the duality of his character.

title: Cards Boast Only One 10-Game Winner in Final Drive
description: SINCE division play began in 1969, teams that have won National League division championships have averaged two pitchers with 15 or more victories and three pitchers with 12 or more victories. The way Whitey Herzog sees it, even if his St. Louis Cardinals win the National League East title this season, ''I don't know if I'm going to have one 12-game winner.''

title: In Zydeco, the Accordion Is the Life of the Party
description: IN ANN ALLEN SAVOY's BOOK ''Cajun Music: A Reflection of a People'' (Bluebird Press, Eunice, La., 1984), Bois Sec Ardoin, an accordion player from Louisiana, contributed a vivid account of the rural house parties where zydeco music was born. ''If the house was small, we'd make a platform of boards all around the outside of the house for a dance floor,'' he recalled. ''There would be an accordion and a triangle, or maybe just two fiddles, old dances like they used to do. They'd play all night. If the dance was inside, we'd take all the furniture out of the rooms and put planks around the walls, like benches.''

Flagg steers his sturdy dory through the quick water of the narrows that lead to the Grand Manan Channel in the Bay of Fundy, past the fog-shrouded, heart-shaped weirs used to trap herring, past the salmon fishery, past boats owned by lobstermen. He is after dulse, an edible seaweed that grows in profusion on the rocky shores of Grand Manan Island, New Brunswick, 10 miles from the coast of Maine.

JOANNE C. FIGUEIREDO Postdoctoral Fellow, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Pop Music
description: Jan Wallman's handsomely appointed new club at 49 West 44th Street is a model of what 80's cabaret ought to be. It offers good food, an ambiance that encourages intimacy but affords elbow room and consistently strong talent, all at reasonable prices. On Tuesday, Ms. Wallman is presenting Claiborne Cary, the Broadway veteran (''Little Me,'' ''Silk Stockings,'' ''New Girl in Town'') who made her critically praised cabaret comeback in the club last July and has been performing there regularly ever since. Accompanied by Buddy Barnes, Mabel Mercer's former pianist, Ms. Cary is a superb singing actress who can be exquisitely torchy (a delicate, heart-tugging ''If He Walked Into My Life'') and slyly comic (Murray Grand's amusing ''You Must Remember to Forget'').

Upon arrival, diners -even those with reservations - are asked to wait in a gloomy, smoky bar area. Considering the casual surroundings, prices are high. But with few exceptions, resoundingly fresh and high quality, if expensive, ingredients - mushrooms such as porcini and chanterelle, Holland peppers, Dover sole -make up the stock of this kitchen.

description: ''NAKED'' is a seldom-seen play by one of the world's great playwrights, Luigi Pirandello. The play strips away barriers between victim and victimizer, and between reality and illusion.

description: THE people at the city's Parks Department and at Creative Time seem to have a knack for putting together enjoyable, provocative mixes of entertainers. Friday night's program at the Central Park Summer Stage got off to a light and bouncy start with Clarice Marshall's ''Plano, TX. '59,'' an excerpt from a longer work about growing up in Texas in the late 1950's. The dance was less evocative than the text to which it was set and the country-and-western score by Bob Wills. But there were a good many memorable moments in the eddying choreography and staging, with bursts of period social dancing sown into the Tharpian flow. A huge, brightly painted inner tube at the side of the stage served frequently as a springboard.

title: Fossil Hunting in North Carolina
description: The day had been long, our schedule grueling, the North Carolina sun unforgiving. But my companions and I were not to be deterred in our search through the mounds of roadside dirt. With the devotion of one who has lost a contact lens, we peered closely at the ground, stooping frequently to paw some piece of soil, sometimes pausing to pocket a prehistoric find.

title: How Long Is The Leash in South Korea?
description: THE wave of political and social activism sweeping across the country has left many South Koreans with the uncomfortable feeling that they are holding a double-edged sword. They cannot tell for sure whether they are making true democratic progress or about to elicit unyielding repression and perhaps even military intervention. Events last week deepened that uncertainty.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: How Genetics Works; From Mendel's Pea Plants To Montana's Disputed Elms
description: IN the late 19th century, an Austrian monk named Gregor Mendel unwittingly began a chain of events that led to genetic engineering and the attendant controversies over invented life. By crossing varieties of pea plants and carefully noting the results, Mendel provided the first evidence for the existence of the gene.

title: McEnroe Wins Noisily
description: Sometimes, watching John McEnroe at his best means suffering McEnroe at his worst, a combination of tennis and tantrums that has made him not only arguably the best player of his generation, but also the most controversial. In a performance that was vintage McEnroe in all respects yesterday, he brought the crowd at the Stadium Court to an emotional boil and tottered on the edge of disqualification from the United States Open, and still won.

title: Portland, Me.
description: Strolling along the cobblestone streets of Victorian row houses in downtown Portland, Me., the cries of gulls, hovering close, seem an aberration. But they are one of the endearing oddities of this quirky city, the largest in the state, yet still small compared with Boston or New York. The gulls are a link with Portland's past - and sometime present - as a fishing and shipping town. Lately though, Portland has traded its old salt image for one more cosmopolitan. Construction, renovation and restoration are evident everywhere, but so far most concentrated in the area known as the Old Port. Rundown warehouses, boatbuilding shops and homes on the waterfront and adjacent blocks have undergone a facelift. The result is an array of restaurants, galleries, shops, offices and dwellings.

description: AT first glance, it would be difficult to imagine two Western leaders who are less alike than Ingvar Carlsson, the socialist Prime Minister of Sweden - which is known for neutrality, high taxes and its generous welfare state - and Ronald Reagan, the conservative tax-cutter. But when the President welcomes Mr. Carlsson Wednesday during the first state visit to Washington by a Swedish prime minister in 26 years, the two leaders' similarities are likely to become clear.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ABRAHAM JOSHUA HESCHEL & ELIE WIESEL: You Are My Witnesses. By Maurice Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) Reading this book is like meeting an avuncular sort of fellow on a long train ride and hearing stories, many of them trivial, about the great men he has known. By the end of the ride, although you may be bored, you might find you have learned a thing or two. In these pages, Maurice Friedman, an expert on Martin Buber and a professor of religious studies at San Diego State University, analyzes the lives and works of two people with whom he has had friendships: Abraham Joshua Heschel, the great Jewish philosopher and social activist who died in 1972, and Elie Wiesel, the chronicler of the Holocaust and Nobel laureate. Probably to establish his personal ties with the two men, Mr. Friedman throws in the trivia. He tells how he used to walk home with Heschel and ''stop and have an orange juice along the way,'' or how he bought a cowboy suit as a present for Mr. Wiesel's son. ('' 'He will be the first Hasidic cowboy,' Elie remarked to me, much amused,'' Mr. Friedman reports.) With the personal details out of the way, Mr. Friedman provides a useful summary of Heschel's philosophy and shows how that philosophy motivated his civil rights and peace activities. The author does a less credible job of summarizing Mr. Wiesel's works, relying too heavily on quotation and on the critics. He also has the irritating habit of quoting at length from his own works, especially the autobiographical ''Touchstones of Reality.'' If you were indeed riding a train instead of reading a book, you'd probably change your seat.

description: President Jose Sarney has announced that Brazilian scientists have succeeded in enriching uranium, a key stage in this country's development of its own nuclear energy technology.

description: Garry Templeton hit a three-run homer tonight and the San Diego Padres ended a four-game losing streak by beating the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-1.

title: Headliners; Running in New York?
description: Was Donald J. Trump flirting with the Republican Party kingmakers last week? In a full-page newspaper advertisement that got national attention, the New York City real estate developer attacked Reagan Administration foreign policy and invited the inference that his own would be better. But he denied having any Presidential ambitions. Said Mayor Koch, who has occasionally feuded with Mr. Trump, ''Who cares?'' Maybe nobody, but debate over Mr. Trump's ideas might have enlivened the campaign. One proposal in his ad was that the United States should bolster its economy by hiring out as a bodyguard. ''Our world protection is worth hundreds of billions of dollars,'' he said. ''Make Japan, Saudi Arabia and others pay for the protection we extend as allies.''

As facilities director for the Shubert Organization, Olsson is overseeing the modifications being made in Broadway's Majestic Theater to accommodate Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Phantom of the Opera,'' the hit British musical that opens here in January.

title: BLOOMSBURY'S PAINTERS: A COMPLEX SETTING
description: THE man in Vanessa Bell's ''Dining Room Window, Charleston'' is her lover, Duncan Grant; the woman is their daughter, Angelica Bell, and the setting is the country house where the couple took up residence in 1916. It's not the most distinguished of the 22 works in ''Bloomsbury Artists at Charleston,'' the show that is hanging in the Katonah Gallery at 28 Bedford Road in Katonah. But it is the one that best sums up the complex emotional background of the group that coalesced around Vanessa and her sister, Virginia Woolf, before World War I and remained an important presence on the London scene until World War II.

description: Tim Vesling made four field goals and the defense stymied the passing game of Dan Henning to give Syracuse a 25-11 victory over Maryland tonight.

title: The Cost of Money Is Going Up Again
description: Interest rates have been creeping up in several sectors and the Federal Reserve, in part to support the dollar, gave in to the pressure by raising the discount rate to 6 percent, from 5 1/2 percent. Since rates were already rising, the Fed move to nudge them further could help to stabilize the dollar - in part by attracting more foreign money into United States securities - without causing an inflationary spurt at home. The move was the first by the new Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, but the immediate reaction was a negative one - stocks continued to drop sharply and the dollar barely moved. That led some analysts to predict that another increase could be in the offing. Banks immediately responded, though, with an increase in their prime rates, to 8 3/4 percent in most cases, and consumer rates are sure to follow. In the credit markets, where traders show their view of the future, bond prices have already dropped sharply and yields are at or near yearly highs. Analysts say the bond price drop is a result of a combination of factors - a strong economy, the fall of the dollar that has led to a pullback of investors from abroad, and the bull stock market, which has siphoned some investments from Government securities.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BILL VEECK: A Baseball Legend. By Gerald Eskenazi. (McGraw-Hill, $16.95.) For half a century, Bill Veeck was a baseball gadfly. From his first baseball job in 1933, through his adventures as a franchise owner in Milwaukee, Cleveland, St. Louis and Chicago, until his death in 1986 at the age of 71, Veeck had a knack for revitalizing the fortunes of his teams and simultaneously scandalizing his business colleagues. In this biography a veteran New York Times sportswriter, Gerald Eskenazi, presents the many facets of Veeck's complex character - spirited entrepreneur, opportunist, altruist. Veeck may be best known as the publicity-seeking club owner who made the 3-foot-7-inch Eddie Gaedel a member of the 1951 St. Louis Browns. As the owner of a minor league team in Milwaukee, he also adopted the practice of moving the outfield fences according to the hitting capacity of the opposing teams. But there was more to the man than a gift for outrageous gags. In 1947, as owner of the Cleveland Indians, Veeck was the first American League owner to hire a black baseball player, Larry Doby. Acts like this and his own struggles against injuries and illness earned Veeck a reputation as a humanitarian, yet he seems to have virtually disregarded the existence of his children by his first wife. Who was the real Bill Veeck? Mr. Eskenazi provides no definitive answers, but his numerous interviews and anecdotes provide an entertaining portrait of a maverick who refused to be pinned down by anyone, including his biographer.

title: Today's Debut Is Often a Letdown, Not a Launch
description: THIS SEASON'S MUSICAL DEBU-tants, the first of whom will appear this week, might do well to contemplate the fate of the pianist Jeffrey Biegel. As recipient of the Juilliard School's William Petschek Award, Mr. Biegel was sponsored in his New York debut in April 1986 at Alice Tully Hall. Donal Henahan, chief music critic of The New York Times, considered the performance ''the sort of event that can propel a young career into orbit.'' International Creative Management, among the world's most powerful artist management organizations, signed up the musician. With I.C.M.'s help, Mr. Biegel has been engaged to play with the Seattle Youth Symphony and, on his own, he arranged a date with the Nassau Symphony on Long Island.

title: When Hatred Seized a Nation
description: THERE WAS A TIME WHEN one man's fate fascinated and moved millions of people for longer than a single day. That time - the last five years of the last century - seems very distant now. How are we to explain the furious storm caused by the Dreyfus Affair throughout French society? Why should such passions have been unleashed by the situation of a man who seemed no different from his peers? What was there about him - obscure as he was, ordinary as he was - that France should have split into two fanatical camps, one of which turned him into a symbol of criminal ingratitude, the other into a symbol of admirable innocence?

title: Data Update: September 6, 1987
Correction
description: The selective guide to classical music last Sunday in The New Season, part 2 of The Times Magazine, incorrectly identified the stage director of the Minnesota Opera's production of ''Die Fledermaus.'' The director will be Dorothy Danner. Also, John Cage's first opera was misidentified in the guide. It will be ''Europera 1 and 2.''

title: Alan Dorsey Wed To Andrea Liddle
description: Andrea Graham Liddle, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold V. Liddle of Salt Lake City, was married there yesterday to Alan Harold Dorsey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George K. Dorsey of Purchase, N.Y. The Episcopal ceremony at the Cathedral Church of St. Mark was performed by the Rev. Peter J. Van Hook and the Rev. Fred E. St. John.

title: CONCERN RISES ON WASTE-DISPOSAL COSTS
description: GEORGE De KORNFELD, manager of the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains, estimates that the hotel serves about 5,000 meals a week. ''We're happy to do the business,'' he said. ''But, unhappily, getting rid of the waste that is generated by a successful hotel costs much more every year. Three years ago our bill was $25,300 a year for garbage removal. Now we're paying $80,000 for the same service.''

title: SCHOOLS FACE ADDITIONAL CHANGES IN 1987-88 TERM
description: WHEN the 1987-88 school year begins this week, New Jersey's 2,251 public schools should expect no respite from the barrage of educational changes they have had to respond to in recent years.

title: Ortega Attacks
description: 'The Senators and Congressmen come only so they can go back to the United States and say ''I talked to Ortega - I'm now completely convinced this is a totalitarian regime and we have to continue supporting the contras.'' . . . Why doesn't President Reagan receive me or my congressmen? We receive you whenever you want. You don't even consult us in advance, which is a lack of respect.' - Daniel Ortega Saavedra, President of Nicaragua, during a public meeting in Managua with five Republican United States Senators.

title: YOUTH AND AFFLUENCE
description: Daniel Menaker seems to be saying that rich people should not buy expensive things for their children. And yet, it seems to me that a wealthy parent who buys an antique Egyptian ring for his 8-year-old son is no different from a person of modest means who buys a Captain Marvel ring for his son (the relative ability to afford either being approximately comparable).

title: The Spy as Hero - or Heel
description: OUR APPETITE FOR TALES of spies and secret agents is unassuaged - if anything, it seems to be growing. ''The Fourth Protocol,'' for example, in which a British agent (played by Michael Caine) pits himself against the K.G.B., is the latest in a long, long line of similar movies, but it is unlikely that it will be the last; and it comes hard on the heels of ''No Way Out,'' a film in which much of the action is made to turn on the possible presence of a Soviet mole in the Pentagon.

title:
ART;
FACULTY SHOW: RANGE OF IDEAS
description: LEAD: DURING the height of the summer season, East End artists with substantial reputations often show their most recent work in local galleries. The current offering at the Vered Gallery in East Hampton, featuring Audrey Flack, Claus Hoie and Syd Solomon, is a case in point.

title: Refuge Denied
description: The tiny semipalmated sandpiper that set a long-distance speed record with its four-day flight from Plymouth, Mass., to South America didn't survive to celebrate. It was shot by a hunter in Guyana. Alas, the beach in Plymouth is not much more hospitable.

title: Alison A. Daley Marries Kenneth C. Stevenson 3d
description: The marriage of Alison Anne Daley and Kenneth Campbell Stevenson 3d, 1986 graduates of Brown University, took place yesterday in Georgetown, Me. The ceremony at St. Cuthbert's Chapel on MacMahan Island was performed by the bride's parents, the Revs. Patricia and Eliot Daley of Princeton, N.J.

title: POSTINGS: 'Portable' Mortgage; Travel-Wise
description: A new ''portable'' mortgage offered by the Chase Home Mortgage Corporation will allow homeowners to take their mortgages with them when they move.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: JESUS AND FAT TUESDAY: And Other Short Stories. By Colleen J. McElroy. (Creative Arts Book, Paper, $8.95.) These 14 strikingly original stories have a common theme refracted through the different characters' lives like light passing obliquely from one medium to another. In writing about black Americans' search for connection, self-worth and love, Ms.

title: Lynn C. Gardner And N. S. Stack To Marry Oct. 24
description: Lynn Carson Gardner, promotion manager of Scientific American magazine, and Nathan Scott Stack, executive vice president of Steve Burnett Inc., a graphics design company in New York, plan to be married Oct 24. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Gardner of Locust Valley, L.I., who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Stack Jr. of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Keeping an Eye On Scoreboard
description: To the Sports Editor:

GARDENING;
PLOTTING SUCCESS BY NATURE AND DESIGN
description: LEAD: ALL things created by humans are of a temporal nature.The pyramids of Egypt and

title: Peron Hands: Police Find Trail Elusive
description: Investigators trying to determine who broke into the tomb of Juan Domingo Peron and sawed off his hands have arrested six people in recent days, only to see five of them cleared by a judge.

GARDENING;

title: In Noisy Athens, a Quiet Appeal for Silence
description: The sandwich bar on Skoufa Street has reopened after a long break, and these days there is a chance that a telephone caller might find someone at some office to take a call.

title: Iowa Eclipsing New Hampshire Among Hopefuls
description: In a political tradition of sorts, most Presidential contenders visiting here choose their lodging based on party affiliation: Democrats stay at the Hotel Savery and Republicans at the nearby Marriott Hotel.

title: For a Town's Barkeeps: Instruction on Drinking
description: Bar owners and managers here must now take courses in alcohol management that include tips on when to shut off their customers' drinking.

title: Capture of Sikh in India Prompts New Fears About Arsenal
description: The capture of the country's most-wanted terrorist suspect has led to greater concern about the type of weapons reported to be in the hands of Sikh extremists, officials say.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
Industry Finds Its Way Back to Carteret
description: LEAD: EMPTY factories still dot the landscape in Carteret, stretching 4.3 square miles to the banks of the Arthur Kill in Middlesex County. But this gritty old port, which went into decline in the early 1970's, has received a second chance.

title: Return of the Ginkgo
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article Aug. 30 about the pitch of A in the symphony orchestra misidentified Joseph Robinson. He is the principal oboist of the New York Philharmonic.

title: NEW ROLE AT PILGRIM?
description: The appearance of Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center on a preliminary list of a possible site for housing low-income residents has revived speculation about the fate of the largely vacant Brentwood facility.

title: Mecca Tragedy: Chain of Events Begins to Emerge
description: Nearly six weeks after riots in the Moslem holy city of Mecca that left more than 400 people dead, a more detailed picture is beginning to emerge of what led to the violence.

title: Ousted Burundi Leader Seeks Uganda Asylum
description: The deposed leader of Burundi, Jean-Baptiste Bagaza, looking for temporary political asylum, left today for Uganda after spending two days in Kenya.

title: A PLACE FOR NO-NONSENSE SEAFOOD
description: THERE must be something deep in the American psyche that responds to fried foods. Even today, when many of us have become vigilantly health-conscious, there is an occasional need to break out, to be casual about cholesterol, to pig out with a deep-fried food binge.

title: Sense About Nonsense
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL TO OPEN
description: LEAD: It's only 80 percent complete now, but some time around the beginning of the new year the first high school to be built in New York State for the past 10 years will open its doors. The opening of the new Longwood Senior High School (in what was formerly the Middle Island School District) to its first group of 1,800 students will finally end the splitsession schedules that have existed for secondary students in the Suffolk School

title: Donna L. Ching Wed To Mark M. Boehme
description: Donna Lee Ching, a daughter of Mrs. Ellsworth Y. L. Ching of Honolulu and the late Dr. Ching, was married yesterday to Mark Macklin Boehme, a son of Dr. Diethelm H. Boehme of South Orange, N.J., and Irbid, Jordan, and Cameron Johnson of Summit, N.J. The Rev. C. Richard DuFresne performed the Congregational ceremony at the Community Church of Honolulu.

title: DEATH COMES FOR THE ARCHBUREAUCRAT
description: THE WHITE TIGER By Robert Stuart Nathan. 431 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
NOODLE MAGIC
description: LEAD: Like rodeo cowboys twirling lassos, Kim Jing Mark and Chang Yongcai adroitly loop long ropes and swing them in the air. But these are ropes of dough, not hemp, and the men are not rodeo stars but chefs at two New Jersey Chinese restaurants.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: Der Freischutz By Carl Maria von Weber. A production of the Wurttembergische Staatsoper, Stuttgart; featuring Catarina Ligendza and Toni Kramer, with Dennis Russell Davies, conductor. Stereo Hi-fi. Color. Home Vision. 150 minutes. $49.95. Lovers of singing be warned: You'll hear little bel canto from this cast.

title: CABLE TV AND FEINER: SOME FURTHER POINTS
description: Regarding the criticism of County Legislator Paul Feiner, your story missed the point [ ''Cable TV Campaign Criticized,'' Aug. 23 ] . Of course, UA-Columbia Cable would prefer not to be aggravated by Paul Feiner's intervention in subscriber complaints.

title: Jill Stauffer Is Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. John E. Stauffer of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jill Stauffer to James Ware Cobbs Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cobbs of Greenwich and Snowville, N.H. The wedding is to be next month.

title: SOME COLLEGE ENROLLMENTS RISE AND SO DOES TUITION
description: LEAD: TUITION at Long Island's colleges and universities has risen an average of 6 to 8 percent, replicating the national rate and running well ahead of general inflation. School officials, however, point out that the increases are down from the double-digit increases of the early 80's.

title: Striking a Balance On Scholarships
description: THERE were complaints that New York State was biased against women in its awarding of college scholarships. To the Board of Regents in Albany, the remedy was clear: change the test that determined who got the grants, worth up to $10,000 apiece.

title: A Summer of Discontent
description: There exists a small, cranky minority that doesn't necessarily love a beach, and I am a member of it.

title: Struggle to Save Landmark Hotel
description: IT WAS an uphill fight at best, but civic groups banded together in March nonetheless to try to keep the sumptuous Hotel Utah in downtown Salt Lake City from closing.

title: Retailers Sturdy Performers
description: EARLY this summer, the retail trade research group of Kidder, Peabody & Company brought before New York analysts the managements of 10 retailers whose initial public offerings the firm managed last year. It was a successful reunion: of the 10 companies, 8 had higher stock prices than they did the day they went public.

title: Northwest Is First in Complaints By Travelers; Continental Now 2d
description: Northwest Airlines now outranks Continental as the carrier with the most traveler complaints filed against it with the Federal Government.

title: Q and A
description: Rights of Survivorship Question: I share my rent-stabilized apartment with my gay male lover, but the lease is in my name only. What can I do now to protect him so that he can remain in the apartment as a legal tenant if I should predecease him? . . . D. J., Manhattan Answer: There are no laws or housing regulations that give you the right to add your partner's name to the lease. But according to Russell Pearce, an attorney with the Legal Aid Society's civil division, in seven out of eight recent cases involving the rights of the surviving partner in a gay relationship, the court has upheld the right of the survivor to remain in the rent-regulated apartment after the death of the tenant of record.

title: A GIANTS MAN, ALL THE WAY
description: Why did football bring me so to life? I can't say precisely. Part of it was my feeling that football was an island of directness in a world of circumspection. In football a man was asked to do a difficult and brutal job, and he either did it or got out. - FREDERICK EXLEY, ''A Fan's Notes'' Football is a very direct game. It's either disaster or euphoria. - BILL PARCELLS

title: Hope P. Van der Wolk Marries Reed A. Morrison
description: Hope Powell Van der Wolk, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson F. Van der Wolk of Delray Beach, Fla., and Osterville, Mass., and Reed Alexander Morrison, the son of Helen L. Morrison of Emeryville, Calif., and Murdo D. Morrison of Redwood City, Calif., were married yesterday at the South Congregational Church in Centerville, Mass. The Rev. William R. Baran performed the ceremony.

title: A LIVING SCRAPBOOK
description: THE ELEMENTS ARE SIMILAR in all of his interiors: old-fashioned chintzes and blue-and-white porcelains, bows atop romantic paintings and floral needlepoint or Aubusson rugs. To be sure, Mario Buatta's interpretation of the English country style is well known, even to those with only the slightest interest in decorating. While this cozy, lived-in feeling may be in vogue one season and out the next, some people will forever dream of sinking into a sumptuous sofa in a room well-appointed with bibelots, plants and family memorabilia.

title: REPORTS OF U.F.O.'S INCREASE
description: LEAD: WHILE United States Air Force officials deny any experience with or interest in unidentified flying objects in the Hudson Valley area, an estimated 6,000 residents in Westchester and Putnam Counties and Connecticut have reported U.F.O. sightings since 1983, representatives of a volunteer group of U.F.O.

title: Bears Beat Raiders On Last Play, 20-17
description: Kevin Butler kicked a 42-yard field goal on the final play of the game today to give the Chicago Bears a 20-17 exhibition victory over the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: A History of Defying Public Policy By WILLIAM B. O'CONNELL; William B. O'Connell is president of the United States League of Savings Institutions.
description: IN a quiet setting in Stamford, Conn., there is a group of seven men who make up the Financial Accounting Standards Board. Although this group has a profound influence on the economic life of the country, the members are not publicly elected, nor appointed by or answerable to any elected official body.

title: Film: Costa-Gavras's 'Family Business'
description: COSTA-GAVRAS, the Greek-born French director, makes political thrillers of more effective style than anyone else at work today. Helping himself to dark chapters from contemporary history, he simplifies facts and shapes events to his own ends. He constructs movies that seethe with passion in the cause of justice and, incidentally, are whopping good suspense-melodramas, which is what most outrages those critics who stand to his political right. Nobody would give a hoot about the politics of such movies as ''State of Siege'' and ''Missing'' if they weren't so bloody entertaining.

title: In India, an Argument Over Food vs. Phones
description: A Government plan to import millions of dollars worth of advanced car telephones and credit card-operated public telephones has Indian officials criticizing each other over whether the country needs such expensive equipment.

title: RICHARD MARQUAND,MOVIEMAKER, DIES
description: Richard Marquand, a British director who captivated American movie-goers with ''Return of the Jedi'' and ''Jagged Edge,'' died Friday at a hospital near London. He was 49 years old.

title: As Other Industries Fade, States Set Their Sights on Tourism
description: ABOUT 165 times a day, a letter is dispatched from the office of Montana's Gov. Ted Schwinden to someone outside the state. Each of the letters, which are personalized invitations to visit the wonderful wilds of Montana, is one more shot in an expensive, escalating battle among the states over some unnatural resources - tourists. This struggle, once confined to the summer months, is now waged year round.

title: In Cameroon, Press Finds Caution Pays
description: Of sub-Saharan Africa's 44 countries, only Botswana, Gambia and Mauritius have a ''generally free'' press, according to a report by Freedom House, a New York-based group that tracks civil liberties throughout the world.

title: Kenyon Bissell To Be the Bride Of C. J. Grogan
description: Kenyon Bissell and Christopher Jeffrey Grogan, a son of the late Margaret F. Peabody and the late Dr. Richard H. Grogan, both of Boston, plan to marry Nov. 1, the parents of the future bride, Marcia Cunningham Bissell and George H. Bissell, both of Boston, have announced.

title: AWARD OF HONOR
description: IN THE SUMMER OF 1982, I went back to my hometown to collect an award. The town is Fergus Falls, Minn., 50 miles east of Fargo, N.D. In 1949, when I left it to become a cadet at West Point, the place had about 12,000 people. It still does. Because I had become the C.E.O. of an international corporation, Fergus Falls decided to give me its first Award of Honor. But I felt the evening should have been for my friend Paul Gust.

title: Hunting for Gold in the 'Pink Sheets'
description: LIKE characters seeking the jewel-encrusted bird in ''The Maltese Falcon,'' investors are increasingly prowling the back alleys of the stock market, searching for treasure. They hope to duplicate legendary finds - such as the Belridge Oil Company, Doubleday & Company, and Oshkosh B'Gosh Inc. - that brought astronomical gains when they were taken over or recognized by Wall Street as growth vehicles.

title: DARK PROGNOSIS OF THE FAMILY BUSINESS
description: MY son is pre-med at college. His father is a physician. His grandfather is a physician. Words like ''hemodialysis'' and ''ophthalmodynamometry'' are as natural to us as ''hostile bid'' and ''arbitrage'' are to a stockbroker. Although medicine is the family business, medical practice is changing so rapidly that my husband and I recently felt compelled to talk to our son about his career plans. ''We're not saying 'Don't become a doctor,' '' we explained. ''We just want you to be aware that the profession you're choosing is not going to be the same profession your father and grandfather chose.''

title: Dr. Laura Lee Forese to Wed
description: The engagement of Dr. Laura Lee Forese to Dr. Robert John Downey has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James J. Forese of Paris, Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Osterville, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Dr. John A. Downey of New York and Sharon, Conn., and Elsie Downey of Closter, N.J.

title: BOARD SEEKS EVICTION FROM SCHOOL
description: LEAD: A SCHOOL board is seeking to evict a day-care center and an arts school from the former Little Plains Elementary School in Huntington.

title: Texas Stops Detroit's Streak
description: Oddibe McDowell's run-scoring single in the ninth inning tonight scored the winning run as the Texas Rangers beat Detroit, 8-7, and snapped the Tigers' four-game winning streak. Detroit's lead in the American League East was cut to half a game over Toronto. The Yankees were in third place, four games back.

description: Bohemia $163,000 25 West Wind Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 2-car garage, 0.75 acre, horse barn; taxes $3,100. title: Dr. Michael Kelly And Sarah Brand Are Wed in Jersey
description: Sarah Babcock Brand, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Archibald Brand of Mantoloking, N.J., and Sewall's Point, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Aloysius Kelly, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jacques Michael Kelly of Washington. The Rev. William G. Graham performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Bay Head, N.J.

title: Protecting Roof's 1st Line of Defense
description: ROOF gutters aren't just trim. They provide a first line of defense against many serious and expensive problems resulting from poor drainage. Consequently, it's important to inspect gutters regularly and to perform maintenance promptly.

title: Marva Scott, Consultant, Is Wed to Donnie Horne
description: At Christ United Methodist Church in New Rochelle, N.Y., Marva Lisa Scott, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Scott of New Rochelle, was married yesterday to Donnie Horne, the son of Selena Horne of Miami and the late Tommy Horne. The Rev. Ralph Morris Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Black Is Back in Town
description: BLACK is a color that occasionally turns up in midsummer, glamorously setting off a good tan or adding a touch of sophistication to a season that doesn't take itself too seriously. But with September's arrival, black really takes off.

title: PAINTINGS ON LEATHER KEEP ALIVE THE SPIRIT OF WORLD WAR II
description: ENTERING Nicholas Gamarello's studio here is like taking a step into the past. Mr. Gamarello works - with Glenn Miller's Army Air Corps Band as background - with leather dyes to keep alive an art his admirers say was lost after the last American World War II combat plane was scrapped.

title: ALL TOO SUDDENLY, SEPTEMBER
description: I'M not sure when my love-hate relationship with September began, but I suspect it was in the first or second grade.

title: FOR CHILDREN, A NEW STATE GUARDIAN
description: FIVE years ago, when Thomas Blatner was appointed director of the state's Division of Youth and Family Services, an arm of the Department of Human Services, he tried to open the $300 million-a-year agency to the community.

title: MONTCLAIR BANKER A HISTORY BUFF, TOO
description: LEAD: J. CARTER BACOT of Montclair is a man with a passion for early American history and, as chairman and chief executive of the Bank of New York, he has ample opportunity to indulge it.

title: French Modern Dance Stresses Its Own Accent
description: CLASSES IN THE MERCE CUN-ningham technique. Workshops in new dance forms. An antipathy toward dance critics. A scramble for money and space to perform. It all sounds like an ordinary dance week in New York City. But the setting is France, the cradle of classical ballet and, for the past 10 years or so, of a national modern-dance boom.

title: In City Schools, a Big Contract, a Big Vacancy
description: THE smiles are usually broad, the words effusive at the end of city labor negotiations. They were especially so last week when Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, and Robert F. Wagner Jr., the president of the Board of Education, announced that the new three-year contract would give teachers handsome raises - by far the highest since 1969 - as well as increased influence in the schools.

title: A Gorbachev Signal on Nicaragua?
description: In an artful stroke of geopolitical irony, Mikhail S. Gorbachev seems to be presenting President Reagan with a powerful incentive to extricate the United States from the Nicaraguan morass and to advance toward a Central American settlement.

title: Fordham Wins in Upset, 14-9
description: Rodney Knight, a senior fullback, scored twice on 1-yard runs yesterday to lead Fordham to a 14-9 upset over the Merchant Marine Academy, the two-time defender in the Liberty Conference, at Tomb Memorial Field, Kings Point, L.I.

title: SYMPHONIC SEASON IS CLOSER
description: AT least seven of Connecticut's major symphonies have chosen October for their seasonal openers. As always, subscribers get better seats at lower prices and, usually, various additional advantages: newsletters, restaurant discounts, preconcert lectures and the like.

title: Democracy in the Wings as Turks Vote Today
description: Suleyman Demirel, a former Prime Minister, was reported the other day to have ordered the printing of 130,000 blue pamphlets, six million blue posters, 58,000 yards of blue bunting and countless blue candy-bar wrappers emblazoned with ''evet,'' the Turkish word for yes.

title: RYE ARTS CENTER RETURNS TO ITS HOME
description: THE Rye Arts Center, which began 27 years ago in a neighborhood barn with some painting and drawing classes for local residents, is reopening this month after a successful battle to save its present building -which it renovated at a cost of nearly $1 million.

title: World Threat of Plastic Trash defies Technological Solution
description: ONCE almost synonymous with cheap flimsiness, plastic has become respectable. Synthetic polymer resins still go into disposable cups, hamburger boxes and party favors, but lately they are also the stuff of motorcycle sprockets, tank armor and rocket engines. The plastic helmets and daggers used by today's soldiers are not only lighter and stronger than their steel counterparts, but they will remain in mint condition for centuries, to the possible delight of future archeologists.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section on Aug. 16 misidentified Kathryn Falk. She is the publisher of Romantic Times and other magazines.

title: NEW TAX ABATEMENT WOULD HURT NEWARK
description: SUPPOSE you and a friend decided to buy a lottery ticket together, with both of you chipping in equally and with an agreement that you would share any winnings. Suppose the ticket won a million dollars, but your friend gave you only $100 because, he claimed, having to give you a half-million dollars was a terrible shock for which he was psychologically unprepared, never having done anything like that before.

title: Suspect Held as Fake Doctor
description: A man who treated hospital patients as a physician although he allegedly lacked even an undergraduate degree has been charged with mail fraud. Thomas R. Theodore, 41 years old, formerly of Arlington and Winchester, was accused of improperly obtaining a medical degree and license to practice medicine, postal officials said Tuesday. Acting United States Attorney Frank L. McNamara said, ''There is no allegation that any patient suffered harm as a result.''

title: Jill Allison Edwards Is Wed to David Peter Paul
description: Jill Allison Edwards, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larry K. Edwards of Raleigh, N.C., and David Peter Paul, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard T. Paul of Weston, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert F. Regan performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius of Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Mayor of Jerusalem Appeals For Soccer Field to Be Built
description: Mayor Teddy Kollek staged a one-man protest Friday in favor of a soccer stadium opposed by rigorously Orthodox Jews.

title: >Susan Epstein Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Burton I. Epstein of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Michele Epstein, to Morton Jay Fertel, the son of Mrs. Sanford Crisconi of Springfield, Pa., and Theodore Fertel of Philadelphia. Ms. Epstein, a financial analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, graduated from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, as did her fiance. He is in sales and trading at the Bankers Trust Company in New York. The wedding is to be in October.

title: Little League Is Boon to a Fading City
description: This city of 61,000, long suffering from industrial decline, received a huge civic boost this week when Little League Baseball Inc. selected it as the site for a $3.5 million Eastern regional center for 11 states from Maine to Maryland.

title: FINE CUISINE SUPERBLY PRESENTED
description: MIRABELLE is marvelous. This three-and-a-half-year-old French restaurant in St. James is one of Long Island's best.

title: Poll Finds Voters Place Premium on Honesty
description: Americans will place a premium on honesty and ''playing by the rules'' as they choose their next President, a new survey has found.

title: Giants Triumph In Final Seconds
description: The Giants had their final exhibition game won tonight. Then, they let the Pittsburgh Steelers apparently win it on a field goal with 79 seconds remaining. Then they bounced back and won it, 26-20, on a 20-yard pass from Phil Simms to Lionel Manuel in the end zone with 13 seconds left.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SCULPTURE AND DANCE Henry Moore's 1960's sculpture ''Large Two Forms'' will be the focal point of a dance program by Victoria Marks and Company on the mall of the State University of New York at Purchase at 3 P.M. Saturday. The noted choreographer was commissioned by the university's Neuberger Museum to devise a piece of choreography indicative of the monumental bronze. The troupe will also perform recent works from its repertoire.

title: Several More Questions and the Answers
description: FOR those who tuned in to last week's column, here is the continuation of the back-to-school quiz I devised to gauge practical photographic skill. If you missed the beginning of the quiz, don't despair; you can start now without any penalty. title: Q and A
description: Paris-Vienna Question: How much time is needed for a really quick rail trip from Paris to Vienna? I would want to stroll around Vienna before taking the train back to Paris. - R. P., New York Answer: The round trip would be spread over at least four days. There are two direct trains every day. The slower one offers the more scenic journey - and it costs less. This trip is aboard the Arlberg Express, which leaves Paris at 10:40 P.M. and goes through Switzerland before arriving in Vienna the following evening at 8. The most scenic part of the journey is between Zurich, reached at 7 A.M., and Innsbruck, Austria. The train then travels on to Kitzbuhel, Salzburg and Vienna. On its western run, the Arlberg leaves Vienna at 10 A.M. and reaches Paris the following day at 6:48 A.M.

title: THE POPE, THE MEDIA, THE DRAMA

This particular Pope is telegenic: He has a nice face, striking robes and a 2,000-year-old presence. Cameras like him, and although he has publicly fretted about the ''manipulation and, consequently, evasion and hedonism'' that cameras can bring, he knows a thing or two about their uses. Indeed, church officials last winter spoke of auctioning the television rights to his American visit. This was a terrible idea, quickly dropped, but someone surely would have bought the rights, and this would have beaten a bingo game or collection plate as a way of raising money for good causes. The Pope is a media star, most likely the biggest in the world today.

title: The Presidential Contenders Seek to Make Their Mark
description: BY tradition, Labor Day is the opening day for general election campaigns. Labor Day of the Presidential election year, that is. The primary season begins some months earlier, when the primaries do, and the pre-primary period at some undefined time before that, generally the previous fall. But this time, in part because the election industry has become a perpetual motion machine, and in part because the primary schedule has been accelerated, the 1988 Presidential cycle has begun early - very early. Not every candidate has formally announced, more may yet enter - events might still attract some, like Governor Cuomo of New York, who have said they are not candidates - and more will drop out. But the field is crowded early, and all summer, people who aspire to the Presidency have been stumping the country, telling voters that Election Day 1988 will produce a leader for the next decade, perhaps even set the tone for the next century. Candidates who have experience have been emphasizing it. Sometimes, they have also talked about the issues - subjects that are constants, such as the economy and the farm problem, and subjects that have been thrown up by current events, such as the Bork nomination and the AIDS epidemic. What follows is an outline of the issues and highlights of what the candidates have been saying about them. THE CONSTANTS Farm Policy

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ERNESTO. By Umberto Saba. Translated by Mark Thompson. (Carcanet, $15.95.) ''I knew as soon as I'd written the first sentence that this wouldn't be for publication.'' So wrote Umberto Saba, the prominent Italian poet, of this short, highly autobiographical novel about an adolescent boy in fin-de-siecle Trieste. Saba, who left the novel unfinished at his death in 1957, believed his characters' blunt language would work against it. Equally problematic for the public of that time would have been his frank descriptions of homosexual and heterosexual lovemaking. In ''Ernesto'' - now annotated and in a straightforward English translation for the first time - Saba presents his hero's emotional education (through a series of encounters with a day laborer, a prostitute and a younger boy) with a forthrightness that would certainly have raised eyebrows back then. Anyone reading these scenes today, however, will probably find their sexually explicit content redeemed by the unfailingly affectionate tone. The author's intent in this novel, as he has said of a previous work, is ''to describe, with serene innocence, the marvelous world.'' Of course, this kind of endeavor has its pitfalls; Saba's ''serenely innocent'' style can occasionally sour, turning into a mannered ingenuousness that is just one step away from sentimentality. But there are remarkably shrewd social and psychological insights beneath the simplicity of Ernesto's encounters. And in the early flirtation scene between the boy and the day laborer, for instance, Saba truly achieves his goal, with a style of storytelling that is direct, honest and - in its own quiet way - even courageous.

title: False Forward
description: To the Editor: Your Aug. 30 article on Ravi Batra (Economist or Mystic? Tune In, Around 1990, to Find Out) contains an error of usage, thrice repeated. You report that Lester Thurow is upset that his ''forward'' appeared in Dr. Batra's book. ''Forward'' may be used as a noun, but only to denote a position on a sports team. ''Forward'' may also be used as a verb, an adjective and an adverb: for example, ''Dr. Thurow felt that the publisher's use of his foreword was rather forward and did little to forward his reputation as a forward thinker.'' You many not use ''forward'' when you mean to say ''foreword.'' RALPH T. BIRDSEY Atlanta, Ga., Aug. 31

MOONRISE, MOONSET, by Tadeusz Konwicki. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) Neither quite fiction nor memoir, ''Moonrise, Moonset'' brilliantly assimilates earlier memories into a reflective essay on the coming of martial law in Poland in 1981. THE LIVES OF JEAN TOOMER: A Hunger for Wholeness, by Cynthia Earl Kerman and Richard Eldridge. (Louisiana State University, $29.95.)
