title: Giants Puzzle Over Galbreath
description: Now comes the dirty work, telling 12 football players they no longer are members of the Giants.

title: At a Party for 100th Birthday, Landon Receives a Kid of 76
description: Three days shy of his 100th birthday, Alf Landon looked a bit frail but happy and alert today as President Reagan stood beside him on his front porch and said, ''You don't know what a joy it is to come to a birthday party of someone who in all honesty can call me a kid.''

title: Anne Robinson Becomes a Bride
description: Anne Emily Robinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elton Seydel Robinson of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married in the chapel at Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, Conn., yesterday to Gordon Field Armour, a son of Pamela Kelley Armour of Lake Forest, Ill., and Vernon Armour of Chicago. The Rev. Thomas O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest and a chaplain at the school, performed the ceremony.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/2-5

title: TAX LAW AND ART GIFTS
description: The announcement last Wednesday by a philanthropist and art dealer that he would sell Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises,'' rather than donate the painting to the small Maine college it has been on loan to for the last decade, is the first public evidence that the current art boom and changes in the Federal tax law may result in a cutback in gifts to museums this year.

title: A Search for Image and Relevance
description: Through the huge picture windows in his office suite, Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., can look out over Lafayette Square and across the street to the White House, less than 250 yards away.

title: Moscow Journal; The New Ingenuity Flaps Its Wings
description: If Wilbur and Orville Wright had mated a windmill with a bumblebee they might have ended up with the contraption that stood the other day awaiting its first attempted flight at an airfield in north Moscow.

title: Time to Get Serious
description: A FEW opinions with four weeks left in the baseball season, one week left in the United States Open and, who knows, maybe two weeks left in the professional football season:

title: Schools Chancellor Job: Does Anyone Even Want It?
description: As the New York City Board of Education prepares to search for a new schools chancellor, a major hurdle has already begun to emerge - finding someone who actually wants the job.

title: Youth Is Arraigned in Attack
description: A 17-year-old from the Canarsie section of Brooklyn was released on his own recognizance last night after being arraigned on charges stemming from a racial attack in the neighborhood last week.

title: Steel Prices Climb to a Three-Year High
description: Defying widespread predictions earlier this year that they would erode by the summer, steel prices have risen gradually to their highest point in more than three years.

title: Labor Truce Welcomed at Coors Base
description: Inside the sprawling, campus-like complex of the Adolph Coors Company and on downtown streets here, a new word is working its way into conversations - union.

title: MGM Grand Air's Chief Is Starting a New Battle
description: F. Michael Rogers, a former fighter pilot who shot down 12 enemy planes during World War II, will begin another aerial battle this week. The inaugural flight tomorrow of MGM Grand Air from Los Angeles to New York will open the latest effort by a wealthy investor to build a luxury airline by luring business travelers from the big commercial airlines.

title: Meri Nieda, a Lawyer, Married to Jeffrey Lane
description: At the Swedenborgian Church of the New Jerusalem in San Francisco, Meri Ann Nieda, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Isamu Nieda of Tiburon, Calif., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Mark Lane, a son of Betty G. Lane and Dr. I. William Lane, both of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. James Lawrence performed the ceremony.

title: College Tuition Soars in Uncompetitive Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Books: Build a Nation
description: THE FORGING OF THE UNION, 1781-1789. By Richard B. Morris. 416 pages.

title: The Hunger for Land Feeds The Crisis in Central America
description: Amid the noise and bustle of this frenetic capital, Alejandro Canoj Morales spends most of his time sitting on a sidewalk selling trinkets and asking for handouts.

title: 7th Death in Oregon Mystery
description: The skull of a seventh person was found Saturday evening on a rural hillside where the remains of six others have been discovered, including five women the authorities have confirmed were murdered.

title: Cards' Tudor Helps Himself
description: John Tudor pitched three-hit ball for seven innings today and had a pair of run-scoring singles, and Jack Clark hit a two-run homer as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the San Diego Padres, 6-4.

title: An Eclectic Theatrical Festival
description: Music theater has emerged in recent years as a catch phrase encompassing the great range of works falling in the gap between traditional opera and musical comedy. It has gained credence as lines dividing so-called high art and pop art have blurred. The American Music Theater Festival, which begins its fourth and most ambitious season yet on Saturday, revels in the disconcerting ambiguity.

title: Sony Digital Portable
description: The Sony Corporation will sell the world's first portable digital audio tape recorder in Japan in December, a company spokesman said Friday. The product will not be as small as two other Sony products, the Walkman and Discman, and it will be priced at 250,000 yen, or $1,775, the spokesman said.

title: Twins Boys Are Separated in 22 Hours of Surgery
description: In a 22-hour surgical marathon that ended at 5:15 A.M. today, a 70-member medical team at Johns Hopkins Hospital here successfully separated 7-month-old twin boys who were born joined at the head, using a unique combination of techniques designed to prevent neurological damage.

title: Catherine Furth Weds A Recording Executive
description: The marriage of Catherine Barbara Furth, a daughter of Dr. Hans G. Furth and Madeline B. Furth, both of Washington, to Theodore David Lehrman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. Lehrman of New York and Edgewater, N.J., took place yesterday at Woodend Mansion in Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Sindelar B.C. Open Winner: Joey Sindelar won the B.C. Open title in Endicott, N.Y., with a final-round two-under-par 69 yesterday, becoming the first two-time winner in the tournament's 16-year history. The four-stroke victory was Sindelar's first since he won the B.C. Open two years ago by one stroke. Sindelar, who failed to make the cut here last year, received $72,000.

title: Manila Mutiny Almost Worked, U.S. Aides Say
description: A wide range of senior United States officials say the recent coup attempt in the Philippines came very close to succeeding.

title: DR. MURRAY M. LIPTON
description: Dr. Murray M. Lipton, a retired University of Louisville microbiologist who conducted research on the polio virus, died of Parkinson's disease Aug. 29 at the Northfield Manor nursing home in Louisville, Ky., where he was a resident. He was 68 years old. Dr. Lipton is survived by a daughter, Dr. Deborah Lipton of Manhattan, and a brother, William, of Sebastopol, Calif.

title: Grand Old Logotype
description: In the hectic world of modern marketing, any product or enterprise of consequence must have a logotype. The Republican Party foresees its 1988 national convention in New Orleans as consequential, so it has promulgated a logo to symbolize the event. It consists of the stylized three-star elephant used by the Republican National Committee since 1968, with its back reshaped to represent the Superdome where the Republican delegates will gather next August. The colors, no one will be shocked to learn, are red, white and blue.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Slain in Gangland-Style Shooting
description: A 42-year-old Brooklyn man was shot to death gangland style on a street corner in the Bensonhurst section early Sunday morning, the police said.

title: Ms. Shaffer Is Bride Of a Film Executive
description: The marriage of Monica Shaffer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Norman Shaffer of Potomac, Md., to Richard I. Karo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Karo of Highland Park, N.J., took place last evening at the Water Club in New York. Rabbi Marshall Meyer officiated.

title: Richard Card Is Wed To Nancy McAllister
description: Nancy Alexandra McAllister, an officer in the capital-markets group of Bankers Trust Company, and Richard Malone Card, an officer in the corporate finance department of Bankers Trust Company, were married yesterday. Msgr. Edmond J. Trench performed the ceremony at the Infant Jesus Roman Catholic Church in Port Jefferson, L.I.

title: Brown Holds To Trust Rule
description: Despite widespread rumors, Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., the dealer manager for the Americus Trust for shares of the Philip Morris Companies, said Friday it would not seek to change the original rules of the trust.

title: Loving Babies Before They Are Born
description: An expectant mother who consults her obstetrician regularly vastly reduces the chance that her baby will come into the world too soon or too small. Yet frequently in America, more than in most other industrialized countries, women don't get such prenatal advice. The payoff for providing it -healthy children, happy mothers and cost savings -would be enormous. That's why an innovative program in the Bronx bears watching.

title: Parties Who Are Not Clients
description: WHEN the township of West Windsor, N.J., decided that it needed a new sewer system, it asked its law firm, Schragger, Schragger & Lavine, to draw up papers for competitive bidding on the project.

title: College Tuition Soars in Uncompetitive Market; Public-System Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: White's Law: 'Hype' Plus Yards Equals Heisman
description: LAST autumn, Lorenzo White, the Michigan State tailback, followed a healthy and successful sophomore season with a junior year of injury and frustration.

title: Team, and Trophy, Spur Lockbaum
description: WHAT comes first, the team or the Heisman Trophy? That is a dilemma facing the Holy Cross football team this season, but the coaches and the Heisman candidate, Gordon Lockbaum, hope they can meld the choices and work toward common goals.

title: Longtime Friends Are Seldom Rivals
description: ZINA GARRISON and Lori McNeil were born just over a month apart in 1963 and they have been almost inseparable since they met in an elementary school classroom 13 years ago. Their story is one of two friends whose relationship endured and expanded as they became two of the most talented female tennis players in the world. They shared the same two coaches, traveled together for much of the year and attained rankings of seventh and 11th, respectively, going into the United States Open.

title: Cameroon Battles Against Bureaucracy
description: They are called ''Pajero-crats'' - a proud caste of bureaucrats who ride around town in luxurious Jeep-like vans made by Japanese auto makers.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Trader Gave Up Career In Poker for Options
description: LEAD: To the noisy denizens of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, he is known as ''Gentleman'' Jack Keller, the man who traded in his poker chips for blue chips.

title: Pawnbrokers in Britain Draw Affluent Clientele
description: He was educated at Eton, lives in London's fashionable Belgravia district and speaks in the clipped understated phrases of the English upper classes. That may not sound like a description of Britain's leading pawnbroker, but it is.

title: Seoul Accused of Trying To Discredit the Strikers
description: Human-rights activists and opposition leaders say the Government is deliberately overstating the extent of recent labor violence here to try to stir public anxiety and to justify a crackdown against striking workers.

title: Nixon Picks Cuomo And Bush for 1988
description: Richard Nixon says Governor Cuomo of New York is the front-runner for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination and Vice President Bush will probably be the Republican nominee, The Chicago Sun-Times reported today.

title: Article 180187 -- No Title
description: Wearever-Proctorsilex Inc. said Friday that an investor group led by its management had offered to acquire the company for $18 a share in cash, or about $109 million.

title: 'First Light' Author Begins at the End
description: ''First Light,'' Charles Baxter's acclaimed first novel, is, in fact, his fourth. About his first three novels, he said: ''I wouldn't let them out. I did take a brief episode out of one of them but, for the most part, I can't stand to look at them now so I wouldn't want anyone else to.''

title: Czechs Eliminate U.S.
description: Czechoslovakia defeated the United States, 3-1, tonight to advance to the semifinals of the Canada Cup hockey competition and eliminate the Americans from the tournament.

title: Why Bear Burdens for Allies?
description: Dear Donald Trump:

title: Port Allen Journal; Ancient Bequest Puts Some Profit In Wedding Vows
description: Getting married has always meant a lot to people here in Louisiana's tiniest parish, in the heart of the sugarcane country near the Mississippi River.

title: Copenhagen Airport Struck
description: A strike by fuel transport workers at Kastrup Airport in Copenhagen today caused delays and cancellation of some flights, airport officials said. About 70 fuel truck drivers refused to work to protest a reduction of their hourly Sunday wage, which is higher than the weekday wage.

title: Letter: On City Planning; Add Park to the West Side Highway
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Is Turning Political Science Into an Art
description: Many political scientists say Ronald Reagan's Presidency keeps taking them by surprise. There they were in the 1970's, dissecting the travails of Jimmy Carter and Gerald Ford and the final days of Richard M. Nixon, focusing on the limitations of the office and the woes of a White House beset by Congress, the press and implacable interest groups.

title: Tishman's Venture in Britain
description: George Wimpey P.L.C., Britain's largest building company, and the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, the big New York contractor, have established a joint venture to provide construction management for large projects in Britain.

title: Inside a Key Russian Radar Site: Tour Raises Questions on Treaty
description: The Soviet Union allowed Western experts to inspect its top-secret giant radar here today, known as the Krasnoyarsk site after a large city south of here.

title: Blacks Would Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: AFGHANS BELIEVED SET TO COMPROMISE
description: Diego Cordovez, the United Nations mediator for the Afghan conflict, believes the Moscow-backed Kabul Government is now prepared to compromise on a shorter time to withdraw Soviet forces from Afghanistan, senior United Nations officials say.

title: College Tuition Soars in Uncompetitive Market; What Future?
description: To the Editor:

title: In 3 Countries, a Tangle of Election Campaigning; Argentina: Democracy Is Declared The Winner
description: Argentines voted today in legislative, provincial and local elections that political leaders hailed as another step in the country's consolidation of democracy.

title: McEnroe Draws Fine, Suspension
description: John McEnroe received the bad news late Saturday night. In this case, he wasn't the last to know. Earlier in the evening, he had suspected that Ken Farrar, the grand prix supervisor of officials, might issue a harsh penalty, one that could cost McEnroe not only in dollars and cents, but also deprive him of his right to play tennis for the rest of the year.

title: Conagra in Settlement
description: Hundreds of former Armour Food Company workers will get back pay, job offers, retroactive seniority and preferential hiring rights under a settlement announced last week by their union and Conagra Inc., which bought 40 Armour plants four years ago. The settlement, negotiated with the United Food and Commercial Workers union and the National Labor Relations Board, does not establish that Conagra violated any Federal labor laws in hiring a new work force for the plants. Under terms of the settlement, Conagra will pay a total of $6.6 million, including $1.6 million in interest and taxes, to the N.L.R.B. for disbursement. In addition, more than 550 workers who unsuccessfully applied for Conagra jobs will be entitled to job offers, with retroactive seniority.

title: E.P.A. Radon Figures Raise Some Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: At Seaport: New Wine for Old Skins
description: A wave of redevelopment plans is likely to wash over the northern half of the South Street Seaport Historic District by year's end, carrying with it the potential to alter forever one of the last remaining 19th-century pockets in lower Manhattan.

title: Illinois Town Stunned by Heir's Death
description: In this older, working-class Illinois town of about 30,000, only a few names evoke the image of gentry.

title: Accidents Disrupt Families
description: IN the award-winning film ''Ordinary People,'' members of an upper-middle-class family fall out with one another and suffer severe distress because they cannot cope with the strong emotions that erupt in the wake of a boating accident that has killed the eldest son.

title: Reagan's Travails
description: In his Current Comedy newsletter, Robert Orben, who was on President Ford's White House speech-writing staff, observed in the wake of the Iran-contra hearings: ''There is now a theory that anyone who takes a good look at what Ronald Reagan is going through and still wants to be President isn't smart enough to be President.''

title: Dance: Baryshnikov & Co.
description: New Yorkers may not have seen Mikhail Baryshnikov dance with a ballet company since the summer of 1986, but that does not mean the rest of the country is as deprived.

title: Books of The Times; Order and Disorder
description: IN THE SKIN OF A LION. By Michael Ondaatje. 244 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Hopes for Economy Stir in Sri Lanka
description: After four years of escalating warfare that devastated a once-robust economy, the island nation of Sri Lanka has begun pushing for at least a partial recovery built around its peace agreement signed with India a few weeks ago.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Tompkins Sq. Tumult

title: 25 States Bid for Big Atom Smasher
description: At least 35 sites in 25 states have been proposed to the Department of Energy as the location for the Federal Government's $4.4 billion supercollider, a giant atom smasher meant to extend the experimental reach of modern physics.

title: Americans Win Five Medals As World Meet Ends in Rome
description: On the final, and busiest, day of the world track and field championships, the United States rallied to win five medals, three of them gold, easing the sting of an otherwise bland overall performance.

title: Memories of Broadway When the Upper West Side Was Younger
description: To the Editor:

title: In 3 Countries, a Tangle of Election Campaigning; Turkey: Voters Weigh 10-Year Ban On Politicians
description: Prime Minister Turgut Ozal called early general elections today as his countrymen voted in a narrow contest on whether to lift bans on his political rivals imposed during the nation's most recent spell of military rule.

title: Chances Are Slim For Subway Series
description: The Mets and the Yankees, striving to produce that elusive Subway Series, each have 26 games in which to overtake the teams ahead of them. They need a stretch similar to the one that catapulted the San Francisco Giants into the most commanding position of any of the division leaders entering the final four weeks of the season.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Roger Maris has held the major league record for home runs in a season since he hit 61 in 1961. Babe Ruth held it before that. Who held it before Ruth?

title: On Straw Polls
description: Presidential contenders who are not satisfied with their ratings in public opinion surveys, which claim a considerable degree of scientific accuracy, are turning to straw polls, which make no such claim but sometimes sound good.

title: First Woman Set To Lead Group
description: Catherine E. Rudder this weekend became the first woman to be named executive director of the American Political Science Association.

title: Carter W. Clarke Dies at 90; An Army Intelligence Officer
description: Carter W. Clarke, a retired brigadier general who headed a War Department investigation of the military intelligence role in the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Clearwater, Fla. He was 90 years old.

title: Quinn Martin Is Dead at 65; Produced Popular TV Series
description: Quinn Martin, one of Hollywood's most successful producers of action-adventure series for television, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 65 years old.

title: Sandinistas' Foes Stage a Rally
description: Nicaraguan opposition leaders denounced the Sandinista Government today at a public rally attended by more than 1,000 people in this provincial capital.

title: Datapoint Losing Operating Officer
description: Doris D. Bencsik wants a vacation.

title: Meadowlands Glances Back At Dirty Past
description: About a mile north of Giants Stadium sit two contaminated lots. They are so filled with chemical pollution that they qualify for the Federal Superfund cleanup list.

title: Fishing Case Unites Divided Tribe. . .and Another Stirs Protest on Treaty and Prison Sentences
description: The largest Indian tribe in the State of Washington, the Confederated Tribes and Bands of the Yakima Indian Nation, has enlisted the aid of members of Congress in protesting the prison sentences of five Yakimas convicted in Federal court of illegal fishing.

title: One Germany? Poland and Soviet Say No
description: On the eve of Erich Honecker's visit to Bonn, Poland and the Soviet Union, East Germany's major Warsaw Pact neighbors and partners, have warned West Germany against raising hopes that the trip will lead to eventual German reunification.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Elantec Inc., Milipitas, Calif., an analog semiconductor maker, said Dave O'Brien had accepted the position of president and chief executive.

title: Consumers' Credit Cost Increasing
description: Last week's increases in the prime and discount rates dashed any remaining hopes that consumers will soon get a second chance to borrow at rates as low as those that prevailed early this year.

title: Best in the East? The Usual Suspects
description: Boston College, Pitt and Penn State will field the East's best teams this season, the ones that will surface in the top-20 polls and vie for bowl-game invitations.

title: Film: 'The Return of Ruben Blades'
description: Ruben Blades, more than most popular singers, is a public, political figure. His lyrics are addressed to all of Latin America, urging self-determination and an end to outside intervention; his ambitions, as he says in a careful statement during the film ''The Return of Ruben Blades,'' showing tonight at the Bleecker Street Cinema, might well encompass running for ''the highest office'' in his native Panama. They also involve reaching past the Spanish-speaking salsa audience to North America and beyond, but doing so on Mr. Blades's own terms - not an easy proposition.

title: Jell-O Eating Masks Sober Side of Freshman Week
description: Shortly after she arrived at Drew University, Jennifer Carrea had to gobble a plateful of red Jell-O with her hands tied behind her back while hundreds of cheering classmates watched.

title: Robertson Plans an Ad Campaign To Enhance TV Minister's Image
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -

title: Dr. R.E. Fremont Dies; Was Medical Official
description: Dr. Rudolph Eric Fremont, medical director of the New York City Department of Personnel, died Friday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y., of injuries he suffered in an auto accident near his summer home in Somers, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Markets Closed Today
description: In observance of Labor Day, the stock and commodity exchanges and most businesses in the United States and Canada will be closed today. Federal, state and local government offices will also be closed.

title: Venetian Gondoliers Protest
description: Venice's gondoliers boycotted the city's annual Historic Regatta today and instead staged a demonstration against pollution, decay and an absence of traffic controls. More than 300 gondoliers took part in the demonstration, which followed the same route as the regatta, held every year on the first Sunday in September. The gondoliers are also seeking strict controls on motor launches, which are damaging historic buildings, and over the dumping of waste into the city's waterways.

title: Epson Event Briefly Held A Record for Participation
description: It appears that bridge captured the world record for participation in a single competitive event earlier this year, but held it for barely 24 hours.

title: Margaret Yelle Weds G. M. Pforzheimer

Yelle of Mattapoisett, Mass., and the late Mr. Yelle, was married yesterday at the Charles Hotel in Cambridge, Mass., to Gary Mahler Pforzheimer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Pforzheimer 3d of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Burton L. Padoll performed the ceremony.

title: Fat People Meet to Lift Self-Esteem
description: It had all the hallmarks of a typical American convention: goofy hats, giggling participants, snapping cameras and lots of name tags. But for these conventioneers, it offered a rare opportunity, ''a chance for them to act like average-sized people do all year round,'' said William Fabrey of Port Washington, L.I.

title: Dolphin Investigator Concludes On-Site Work
description: The marine pathologist who is trying to determine what has been killing bottle-nosed dolphins along the Atlantic coast this summer left Virginia Beach on Saturday to return to his laboratory at the University of Guelph in Ontario.

title: Greece Ending Wage Freeze
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou pledged to end a two-year-old wage freeze but said Saturday that the struggling Greek economy still faces serious problems.

description: When Ben Johnson, the sprinter from Canada, set a world record of 9.83 seconds for 100 meters in Rome eight days ago, he also set the telephone ringing off the hook in the home of another Ben Johnson, in Harrisburg, Pa.

title: Andrea Feirstein Weds

Schiff of Denver. Rabbis Daniel Goldberger and Martin Berman and Cantor Isaac Koll officiated. The bride is an investment banking associate in the public finance division of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York. The bridegroom is an associate at the New York law firm of White & Case.

title: Workers of the World
description: Labor Day 1987 finds organized labor in America, as elsewhere in the West, sapped by falling numbers, waning idealism and declining political clout. Yet in newer industrial societies like South Korea and South Africa, labor movements show signs of vitality and, following in the path of Poland's Solidarity, of playing a key role in the struggle for democracy.

title: Moore Retires; Jets Need Help
description: Unless they make a deal, or discover an unwanted player out there, the Jets will open the season at Buffalo next Sunday with only one nose tackle: Gerald Nichols, the rookie drafted on the seventh round.

title: Cuomo's Travels: Seclusion Gauges A Political Style
description: The national political figures have it all wrong. Their measure of Governor Cuomo's trip to the Soviet Union this month will be how he holds up in the world of international diplomacy and in face-to-face meetings with Soviet leaders. But anyone close to the Cuomo circle knows what the real test is: Once in Moscow, will the Governor venture out of his hotel room? His history says maybe not. After four years of taking few trips outside New York, Mr. Cuomo began to travel a lot this year - Los Angeles, New Orleans, North Carolina, Iowa, New Hampshire, Detroit, Indianapolis - in what many political strategists believe is an effort to build support nationally.

title: Top Women Play Beat the Clock to Gain
description: The top women players, after enduring five days of general monotony and predictability, finally found an opponent yesterday that could challenge them: the clock. But not even that was much of a test; they beat it, too.

One of the first of the carpetbaggers to arrive with me from the North during the migratory boom of 1981 recently packed his portfolio and left for Atlanta. Other compatriots from that era are paying state income taxes in New York, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts.

title: METS LOSE ON JOHNSON'S ERROR IN 16th; YANKEES FALL; Finish 7-2 On Last Trip To the West
description: The Mets and Los Angeles Dodgers grappled across 16 innings for 5 hours 16 minutes today before a wild throw gave the Dodgers a 3-2 victory and ended two streaks at once: the Mets' winning streak at six games and the Dodgers' losing streak at nine.

description: Eleanor Houston Smith, a leader in environmental protection and nature conservation, died Aug. 29 at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. She was 77 years old and lived in Philadelphia and Freeport, Me. She is survived by 6 children and 15 grandchildren.

description: Looking ahead to a Congressional session that will consider major trade legislation, the auto workers' union begins a television advertising campaign today aimed at companies that have moved their plants to cheaper labor markets abroad.

description: The United States Open has been very good to Mark Woodforde of Australia. He made it through the qualifying rounds, now spends every other day advancing through the main draw, enjoys a few giggles during mixed doubles play, and occasionally has an opportunity to practice against Steffi Graf of West Germany, the top-ranked woman.

title: Inventors' Museum Moving
description: Directors of the National Inventors Hall of Fame have decided to move it from the lobby of the United States Patent and Trademark Office to Akron, Ohio. Akron edged out the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia as the new site for the museum, which opened in 1973. Eight inductees have been from Ohio, Mayor Don Plusquellic of Akron noted at the directors' meeting in Arlington, Va., Thursday.

description: The chief military commander of the Nicaraguan guerrillas sat in the debris of the former main rebel border base Friday and acknowledged that he and his men were facing the prospect that their long war could be over.

title: Getting Together: Dating for the Disabled
description: Dateable - pronounced with the accent on the ''able'' - is a dating service for single people with physical disabilities and illnesses, the first such service in Washington and one of only a handful in the United States.

title: Autumn's Allure
description: ALTHOUGH summer's lease will not expire for two more weeks, wheeling flocks of starlings, squash vines dying in the garden and mist rising from lakes and ponds on chilly dawns have triggered that haunting, half-sad, half-exultant state that autumn engenders in many, particularly those who have lived through more than 50 winters.

title: Violence Plagues New Latin Quarter

But now, as the crowds of young people spill from the club on West 48th Street near Broadway early Saturday and Sunday mornings, robberies and fights are frequent and shootings are not uncommon.

description: When Erich Honecker, the East German leader, arrives in Bonn on Monday for his first official visit to West Germany, it is generally agreed that he will be making history. What kind of history, however, remains very much in dispute.

title: Landslide Toll in China Is 65
description: Rescue workers have recovered 65 bodies and have little hope for 20 people still unaccounted for after a landslide in southwest China, the official news agency said today. The landslide on Tuesday demolished a five-story apartment building and two private hotels in Wuxi County in Sichuan Province.

title: Father and Son Killed In Jersey Bus Accident
description: A bus driver and his teen-age son were killed yesterday morning and 30 others were injured when a chartered bus, returning from a gambling junket in Atlantic City, overturned on the Garden State Parkway in Middletown, N.J.

title: CHAD SAYS TROOPS ARE RAZING BASE CAPTURED IN LIBYA
description: Chad, which conducted its first raid into Libyan territory on Saturday in a surprising counteroffensive, said today that its army was demolishing an air base it had captured there.

title: TV: Satire of Ad World From Britain on A&E
description: Flanked by a contingent of terribly modish advertising-agency executives, the rather staid brewery official has just listened to a proposal for an ad campaign that would humorously link one of his products to the Titanic. Gently offering the ''tiniest of quibbles,'' he wonders just ''how prudent it is to couple a disaster of such major proportions to our little bottle of lager.'' An ad executive quickly explains, ''We're talking of the 18-to-24 market; for them, the sinking of the Titanic is little more than a bad joke.''

title: Higuera's Rolling
description: Teddy Higuera's fastball is popping, his temper is under control and the left-handed pitcher for the Milwaukee Brewers has three consecutive shutouts. ''He's over all the emotional problems that troubled him for a while,'' said Chuck Hartenstein, the pitching coach of the Brewers. Higuera, who was 20-11 last season, held out in spring training. He started the season 4-0 and then fell to 5-7 as he battled a sore ankle and his emotions. He is now 15-9 with 28Y straight scoreless innings. In another piece of good news for the Brewers, Jim Gantner, the second baseman, was activated yesterday from the disabled list, where he was placed July 30 with a hamstring injury.

Kirby, 19 years old, had been arrested a day before the accident on a disorderly conduct charge, the trooper said. Mr. Kirby died along with eight passengers of the motor home, which was returning from a University of South Carolina football game at Columbia.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Football Michigan State 27, Southern Cal 13: Michigan State ended Southern Cal's 13-year mastery of Big Ten teams. It was the first night game ever at Spartan Stadium, in East Lansing. Lorenzo White, the Spartans' star tailback, rushed for 111 yards and scored two touchdowns. Southern Cal had won 17 straight against Big Ten teams since a 42-21 loss to Ohio State in the 1974 Rose Bowl. (AP) Golf Jones Beats Lopez: Rosie Jones sank a seven-foot birdie on the 18th hole to beat Nancy Lopez by a shot in the Rail Charity Golf Classic, in Springfield, Ill. It was Jones's first Ladies Professional Golf Association victory. Lopez missed an eight-foot birdie on the final hole, then Jones made hers for a two-under-par 70 and a 54-hole total of 208. (AP) Horse Racing Afleet Wins: Afleet, the best 3-year-old in Canada, ran the fastest mile of the year in New York while posting a 3 1/2-length victory over Stacked Pack in the $179,400 Jerome Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park. The 3-year-old son of Mr. Prospector, making his United States debut after winning four of six starts in Toronto, moved to the lead leaving the backstretch and motored home in 1:33 4/5 under Gary Stahlbaum. title: Delay on Sileo
description: The National Football League yesterday put on hold the status of Dan Sileo, the former defensive tackle from the University of Miami, while it determines whether he must go through a supplemental draft. Sileo signed with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers Sunday after the National Collegiate Athletic Association ruled Friday night that his eligibility had run out. Joe Browne, a spokesman for the league, said yesterday that Sileo wouldn't be allowed to play or practice with Tampa Bay ''subject to a review of his contract by our office.'' Joe Martinez, Sileo's lawyer, has said that Sileo did not enter the regular draft last spring because he didn't know he would be eligible for the N.F.L. and that now he is legitimately a free agent. Under N.F.L. rules, a player declared ineligible for further college play is usually required to go through a supplemental draft, in which all 28 teams are given a chance at selecting him. If he is not chosen by any team, he then becomes a free agent and can sign with anyone he likes.

Speaking after the Cubs' 3-2 loss to Pittsburgh in Chicago, Michael said in a radio interview: ''Up until a week ago, I had not made up my mind. But I have now decided I do not want to come back.'' He added: ''I have to qualify my remarks because after I made up my mind, nobody asked me whether I wanted to come back or not.'' It wasn't clear what Michael meant by ''qualify my remarks.'' Michael was named manager of the Cubs in June 1986 when Jim Frey was dismissed. The Cubs finished fifth in the National League East last season and are in fifth place this year. Dallas Green, the general manager, had no immediate comment on Michael's remarks.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Hockey Soviet Union Beats Sweden: Vladimir Krutov scored a goal and assisted on two others last night in Hamilton, Ontario, to lead the Soviet Union to a 4-2 victory over Sweden and a berth in the final of the Canada Cup tournament. Viacheslav Bykov, Igor Larionov and Sergei Makarov also scored for the Russians. On Friday in Montreal, the Soviet Union will play the winner of tonight's semifinal between Canada and Czechoslovakia. Jonas Bergqvist and Peter Andersson scored Sweden's goals. The Soviets led 1-0 after the first period on the strength of a power-play goal by Krutov and the outstanding goaltending of Sergei Mylnikov, who was back in the nets after being replaced by Evgeny Belosheikin in a 3-3 tie with Canada. (AP) Track and Field Lewis and Johnson Win: In separate 100-meter races, Carl Lewis had a better time than the world champion Ben Johnson, 10.05 seconds to 10.35, yesterday in Rieti, Italy. Johnson refused to race with Lewis, saying he was too tired and did not want tough competition. Lewis said he was disappointed at Johnson's decision. In the world championships in Rome last week, Johnson set a world record of 9.83 in beating Lewis. Said Aouita of Morocco won the 1,500-meters in 3 minutes 32.71 seconds, three seconds off his world record. The disappointment of the meet was the pole vaulter Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union. The world champion and world-record holder failed to clear in his three starting attempts at 18 feet 4 1/2 inches and was eliminated. Earl Bell of the United States was the winner at 18-8 1/4. (AP)

Syndicators, of course, hope to market these as ''cult classics'' but many of them are merely campy curios. Consider ''Dark Shadows,'' the ''gothic'' afternoon soap opera that made its debut on ABC in 1966. Adding vampires and witches, it became popular in 1967 with youngsters getting home from school, and then sputtered out in 1971. title: Q&A
description: Q. The poured concrete wall in my basement developed a couple of vertical cracks less than an eighth of an inch wide and several feet long. They seemed to get no worse, but water leaked in after a heavy rain so I filled them with patching cement. However, after a few months the cement seems to be cracking or falling out. What did I do wrong? A. You probably did not fill the cracks properly. You should first cut the cracks to make them a bit wider inside than on the surface; this insures a better bond between the old and new cement. Wet the crack and pack in the new cement with a trowel. A hydraulic patching cement is better than a conventional sand-mix patching cement; it expands in curing, making it more resistant to water pressure. Q. Our 1919 house has had a problem for 25 years: the wallpaper in the second-floor study is stained by water whenever it rains. The study is not on an outside wall, but a wall backed by a chimney. Contractors have redone the flashing around the chimney, topped the chimney with a cap and rebuilt the chimney from the roof up. Nothing has worked. Have you any suggestions? A. Water is obviously entering through the chimney, so I suspect that one of the measures was done incorrectly. The most common culprit in such leaks is defective flashing around the chimney; it would probably pay to have another contractor check it. The flashing must go into the joint between the first or second course of bricks and must extend well below the roofing material. Have the chimney cap rechecked for cracks in the cement; patch any that are found. Q. My three-year-old town house has white cement steps in front. The metal railings have rusted, leaving a trail on the cement. How can I remove this rust and prevent it from returning? A. Removing the rust completely is almost impossible, but you can lighten the stains with a commercial rust remover sold in hardware stores. Apply liberally several times. Persistent stains can be lightened still more by bleaching with oxalic acid, also sold in hardware stores. To prevent a recurrence, clean and paint the railings. Remove all loose rust, and coat with a rust converter or a rust-inhibiting metal primer. Be sure to coat all sides and edges. Then paint with a rust-resistant outside enamel. Q. A long cabinet with a matte lacquer finish was built under the living-room windows. Whenever I leave the windows open I get a fine soot on top of the cabinet. The soot often leaves streaks when I wipe it off, and I have to use a damp cloth to wipe the streaks off. I'm afraid this will scratch the fine finish. Can I put a coat of wax on the finish to protect it? A. Yes you can - and you should.

(AP) Horse Racing Same Ending: Five weeks ago, it took 10 minutes for a photo-finish camera to determine that Easy n Dirty had beaten Tinchen's Prince by a nose in the Evan Shipman Stakes, at a mile and a sixteenth, for New York-breds at Belmont Park. Yesterday, it took seven minutes to determine an identical result in the Hudson Handicap at the same track and distance. Easy n Dirty, who rallied on the inside to win the Evan Shipman, rallied on the outside yesterday to win over Tinchen's Prince, who led one step before the wire. Easy n Dirty, a 4-year-old colt, ran the distance in 1:42 under Robbie Davis and paid $10.40 for $2 to win. Easy n Dirty completed a Pick-Six sequence that returned $273,794 to one bettor at an OTB shop in the Albany area.

title: A Roadside Beauty Finds a Good Home
description: ITS common names include boneset, thoroughwort, mistflower and hardy ageratum, but it's not really an ageratum. Instead, it's a Eupatorium coelestinum, a perennial native to the eastern United States.

title: U.S. Open: McNeil Upsets Evert; Lendl Tops McEnroe in 3 Sets; Connors Defeats Gilbert
description: There was an air of expectation, the kind of excitement that usually precedes a Grand Slam final, especially when two adversaries meet. This would be John McEnroe's chance to reassert himself against the best player in the world, showing he still has the game to back up the often heated words.

title: Catholics, in Poll, Admire Pope but Disagree
description: Most of America's Roman Catholics hold a favorable view of Pope John Paul II, although even larger majorities of them disagree with him on birth control, ordaining women as priests, divorce and several other widely debated issues, The New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: Over Easy: Slipcovers for Side Chairs
description: SLIPCOVERS have always been a quick and easy solution for camouflaging furniture that needs updating. Usually, however, slipcovers have been reserved for upholstered pieces: a shabby camel-back sofa, or a club chair that has seen better times. But recently the basic side chair - particularly in hard metal or wood - has been getting snappy new treatments.

title: An Italian Factory Turns Terra Cotta Into an Art Form
description: LEAD: ON the narrow stretch of highway that winds down a rugged hillside to this seaside town, the shimmering sea-green cupola of the church of San Giovanni Battista draws one's attention through the bends and curves of the road.

description: A man who spent 10 years on death row was executed early today for murdering a probation officer.

description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would head a private group of New Yorkers that would spend a week in Nicaragua in November monitoring the country's progress under the Central American peace plan.

description: The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, under the direction of Zubin Mehta, will perform in Poland and Hungary in November, its first appearances in Eastern-bloc countries since all but one of them severed relations with Israel in the 1967 Middle East war, an orchestra spokeswoman said today.

title: Iraq Declines to Accept Full Cease-Fire
description: Iraq has declined to accept a full cease-fire as demanded by the Security Council while Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is in the Persian Gulf region on a peace mission, senior United Nations officials said today.

title: L.I. Report Urges Jail in Father's Slaying
description: Cheryl Pierson should be sentenced to jail for hiring a high-school classmate to kill her father, according to a Suffolk County Probation Department report, her attorney revealed today.

title: TOSHIBA DETAILS TRAIL OF CRIME IN SALE OF MACHINERY TO SOVIET
description: In a rare look at the inner workings of Japanese corporate crime, the Toshiba Corporation explained in detail today how a subsidiary had signed secret agreements with Moscow, twice duped Japanese authorities, silenced its employees when they complained of illegalities and burned documents once investigators were on its trail.

title: Politicians and Privacy
description: Gary Hart keeps missing the point. Under Ted Koppel's sharp questioning on ABC Tuesday night, he insisted anew that the point was privacy. No, he said, he had not been absolutely and totally faithful to his wife. But having said so, he exhorted the national press corps: ''Never ask another candidate that question,'' because it's no one else's business, and questions like that drive good candidates out of politics.

description: ANSWERED PRAYERS: The Unfinished Novel. By Truman Capote. 180 pages.

title: Nominee for Trade Post
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Alan F. Holmer to be a deputy United States trade representative with the rank of ambassador. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Holmer, 38 years old, would succeed M. Alan Woods. Since 1985, Mr. Holmer has been general counsel in the Office of the United States Trade Representative.

title: Mortgage Banker to Go to Prison In Teen-Ager's Hit-and-Run Death
description: A 26-year-old mortgage banker who was convicted of the hit-and-run death of a Manhattan high school student last year was given the maximum prison sentence yesterday after a judge said the victim's family and society as a whole demanded ''just retribution.''

title: Cabaret: Marilyn Sokol
description: FEW performers radiate more zany mischief per square centimeter than the actress and singer Marilyn Sokol. An entertainer with a deep streak of old-time vaudevillian merriment, Ms. Sokol belongs in a lineage that runs from Sophie Tucker to Bette Midler.

title: KOCH MOVES ON LANDLORDS OVER REPAIRS
description: In what Mayor Koch yesterday called a novel attack on speculators who ''cynically purchase buildings with no intention of maintaining them,'' the city has asked a court to allow it to make repairs on 15 Harlem apartment buildings and to force the landlord and his business associates to pay the bill.

title: A High-Rise Is Not a Home For Children, the Experts Say
description: LIFE for Mary and her 3-year-old son in their high-rise apartment was like living in a prison. ''He was like a confined animal in the apartment,'' she recalled. ''He broke every appliance we had; he tore the wallpaper from the walls of his room. He would run out into the hall and it would take me a half-hour to coax him back in.''

title: Breaching the Wall at Krasnoyarsk
description: When Richard Nixon made his historic visit to China in 1972, his hosts took him to inspect the Great Wall. The President was said to have remarked, ''This is a great wall.'' The U.S. representatives who returned this week from the large Soviet radar at Krasnoyarsk also made a historic visit, to a controversial Soviet installation that the Administration says violates the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972. Their visit also confirms the obvious: the radar is still where it shouldn't be, and will violate a solemn treaty if it becomes operational.

title: European Airlines Busy
description: European airlines' passenger traffic rose 15 percent in July from a year earlier, aided by a strong 23 percent North Atlantic increase plus growth in Asia and Europe, the 21-member Association of European Airlines said today.

description: William Dean Singleton, a Texas-based newspaper entrepreneur whose rapidly expanding holdings include The Dallas Times Herald, announced yesterday that he would add The Houston Post to his chain of 27 dailies.

description: JAMES MADISON: The Founding Father.

description: A man who shot his pleading burglary victim to death, then spared the slain man's wife and daughter because he killed only ''dopers and pigs,'' was executed by the state early today.

Ivanhoe has already begun a $95-a-share partial tender offer for 28 million Newmont shares.

title: Dakota Staton
description: Dakota Staton, a singer, will perform tonight and tomorrow at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum. Tonight's first set will be broadcast by WKCR, 89.9 FM.

title: Winning Started at Home for McNeil
description: When Dorothy McNeil needed a respite from raising four children, she sought refuge on the tennis courts near her home in San Diego. She often brought along her youngest, a daughter. It wasn't a burden and it turned out to be an arrangment that was beneficial to both parties.

title: N.J. Woman Killed in Britain
description: An American woman who was one of four people killed Wednesday in an accident involving a bus full of United States tourists between London and its main airport was identified by the police today as Sandra Bailowitz, 48 years old, of Fort Lee, N.J. She was traveling in the tour bus when another bus, a beer truck and four cars piled up on the highway to Heathrow Airport.

title: BENNETT ROSE
description: Bennett Rose, a real-estate developer and a veteran of the Jewish Legion in Palestine during World War I, died of cancer Tuesday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: THE Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's pledge Wednesday of nearly $1 billion to help recapitalize the troubled First City Bancorporation of Texas dramatized not only past blunders of Texas banks, but the certainty of more trouble ahead, analysts said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday, about the week's debt financings, carried an incorrect description supplied by a rating service for an offering by the Old National Bancorp. The securities have not been assigned a rating.

title: Peter Fingesten, Artist And Professor, Is Dead
description: Peter Fingesten, a Surrealist artist who founded the art department at Pace University in New York City, died of pancreatic cancer Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Edberg Sweeps Into Semifinals
description: He is short and stocky, hardly imposing-looking with a boyish face, quiet manner and a serve that could not put out a match. But Ramesh Krishnan of India has the kind of tennis game that can unnerve even the most mild-mannered opponent, inspiring courtside soliloquies and racquet tossing. He would be a good test for Stefan Edberg, a barometer of how much progress Edberg has made in the past 12 months.

title: FRIEND SOUGHT AID BEFORE L.I. SLAYING
description: A classmate of Cheryl Pierson - the teen-ager who hired a friend to kill her father because, she said, the father had sexually abused her - testified today that she had sought help for her friend from a school counselor but was told nothing could be done unless Miss Pierson came forward.

title: Oxford Journal; Mystery Disease Ravages Oysters And Way of Life
description: There was an audible gasp when the tongs filled with oysters broke the surface of the Chesapeake Bay and the dripping load was deposited with a clatter on the port-side culling board of the Miss Patrice. Most of the oysters were dead, their shells agape and clogged with mud.

title: Cris Carter Files Suit
description: Cris Carter, the all-America wide receiver declared ineligible by Ohio State and subsequently drafted by the Philadelphia Eagles, filed a suit yesterday against the agents, Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, in United States District Court in Columbus, Ohio. In the suit, Carter contends that Walters and Bloom, of World Sports & Entertainment Inc., induced him to accept a loan through ''fraud and unfair use'' of Carter's older brother, George. Cris Carter seeks the cancellation of his contract with Walters and Bloom and damages in excess of $1 million. Mitchell Frankel, Carter's attorney, said the contract with Walters and Bloom deprived Carter of a chance to finish his career at Ohio State and cost Carter ''a certain prospect of being a high first-round National Football League draft pick in 1988.'' . . . The University of Minnesota quarterback, Rickey Foggie, has been suspended for two games by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for accepting a loan for an airplane ticket from Larry Beckish, the assistant coach, in 1985.

title: Farming in a Corporate Age
description: Sitting at the controls of a plane several thousand feet above the San Joaquin Valley, discussing strategic planning, cost centers and the latest uses of technology on his family's vast farm below, Scott Salyer paints a portrait of an agricultural company at the vanguard of sophisticated management.

description: New York is a city in constant transformation, and a summertime can bring a host of changes big and small. Sculptures are installed in various and unexpected places, old clubs have moved and new ones opened up, venturesome performing spaces have been created, and familiar landmarks have received glossy refurbishings. description: Two months before this city's municipal elections, the question asked most often here is not whether Biagio (Ben) DiLieto will win a fifth term as Mayor, but by how large a landslide.

title: Macmillan May Bid For Bell & Howell
description: Macmillan Inc., a leading publishing company, disclosed yesterday that it had bought the equivalent of a 6.6 percent stake in the Bell & Howell Company and said it might seek control of the concern, which is based in Skokie, Ill. title: Snakes Bite Two Worshipers
description: Two men were bitten by rattlesnakes during a snake-handling church service here last weekend but were reported recovering and in satisfactory condition at a hospital today. The incident occurred at the High Way Holiness Church of God, whose pastor, the Rev. Arnold Saylor, said the men would not have been harmed if they had used the ''power of God'' to control the timber rattlers.

title: SUMMER JOBS PROGRAM A SUCCESS IN NEW YORK
description: Summer job seekers, benefiting from a robust regional economy and a shrinking population of teen-age workers, found more opportunities this year in the New York region than at any time in memory, economists and business executives said yesterday.

title: Afghan Talks End Without Major Gain
description: A new round of negotiations on the seven-year-old Afghan conflict ended today without producing the major concessions from the Soviet-backed Afghan Government that had been widely anticipated, a senior Pakistani official said.

title: Tudor Provides Unexpected Dividends
description: A New England summertime was on its way, and John Tudor of the St. Louis Cardinals was suddenly a warm-weather resident of Peabody, Mass. There cannot be very many displeased New Englanders when winter coats can be placed in storage and the National Basketball Association playoffs are the only remaining evidence of the winter that was left behind.

title: MENTALLY ILL POORLY SUPERVISED, EXPERTS SAY
description: Each year hundreds and perhaps thousands of mentally ill patients slip though a wide range of state facilities and treatment programs and join the ranks of the homeless on New York City's streets because of poor supervision, mental health experts say.

title: U.S. and Soviet Protest to Libya Over Iran Mines
description: The United States and the Soviet Union sent separate messages of concern to Libya several days ago in an effort to stop the Libyans from sending Soviet-made mines to Iran, Administration officials said today.

description: President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina, responding to his party's defeat in midterm elections last Sunday, has announced plans for a new diplomatic offensive aimed at reducing the social and economic burdens of servicing the country's $53 billion foreign debt.

description: A panel of 20 experts in health, law and ethics have developed a comprehensive set of guidelines for deciding when to forgo or halt life-sustaining treatment of dying patients.

title: Mexico Oil Price Down
description: Mexico, the world's fourth-largest oil producer, trimmed the average price of its light crude by more than $2 a barrel to American customers last month, the Government oil monopoly said. Petroleos Mexicanos, in a statement carried Wednesday by the Government press agency Notimex, said the average price of its light Isthmus brand was $17.94 a barrel in August for the United States. In July, the average price to the American market was $20.23 a barrel, up from $19.18 a barrel in June.

title: A Better Way Than Star Wars
description: Now some major critics of President Reagan's Star Wars program have come up with a proposal of their own for strategic defense research. It makes sense, and bolsters their claim that they aren't just opposed to S.D.I. because it's a Reagan obsession, or because they love the bomb, but for scientific, technical and budgetary reasons.

description: President Corazon C. Aquino asked the country today to ''bear with us if we failed in some aspects,'' but she gave no indication of her plans a day after the mass resignation of her Cabinet.

description: The trial of John A. Zaccaro, which was to begin in Queens Supreme Court Monday, was adjourned yesterday until Sept. 28, until a key prosecution witnesses is available.

title: 'Bluffing It,' on Illiteracy
description: ILLITERACY is the subject of ''Bluffing It,'' another of those social-issue movies that have become the special province of television. It's not the first made-for-television movie to deal with the subject. Johnny Cash, the country singer, starred in a similar project several years ago. And despite predictably upbeat endings, it remains to be seen whether such presentations contribute much to solving the problem. But the effort is surely worthwhile. While estimates of the number of functionally illiterate people in this country vary widely, the total is substantial; the movie gives the figure 20 million.

title: Guerrero Injured In Speedway Test
description: Roberto Guerrero of Colombia was in very critical condition today after hitting the wall at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway during tire tests.

title: Film: Tennessee 'Curse'
description: ON a thundery night in Tellico Plains, Tenn., the sex-hungry wife (Kathleen Jordan Gregory) of a Bible-quoting farmer (Claude Akins) finds what she needs in the arms of a hairy-chested handyman. Before you can say, ''Abstain from fleshly lusts,'' a flaming ball or egg or something falls to earth, contaminates the water, rots fruit, spoils people's complexions and turns chickens and humans homicidal. That, in an eggshell, is ''The Curse,'' the week's entry in the suppuration stakes. Wil Wheaton and Amy Wheaton play a young brother and sister whom all the infected people, livestock and vegetables are out to get. David Keith directed from a screenplay by David Chaskin; they're asking for boils. If you need to see the worms, sores and nasty oozing glop for yourself, they're at the Criterion and other movie houses. Ooze and Glop THE CURSE, directed by David Keith; written by David Chaskin; director of photography, Robert D. Forges; edited by Claude Kutry; music by John Debney; production designer, Frank Vanorio; produced by Ovidio G. Assonitis; released by Trans World Entertainment. At Criterion, Broadway and 45th Street; Orpheum, Third Avenue at 86th Street; Movie Center Five, 125th Street, between Powell and Douglass Boulevards; Essex, Grand Street, off Essex Street; Nova, Broadway and 147th Street. Running time: 100 minutes. This film is rated R. Zachary... Wil Wheaton; Nathan Hayes... Claude Akins; Frances... Kathleen Jordan Gregory; Mike... Steve Davis; Alice... Amy Wheaton; Cyrus... Malcolm Danare; Dr. Alan Forbes... Cooper Huckabee; Carl Willis... John Schneider.

title: Tracking the Food Trends: They're Italian and Tropical
description: NEW YORK sizzled in more ways than one during this tropical summer. The restaurant industry, which ususally cools off to a dog-days torpor, raced full-throttle ahead, with more than 30 noteworthy openings (offset by about a dozen major closings). This is not to say that the business is booming; on the contrary, times are relatively tough, according to restaurateurs and industry observers who point to a saturated marketplace, ballooning rents and growing price resistance among diners.

title: Chiles Fine Reported
description: Eddie Chiles, the owner of the Texas Rangers, has been fined $250,000 by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth, over his calling up of Steve Howe, according to a report in today's Dallas Morning News. Chiles, however, said earlier in the day at the major league baseball meetings in Toronto that he was not fined and was ''not going to speculate'' on whether a fine was forthcoming. Howe, who was making a pitching comeback after a series of drug-related problems, was signed by Texas to a minor league contract July 12 and was called up by the Rangers Aug. 6. Ueberroth, who has unilateral power to levy the fine, asked clubs this year to have players returning from drug rehabilitation remain in the minor leagues for 60 to 90 days to make sure they have their problem under control before elevating them on a major league team. A spokesman for Ueberroth said thaat even if a fine had been levied, it would not be announced. The fine would be the second largest ordered by a baseball commissioner. George Steinbrenner was fined $250,000 plus $50,000 to reimburse the legal fees of the office of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn in December, 1983 over the ''pine tar'' decision.

''With a twist here, we could have a very good season. But a twist there, a poor season - eight and three or three and eight.''

title: Film: 'Prayer for The Dying'
description: THE things that attract attention in ''A Prayer for the Dying'' are not the things that should. How could a thriller starring Mickey Rourke, Alan Bates and Bob Hoskins so distract its audience with accents, costumes and hairdos that effectively upstage the cast? The most striking aspects of Mr. Rourke's performance (as a reluctant Irish Republican Army terrorist) are the reddish hue of his hair and the harsh brogue, so different from his normally buttery voice that it almost sounds dubbed. Meanwhile, Mr. Hoskins looks equally out of place in a cleric's robes. And Mr. Bates, as a sleek, ruthless gangster, sports hair that grows thicker and darker with each passing year.

title: Art: The Landscapes Of Ralph A. Blakelock
description: ALONG with the art of Albert Pinkham Ryder, that of Ralph A. Blakelock is one of the great treasures and great mysteries of the American 19th century. Largely self-taught, and unaided by a European tour, Blakelock made a substantial and highly personal contribution to the evolution of landscape painting. His best work, done in the last two decades of the 19th century, is conservative when compared to that of van Gogh or Cezanne. Blakelock is more credible when seen as an eccentric, belated offshoot of the Hudson River or Barbizon Schools. Still, in looking at the 46 canvases on view at the Salander-O'Reilly Galleries, it is possible to grasp that, for his time and place, Blakelock was something of a radical artist in terms of both subject matter and painting surface. With their flattened, subtly psychologized surfaces, the woodland scenes and the images of dark trees silhouetted against moonlit skies for which he is best known can strike us as incipiently modern, a peculiar blend of Impressionism and Symbolism.

title: Hampton Still Swings At Age 78
description: THE phone was ringing in Lionel Hampton's spacious midtown apartment for perhaps the 10th time in an hour. Mr. Hampton, who admits to being 78 years old and recently returned from leading his big band through a grueling bus tour of Europe, bounded up from the couch, as he had for every other phone call. ''I can't keep up with him,'' complained an associate. ''He'll take a cat nap, get up, and call me at 3 A.M.: 'Hey, it's Gates! What's happening?' ''

title: Honors for Carner
description: JoAnne Carner, a three-time Ladies Professional Golf Association Player of the Year, and six others have been named to the Women's Sports Hall of Fame. Also named were Louise Suggs, golf; Debbie Meyer-Reyes, swimming; Madeline Manning Mims, track; Lyudmila Tourischeva of the Soviet Union, gymnast; Maureen Connolly Brinker, tennis, and Marie Marvingt of France, a multiple-sports athlete. They will be officially inducted into the Hall of Fame at the Women's Sports Foundation dinner Sept. 21 in New York. Connolly and Marvingt are deceased.

title: Bethlehem Order
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said its freight car division had received an order from the Norfolk Southern Corporation for 500 covered hopper railroad cars, used for the shipment of cement. The division said it was the largest single order received since it was formed in August 1983. Each steel hopper car would hold 3,000 cubic feet. Bethlehem said shipment would begin in the fourth quarter. The company's stock price jumped $1.375 today, to $17.75 a share, after the deal was announced.

title: No More Thrillers in Manila
description: Last month's coup attempt against the Philippine President, Corazon Aquino, did not succeed. Another one might, however, and there is only one way to head that off: Mrs. Aquino has to reinvigorate her Government. Meanwhile, wavering army commanders have to understand that their battle against Communist rebels requires a popular civilian government. And Washington needs to send the unremitting message that a successful coup would mean the end of American military aid. Democracy in the Philippines will sink or swim with the Aquino Government.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Valerie Wellington, at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Valerie Wellington started out singing soul music. Then she studied opera. And then, living in Chicago, she discovered the blues of Bessie Smith, Ma Rainey and Helen Humes, and she started sitting in with the blues bands that hold forth regularly on Chicago's South and North Sides. With her lung power and her taste for feisty, no-nonsense songs, she quickly gained a reputation as one of Chicago's best young blues singers, a reputation that's starting to extend to New York City. She'll bring a band of Chicago musicians to Tramps tonight and tomorrow. Sets are at 9:30 and midnight; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum. Hugo Largo, the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Using two electric basses, a violin and the clear voice of Mimi Goese - nothing more - Hugo Largo's music floats on the far fringe of rock. The songs are deep-toned and unhurried, like something absent-mindedly hummed by a sleeping giant; on stage, Ms. Goese could be dreaming with open eyes, singing words and sounds with bemused grace. Its sustained, sonorous calm is just about the last thing anyone would expect from a New York band. Jo Andres, a dancer, will perform with the band tonight at 9 and 11; admission is $6. New Music at Summerstage, Central Park Band Shell, 72d Street in mid-park (860-1335). New York new music tunes in the world, almost literally, at this weekend's three Summerstage concerts. Tonight at 8, there's a performance event directed by Travis Preston that will include 50 teen-agers carrying radios and a 50-member speaking chorus; sharing a double bill is an ensemble led by Butch Morris, a composer and cornetist whose ''conductions,'' or conducted improvisations, are full of melody and wit. Tomorrow at 3 P.M., the A. Leroy Invitation will present new pieces for eight winds and six percussion, a lineup Mr. Leroy calls a ''stationary marching band.'' Mr. Leroy and the other composers -Scott Johnson, Lenny Pickett, Steve Elson, Peter Zummo and Bill Obrecht - have their fingers in rock, jazz and classical music; they know James Brown is an arch-minimalist and Steve Reich can get funky, and their pieces often strut along like dancers with big ideas. On Sunday at 3 P.M., Glen Velez will lead a quartet that includes Steve Gorn on Indian flute, Larry Karush on keyboards and Layne Redmond on vocals. Mr. Velez is a virtuoso on frame drums, the far-flung relatives of the tambourine; last year, he made a brilliant, austere, mostly solo album, ''Internal Combustion'' (CMP Records), that showed just how many sounds and rhythms can be made with fingers on stretched skin. All three concerts are free. Rock Album of the Week: The dB's: ''The Sound of Music'' (I.R.S./ M.C.A.). Sometimes - actually, most of the time - love gets more complicated than the scenarios proffered by typical pop songs. So adults who love the pop-song form have to decide whether to keep things simple or to bend the rules. The dB's, a long-running New York band that has just released its fourth album, decided to tell realistic love stories, conflicts and all - but still keep things catchy. On ''The Sound of Music,'' Peter Holsapple's songs sketch love affairs that are fraying at the edges: ''She was on her way out of town and she wanted to know if I'd gone insane/Well I might but I doubt if it changes things,'' the band sings in ''Molly Says.'' All that contains the strife and yearning are melodies with the twang of Buddy Holly, the pop sense of vintage Tommy James and the Shondells, and the urgency of Elvis Costello. The dB's pull no punches, but the songs are designed to set toes tapping.

title: Marine Cleared on Main Charges
description: A Marine Corps jury tonight found Staff Sgt. Robert S. Stufflebeam guilty of two counts of dereliction of duty for contacts with prostitutes in Moscow while he was an American embassy security guard there.

title: Marist Is On Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association put Marist College on probation for two years today and barred the school from postseason basketball play during 1988 and 1989. An assistant coach, who was not named, was banned from off-campus recruiting for two years, effective Feb. 1, 1987.

title: Film: 'He's My Girl,' A Comedy
description: T.K. CARTER has nice legs, which is a lucky thing because they come in handy for his starring role in ''He's My Girl.'' Mr. Carter plays Reggie, the best friend and would-be manager of an aspiring singer named Bryan (David Hallyday). Reggie enters Bryan's name in a contest being held by an MTV-like video station and they win, but there's a catch - Bryan must be accompanied on his free trip to Hollywood by a female date. Bingo! Arriving at the airport in Los Angeles are smallish blond Bryan and Regina, the towering, outspoken black woman who is Reggie's new alter ego. This is hardly the small-town Missouri couple that the video station had in mind.

title: Art: Jan Dibbets Show At the Guggenheim
description: JAN DIBBETS is a Dutch artist, now 48 years old, who first came to international notice in 1971. The pictures that he made were not quite like anyone else's. Sliced, as much as painted, and minutely calculated, they were based on sequential perception. Dumb objects were set free to talk and sing when Mr. Dibbets charted their shadows from hour to hour. The Dutch landscape, paradigmatic in its flatness, was persuaded to get up on its hind legs. Sea and land were caught wearing one another's hats.

title: It's Apple-Picking Time
description: It's apple-picking time once again, with scores of orchards in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut open for those who want to pick their own fruit.

title: 'I've Heard The Mermaids Singing'
description: IN its opening scenes, Patricia Rozema's ''I've Heard the Mermaids Singing'' displays a certain amount of engaging whimsy. Polly Vandersma places herself in front of a home-video camera to tell us her story. Polly is 31 years old, a self-described ''person Friday'' who's been called ''organizationally impaired'' by the agency that finds her employment as a ''temp.'' Polly can't type. Her mind wanders. Polly is the sort of young woman whose heart leaps up when she beholds diners through a restaurant window ''talking, laughing and interfacing.'' Sitting in a Japanese restaurant, before a table that's footstool-high, she doesn't know where to put her legs. Polly is innocent beyond belief. Yet she's so slyly and self-mockingly played by Sheila McCarthy, a very good new Canadian actress, that belief is willingly suspended. For about 40 minutes.
