title: Dining Out Guide; Large Groups and Parties
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CHEZ LOUIS, 1016 Second Avenue, near 53d Street (752-1400) - **(Feb. 13, 1987) This simply appointed, comfortable bistro has French posters on the walls and a large glass wall in back overlooking a cluster of trees, and larger groups of 8 to 10 are welcome. Portions are for big eaters, and you might be wise to go lightly on appetizers: roasted wild mushrooms and garlic cloves or endive and watercress salad with walnuts and Roquefort. The kitchen specializes in roasting, and the results can be wonderful - from the herb-flecked whole chicken for two to the roast baby lamb. Other good main-dish options are grilled giant shrimp with beurre blanc and grilled fresh tuna, depending upon availability, as well as a club dish for those watching their weight: boneless breast of chicken with roasted garlic sauce, or sole with fresh tomato basil sauce. Dinner entrees $13.95 to $28.95. Fridays, 11:45 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 6 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays, 6 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 5 to 10 P.M. DEVON HOUSE, 1316 Madison Avenue, at 93d Street (860-8294) - **(May 24, 1985) An understated restaurant with two small and graceful dining rooms, Devon House can accommodate groups of up to 56. The food is essentially Continental with a dash of West Indian salsa. First-course selections include escargot, without shells, in a satiny garlic-tinged cream sauce with bits of tomatoes and scallions; mushrooms on toast with fine herbs, and sweetbreads with Madeira. Main-dish options are fresh salmon braised in fresh lime, white wine and Jamaican peppers; roast Cornish hen with a sauce of pineapple, green peppercorns, lime and Grand Marnier, and filet of beef in a Pickapepper sauce (a condiment bottled in Jamaica) with green peppercorns. Entrees $24.50 to $29.50. Fridays through Sundays, 6 to 11 P.M. MITSUKOSHI, 461 Park Avenue, at 57th Street (935-6444) - ***(March 8, 1985) Below the porcelain and pottery shop of the same name is this polished Japanese restaurant with sushi bar, main dining room and private tatami rooms - Westernized with a sunken well under the table to dangle your feet below - where groups of up to 18 people can be accommodated. The seafood, both raw and cooked, is of the highest quality. The sushi and sashimi are recommended; and other options are light and brittle tempura of vegetables, shrimp and whitefish in tangy ginger dipping sauce; grilled fish of the day, usually red snapper or salmon, perfectly charred and moist, and shabu shabu, a caldron of simmering broth in which diners cook their own food, including lean beef, Chinese cabbage, mushrooms, scallions, carrots and rice cabbage. Complete dinners $22 to $75. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 2 P.M. and 6 to 10 P.M.; closed Sundays, PALIO, 151 West 51st Street (245-4850) - **(May 2, 1986) From the awe-inspiring wraparound bar and wall mural on the first floor to the plush, high-ceilinged dining room, spacious and comfortable, this stylish Italian restaurant is a knockout. Private rooms are available for dinner parties of up to 14, 25 and 40 people. A multipage menu offers hot and cold appetizers, soups, pastas, meat and seafood entrees and desserts. Among the recommended dishes are carpaccio with vinegar and foie gras; fresh mussels in saffron broth; fettuccine in Bolognese sauce and gnocchi with garlic-infused morsels of frogs legs; rolled salmon fillets with a sauce of black olives, spinach and pink peppercorns, and poached breast of capon stuffed with prosciutto over a green sauce. Pre-theater dinner $35; dinner entrees $26 to $32.50. Fridays, 11:30 A.M. to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 4:30 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. ''21'' CLUB, 21 West 52d Street (582-7200) - **(June 19, 1987) In addition to the clubby and comfortable formal upstairs dining room and the famous wood-paneled barroom downstairs, this legendary restaurant offers a number of private dining rooms for parties. The recent refurbishing has made the patrician town house more beguiling than ever: The food is vastly improved and service is holding up reasonably well. Starter selections are foie-gras terrine flecked with black truffles, and marinated sea scallops over mixed greens. Among the entrees are red snapper fillet atop risotto; Black Angus steak in hot mustard crust, and roasted monkfish with beef marrow in light red wine fume with spinach. Dinner entrees $23 to $36. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 6 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. UNION SQUARE CAFE, 21 East 16th Street (243-4020) - **(Jan. 24, 1986) One of the most appealing restaurants in the area is this low-key cafe with a long, handsome bar up front and a cozy room in back with double height ceiling and murals on the walls. Private rooms are available for groups of up to 22, 45 and 75. The food is eclectic and straddles the border between France and Italy. First-course choices are black-bean soup with lemon and Australian cherries; papardelle of zucchini with tomato, shallots, white wine and cream sauce, and deep-fried calamari with graham-cracker crumbs and anchovy mayonnaise. For a main dish, you might have grilled fillet of tuna; broiled swordfish with citrus and green peppercorn sauce, or grilled loin lamb chops with basil mint butter sauce and red-pepper custard. Dinner entrees $14 to $21. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 11:45 P.M.; closed Sundays. What the stars mean, page C2O.

title: Restaurants
description: MY experiences in most health-club restaurants lead me to suspect that their chefs are quietly in cahoots with the asparagus-thin aerobics instructors, whose job it is to inflict pain and help patrons shed weight. It was with such limited expectations that I first jogged over to the new dining spot called Manhattan Island on the third floor of the Manhattan Plaza Health Club on West 43d Street, a short walk from both Broadway and Off Broadway theaters.

title: Crawling With Corruption
description: Corruption remains so familiar a fact of the construction industry in New York and other cities that it's easy to snicker at yet another official report detailing mob influence: dog bites man. Yet the more pervasive the evil, the greater the need to denounce it with force. The state's Organized Crime Task Force deserves credit for doing so, and making clear that effective remedies involve much more than law enforcement.

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Charlie Haden's Liberation Music Orchestra, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street (662-2133). Billed as a 20th-anniversary celebration of the Liberation Music Orchestra, this concert isn't likely to confine itself to the band's original arrangements of Spanish Civil War songs and musical evocations of 60's political turbulence. There is new music, including compositions from Nicaragua and Cuba. Charlie Haden, the orchestra's bassist and leader, has assembled an impressive mixture of original players - Dewey Redman, Paul Motian - and some of the New York scene's outstanding younger musicians, including Geri Allen, Craig Harris and Herb Robertson. The concert is tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets are $10 and $15 at the cathedral or from Ticketmaster (307-7171). The Saheb Sarbib Unit, the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway (718-638-5000, extension 232). Like Charlie Haden, Jean (Saheb) Sarbib is a bass-playing bandleader who anchors his groups, and helps shape his soloists' improvisations, with a big sound, a firm beat and an agile imagination. He is playing Sunday at 3 P.M.; the concert is free with museum admission, which is $3 for adults, $1.50 for students and $1 for the elderly. Olu Dara, Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, between Ninth and 10th Streets (982-3260). Olu Dara's comprehensive trumpet style is a link between the New Orleans tradition, the blues and flash of the old-time Southern tent-show circuit, rhythm and blues, and new jazz. Why isn't this man making records? At least he can be enjoyed in person. He is playing through Sunday, beginning around 9:30 P.M., at this Caribbean restaurant and club. There is a $10 music charge and a $7 minimum. Jazz Album of the Week: ''Cool Struttin','' Sonny Clark (Blue Note LP and CD). Sonny Clark's definition of ''soul'' in jazz is worth pondering. ''Your soul is your conception,'' he said, ''and you begin to have it in your playing when the way you strike a note, the sound you get and your phrasing come out of you yourself and no one else.'' On ''Cool Struttin','' recorded in 1958 and recently reissued by Blue Note, Mr. Clark, a pianist, transformed elements that countless ''blowing session'' albums were reducing to formula - compatible musicians, lengthy solos on simple blues and pop-song structures, minimal unison themes - and came up with something enduring. Art Farmer's harmonic sophistication and concern for detail and structure on the trumpet provide the perfect foil for Jackie McLean's emotional urgency and deep blues feeling on saxophone. The pianist's own solos flow with a sparkling, liquid grace, and his tone is as indelible as Teddy Wilson's. Paul Chambers's bass and Philly Joe Jones's drums are brisk, interactive, always appropriate. The additional tunes on the compact disk include some of the session's most heated playing, and one of the most incendiary Art Farmer solos of all time. ''Cool Struttin' '' is a classic.

title: Owners Vote to Play On
description: National Football League owners voted today to continue the season even if there is a strike, using players who have been cut or ''whatever players are available.'' Jack Donlan, executive director of the N.F.L. Management Council, said, however, that the owners would continue to take whatever steps necessary to avoid a strike. Players have set a strike date after the completion of the Monday night game Sept. 21.

title: SUBWAY DOOR-CLOSING ACCIDENTS LEAD TO TRANSIT AUTHORITY STUDY
description: Hours after another rider was caught in the doors of a subway car, the head of the Transit Authority said yesterday that the agency had begun a study to determine whether the doors could be made safer.

title: Bankers Trust Offers $247.5 Million in Stock
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation began its $247.5 million common stock offering yesterday, the first of many bank stock offerings that are expected to come to the market soon.

title: N.B.A. Talks Resume
description: Representatives of the National Basketball Association and the players' union met in New York for two and a half hours yesterday for the first time since July in an effort come to terms on a new collective bargaining agreement. But according to Larry Fleisher, general counsel for the union, there was no progress on resolving the major issues: right of first refusal, free agency and the salary cap. ''We're no closer than we were eight months ago,'' Fleisher said. ''I have no idea whether we'll have another meeting before Oct. 1, when the moratorium ends.'' Russ Granik, executive vice president of the league, said, ''We're still far apart on the issues.''

title: Brooklyn Lyric Opera
description: The Brooklyn Lyric Opera will present Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. and Sunday at 3 at the Holy Name Auditorium, 95th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, in Manhattan. Tickets are $5. Information: (718) 837-1176.

title: Girl Dies in School Bus Crash
description: A teen-age girl was killed and five other people were hospitalized after a tractor-trailer plowed into the back of a school bus on a rural road in St. Lawrence County. Laurel Marlow, 15 years old, of Ogdensburg, was killed when she was preparing to get off the bus.

title: Lewis Continues Plea
description: Carl Lewis, the American track star, continued his campaign against drug use in sports by suggesting yesterday in Brussels that an independent company be hired to conduct drug testing on a worldwide basis for amateur sports. The company, he went on, should test not only for substances banned by the International Olympic Committee but also for drugs designed to mask the presence of banned substances. The company should also have the authority to release the names of athletes found to be using the drugs, without first submitting them, for example, to the International Amateur Athletic Federation, the world governing body of track and field. ''We need to take a stand,'' Lewis said in Belgium, where he will compete today in the Mobil Grand Prix finals. ''And Americans should clean up their act first.''

title: MEDICAL IMAGING CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DIAGNON CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,262,195 and $1,002,818 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Restaurant Associates Dispute
description: Restaurant Associates Ltd. of New York, stepping up hostilities against its unsolicited suitor, denied today that it had rejected a $19-a-share, or $109 million, buyout offer from Anwar S. Soliman, an Orange County, Calif., restaurateur. Martin Brody, chairman of Restaurant Associates, said unspecified legal steps might be taken against Mr. Soliman, who he said had misrepresented the company's actions.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Summerstage Finale

title: Completions Of Homes Rise
description: Completions of new homes rose 3.8 percent in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.652 million units, from 1.591 million in June, the Commerce Department said today.

title: NEW TWIST FOR 'CALL WAITING'
description: IT was born from the desire to add a new use to a single telephone line.

title: What New York City Calls Justice
description: LEAD: While corruption scandals have become so commomplace in New York City that we've forgotten how to live without them, I'm here to report that the system works. I stood up to the bureaucracy and it found me wanting.

title: From Soviet, New Chances To Visit West
description: In a waiting room at the American Embassy Thursday morning, Elena Tumaviciene leaned on her cane, a little disoriented by the throng around her but clutching firmly a valuable, once unobtainable document - a Soviet passport valid for foreign travel.

title: INSIDE
description: Mets Lose a Tough One The St.Louis cardinals, one out away from defeat, rallied and beat the Mets, 6-4, in 10 innings. The first-place Cardinals now lead the Mets by two and a half games. Page 51. Not a Heffalump in Sight In which the original Winnie-the-Pooh finds a permanent home on public view in New York. Page 35. History of Homelessness Mayor Koch's call to hospitalize the mentally ill homeless has roots in a 20-year-old policy debate. Page 29.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
GENE M. MARSHALL
description: Gene M. Marshall, one of the marines who helped raise the first American flag on Iwo Jima in World War II, died Tuesday night of burns he suffered in a fire at his home three weeks ago. He was 60 years old.

title: Report on AIDS Lab Case
description: The Federal Government announced today that faulty equipment appeared to have played a role in allowing the AIDS virus to infect a laboratory worker whose plight was disclosed last week.

title: Saudi Rejects Iran Oil View
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister said today that his country would not play swing producer, reducing its output to help bring OPEC's overproduction into balance.

title: Offer for Walbro
description: UIS Inc. said today that it was prepared to increase the $57 million unsolicited bid it made Wednesday for more than half of the oustanding shares of the Walbro Corporation, a manufacturer of engine fuel systems in Cass City, Mich. Walbro would not comment, except to say that its board of directors was meeting to consider the offer. Jeffrey Lehman, an investment banker with Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, which represents UIS, said any increase in the offer, which stands at $27.25 a share, could only be made in face-to-face negotiations between the companies. The offer, for 2.1 million of Walbro's 3.5 million outstanding shares, expires at midnight Oct. 7. UIS owns 8.3 percent of Walbro's stock, and the tender would raise its stake to about 70 percent.

title: PEREGRINE ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $171,352 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: Your Money; Venture Capital Partnerships
description: MICHAEL ONDRA, an Allentown, Pa., contractor, invested $10,000 in a venture capital limited partnership recently because ''I had gone to M.I.T. with people who went to Harvard Business School and they got into various venture capital consulting situations; I was impressed by the caliber of people involved.''

title: ROSE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $2,422,000 on the sale of a warehouse.

description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1987
description: International

title: World Delegates Cite Peril to Wilds
description: The earth's stockpile of wilderness is large, but much of it is threatened by human development, according to a report presented to the Fourth World Wilderness Congress, which opened here today.

title: At Salad Bars, Green Is Out
description: ''I never go to salad bars anymore,'' said a friend. But not for the reason you might suspect: concern about cleanliness. This friend said she is too tempted by the mixed salads - salads that have about as much to do with good nutrition as french fries and a Big Mac.

title: Nine More Top Officials Resign in the Philippines
description: The Governor of the Central Bank and eight other senior officials of the Philippine Government resigned today, in the wake of the resignations this week of the entire 25-member Cabinet of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: Ex-Illinois Senator Sees Peril In a Club Opposed to Koch
description: In an unusual intervention in a local and distant primary, Adlai E. Stevenson 3d of Illinois has written a letter warning of possible Communist infiltration of the Village Independent Democrats, once the premier reform Democratic club in New York City and a club that was founded to promote the 1956 Presidential campaign of Mr. Stevenson's father.

title: Bass Lifts Stake In Bell & Howell
description: The Bell & Howell Company, which is already the target of a possible takeover attempt from Macmillan Inc., disclosed today that Robert Bass, the Fort Worth investor, had increased his stake in the company by 117,200 shares, to 8.5 percent.

title: CBS SAYS SONY SEEKS RECORD UNIT
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that the Sony Corporation had inquired about buying all or part of the CBS records unit and added that it would ''consider and respond to Sony's inquiry in due course.''

title: Rash Rush to Denounce High Schools
description: After surveying how much high school students know about history and literature, educators profess dismay. Diane Ravitch of Columbia Teachers College and Chester Finn, an Assistant Secretary of Education, lament ''shameful'' performance and warn that students are ''at risk of being gravely handicapped.'' Lynne Cheney, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, declares that ''In our schools today, we run the danger of unwittingly proscribing our heritage.''

title: Radium-Laced Dirt Removed in Jersey
description: A contractor hauled away 44 drums of radium-tainted dirt from the lawns of four Essex County homes yesterday in the final stage a two-year saga for state officials and the neighborhood where 5,000 barrels of the contaminated soil have been kept.

title:
PATENTS;
Test for AIDS Virus
description: LEAD: A method for detecting the AIDS virus has been developed for Texas A & M University. Patent No. 4,692,403 was awarded this week to Prof. Luther E. Lindner, head of the department of pathology, and Stephen R. Wechter, a former student. The patent is now assigned to Mr. Wechter, who is offering rights to the pharmaceutical industry.

title: Broadway Continues a Rise In Both Tickets and Receipts
description: Weeks before the fall openings of more than a half-dozen new shows, the 1986-87 Broadway season is already showing signs of continued improvement in both attendance and box-office income. A strong summer for tourism and the drawing power of several new musicals have prolonged an upswing that began last spring.

title: Jorge Anders Big Band
description: The Jorge Anders Big Band will play music for dancing, presented by the New York Swing Society, tomorrow at the Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (505-0090). Doors open at 7 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: JETS ARE SHUFFLING FOR BUFFALO
description: In today's final practice for opening day, the Jets employed three rookie starters, kept their most visible defensive lineman on the bench, and shifted three players on the offensive line.

title: Imposing Majority Values on Minority Members
description: LEAD: When I taught at the University of New Mexico, I got to know a Navajo student, a pleasant and intelligent young man who couldn't wait to get back to the reservation.

title: The Dance: Lillo Way's Choreography
description: The Lillo Way Dance Company, which performs again tonight at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, is a rare specimen - a chamber-sized troupe that bears the distinctive and indelible mark of its choreographer-director.

title: SCHEIB (EARL) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Pickens Rejection Urged by Newmont
description: The Newmont Mining Company, as expected, advised its stockholders today to reject a $95-a-share offer from a group headed by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas investor, for 28 million Newmont common shares.

title: SAN DIEGO SAILS AHEAD
description: The San Diego Yacht Club announced yesterday that it intended to stage the America's Cup in 1991. The club ignored a legal dispute involving New Zealand that could negate that plan later this month.

title: Producer Prices Steady in August
description: In an encouraging report on inflation, the Labor Department reported today that the Producer Price Index for finished goods held steady in August, with a continued drop in food costs helping to offset rising energy prices.

title: A TV SITCOM TAKES TO THE STREETS
description: At the corner of 158th Street and Broadway earlier this week, in the middle of a downpour, a woman got out of a cab, then realized too late that she had left her purse on the seat. As she ran after the vehicle, a bystander joined her chase. The woman stopped, surprised, then doubled up with laughter.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT HITS $16.5 BILLION AS IMPORTS CLIMB
description: The nation's trade deficit surged to a record $16.5 billion in July, another sharp setback to expectations that the huge, longstanding gap between imports and exports had at least stabilized.

title: Posts Vacated At Sherwood
description: John E. Dell, a director and senior executive vice president of Sherwood Group Inc., has stepped down from those positions pending the outcome of a grand jury investigation into possible illegal securities practices at the Manhattan brokerage firm.

title: WHEREHOUSE ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
In Jersey, Old Theaters Get New Role
description: Victoria Holt Hardy describes the interior of the old Rivoli Theater here as a ruin, and it is. Yet these are exciting times for both theater restorers and regional theater in New Jersey, and she is not letting a little missing plaster, or even a lot of missing seats, stand in her way., Special to the New York Times

title: Double Blow To the Mets
description: It was a stricken clubhouse, and they hadn't even heard about Ron Darling's thumb yet.

title: BROTHER OF L.I. TEEN-AGER DESCRIBES LIFE WITH PARENTS
description: The brother of Cheryl Pierson, the teen-ager who says sexual abuse by her father led her to arrange his murder, painted a frightening portrait today of life in their parents' home.

title: Correction
description: A listing in Weekend yesterday with an article about apple-picking gave an incorrect telephone number for the Dr. Davies Farm in Congers, N.Y. Its number is (914) 268-7020.

title: Correction
description: An obituary yesterday of Peter Fingesten, a Surrealist artist who founded the art department at Pace University, listed his survivors incompletely. He is also survived by a daughter, Alexandra.

description: b-Net income

description: The chief of Canada's security and intelligence agency, Ted Finn, abruptly resigned today after a Government lawyer admitted in court that misleading information was used to obtain a warrant to tap the telephone of a Canadian Sikh.

description: A few days ago, at one of this city's better restaurants, reporters hunched around an earnest-looking young man, bespectacled and mustachioed, eagerly writing down his comments.

title: OFFICERS RESCUE MAN FROM PATH OF AN IRT TRAIN
description: Transit police officers rescued a man from the path of a subway train yesterday after he had been beaten during a robbery attempt and thrown onto the tracks in a Bronx station.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jose Santos, New York's leading jockey, will return to riding today at Belmont Park. Santos had been hospitalized and in traction earlier this week because of a pinched disk. . . . The Rangers signed a former Devils defenseman, Dave Pichette, as a free agent. Pichette, 27 years old, played with the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League last season, but in 1984-85 with New Jersey, he had 17 goals and 40 assists.

title: PAGE AMERICA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fervor Over Bork Nomination Intensifies as Start of Senate Hearings Nears
description: Praise and protest over the nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court filled the air here today as the start of his Senate confirmation hearing next week drew near.

title: Eli Lilly Drug Passes a Test
description: The Eli Lilly Company said today that its Prozac anti-depressant drug, which has also been found to induce weight loss, had met key Government safety requirements, bringing it a step closer to full approval.

title: Debris Left in Brooklyn High School Keeps Students From Classes
description: More than 2,000 students and their teachers missed the first day of classes at a Brooklyn high school yesterday because the Division of School Buildings had failed to clean the debris that remained after extensive renovations.

title: TV's Double Standard on Sex
description: Last spring, as part of a five-year state campaign to curb unplanned pregnancies and abortions, health professionals started knocking on the doors of New York City's commercial television stations. They wanted to buy time for a commercial urging people to practice birth control - ''from saying 'no' to taking the pill.'' The consortium, sad to say, is still knocking.

title: About New York; In Brooklyn Bar, Warm Memories Of Elsie the Cow
description: Comes a time in a man's life when he can sit in a neighborhood bar, and let the memories roll across his mind like a soothing stream.

title: Wife of Perry Dies in Accident
description: The wife of Gaylord Perry, the former major league pitcher, died in a traffic accident today when another car ran a stop sign and hit her car broadside, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.

title: BOSSY CAN'T BEAR TO WATCH
description: Last September Mike Bossy came to his 10th Islander training camp intent on delivering his 10th 50-goal season to break his own record and set himself up for this season, which he wanted to make his last.

title: KEY RATES
Two Media Giants' Dinosaur Labor-Relations Policies
description: The arrogance and self-righteousness that so often are among the less engaging characteristics of the mass media's discharge of their public responsibilities are currently being exhibited by two of the country's premier communications empires - NBC and The Washington Post - in their relations with their own news writers and other unionized employees.

title: Upstate Police Chief Is Slain
description: A gunman shot and killed the chief of a village police force and one other person Friday evening before being critically wounded at the end of a high-speed chase.

title: Address by Representative of U.S. Jews, and the Pope's Reply
description: Following are the texts of an address delivered today to Pope John Paul II by Rabbi Mordecai Waxman, honorary president of the Synagogue Council of America, on behalf of the Jewish community of America, and of the Pope's address in response. In delivering his address the Pope did not use biblical or other citations, but these were provided in the printed text. RABBI MORDECAI WAXMAN

title: Artifacts of Titanic Headed for France; Treasure Hunt Ends
description: Jewels, a safe and other items retrieved from the wreck of the Titanic were on their way to a laboratory today, after a 46-day treasure hunt in the sunken ocean liner.

title: CROWN BOOKS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

description: They are painting the hotels and sprucing up the shops along Main Street these days, bracing for what is expected to be a record tourist season in Jamaica.

title: Marine in Spying Case Sentenced to Rank Cut
description: Staff Sgt. Robert S. Stufflebeam, a former Marine Corps security guard who was a suspect in the Moscow Embassy espionage affair, was sentenced today to be reduced one grade in rank to sergeant for having drinks in off-limits Moscow bars.

title: A Liberal Applauds Conservative Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope Defends Vatican's Response To Holocaust in Talks With Jews
description: In a public encounter with American Jewish leaders, Pope John Paul II defended the conduct of Pope Pius XII today against assertions that he failed to publicly condemn the persecution and extermination of Jews by the Nazis.

title: Biden's Debate Finale: An Echo From Abroad
description: The Neil Kinnock commercial did not lead to electoral success last May in Britain, but the 10-minute spot of the Labor Party leader's passionate speeches, against a cool soundtrack of Brahms, raised his approval rating by 19 points and became an instant classic.

title: Hammer Donates His Papers
description: Dr. Armand Hammer, the industrialist whose friendships and acquaintances have ranged from Lenin to Ronald Reagan, is donating his voluminous papers to the Library of Congress.

title: YANKEES ARE LEFT STRANDED IN TORONTO
description: Time is running out for the Yankees. They lost another day on the calendar tonight, another opportunity to make up ground in the American League East. And now, they are thinking about holding off what appears to be inevitable: their elimination.

description: Frank Sinatra was in high spirits at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening.

description: To the Editor:

title: Driver Unconscious
description: Roberto Guerrero of Colombia, who was injured on the last lap Thursday in the last day of tire-testing at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway when his car careered into the wall, remained unconscious in critical but stable condition yesterday at Methodist Hospital with moderate to severe head injuries. According to Dr. Stephen Olvey, medical director for CART, the Indy-car sanctioning body, ''His vital signs remain stable. It's too soon to make any kind of prognostic statements.''

title: Threats, or Peace, in Central America?
description: The Reagan Administration contends that making peace in Nicaragua requires making the Sandinistas worry about the contras. Otherwise the Sandinistas may promise everything, wait for Congress to stop aid to the rebels - and then deliver nothing. It's a plausible argument, one that justifies keeping alive the possibility of further aid to the contras. But that's the only plausible part of the Administration's policy, which in almost every respect remains misguided, or worse.

title: Report Sees 'Big Brother' in Israeli Data on Arabs
description: Israel is creating a computerized data bank with a wide range of personal information about Arab residents of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, a research organization said today, asserting that the aim was to enhance control over the occupied territories.

title: Robertson Readies Candidacy
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson is expected to announce next Tuesday that he has obtained the three million pledges of support he has said he needs to run for President and will formally begin his Republican candidacy within a few weeks.

title: P.L.O. and Lebanese Shiites Agree to End Fighting
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization and Lebanon's dominant Shiite Moslem militia announced today that they had reached an agreement to end three years of fighting between them.

title: Chief Publishing Officer For Simon & Schuster
description: Jeremiah Kaplan, who joined Simon & Schuster in January as a special adviser to the chairman, was named president and chief publishing officer on Thursday.

title: BRIAN F. NEWTON
description: Brian F. Newton, who retired last year as manager of the sulfur division of Exxon Chemicals, died of cancer of the gall bladder Monday at his home in Quechee, Vt. He was 61 years old.

title: METS, ONE OUT FROM VICTORY, ARE STUNNED BY CARDS
description: The Mets took a spectacular tumble on the threshold of first place last night when they blew a 4-1 lead with two down in the ninth inning and lost to the St. Louis Cardinals in the 10th inning, 6-4.

title: Catholic Schools: Unchanged Values
description: When Mary F. Davis was a pupil 40 years ago at St. Mary's Roman Catholic School in Alexandria, Va., her older brother carried an envelope to school every Monday that contained the tuition for the entire Davis family. Inside was 25 cents.

title: Dollar Rallies After Fall While Gold Plummets
description: The dollar rallied on a wave of buying by Japanese and European corporations in New York yesterday, after dropping sharply early in the day when July's record $16.5 billion trade deficit was reported.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Carpenter Technology Corp., Reading, Pa., said it would close its specialty steel plant in Bridgeport, Conn., in early 1989, idling about 580 workers.

title: REV. JOHN SKVIR
description: The Rev. John Skvir, rector of Saints Peter and Paul Russian Orthodox Church of Jersey City for the last 35 years, died at his home in Jersey City Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

description: INTERNATIONAL/2-5, 28

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Both latest periods' earnings were hurt by the discontinuance of the CT Medical Imaging product line by Johnson & Johnson's technicare division, which was acquired by General Electric Co.

title: Recital: Mika Mori, at Altered Weill Hall
description: Mika Mori, a Japanese pianist whose resume includes studies at at the Tokyo Art University and the Vienna National Music University, had the distinction of being the season's first debutante. More importantly, her recital Wednesday evening provided the first opportunity to evaluate what effects various acoustical alterations have had on Weill Recital Hall.

title: Source of Blood in Atlanta House Still a Mystery
description: An investigation has determined that human blood found inside a house here does not belong to either occupant, the police said today.

title: EDWARD H. ROGERS
description: Edward H. Rogers, an insurance and banking executive of Westhampton Beach, L.I., died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in the village of Westhampton Beach. He was 68 years old.

title: Chiles Is Fined
description: Eddie Chiles, the owner of the Texas Rangers, said yesterday that Commissioner Peter Ueberroth had fined him for violating his policy on drug abuse. The Rangers did not wait the required 60 to 90 days to call up from the minors Steve Howe, a pitcher with a history of drug-related problems. Chiles, who had denied he had been fined, said that Ueberroth had met with him and Mike Stone, the club president, and ''he did levy a fine.'' The owner declined to disclose the amount, which was believed to be $250,000, the maximum Ueberroth has the power to fine. Howe was in the minors for 25 days.

title: AL COHN QUARTET
description: Al Cohn, a saxophonist, and Mundell Lowe, a guitarist, will lead a quartet tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title:
PATENTS;
Orbiting Arrangement For Satellite Cluster
description: LEAD: An orbiting arrangement that uses a cluster of satellites with substantially constant intercommunication was patented this week for British Aerospace P.L.C. Patent No. 4,691,882, granted to Ronald W. Young, a staff member, states that communication can be handled from a satellite in orbit at a considerable distance from the cluster.

title: U.S. Subpoenas 7 Sanitation Workers
description: Seven New York City sanitation workers have been subpoenaed to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the origins of the 50-mile garbage slick that littered New Jersey beaches with medical and household trash in mid-August.

title: WHY POLICY FORMENTALLY ILL IS FALTERING
description: The emptying of New York State's large mental institutions was spurred by advances in drugs, a new concern for the civil liberties of patients and a hope that a new system of community-based care could be established.

title: Correction
description: A Geneva dispatch yesterday about United Nations-sponsored talks on the Afghan war misidentified the Pakistani Foreign Minister. He is Sahabzada Yaqub Khan.

title: Honecker Flies Home, Leaving a Puzzle Behind
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, ended his long-anticipated visit to West Germany today with a smile and a jaunty wave, and left West Germans confused over an off-the-cuff remark that the border between the Germanys could someday be like East Germany's border with Poland.

title: Ex-Player Charged
description: Skip Dillard, a former DePaul basketball guard, has been charged with a series of armed robberies after a Federal judge saw him fleeing from a gasoline station, the police in Chicago said.

title: Siebe to Acquire Barber-Colman
description: Siebe P.L.C., the safety products and engineering company, said it had agreed to acquire the Barber-Colman Company for $:137.9 million, or about $227 million, in cash, its third United States purchase in a year.

DR. MAURICE B. GORDON
description: Dr. Maurice B. Gordon, a psychiatrist who practiced in Manhattan since 1953, died of a cerebral hemorrhage July 31 while vacationing in Brunswick, Me. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Utility Default Settled in Part
description: The first settlement in the litigation surrounding the Washington Public Power Supply System's default on $2.25 billion worth of bonds in July 1983 was announced Thursday by Junius Hoffman, the settlement master in the Federal court case.

description: b-Net income

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think he likes to be hugged.'' - Sara Gould, 6 years old, hugging Winnie-the-Pooh. [ 35:4. ]

title: Dance of Life Retired
description: Mack Miller trains the nation's leading 2-year-old, Crusader Sword, and the leading 3-year-old, Java Gold, but he has lost his top older horse. Miller announced yesterday that Dance of Life, a Grade I stakes winner on the grass, has been retired to stud because of an injury to his left foreleg. Dance of Life, a 4-year-old Nijinsky colt who earned $842,187, developed a filling last week and was scratched from the Arlington Million, in which he would have been among the favorites.

title: Senate Begins a Debate On Arms Control Issues
description: After blocking action for four months, Republicans stepped aside today and the Senate began debate on its 1988 Defense Department programs bill, which includes restraints on the development of President Reagan's space-based antimissile system.

title: Aerospatiale Shift
description: Aerospatiale, the French state aerospace group, is reorganizing its aircraft division to meet an increase in orders and the challenge of strong foreign competition, Henri Martre, the company chairman, said. The reorganization will include increased specialization for each of Aerospatiale's 13 plants, splitting the aircraft division between production and marketing, and putting more work out to subcontractors.

title: In Provincial City, Frustration Over Aquino's Stewardship
description: ''The ex-mayor is laughing,'' said Ramon Nolan, as he recited a litany of the grievances against President Corazon C. Aquino that are common here. ''You know why? Because he voted for Marcos and I voted for Cory, and he enjoys what I'm saying.''

title: TV: NO ONE STEALS THE POPE'S SCENES
description: How has Pope John Paul II been playing on television? So far, remarkably well; the Pope dominates television almost by ignoring it. At the same time, it's clear that no one will ever steal a scene while he's on camera. John Paul forces the action to come to him.

description: Albert A. List, an industrialist and philanthropist who began his career working in his family grocery store and ended it a multimillionaire, died yesterday of heart failure at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 86 years old and lived in Byram, Conn.

description: It is not often that a tennis player can use the two weeks of a Grand Slam event as a confidence booster. It is not the place to be having doubts. But in a year in which Navratilova has won only one tournament, she has played her best in the Grand Slams. He repeats brand names -Star-Kist tuna, Hellmann's mayonnaise, Squibb mineral oil - while bouncing off the furniture in the ramshackle house that he shares with his older brother, Treat. The character's name is Phillip, and in Lyle Kessler's drama ''Orphans,'' he is the shy youth with perpetually untied sneakers who just needs a little encouragement. On Chicago, New York and London stages - and now, in the director Alan J. Pakula's screen version - Phillip has been portrayed by the same frenetic young actor: Kevin Anderson.

title: A Guide to Antique Shops . . .
description: The well-stocked shops and confident air of antiques dealers on both sides of Hong Kong Harbor belie qualms expressed in recent years about the economy of the British territory as it faces transfer to Chinese control in 1997. The majority of antiques merchants concentrate on vintage Oriental wares and are in two major areas - the Ocean Terminal on Kowloon and along Hollywood Road and environs on Hong Kong Island.

title: AMERICA'S OWN ARABIA
description: FOR the short run, increased pipeline capacity in the Middle East has eased worries of a possible cut-off of supplies coming through the Persian Gulf and a consequent series of price shocks that would stagger the economy. Indeed, at midweek, after a report from the International Energy Agency that Saudi Arabia, OPEC's pivotal member, had exceeded its quota last month, oil prices dipped below $19 a barrel on the world markets.

title: WHEN THERE IS A DRIVING HAZARD, REPORT IT
description: I AM guilty - perhaps of contributing to death, permanent injury, damage to property or person. Who knows for sure. But I am guilty!

title: Wightman Team Named
description: Lori McNeil, who upset Chris Evert before losing in the semifinals of the United States Open, was named yesterday to the United States team that will defend its Wightman Cup tennis title against Britain Oct. 29-31 at Williamsburg, Va. Also on the squad, chosen by

title: Patricia Yeh Marries
description: Patricia Teresa Yeh, the daughter of Joseph Yeh of Williamsville, N.Y., and the late Dana Yeh, was married yesterday to Lawrence Livingston Lue, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Lue of Monroe, N.Y., at Christ United Methodist Church in New York by the Rev. Stephen P. Bauman. The bride and bridegroom graduated from Cornell University and received M.B.A. degrees from New York University. She is a financial analyst at the International Business Machines Corporation in White Plains, and he is an account executive at HDM Advertising in Manhattan.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: DESK TOPS TELL ALL
description: Among the treasured memorabilia on the desk of the industrialist Armand Hammer are a 50-million-year-old piece of fossil shale and a check, set in clear Lucite, for one billion dollars - a souvenir of the repayment of a debt. The real-estate magnate Donald J. Trump's desk is cluttered with important papers, but on a window ledge behind him, he keeps a small replica of Trump Tower and a pair of antique ice skates presented to him upon the reopening of Wollman Skating Rink in New York City. The bank chairman Lewis T. Preston has a comparatively bare desk that is a memento itself: an early 20th-century roll-top used by one of the original partners of J. P. Morgan & Company.

title: SUMMER'S PORTENTS OF MONEY AND SEX
description: IT'S CERTAINLY SOBERING TO glance backward at the newspapers of several months ago and see the projected big hits of the summer - ''Harry and the Hendersons,'' ''Who's That Girl,'' ''Ishtar'' - twinkling on the horizon. Needless to say, things never work out as planned. That was especially true in a summer without familiar landmarks, with no ''Saturday Night Live'' comedy spinoff or Paramount musical (unless you count ''Beverly Hills Cop II'' in both categories), no kiddie-oriented blockbuster and Sylvester Stallone otherwise engaged.

title: EVANESCENT SNARE OF A SPIDER'S WEB
description: IT was a warm evening, and my friend and I had just returned from a restaurant on the Island. I drove into the dark driveway of my home and pressed the electric garage door clicker on my windshield visor; the door swung up and the headlights of my car shone through the blackness at a beautifully constructed spider's web, suspended dead center in the driveway between two matching shrubs on either side of it.

title: SHAYS SETTLES IN
description: WITH a few words and a bit of ceremony, Christopher Shays was transformed last Wednesday from a veteran state representative with seven terms of experience to a freshman Congressman with no experience at all.

title: Keep Up With Chores And Seasonal Planting
description: CONTINUE digging, dividing and replanting overgrown clumps of spring-blooming perennials; wait until spring to dig and divide fall-blooming perennials such as asters, chrysanthemums and Japanese anemones. Plant peonies after the soil is prepared well; be sure to keep the eyes just below the surface; roots planted too deeply do not bloom. Continue spraying established rosebushes with fungicide to control black spot. Keep up with lawn care. Tree Peonies

title: TOO LONG TOO ANGRY
description: ANEURIN BEVAN And the Mirage of British Socialism. By John Campbell. Illustrated. 430 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.95.

title: New York Is 3d in Apple Output
description: Despite a large increase in the apple crop this fall, New York will drop from second to third place in the nation in apple production, according to crop estimates released this week by the state agriculture department here.

title: Penn State's $20 Million Touchdown
description: THE start of the college football season is always a happy time for Jack Garbrick. Not that the games themselves mean a whole lot to him. He never watches them. He flies over them.

title: ANOTHER QUESTION FOR FAIRCHILD
description: Re: ''Fairchild Layoffs Pose Tough Questions,'' Aug. 23:

title: Casey's Role in Shaping the Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo
description: Tokyo is a splendid place for a visit as fall approaches. The worst of the summer heat and humidity is just about over, but the autumn chill is weeks away.

title: PORTRAITS OF PRIDE AND PERSISTENCE
description: LEAD: AS a photographer, Toba Tucker considers herself ''an observer.'' For the last six years, propelled by what she calls a ''mystical, magical'' force, she has been preoccupied with observing Native Americans.

title: QUARTETS PLAY LAST NOTES OF SUMMER
description: BETWEEN two summer holdovers and the early stirrings of the fall season, the concert scene in Connecticut is gradually coming back to life. The recital postscripts, both featuring outstanding string quartets as it happens, are this afternoon's Music Mountain finale, and the last Friday night concert in the South Shore Music Club's summer series.

title: Free the Aviation Billions
description: Stung by charges that she has mismanaged the nation's air transportation system, Secretary of Transportation Elizabeth Dole blames Congress. It is responsible for the unspent $5.6 billion in the Aviation Trust Fund, she says, and thus for increased congestion and delay.

title: WHICH IS BETTER, BASEBALL OR FOOTBALL?
description: Which is better, baseball or football? Je ne sais quois. Ask Bo Jackson in three months. JOAN MARY MACEY Binghamton, N.Y.

title: Evanston: A Landmark Marshall Field's Is Becoming Residential Lofts
description: WHEN Marshall Field & Company, Chicago's prime retailer, opened its first two branches in the suburbs, here and in Oak Park, the owners were determined to bring with them the company's downtown image. A slate mansard roof with copper trim, a facade of marble and limestone and a five-foot bronze clock graced the blocklong Marshall Field store that was completed in 1929 at Church Street and Sherman Avenue, on Evanston's prize downtown corner. And for maximum effect, floodlights illuminated the building at night.

title: Crime
description: Don't be thrown off by the title. LOVER MAN by Dallas Murphy (Scribners, $14.95) is not a romance. Artie Deemer, the central character in this novel, is a suspect in a murder case, and the tough New York cop who is in charge of the investigation calls him ''lover man'' for no good reason.

title: Miss Hodes Is Married To Richard H. O'Leary
description: Susan Dean Hodes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Hodes of Katonah, N.Y., and Richard Hope O'Leary, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James J. O'Leary of Oyster Harbors, Mass., and John's Island, Fla., were married yesterday at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smolover and the Rev. Robert Springer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Commercial Property: Midtown Development; New Zoning Battles Are Looming for the West Side
description: BOWING to self-applause, New York City's Department of City Planning recently announced the ''fulfillment'' of key goals established five years ago when a zoning initiative opened the west side of midtown Manhattan to a spate of skyscrapers.

title: FRESH TUNA STARS IN 'CANNED TUNA' ROLES
description: THE availability of fresh tuna makes it a viable replacement for the canned variety in a number of recipes. Although it cannot and should not be used in the traditional salad mixture calling for the canned tuna mashed nearly to a paste with mayonnaise, then made into a sandwich or a component of a salad plate, a stylish tuna salad to serve on a bed of lettuce is delicious when prepared with chunks of fresh tuna.

title: LILCO PLANS SAFETY FILTER AT SHOREHAM
description: ADJACENT to the distinctive round reactor building of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, the Long Island Lighting Company may soon be erecting another structure that looks like a silo - to cut the accident risk at the reactor and to try to convince the public of its safety.

title: U.S. Orders Closing of Central National Bank
description: The Central National Bank of New York has been declared insolvent and closed by the Comptroller of the Currency.

title: CAN'T ANYBODY HERE FIGHT THIS WAR?
description: TIME AND TIDE By Thomas Fleming. 734 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Dates in Lights
description: IT sounds too good to be true: a wall calendar that is not only good-looking but will remind you of important dates. It is Continuum Limited's battery-operated electronic calendar, and this how it works: Punch in the year, month and day you wish to remember. A small red light will appear one, two or three days in advance of the dates you have recorded. As the day comes closer, the light will flash faster as a reminder that time is running out. The only problem might be remembering what to do on the date you're being reminded not to forget.

title: MICHIGAN UPSET BY NOTRE DAME
description: Terry Andrysiak completed 11 of 15 passes for 137 yards, including an 11-yard touchdown toss to Tim Brown, as Notre Dame scored a 26-7 upset victory over Michigan today.

title: Concert: To Celebrate Alice Tully's Birthday
description: SEEN in its most sentimental light, Friday evening's lieder concert by Hermann Prey at Alice Tully Hall was one man's serenade to a woman. And who was to deny us a little sentimentality on such an occasion? It was Alice Tully's 85th birthday, and friends, colleagues and fellow listeners joined to celebrate it in the hall that she made possible and that bears her name.

title: DATA BANK: September 13, 1987
The 'Cruel Hoax'
description: DESCRIBING today's system of college athletics as a ''cruel hoax'' on student athletes, Bart Giamatti said yesterday that it was unfair that some schools used athletes to ''make money off them, increase their fame because of them and do not educate them.''

title: Gooden Routed, 8-1; Mets Fall 3 1/2 Back
description: Not many hours after they blew a lead in the ninth inning and a game in the 10th, the Mets were struck by the ultimate and maybe even the unthinkable shock yesterday: Dwight Gooden was knocked out in two innings, and the Mets lost for the second straight time to the St. Louis Cardinals, 8-1.

title: HARDBALL ON WALL STREET
description: I meet many men like Robert Minicucci in my practice as a marriage therapist -rich yuppies with poor personal relationships. They are blind to the folly of spending zero time on marriage and zoom time in the market. Mr. Minicucci's marriage never had a chance to succeed because he was already married - not to his wife - but to Shearson. Like most soon-to-be-divorced persons, he can statistically expect to suffer more depression, intestinal conditions, stomach troubles, colitis and ulcers, but there will be ample money in his wallet to pay the doctor bills. ANN MOLIVER RUBEN North Miami Beach, Fla.

title: FILLING OPERA PODIUMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Help From Friends
description: Recent years have not been kind to Woody Herman, the jazz clarinetist and band leader. For a while last week it appeared that Mr. Herman, who is broke and bedridden, would suffer the further misfortune of becoming homeless.

title: New Chief Lends Militancy to Vermont Tribe
description: The Abenaki Indians of northwestern Vermont have elected, by a vote of 144 to 141, a tribal chief who says he is ''sick of dealing with the white man'' and who is seen as representing a more militant faction of the tribe of 2,200 people.

title: '20TH-CENTURY MASTER AMERICAN PHOTOGRAPHS' IN STAMFORD
description: THE exhibition at the Whitney Museum in Stamford, Conn., is in some respects as routine as its title, ''Twentieth-Century Master American Photographs.'' A selection of 86 mainly black-and-white prints, it surveys photography's metamorphosis into high art - assuming the change has been in the product and not, as seems more likely, in the public's perception of it.

title: Stage: 'Why to Refuse,' an Allegory
description: FOR a playwright to cast himself as the self-martyred central character in his own drama takes considerable nerve. But when that character spends most of his time on the stage naked, that decision seems more than an act of daring. It smacks of angry, exhibitionistic desperation.

title: ISLIP PONDERS FUTURE OF PARK
description: LEAD: A CLOSED neighborhood park dedicated to a local youth killed in Vietnam has become the focal point of a disagreement between the Town of Islip and 700 families who live near the four-acre park, on MacArthur Avenue in the Regis Park section of Brentwood.

title: Rather Walked Off Set of CBS News
description: Dan Rather, angered because CBS decided to shorten the ''CBS Evening News'' to broadcast the end of a tennis match on Friday, walked off the set and caused the network to ''go black'' for six minutes.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. We have just moved into a house that has a septic tank system with a drainage field. We have heard many stories about how to maintain this system and wonder what advice you have to offer.

title: Deborah Paquette Becomes the Bride Of Philip Gelston
description: At St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in Manchester, N.H., Deborah Ann Paquette, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore G. Paquette of Manchester, was married yesterday to Philip Andrew Gelston, a son of Mrs. Robert H. Gelston of Indianapolis and the late Mr. Gelston. Msgr. John E. Molan performed the ceremony.

title: ELECTRONICS CONTROL IS NEW SELLING POINT
description: GEORGE FORREST is clucking about chicken, more specifically about ''chili-rubbed'' Arizona chicken, whatever that is.

title: POLICE ARE COMBATING NEW HAZARD: AIDS
description: LEAD: THE Torrington Police Department is making available to its officers full bodysuits, masks and gloves to use if they are exposed to people they think might have AIDS.

title: Dispute Grows Over Cornell Computer Center
description: ''Ithaca is gorges,'' say hundreds of bumper stickers in this scenic upstate town. And when Cornell University announced plans to build an eight-story, $29 million supercomputer center on the rim of Cascadilla Gorge, residents and officials rose up.

title: '60 Minutes': A Hit Confronts the Odds
description: THE MORNING HAD JUST BEGUN AND DON Hewitt was already quite agitated, which drew no special notice, as agitation is Mr. Hewitt's natural state. On this particular morning, the executive producer of ''60 Minutes'' was aroused by a splashy magazine advertisement trumpeting the new fall schedule of the CBS television network. Somehow, someone at the network had listed every single CBS show except one - Mr. Hewitt's ''60 Minutes.''

title: MARINA PROPOSAL STARTS A DISPUTE IN NORWALK
description: AS one of the busiest harbors in the state, Norwalk is confronted with a problem common to many coastal communities - inadequate dock and mooring space for the increasing number of boats on Long Island Sound.

title: A Better Approach To Contract Disputes
description: THE Supreme Court recentlyhanded the securities industry a major victory in a case called Shearson/American Express Inc. v. McMahon. The Court said that almost all securities cases brought by customers against brokers, including cases involving the violation of Federal statutes, must go to arbitration, not Federal court, if the customer has signed a standard agreement containing an arbitration clause.

title: The Final Say
description: ARTICLE III: Section 2. The judicial Power shall extend to all case....

title: India's Assam State Demanding Ban on Migration
description: The government of the northeastern state of Assam is demanding that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi block the migration of other Indians to the area, and deport millions of immigrants from Bangladesh.

title: Coppede
description: To the Editor: It took more than 25 years, but now I know who did the strange and lovely forms described by Martha Pichey in her article on Coppede (''Rome's Mischievous Architect,'' Travel, Aug. 2).

title:
IN THE NEW YORK REGION;
New Jersey: A Mixed-Income Rental Project Accessible to the Route 1 Corridor
description: LEAD: IN the last decade, the Township of West Windsor, covering nearly 27 square miles in Mercer County, has been a natural place to develop housing.

title: Civil Rights Group Plans to Protest Attack Against Black Teen-Agers
description: A coalition of more than 60 civil rights, religious and community organizations announced yesterday that it would hold a march through the Canarsie section of Brooklyn next Sunday to protest a recent attack against three black teen-agers by a group of whites.

title: BASEBALL VS. FOOTBALL: THE WINNER IS...; GET SERIOUS! BASEBALL IS BEST
description: LAST spring, when the world was immensely younger and we knew with golden April arrogance that the Yankees and the Reds would collide in the forthcoming World Series, a number of us were subpoenaed - asked, actually - to address the Sports Lawyers Association in a Washington hotel. Bowie Kuhn, baseball's vanished Romanov, freed from the restraints of czarism, spoke with particular intensity about problems assaulting the game.

title: Shauna Tarshis Is Married To Michael P. Denkensohn
description: Shauna Tarshis, chief of the office of parking control at the New York City Department of Transportation, was married in New York last night to Michael P. Denkensohn, a certified public accountant and an audit partner in the New York office of Arthur Andersen & Company. Rabbi Joel Goor officiated at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Counted Out
description: AS a linebacker at the University of Oklahoma, he brought fame to his jersey, No. 44. So when Brian Bosworth signed a multimillion-dollar contract with Seattle, it came as no surprise that he picked the same number for his Seahawks jersey and moved to cash in on its fame. He named his personal corporation 44 Boz Inc., signed a contract for production of a line of 44 Blues sunglasses, posed in his No. 44 for a Land of Boz poster and negotiated with a jeans manufacturer for a line of Seattle 44 Blues jeans.

title: Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Tempe, Ariz.;
A High-Rise in Cactus Country
description: LEAD: A 39-YEAR-OLD developer in this valley southeast of Phoenix has taken an unconventional path by building a high-density condominium project, catering to people who want an urban way of life, in a region of suburban sprawl.

title: Four Hotels in the Grandest Manner. . .And Food Fit for Emperors
description: There are nearly 20,000 restaurants in Hong Kong, a city where it may seem that every resident is a self-styled gourmet and that everyone eats out as often as possible. The result is some of the very best cooking in the world, be it French, Italian or Vietnamese.

title: ROAD COMPLETED AFTER 52 YEARS
description: The Blue Ridge Parkway has been officially completed 52 years to the day after ground was broken for the scenic highway that winds through the southern Appalachian mountains of western North Carolina and Virginia.

title: FOREST FIRES LEAVE BEHIND MUCH MORE THAN ASHES
description: IT is one of the most dramatic scenes in nature, fire flashing through the forest. Ten-story trees suddenly erupting in flame. Large limbs, ablaze, soaring on hot-air currents. Terrified people fleeing with pets and armloads of clothing. Airborne water-bombers and helmeted firefighters struggling against the heat. And always the roar, like a jet engine, just over the hill as the blaze sucks in air from behind and blasts it out ahead to preheat anything in its path.

title: The Dance: Judy Trupin
description: JUDY TRUPIN combined choreography with spoken texts in the works that the Extrapolating Movement Theater offered Wednesday night at the Rapp Arts Center. At their best, these pieces were goofy and satirical.

title: HARDBALL ON WALL STREET
description: James Sterfold's article ''Hardball on Wall Street'' (Aug. 16) was interesting. I greatly admire Robert Minicucci for his intelligence, perseverance and integrity. However, I am sorry that he chose to become an investment banker instead of, perhaps, a university professor, a doctor, a scientist or a politician. I wonder how many young people with good minds are going in that direction. BARBARA GURMAN New York, N.Y.

title: Darling Is Lost For Rest Of Season
description: The Mets' pennant chances took another stunning jolt yesterday when Ron Darling was found to have torn the ligaments at the base of his right thumb, and he will be lost for the rest of the season.

title: Fight Over Cup: By Land, Then by Sea
description: A lull as ominous as the eye of a hurricane has settled around plans for America's Cup competition. Efforts on Friday by the San Diego Yacht Club to set a time and place for the next series - May 1991 in San Diego - answered long-posed questions. But the club's game plan is still surrounded by winds of discord.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TRAITORS: The Anatomy of Treason. By Chapman Pincher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) In this densely packed, exhaustively researched study of the most heinous kind of spy - one who betrays his own country's most sensitive secrets - Chapman Pincher, a British journalist and a specialist in intelligence activities, has put together a composite profile of such people, ranging from the John Walker ring to Sir Anthony Blunt, the Rosenbergs and dozens of lesser titans of treachery.

title: FOR CHAGALL, AN END TO ARTISTIC EXILE
description: IN THE FIRST WEEK OF SEPTEMBER the bloom went off the Moscow summer, and in the streets adjacent to the Pushkin Museum amber lamplight shone behind tall windows set in pale yellow facades. The morning was dark and dank, but people were standing five and six abreast in a line that snaked around the museum for 100 yards and more. In an exhibition mounted in short order to mark the centenary of his birth, Marc Chagall's work was back in town and in bulk after many, many years, and no one in Moscow was put off by the weather.

title: OLDER THAN TEXAS, BIGGER THAN ISRAEL
description: SARUM By Edward Rutherfurd. 897 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $19.95.

title: New York Assembly to Install An Electronic Voting System
description: An electronic voting system is to be installed in the New York State Assembly chamber to make voting by the 150 members quicker and more orderly, Speaker Mel Miller has announced.

title: 3 DISTRICTS ARE STRONGHOLDS FOR INCUMBENTS
description: LEAD: RUNNING for re-election to the county's Board of Legislators is nothing new for Audrey G. Hochberg.

title: BOARD FACES NEW PROBLEM ON HOTEL TAX
description: THE county's proposed hotel tax, which would raise money for Westchester's growing homeless population through hotel-room occupancy charges, faced a new snag last week when legislators learned that the state would not collect the levy, as it does county sales taxes.

title: Going to China? What to Expect
description: If you want good Peking duck in unhurried surroundings on your trip to China and don't have a friend in Beijing who can select a restaurant for you, go to Hong Kong or Taipei. That's the advice of Robert K. McCabe, an old Asia hand and author of the new book ''Asia Guide to Business Travel.'' Howard C. Smith, president of Chinasmith, a travel wholesaler, concurs. He says that one restaurant in Beijing, Hepingmen Kaoya Dian, a six-story establishment, serves 1,200 dinners a night. That puts it into what teen-agers would call the McDuck category. Mr. Smith orders his duck in Shanghai.

title: Contras Are Reported to Establish A Foothold in Central Nicaragua
description: Guerrillas backed by the United States have established a foothold here in central Nicaragua, residents of the area say.

title: The North Fork Fights the Tide of Building
description: LEAD: WHEN Ruth Oliva of Orient, L.I., stopped in Queens recently for ice cream, she was startled by what some people at the counter had to say over sundaes about her quiet hamlet. Not only had they heard of it, she recalled, they actually knew where it was.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: AGENTS OF INNOCENCE. By David Ignatius. (Norton, $17.95.) David Ignatius, an associate editor of The Washington Post, has written a superlative spy novel expertly set in the maniacal turbulence of the contemporary Middle East. He has the true novelist's skill in portraying the shadows as well as the substance of his large gallery of characters; these colorful human beings range widely in background and nationality, from urbane C.I.A.

title: REDSKINS AND BEARS READY TO CHALLENGE GIANTS
description: The following conference preview was reported and written by Frank Litsky. The teams are listed in the predicted order of finish, with the Giants picked to finish first in the East. EAST Washington Redskins

title: INSTRUCTION
description: Light and Fresh Cooking Bon Appetit's ''Too Busy to Cook'' Series. Lorimar Home Video. 60 minutes. $14.95.

title: Designating An Asterisk
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lori Halpern Wed To Paul Reszutek
description: Lori Beth Halpern, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred J. Halpern of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Paul J. Reszutek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Reszutek of Colonia, N.J. Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim, assisted by the Rev. Peter P. Brennan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.

title: THE VERDICT ON CREATIONISM
description: The Rev. Richard H. Baker Jr. greatly overestimates fundamentalist creationists when he claims that they are motivated by a desire for ''societal values that are worthy of humane people'' and by their fear that a morality based on the survival of the fittest would be ''bad ethics''(Letter, Aug. 23d, in response to ''The Verdict on Creationism,'' by Stephen Jay Gould, July 19).

title: MISSION: DEMONIC
description: DANILOV THE VIOLIST By Vladimir Orlov. Translated by Antonina W. Bouis. 307 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: Commercial Co-ops: Tribeca Deja Vu
description: The old mercantile district on the Lower West Side, which has become quite different and fashionable under its new name, Tribeca, is attracting commercial as well as residential cooperatives.

title: Man Who Killed Wife Had Threatened Her
description: A man accused of fatally stabbing his former wife at a downtown New Haven shopping mall was divorced from the woman last week and reportedly threatened to kill her if she took custody of their five children, court records show.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: All of the Answers To Teachers' Wants The Teachers' Room, which expanded in July with a move to Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains, is crowded this month with teachers gathering their specialized supplies for the new year - record books and bulletin-board decorations, reward stickers for achievements and good behavior, tools for teaching and items for learning incentives. Parents also use the store's supplies for gifts to children of all ages at home or while traveling, beginning with the simplest books, games, puzzles and puppets. When a teacher's purchases mount to $50, a coupon is given entitling the purchaser to a monthly special. Stickers are available for identifying cubbyholes, team members and belongings for nonreading preschoolers - dinosaurs, animals and birds can be recognized easily by shape and color. These cost $1.25 to $2.50 for batches of 30 or 50. There is also a supply of ''brag tags,'' good-work stamps and ''I'm on a Field Trip'' name badges to help round up lost or strayed pupils. Good News Grams are small pads for brief notes to students or their parents and more complex books holding three-part worksheets for a record of notes sent home, the message sent and reply space on the same sheet helping to insure communication. The design of bulletin boards is explained in numerous advice books that sell for $3.95 (a ditto book on borders) to $10.95 (language arts as a theme), and there are paper crafts and prescalloped corrugated strips or sheets in many colors and designs. Other class supplies reflect the seasons, holidays, presidents, patriotic themes, our changing earth, the solar system, weather choices, simple machines, magnets and electricity, heat, light and sound. Charts can be simple one-color designs for $1, animal and alphabet combinations for $1.50, or two-sided in full color for $2 - other subjects are food groups, insects, animals, flags of the world, five senses, human body, prefixes and suffixes, explorers, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., international children, sign language alphabet, how to write a letter or understand numbers concepts. Books are available on teaching poetry, writing, drama, science, thinking skills, logic, reading and language experiences. Mathematics and word problems and handwriting workbooks are here, too. The ''Instructor's Big Book of Health and Safety'' costs $15.95 and provides 250 activities. ''Naturewatch,'' for $7.95, helps parents explain the world around them to children. Videos are sold here and so is Granny's Dabblin' Dough - five slabs of color for $7.95. Monkey Mitt has velcro on the fingers to hold smaller components -the mitt serves for many stories and costs $5.95; the story puppets are $6 a set and include the Three Blind Mice, Humpty Dumpty and Basic Shapes and Colors. Early-reading materials cover both phonic and sight techniques. Knit puppets cost $3.95 and the most costly plush puppet is $8.95. Many small items are suitable for loot bag fillers, birthday gifts and decorations. The wipe-off cards and crayons favored in nursery schools work on both sides and cost $6.95 - the ''See It, Make It'' side suggests shapes, or a path, a maze or the alphabet. The reverse side allows for original designs. Home workbooks for $2.50 have alphabets, puzzles or hidden pictures, and other books help with prereading or early-reading skills. A rubber stamp kit featuring jungle animals sells for $5.95 and color charts are $8.95. The Lace-a-Saurus for $6.50 is a precut felt puppet to be sewn and stuffed - the blunt needle and yarn are included in the package. The Bug Bottle holds a soft-cover field guide to 24 insects and ''Blood and Guts'' is a work guide to a child's own insides -each science item sells for $7.95; a child's apron with added-on anatomy parts - liver, heart, lungs at the front and kidneys at the back - sells for $19.95. Small magnets are $3.50 and a larger magnet for 2-year-olds is $4.25; a Lift and Learn wood puzzle costs $7.50. Six car-game books at $4.95 are for older children and cover amazing animals, space, puzzles and geography, with one decoder for $1.50 used with any subject in the series. New True Books on subjects such as North or South America, Africa, the Atlantic Ocean, the Arctic, Eskimos and New York City cost $3.95 each. The Teachers' Room is at 259 Mamaroneck Avenue, between Maple and Carhart Avenues, in White Plains. Open 10:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Monday through Friday and 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Saturday; closed Sunday. During September and October the hours are extended until 7:30 P.M. each Thursday for the convenience of teachers. Visa, American Express, MasterCard and checks are accepted with two identifications. The telephone number is 682-8496. All Manner of Things Designed and Crafted The store Of Cabbages and Kings opened 10 years ago this December in Mamaroneck with all kinds of contemporary crafts for owning or giving - artistic and functional glass, ceramics, metal, wood, fiber, leather and paper, plus woven, crocheted and hand-painted separates, shawls and scarves, purses, wallets and jewelry. Windchimes, soft sculpture, photograph frames, candelabra, serving pieces and utensils and stemware also are here. Whimsy is included in the ''boxes'' fitted into a hippo or a puffin shape for $50; another box in a redwood burl sells for $36 and comes from California; a walnut three-level, dresser-top storage cabinet costs $130 and is suede-lined. Burmese Padauk wood shaped as a building contains four storage compartments and is $175. A maple burl, one-drawer container made in Oregon sells for $75. Desert hardwoods are shaped into sleek letter openers for $22 in Cortez, Colo., by Bob Womack. Jonathan's from Pennsylvania uses wild cherry for small spoons and spreaders ($4), stirrers ($7.50), spaghetti forks with rippled tines ($10), one-handed salad-serving forks ($12) and deep serving spoons ($22). A two-pen desk set for $115 is made of olive-ash veneer from Turkey. Zebra wood and mahogany salt and pepper mills cost $48 a pair, and a smaller, combination mill sells for $32. Wood is also cut into jigsaw puzzles ($10 to $24, one with a worm coming out of a red apple, another incorporating wine bottle and cheese shapes), a pull toy ($18.50) and various sizes of bread and cheese boards for $20 to $52. Ceramic casseroles, soup tureens, pitchers, mugs and tea sets are here as well as porcelain wind chimes or bronze wind bells. The weather-protected Woodstock Chimes of aluminum and black ($64) or natural birch ($60) have a choice of Lun, Partch or Olympos scales. Breadbaskets for retaining warmth cost $30 to $60 in white, natural or a mixture best described as sky-blue pink. One white vase by Nancee Meeker is incised with black and holds water. It was $125 and is $95 now; a similar shape by the same artist, hand-carved and black, pitfired and not meant to hold water, is decorative by itself or used with a dried arrangement and costs $225. One tall, black glass vase by Sclafani, earlier $240, sells for $168 now and several others are $84, clear with colored stripes. Stemware includes yellow-tinted crystal by Josh Simpson at $45 each; tulip-based goblets at $46 each in white or pink or $52 in the tallest white style; and gold designs within and a black stem for $44 each - many of these are from California and are hand-blown into wet wood forms to insure a uniform shape and unusual stems and colors are added. Steven Maslach makes the art glass marble goblets at $52, clear except for the swirl of color at the top of the stem. Pillows abound, metal sculptures suit many tastes and decorative serving dishes can go into the oven with hot canapes. Pewter photograph frames range from tiny at $10.50 to $65, with many $14 to $30. Hand-blown glass perfume bottles and paperweights range in cost from $38 to $190; glass vases and bowls from $30 to $300 and wine decanters start at about $100. Wrought-iron and brass candlesticks start at about $56 and the top price is $130. Appalachian-style fireplace brooms cost $16 to $18, depending on the handle design. Switchplates of leather with hand-painted animals are $15. Quilted purses of silk batik are $36 and $60, with matching eyeglasses cases $24. Hand-dyed and -tooled leather wallets and covers for address books for desk or purse, appointment calendars, notepads and checkbooks are here in assorted sizes and prices. Of Cabbages and Kings is at 587 East Boston Post Road, or Route 1, in Mamaroneck, about one-half mile north of Mamaroneck Avenue. Open 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Mondays through Saturdays; closed Sundays except in December; also closed Mondays in January through March. American Express, Visa, MasterCard and checks are accepted. Unlike the earliest budget-priced long-playing vinyl records in the first days of the LP era, which usually featured little-known artists and orchestras, many of the midpriced CD's offer celebrated names and notable performances, usually with first-class sonics. In some cases, the CD's were even selling as part of the companies' full-priced lines not too many months ago. Veteran LP collectors or beginning collectors of classical musical recordings could do worse than start building their CD libraries from these midpriced disks.

title: TWO GIANTS OF MODERNISM AT OPPOSITE POLES
