title: THE BOOK IS DEAD, LONG LIVE THE BOOK!
description: GLAS By Jacques Derrida. Translated by John P. Leavey Jr. and Richard Rand. 262 pp. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press. $50. GLASSARY By John P. Leavey Jr. Essay by Gregory L. Ulmer. Foreword by Jacques Derrida. 320 pp. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press. $50. JACQUES DERRIDA is a teacher of philosophy in Paris, and for some years he wrote only the sort of books that a French philosophy professor of inordinate brilliance might be expected to write - difficult books to say the least, but conventionally philosophical so far as the language they were written in went. They advanced a radical thesis about language, however: when we use it we cannot expect it to mean only what we want it to mean, because it has a semantic life of its own, and its meanings escape from us. There can be no such thing as a mastery of language. Worse, language is sounds and forms before it is concepts, and when we write or speak sounds and forms will come into our minds uninvited because one word can but lead to others. So, it is as much to the resources of the language as to our own proud genius that we owe ''our'' concepts. All of which is the blackest heresy for a philospher, of course, because rational thought is in peril if the thinker cannot be seen as being in full command of his utterances. Irresponsible views such as Mr. Derrida's are better left to poets, who may positively welcome such voluptuous surrender to the surfaces of language.

title: THE ENIGMA OF KURT WEILL

title: Jailing a Judge
description: Many politicians have tried over the last decade to facilitate the installation of cable television service in the outer boroughs of New York. So far, two of them have been convicted of committing crimes in the process. Last week, the first of those convicted, Justice Francis X. Smith, the former Queens administrative judge, was sentenced to serve a year in prison. Justice Smith was found guilty in July of lying to a grand jury about meetings and conversations he had with representatives of a cable television company and two friends, the late Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes and John A. Zaccaro, a real estate broker and husband of Geraldine A. Ferraro. Mr. Zaccaro is to go on trial this month on charges of acting with Mr. Manes to extort a payoff from the cable television company. Justice Smith contended that he had done nothing but try to help out some ''honest businessmen'' and had acted in the best interests of the city. He said he would appeal his conviction.

The insistently idealistic Mr. Murrow added: ''If newness be its vice, let boldness be its virtue.'' Over the years, however, boldness would be restrained; like the overall national public-TV system that was launched five years later, the station has been hobbled by acute financing problems.

title: Details That Make the Difference
description: A wider lapel, full-cut, tapering trousers, a generous slice of shirt front - these are a few of the details defining the new trans-Atlantic look. And at a time when men's wear has struck a decisively cosmopolitan note, they may be the first visible signals of the wearer's savoir-faire. The peripatetic life consisting of coast-to-coast commutes and business weekends abroad calls for this kind of cultural camouflage. Accordingly, even the most rigidly chauvinistic dresser may bend from time to time, donning, if he's Italian, an English spread collar, or, if he's American, a rope-shoulder coat. For in fashion's expanding lexicon, such refinements, once thought showy or exotic, have become increasingly acceptable. The world has grown smaller, some experts maintain. And so, while ventless jackets and similar innovations may still seem foreign to some, they have gained credibility. We are far from one world sartorially, admits Norman Karr, the executive director of the Men's Fashion Association of America, ''but fashion has a less geographic identification.''

title: The Bork Philosophy: Personal Privacy and Majority Rule

In criticizing a major 1965 Supreme Court decision on the right to marital privacy, he stressed the importance of majority rule. He has repeated this criticism in recent years. Following are excerpts from that article: ''The problem may be illustrated by Griswold v. Connecticut, in many ways a typical decision of the Warren Court. Griswold struck down Connecticut's statute making it a crime, even for married couples, to use contraceptive devices. If we take the principle of the decision to be a statement that Government may not interfere with any acts done in private, we need not even ask about the principle's dubious origin for we know at once that the Court will not apply it neutrally. The Court, we may confidently predict, is not going to throw constitutional protection around heroin use or sexual acts with a consenting minor.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE GIFT OF FIRE. By Richard Mitchell. (Fireside/ Simon & Schuster. Paper, $7.95.) In his book ''Less Than Words Can Say,'' and his journal ''The Underground Grammarian,'' Richard Mitchell, a professor of classics at Glassboro State College in New Jersey, has fired broadsides at literary obfuscation. With these 12 linked essays, he attempts something different - to define education. Mr. Mitchell's title is an allusion to Aeschylus: the mythic fire Prometheus gave to humanity was more than actual fire; it was ''the mind's grasp of itself,'' the power ''not only to think, but to think about thinking.'' True education, likewise, is more than learning to solve problems. Education means learning to weigh values and master oneself. It is that which makes us ''able to be good.'' Teaching is not lecturing or role-modeling. It is providing ''an irresistible impulse to thoughtfulness.'' But teaching can only encourage learning; the real impetus must come from within. The examined life, the rearing of the unthinking child within the reasoning adult, is not ''set aside for some temporary purpose and put aside at a certain age. It is the principal business of life.'' These essays could have been more closely reasoned, and some of the examples may have helped the author work out his thoughts more than they will help readers trying to follow him. Even so, this book should educate many.

title: PART-TIME TEACHER: A TROUBLING PATTERN
description: EVERY now and again lately, some recently employed part-time college teacher charges into public print like Don Quixote tilting at the windmills of full-time privilege and institutional intransigence. Always idealistic and usually ill-informed, these stories tell the personal gratifications of teaching a college class or two and the horrible frustrations of poor compensation and an absence of career opportunities.

title: Unexpected Influx of College Freshmen Puts Strain on Campus Housing
description: At the start of the academic year, Boston University had 500 more students than beds. The overflow students were placed in three local hotels, where they lived in $100-a-day rooms complete with bellhops to carry luggage, wake-up calls every morning and turned-down beds every night.

title: LEVINE CONDUCTS A NEW 'ARIADNE'
description: LEAD: WITH AN OBVIOUSLY calculated timeliness, the first compact disk recording of Richard Strauss' ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' coincides with the Metropolitan Opera's current revival of this challenging work, which will have its first perfomance of the season on Sept. 23.

title: Next Week; Can the Giants Repeat as Champions?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Nominee for U.S. Ethics Job
description: President Reagan will nominate Frank Q. Nebeker, a Federal appeals judge, to be director of the Office of Government Ethics, which monitors potential conflicts of interest among top Federal officials. Judge Nebeker, 57 years old , became an associate judge in the District of Court of Appeals in 1969 after 16 years in other Federal jobs. If confirmed, he would succeed David H. Martin, who has resigned.

title: A Historic Hub Where the Sun Sets on Maui
description: A wag, perusing a map of the Pacific, once ruefully remarked that the Hawaiian islands were the ''furthest near islands'' he could find. Queried why, then, he was journeying 2,100 miles from his home base in San Francisco to visit, he replied that he had been enticed there by Mark Twain who described Hawaii as ''the loveliest fleet of islands that lies anchored in any ocean.''

title: HERBICIDE'S AFTERMATH: DISBELIEF, THEN SHOCK
description: THEY shared a common suburban bond, although they came from different communities and different backgrounds. The 55 Nassau County homeowners all adhered to the suburban creed - ''keeping up the property'' - as Judith Simon of Manhasset Hills puts it. To insure that their grass was the greenest, their lawns free of weeds and insects, each homeowner had hired a lawn-care company.

title: THE DAY THE BARD PLAYED JERSEY CITY
description: LAST Sunday, the final night of this past summer's first New Jersey Theater Jubilee in the old Central Railroad Terminal Building at Liberty State Park -a four-week festival of free performances by six of the state's professional theaters - the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival went on with ''The Winter's Tale,'' which has been referred to as Shakespeare's ''late romance.''

title: Iona's Gaels Strive For a Better Season
description: RICHARD PEZZELLA rose from his bar stool in disbelief. ''You mean we haven't won a game since I graduated?'' he asked.

title: Chicanery in Campaign for a Convention
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE POET, MANY VOICES
description: LEAD: SELECTED POEMS 1957-1987. By W. D. Snodgrass. 270 pp. New York: Soho Press. $19.95.

title: Dining Out Under the 80 Percent Rule
description: THE provision of the new tax law that limits the deduction for business meals to 80 percent of the cost has been in force for about eight months, and so far the main effect has been to create an enormous paperwork burden as accounting systems are adjusted for the change.

title: Preserving Views: Waterfront Village Tour
description: Anybody who is worried about the state of the city's waterfront and proposals to develop it can join a like-minded group next Sunday for a tour of Greenwich Village's segment of Hudson River frontage.

title: LEGISLATOR IS LAUDED ON CABLE TV ISSUE
description: I was disappointed to read your article, ''Cable TV Campaign Criticized'' [ Aug. 23 ] .

title: City's Third Chinatown Is Emerging in Brooklyn
description: In the late afternoons, crowds of Chinese workers pour out of the subway station, headed home. Chinese women push baby carriages along the avenue. Chinese children ride skateboards down the street. And in high-ceilinged warehouses, Chinese women bend over sewing machines.

title: Q & A
description: Precautions Question: I am apprehensive about having our money stolen during a lengthy foreign trip. What advice can you offer? - P. W., Syracuse Answer: Among several precautions that can be taken is to carry only enough cash for one day. The rest should be in traveler's checks. Travelers should carry a list of the serial numbers of their traveler's checks and keep it in a place other than where the checks are carried.

title: WILANDER, LENDL ADVANCE TO FINAL
description: On a cool, gray day that was brightened by the anticipation that Jimmy Connors would be able to give the fans at the Stadium Court one more page for their scrapbooks, the most notable event in the men's semifinals of the United States Open was a 15-minute wildcat strike, staged by Mats Wilander and Stefan Edberg, two Swedes protesting the 10 A.M. starting time of their match.

title: G.M. Recalls Compact Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation announced recalls Thursday of about 261,000 1985 and 1986 two-door compact cars for door lock repairs. G.M. also recalled about 13,000 1988 Chevrolet and G.M.C. C-K pickup trucks for various reasons, including cruise control corrections and front end repairs. None of the problems caused accidents or injuries, and G.M. initiated the recalls, a company spokesman said.

title: Arbitration Is Not a Cure-All
description: THE recent Supreme Court decision in Shearson/American Express Inc., et al. v. McMahon, et al. has fortified speculation that the day may be at hand when courts will routinely order contracting parties who have included arbitration clauses in their contracts to arbitrate antitrust claims. Two years ago in Mitsubishi Motors Corporation v. Soler Chrysler-Plymouth Inc. the Supreme Court compelled arbitration of an antitrust claim under an arbitration clause in a foreign automobile dealer franchise agreement.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: U.S. Distributor Of Korea Games Tickets Awaited

title: SOVIET PROMOTING DISSIDENTS IN U.S.
description: A California protester who was critically injured there last week when he was struck by a train during a demonstration against American support for the Nicaraguan rebels has been embraced by the Soviet Union as the newest in a line of American dissidents.

title: Beware the Gambit From Unexpected Quarters
description: WHEN a solid positional player throws a gambit at you, it's doubly time to be wary because it is not the same thing as a habitual gambiteer's doing what he does so often under a variety of conditions.

title: ONE WALKER STEPS TO THE WATER'S EDGE
description: I WAS walking my dog the other morning. It was raining out, and it was too early, too wet and too cold. I started thinking about my life, which at a time like this naturally starts to look pretty dull and gray. So I figured I ought to consider what it is that's important to me, that I really enjoy doing.

title: CARRYING YOUTH TO EXCESS
description: LEAD: THE NEO-PAGANS Rupert Brooke and the Ordeal of Youth. By Paul Delany. Illustrated. 270 pp. New York: The Free Press. $24.95.

title: SPIKE LEE'S STEREOTYPES
description: Spike Lee remarks, ''Woody Allen, he can do a film about Manhattan . . . and he doesn't have a single black person in the film.''

title: 53 Food Sites Are Cited for Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 22 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Joy Rosenberg Is Wed
description: Joy Hally Rosenberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Richard Rosenberg of Saddle River, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to Carl Christoph Horstmann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodor Horstmann of Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Dr. Kurt Metzger, assisted by Rabbi Ronald Gerson, officiated at the Pierre in New York. The couple graduated in 1986 from Lehigh University.

title: Durelle M. I. Corrigan Wed to Richard Green
description: At St. Timothy's Episcopal Church in Fairfield, Conn., Durelle Melinda Isabel Corrigan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice P. Corrigan of Fairfield, was married yesterday to Richard Scott Green, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rhoades Green of Waitsfield, Vt.

title: Expensive New Housing Finding a Ready Market
description: A YEAR ago Blanche Sprague approved plans for decorating five model apartments to help sell 340 condominium units now under construction within the old Barbizon Plaza Hotel on Central Park South. This summer, before the interior designers could begin, she canceled work on all but one.

title: NORTH SOUVENIRS DRAW FEW TAKERS
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North may have captured the hearts of a wide segment of the American people for a brief spell this summer, but he did not capture their wallets.

title: THE HIGHER TRUTH DEPARTS FROM ANTELOPE, ORE.
description: LEAD: THE GOLDEN GURU The Strange Journey of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh. By James S. Gordon. Illustrated. 248 pp. Lexington, Mass.: The Stephen Greene Press. $19.95.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Nashville;
A Golf Club Flees the Traffic
description: LEAD: A NASHVILLE development company, C.R.C. Equities, has begun construction of a new subdivision and is planning a second after having made a deal to acquire a golf club that had occupied its land since 1915.

title: The 'Model T' Still Has Some Life
description: VISITORS came to the PC Expo '87 exhibition in New York earlier this month seeking solutions for their companies' personal computer needs. But many of them were overwhelmed by the sudden proliferation of hardware and software choices and went home with more questions than answers.

title: How Hard It Is To Change
description: ARTICLE V. The Congress ... propose Amendments to this Constitution, or ... shall call a Convention....

title: A Guide to Antique Shops . . . And Art Galleries
description: Hong Kong painting may be the territory's best bargain. In the last 20 years, several styles of art that are distinctly native to Hong Chang, director of Chinese painting for Sotheby's, which holds auctions in Hong Kong in May and November, has started to include the work of living Hong Kong artists in these auctions. According to Mr. Chang, Hong Kong artists have developed a unique character that is an amalgam of traditional Chinese art and Western modernism. ''Appreciation of the character of the art of Hong Kong artists is very likely to increase over time as international exposure is given to Hong Kong art,'' he said.

title: Parading the Constitution
description: THURSDAY IS THE NATIONAL holiday marking the bicentennial of the Constitution, and, according to Barnett Lipton, the ''We the People 200'' parade to be held that day in Philadelphia might be the largest ever. Lipton is creative director of the special-events division of Radio City Music Hall Productions, which is producing the parade for We the People 200, the nonprofit group that has been arranging events in the Constitution's hometown all year long. ''There'll be 20,000-plus participants,'' Lipton says of Thursday's fete, whose $3.5 million cost has been covered by public and private donations.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING FIRE BLIGHT FROM ORCHARDS
description: LEAD: IF you've ever seen a pear or apple orchard or even a single tree that has been severely infected with fire blight, you will understand why it is among the more devastating diseases of these fruits. It is not uncommon for a young orchard to be destroyed within a few weeks by this disease.

title: HOLY CROSS TRICKS ARMY
description: Gordon Lockbaum's candidacy for the Heisman Trophy began today on a note of deception. So aware were the Army defenders of the Holy Cross back that they chased him when he did not have the football, which was most of the time.

title:
The View From:Waterford;
A UTILITY-ENRICHED TOWN FACES A DWINDLING WINDFALL
description: LEAD: AIDED by hefty tax revenues from Northeast Utilities for the Millstone nuclear power complex, Waterford is used to its special status in New London County. Now, the wealthiest town in the state's southeastern region is working on a tougher task - adjusting as Millstone's share of the municipal tax burden slowly diminishes.

title: Dole Considering Resignation To Join Husband's Campaign
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole, the only woman in the Cabinet, is considering quitting the Administration in the next few weeks to work full time for the Presidential candidacy of her husband, Senator Bob Dole.

title: UNMALLING AMERICA: W. Scott Toombs Building a Cozy 'Village' for Suburban Shoppers
description: A FEW weeks before the opening of Princeton Forrestal Village, W. Scott Toombs, its developer, is puttering along Main Street in a golf cart, inspecting the storefronts that are the heart of his ''village'' - a hotel, office and shopping combine. The signs reflect a most up-to-date assemblage of retailers - Polo, Esprit, Cacharel - but the goal is for the overall development to give off the warm glow of a seasoned New England town.

title: RAIDS DON'T DETER ANTI-GANDHI PAPER
description: When hundreds of Government agents raided the offices of India's largest newspaper chain last week, they confirmed what everyone already knew. Day after day, the Indian Express chain is Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's most powerful nemesis.

title: Political Notes; Bronx Strife May Involve The Cuomos
description: A convention in the Bronx to nominate two Democratic candidates for the State Supreme Court is developing into a major political struggle that could involve Governor Cuomo and his wife, Matilda.

title: New Baltimore Stadiums Likely
description: Many baseball fans in Baltimore can now envision an opening day for the Orioles in 1990 with a better team and a new stadium.

title: NEBRASKA DEFEATS U.C.L.A.
description: Steve Taylor, who set a rushing mark for Nebraska quarterbacks last week, threw a school-record five touchdown passes today as the second-ranked Cornhuskers ended Gaston Green's string of eight 100-yard rushing games and defeated U.C.L.A., 42-33.

title: Anne Finn and Mark E. Nelson Wed in Connecticut
description: Anne Finn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Macy Finn of Sharon, Conn., was married there yesterday to Mark Eric Nelson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred F. Nelson of Elmira, N.Y. The Rev. James F. Pilon performed the ceremony at St. Bernard Roman Catholic Church.

title: Radon Tests Are Urged for Homes in Parts of Jersey
description: All residents of Sussex, Warren and Hunterdon Counties and portions of eight other counties are being urged by the State Environmental Protection Commissioner to have their homes tested for radon ''as soon as practical.''

title: Pop: David Rudder's Soul-Calypso Mixture
description: DAVID RUDDER has shaken up pop music in Trinidad.

title: Nicole Bourgois Marries Kim Elliman
description: Nicole Ann Bourgois, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Bourgois of New York and Geneva, and Christopher J. Elliman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Scales Elliman of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas F. Pike, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich.

title: LOT-SPLITTING IRKS GREAT NECK
description: THE Great Neck peninsula as depicted in F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Great Gatsby'' is one of wealth and palatial mansions on sprawling estates. Some sections of the area today, however, are becoming so overdeveloped that residents are fighting the congestion, lack of privacy and strain on community services more commonly associated with city life.

title: Cable TV
description: Some old favorites appear on cable this week. To start with, there's John Huston's graphic version of Stephen Crane's ''Red Badge of Courage'' (1951), depicting the Civil War through the eyes of a naive young soldier (Audie Murphy). It's showing on Monday morning at 10 on Cinemax. Another haunting drama is ''One-Eyed Jacks'' (1961), with Marlon Brando directing himself as a vengeful outlaw and Karl Malden as a former pal turned sheriff. Brooding and a bit uneven, the movie was beautifully photographed in the Southwest. Tune in on WHT on Wednesday at 9 A.M. and 8 P.M.

title: Wendy Wear Walker Becomes a Bride
description: At the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn., Wendy Wear Walker, a daughter of George Herbert Walker 3d of St. Louis and Sandra Kasper of New York, was married yesterday to Bruce Miles Cleveland Jr., the son of Mr. Cleveland of Forest Hills, Queens, and Nancy Cleveland of Williston, Vt. The Rev. Merton Rymph performed the ceremony.

title: Streetscapes: The New York Savings Bank; Landmark Hearing for 14th St. Building
description: ON Tuesday the Landmarks Preservation Commission will hold a public hearing on the old New York Savings Bank, at the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and 14th Street. The building has been the subject of controversy, with mysterious demolition, a stop-work order and an architect's plan for a tower addition that the owner's attorney says does not exist.

title: TO TEACHER, EVERYONE'S A COMIC
description: IT is said that those who can't, teach, and that is what Elliot Frank has done.

GARDENING;
KEEPING FIRE BLIGHT FROM ORCHARDS
description: LEAD: IF you've ever seen a pear or apple orchard or even a single tree that has been severely infected with fire blight, you will understand why it is among the more devastating diseases of these fruits. It is not uncommon for a young orchard to be destroyed within a few weeks by this disease.

title: A BATTLE TO PROTECT THE DELAWARE
description: JUST a little more than an hour from New York City, past the crush of the superhighways and over a few green ridges, a bitter struggle is raging along the Pennsylvania banks of the Delaware River, a struggle that will forever change the valley that runs the length of western New Jersey.

title: MOVIES
description: The Night Porter Starring Dirk Bogarde, Charlotte Rampling, Philippe Leroy and Gabrielle Ferzetti. Directed by Liliana Cavani. 1972. Rated R. Embassy Home Entertainment. 117 minutes. $24.95. The jacket copy on this cassette breathlessly describes it as a ''taut, suspenseful sensual delight'' - presumably for the discerning viewer who finds rape, sadism and death camps delightfully sensual. This movie wasn't easy to take in 1974 when it was first released in America, and after ''Shoah,'' the film seems even more to give off the scent of exploitation, a drama that in a sense reduces the Holocaust to a handy vehicle for titillation.

title: Why Weimar Fell
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPERPOWERS PREPARE FOR TALKS IN SPIRIT OF TOUGH-MINDED REALISM
description: SOVIET-American relations have entered a season of irony. Seven years after Ronald Reagan campaigned against the policy of detente, his Administration and the new Soviet leadership under Mikhail S. Gorbachev have revived major elements of that concept.

title: Pro-Solidarity Priest Honored
description: A crowd of several thousand people attended an outdoor funeral mass today for the Rev. Teofil Bogucki, a pro-Solidarity priest and strong opponent of the Communist Government.

title: CONSTITUTION TAKES CENTER STAGE
description: LEAD: WHEN church bells and firehouse sirens from Great Neck to Orient Point and Floral Park to Montauk start ringing at 4 P.M. Thursday, sounding 200 times, Long Islanders will join the rest of the nation in celebrating the bicentennial of the United States Constitution.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: FAMILY. By Caroline Leavitt. (Arbor House, $16.95.) Orphaned as a boy, Nick Austen spends his adult life trying to recapture the warmth and security of his early childhood. A deep-rooted fear of loss and abandonment, however, keeps him aloof. His anxieties are exacerbated by the sudden death of his adored first child, driving him to be an ''absent'' father to his second daughter, Robin, in the belief that he can somehow protect his family by not getting too involved.

title: Alice Storey Wed To D. D. Thorpe
description: Alice Leovy Storey, a daughter of Mrs. Charles Burlingham Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., and James Moorfield Storey of Boston, was married yesterday to David Dean Thorpe, a son of Mrs. Kenneth Wagenbach of New York and Palm Beach Shores, Fla., and Robert L. Thorpe of Funchal, Madeira. The Rev. Jack Smith, the chaplain of the Groton School and an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McGrath Jr., a brother-in-law and a sister of the bride, in Windham, Conn.

title: India Is Slashing Spending to Help Fight Drought
description: India has slashed nearly $600 million from its military, railroad, telecommunications and other budgets as part of a drive to find new resources to fight the drought that has ruined the summer crops in much of the country.

title: DIFFERENT MESSAGES TO THE HIGH-TECH GOD
description: ''SHOW me a man with no irregular heart beats, and I'll show you a heartless man.''

title: Albatross-Watching In New Zealand
description: Dunedin, on the east coast of New Zealand's remote south island, is the only city in the world that counts among its residents the royal albatross. The huge but graceful seabird that compelled Coleridge's ''Ancient Mariner'' to repeat his story of death and repentance spends 87 percent of its life at sea, circumnavigating the globe. It comes to land only to breed.

title: A Gay 'Love Story'
description: E. M. FORSTER'S LITERARY EXECUTORS -the distinguished Fellows of King's College, Cambridge - were reportedly delighted by the film that Ismail Merchant and James Ivory made of his ''Room With a View.'' But when the two men approached them for permission to adapt the great novelist's ''Maurice'' for the screen, all was donnish consternation and dismay. Wouldn't some other of Forster's books make a better film? Would any other be more, well, suitable?

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'AMERICAN WOMEN ARTISTS' The Connecticut Gallery in Marlborough opens its version today of ''American Women Artists, 1830 to 1930.'' Other galleries in the state are also presenting versions of the theme, and a national exhibition of ''American Women Artists, 1830 to 1930,'' organized by the new National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington, D.C., arrives at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford next Sunday. The Marlborough show includes the works of such 19th-century artists as Fanny and Jenny Burr, Dorothea Litzinger, Anna Hyatt Huntington, Bessie Potter Vonnah and Ruth Nickerson Greacen. Also featured are works by such contemporary Connecticut artists as Carol Anthony, Ilse Getz, Elizabeth MacDonald and Judith Streeter. At a reception from 1 to 5 P.M. today the Arioso Trio will perform works by female composers, and there will be discussions by Helen Fusscas, the gallery's owner, and Deborah Frizzell, its director. Additional discussions and films are scheduled through Oct. 11, when the show closes. The Connecticut Gallery is at 4 Austin Drive. Daily viewing hours are from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday and from 1 to 5 P.M. Sunday (295-9544). A list of participating galleries in ''American Women Artists'' and information about lectures, concerts and other performances may be obtained by calling the Wadsworth Atheneum at 278-2670, ext. 361. BOATING SAFETY COURSE The United States Power Squadron's Lake Candlewood contingent will hold a free 6-week, 10-session boating course at 7:30 P.M. on Tuesdays and Thursdays in the Danbury High School. More than 450 power squadrons are operated by local boaters around the country to promote water safety. With no licensing requirements in Connecticut, the Power Squadron offers an opportunity for learning how to safely operate a boat. The course applies to outboard, inboard or sailing craft. It is conducted by an expert volunteer, covering such topics as boat handling under adverse conditions, rules of the road, compass and chart basics, boat trailering, seamanship and common emergencies, running lights and equipment and in-land boating. Registration will be held before the first class at 7:30 P.M. Tuesday. A $15 fee is charged for course materials and text. For more information call 744-5844. GRANTS FOR ARTISTS Artists interested in applying for $5,000 grants in poetry, playwriting, fiction, music composition or choreography, may attend one of two remaining workshops conducted by the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, distributor of the grants. It is scheduled from 5:30 to 7:30 P.M. Tuesday at the Cummings Arts Center of Connecticut College in New London, and from 5:30 to 7:30 P.M. Wednesday at the Hartt School of Music at the University of Hartford. Those attending the workshops will be instructed on eligibility, the selection process, developing proposals and completing applications. Participants will be offered presentations by artists and lawyers for the arts, who will discuss the implications of the new tax laws on grants. The workshop is free and registration is not required. For more information, call 566-4770. $90ELEANOR CHARLES

title: MARYLAND STOPS VIRGINIA BY 21-10
description: A fumbled pitchout on a 2-point conversion attempt with 1 minute 18 seconds to play spoiled Virginia's comeback bid for a tie as Maryland held on for a 21-19 Atlantic Coast Conference victory today.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: CRYSTAL By Walter Dean Myers. 198 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $12.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: BRAZILIANS STRUGGLE AGAINST GLOOM AND ECONOMIC DISARRAY
description: AFTER surviving two decades of military dictatorship, Brazil's innate sense of optimism has been battered by the political uncertainty and economic disarray that have followed the return of civilian rule 30 months ago. Quite uncharacteristically, gloom has now become the fashion.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: WHEN the East Rutherford-based Becton Dickinson Division of Becton Dickinson & Company transfers its medical products operation to plants in Nebraska, Utah and Puerto Rico at the end of September, the 250 displaced employees will get help in training and finding new jobs through a new program of the state's Department of

title: From Hazelwood to High Court
description: AMENDMENT I. Congress shall make no law ... abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press....

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE INHUMAN CONDITION, by Clive Barker. (Pocket, $3.95.) In ''The Body Politic,'' one of five tales here by Clive Barker, the young British writer of horror stories, two hands sever themselves from their owner and lead a bloody revolution, liberating their oppressed brothers and sisters. ''It's a measure of Mr. Barker's cool control that he makes this bad dream seem not only creepily disturbing but plausible,'' Ken Tucker said here last year. ''Try to imagine 'The Texas Chainsaw Massacre' with a screenplay by V. S. Pritchett.'' SILENT PARTNERS: The Legacy of the Ape Language Experiments, by Eugene Linden. (Ballantine, $3.95.) When disillusionment, bickering and recent cutbacks in Federal funding undermined the attempt to teach sign language to our fellow primates, laboratories were faced with a difficult disposal problem: what to do with unwanted specimens that many scientist-trainers had come to think of as friends. In this sad story of what happened to the apes, Eugene Linden tempts us to stretch our definition of who, or what, deserves the rights accorded to the sentient. ''Kind, quiet and fair, Mr. Linden's book is not only a diagnosis of the cruelty and confusion it describes, but also an antidote,'' our reviewer, Ursula K. Le Guin, wrote in 1986. TONGUES OF FLAME, by Mary Ward Brown. (Washington Square Press/Pocket Books, $5.95.) The author, who has spent her life in Alabama, writes short stories about Southerners whose ingrained, carefully delineated world views have left them unequipped for the modern world. Last year our reviewer, Kathryn Morton, said these tales are ''well written'' and ''delivered in a measured, caring voice''; they won for their author the Hemingway Award for Best First Fiction. LYNDON: An Oral Biography, by Merle Miller. (Ballantine, $5.95.) Some critics have called ''oral biography'' an easy way out: journalism becomes tape-recording and what emerges is stenography, not prose. This new edition of Merle Miller's life of Lyndon B. Johnson is a reminder that, when used well, the technique can produce what Anthony Lewis, writing here in 1980, called ''a coherent, sensitive, fascinating biography.'' THE BOOK OF ABRAHAM, by Marek Halter. Translated by Lowell Bair. (Dell, $4.95.) Spanning two millenniums of Jewish history through the story of one family, this impassioned novel ''suffers from its wide reach,'' Frederic Morton said here last year, but still it is ''spectacular.'' Marek Halter's ''ethical instincts help unify the book, drawing together parts that in the hands of another writer would be disparate. . . . Only an imagination as learned, as indomitable as Mr. Halter's could have even conceived 'The Book of Abraham.' '' DREAMGIRL: My Life as a Supreme, by Mary Wilson with Patricia Romanowski and Ahrgus Juilliard. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) The singer's bittersweet memoir, in which her fellow Supreme, Diana Ross, is cast as an overpowering prima donna, ''keeps nostalgic gush and embittered polemic to a minimum,'' Milo Miles wrote here last year. ''Never [ before ] has a Motown veteran spoken out as a first-person witness from inside Hitsville.'' The same publisher is also reissuing Nelson George's WHERE DID OUR LOVE GO: The Rise & Fall of the Motown Sound ($9.95). In 1986, our reviewer, Larry Birnbaum, said that Mr. George's style is too breezy, but that he admired the book's ''skillful interweaving of artistic and commercial history.'' TAILOR'S DUMMY, by Irving Weinman. (Fawcett/ Crest, $3.95.) When a wealthy New York art dealer is found dead in a Brooklyn warehouse, the detective assigned to the case is a magna cum laude Harvard University graduate married to an art historian. His erudite investigation makes for a novel that is ''fast-moving and clear,'' Newgate Callendar said here last year. THE PROFESSOR AND THE PROSTITUTE: And Other True Tales of Murder and Madness, by Linda Wolfe. (Ballantine, $3.95.) Attempting to make ''real events read like invented tales,'' the author tells nine bizarre true stories. It is the ''fascinating'' title selection, about a rotund Tufts University medical professor and his obsession with a manipulative young prostitute (whom he later kills), that makes this collection worthwhile, Jonathan Coleman said here in 1986. THEOPHILUS NORTH, by Thornton Wilder. (Carroll & Graf, $4.95.) Through a combination of chance and indecision, an unemployed schoolteacher finds himself in Newport, R.I., where he becomes a tutor to the children of the rich and the town's much-needed spiritual adviser. This episodic novel, which turned out to be Thornton Wilder's last, is ''extraordinarily entertaining,'' Granville Hicks said here in 1973, though ''sometimes it comes recklessly close to sentimentality.'' THE SOVIET PARADOX: External Expansion, Internal Decline, by Seweryn Bialer. (Vintage, $9.95.) Written before the word glasnost became commonly known in this country, this book by a respected Columbia University authority on the Soviet Union argues that bureaucratic inertia and an entrenched elite will keep Mikhail S. Gorbachev from initiating the radical decentralization necessary to save his country's overmanaged economy. Last year our reviewer, Peter Reddaway, said that this ''penetrating, often brilliant analysis'' should provide American leaders with ''a major instrument'' for preparing the public for the prolonged United States-Soviet political conflict that lies ahead. IN THE MIRO DISTRICT, by Peter Taylor. (Carroll & Graf, $3.95.) The author of ''A Summons to Memphis'' won the Pulitzer Prize for his fiction about aristocratic Tennesseans. ''I don't think he even knows about it,'' said the President's secretary. But regardless, she added, he won't be there. While other pet owners put flowers on the graves of their beloved Prince, Cherub or Barney Boy, and pause for a moment of silence at the 1 P.M. ceremony to ''honor,'' according to Bide-A-Wee press release, ''those pets that were loved and lost,'' the Nixons won't be around. But then, according to the cemetery manager, Greta Tom, the former first family has never visited the gravesite of Checkers, the pet that saved Mr. Nixon's career.

title: A Winning Loser

Celebrating his 100th birthday last week, Mr. Landon said he expected the 1988 Presidential campaign to be a ''pretty lively race.'' ''I predict it's going to be entertaining,'' he said. A few days earlier, President and Mrs. Reagan dropped by the former Kansas Governor's home in Topeka to offer their personal congratulations. Mr. Reagan praised Mr. Landon as an early opponent of ''too much government spending,'' referring to his efforts to balance the Kansas budget in 1934. But in those days, Mr. Reagan rather favored big spending. In 1936, he was one of 28 million voters who contributed to Franklin Delano Roosevelt's landslide victory over Mr. Landon, who won only the states of Maine and Vermont.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CUISINE NOVELLA. By Antoine Laurent. (Viking, $17.95.) This first novel dealing with the relationship between cooking and storytelling is indeed an original, although it finds honorable antecedents in the fiction of John Fowles and Robertson Davies. Annabelle Fleury, a chic young Parisian fashion designer, meets the mysterious Marquis de St. Lyre in a Boulevard St. Germain brasserie. He commiserates with her over a disastrous champignons a la provencale, and a strange proposition follows: he will teach her the secrets of haute cuisine if she will accompany him to a restaurant he owns in the south of France. Aboard the Mistral the lessons begin. It soon becomes clear that Annabelle is being given more than cooking instructions; she is also receiving a crash course in the mysteries of storytelling. The principles governing both, the Marquis insists, are quite the same. Annabelle's instructions during the overnight journey grow increasingly bizarre and magical as the Marquis's curriculum in fantastic transformations through time and space unfolds. Finally, Annabelle must tell a story of her own. Antoine Laurent's concept is an audacious one but he quickly paints - or writes - himself into a corner. In a narrative so obsessed with the techniques of storytelling, his own story must be brilliant, and unfortunately it is not. Poorly paced, at times confusing and full of half-baked theories, ''Cuisine Novella'' never quite achieves the quality of ''sympathy'' the author sees as essential to a story's success. Yet in its mellifluous flow of language it is an elegant, literate achievement that marks Mr. Laurent as a writer of unusual gifts.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Randolph Leads by Four: Sam Randolph, the 1985 United States Amateur golf champion seeking his first PGA Tour victory, charged past two veteran pros, Lee Trevino and Curtis Strange, and took a four-stroke lead after the third round of the $500,000 Bank of Boston Classic yesterday in Sutton, Mass. Trailing Trevino by two strokes and Strange by one when the round began, Randolph carded seven birdies without a bogey for a seven-under par 64 and a 54-hole total of 199. Randolph, a 23-year-old former Southern Cal star, was just one stroke off the course record of 63 for Pleasant Valley Country Club's 7,110-yard layout. Trevino dropped out of a share of the lead with a bogey on the eighth green. After making the turn, he bogeyed three consecutive holes. He finished with a 72 and a 54-hole total of 205.(AP) Rizzo Grabs Lead: Patti Rizzo took advantage of a disastrous finish by Jan Stephenson yesterday to take a one-shot lead after two rounds of the Cellular One-Ping Golf Championship in Portland, Ore. Rizzo shot a three-under-par 69 for a 36-hole total of seven-under-par 137, one shot ahead of her best friend, Jane Geddes. Stephenson, who was cruising along at eight under through 15 holes, had a bogey on the 15th and a double-bogey on the 16th to drop into a four-way tie for third at five-under-par 139. Also at five-under on the 6,233-yard Columbia-Edgewater Country Club course were Nancy Lopez, Elaine Crosby and Hollis Stacy. Chris Johnson, the first-round leader, and Marta Figueras-Dotti were three shots back of the leader at four-under-par 140.

title: Q AND A
description: Fee for Late Rent Question: I live in New Jersey but I own a house in New York State. I signed a lease with a tenant for the house and he agreed to a clause in the lease that an extra $30 would be charged for rents that were more than five days late. We also agreed that a 2 percent handling fee would be charged on the escrow account containing the security deposit. Now my tenant claims that these clauses are illegal. Is this true? . . . H. S., West Windsor, N.J. Answer: Late fees are permissible for residential leases as long as they are reasonable. According to David L. Smith, a lawyer who specializes in real-estate matters, in general, a charge of no more than 5 percent of the monthly rent is considered reasonable. Mr. Smith noted, for example, that in a 1982 case in Spring Valley, N.Y., a County Court held that a landlord's charge of a $50 late fee on a monthly rent of $405 a month was excessive.

title: NDJAMENA SENDS TROOPS INTO LIBYA
description: Chad, a landlocked equatorial African country of 5 million with a per capita income of less than $100 a year, had rarely attracted world attention in its 27 years of independence until it started fighting with its neighbor Libya several years ago. The concern is not so much over Chad, which has little to buy and sell in the world, but with its enemy's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The Libyan leader's heavily equipped armed forces have been occupying parts of a disputed desert area of northern Chad. From time to time there are battles, and victories for Chad are interpreted as humiliating defeats for Colonel Qaddafi. Last weekend Chad reported that its troops had raided Libya for the first time: a foray to the Matan as Sarra air base 60 miles across the border, killing 1,713 Libyan soldiers. On Monday, Libya responded by sending warplanes over Ndjamena, Chad's capital, formerly Fort Lamy, and one of them was reportedly shot down by French forces. At week's end, Libya and Chad agreed to a cease-fire proposed by the Organization of African Unity, then almost immediately the Chadian embassy in Paris claimed that Libya had violated it.

Sigfried Bing was an entrepreneur in the decorative arts in Paris at that time. Under the sponsorship of the museum's junior committee, the galleries will be transformed into an elegant setting evoking turn-of-the-century Paris. French foods will be served throughout the museum and in the garden. After 1, the party will move to the Surf Club, 415 East 91st Street. Tickets $75, at the door. Information: 212-860-6868. description: LEAD: THE on-again, off-again Democratic primary for mayor of Mount Vernon is definitely off again, and this time there will be no further appeals.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Gold and Silver Coins for the Winter Olympics
description: LEAD: THE Royal Canadian Mint has issued the final three coins in its program of commemoratives for the 1988 Winter Olympic Games in Calgary, Alberta. Two are one-ounce silver, the third is gold. All 11 coins in the set are legal tender.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on Aug. 30 about Vladimir Feltsman misidentified the ballet company Rudolf Nureyev was dancing with when he defected from the Soviet Union. It was the Kirov Ballet.

title: Fatal Shooting by Officers Stirs Charges of Brutality in Atlanta
description: The fatal shooting of a man by the police at a housing project has led to charges of brutality, and the medical examiner says the victim was shot six times, five times in the back at point-blank range.

title: ROAD PLAN GETS MIXED REVIEWS
description: LEAD: THE New York State Department of Transportation is proposing to widen a section of Route 25A in Mount Sinai, an affluent North Shore community, at a cost of $8 million. It may require condemning as many as 18 pieces of commercial property and cost an additional $7 million for the right-of-way along the 1.7-mile strip.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Richard F. Schneller 'A DISASTER JUST WAITING TO HAPPEN'
description: RICHARD F. SCHNELLER of Essex is the chairman of a committee preparing recommendations for changes to the state building code, a panel formed last May following the collapse of the L'Ambiance Plaza apartment complex in Bridgeport. L'Ambiance was being built in the lift-slab technique, but on April 23 as the 240-ton slabs were being jacked into place, it collapsed, killing 28 men.

title: SUMMER PEAKS CAST SHADOWS ON FUTURE COSTS
description: FOR the short run, increased pipeline capacity in the Middle East has eased worries of a possible cut-off of supplies coming through the Persian Gulf and a consequent series of price shocks that would stagger the economy. Indeed, at midweek, after a report from the International Energy Agency that Saudi Arabia, OPEC's pivotal member, had exceeded its quota last month, oil prices dipped below $19 a barrel on the world markets.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HARVEST MOON: Portrait of a Nursing Home. By Sallie Tisdale. (Holt, $17.95.) There are almost 24,000 nursing homes in the United States housing 2 million people and, with the population steadily aging, the health care business is booming. ''Harvest Moon'' is the portrait of a well-run institution in the Pacific Northwest, where the author, Sallie Tisdale, lives. It is staffed by compassionate, overworked and underpaid people. Some patients are young, victims of crippling accidents or degenerative sickness, but most are old, and the book is about them, the staff and the bonding between them. As a registered nurse and the author of one previous book, ''The Sorcerer's Apprentice: Tales of the Modern Hospital,'' Ms. Tisdale speaks knowledgeably about reforming Medicare and Medicaid regulations that bewilder patients and frustrate administrators. She also tackles tough ethical questions involved in caring for the terminally ill, and she even shares her thoughts about why she and others were drawn toward working in a nursing home. In her narrative, a young nurse's aide suggests that everyone in high school do her kind of work for one month, saying, ''They'd look at elderly people in a different way, they would know more about themselves and how life really goes.'' Short of that, there is ''Harvest Moon.''

title: Laurie Field, a Banker, Marries W. A. Ruegger

Ruegger was his brother's best man.

title:

A Sense of Drama

The road switchbacks wickedly, and my motorcycle revs with no complaints as I downshift into a left hairpin. Aiming for the cliff ahead, I slide my gaze up to the left and countersteer: the bike leans over hard.

title: A JUSTICE V. THE PRESIDENT
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall, the first black to sit on the United States Supreme Court, has become the first sitting member in recent memory to criticize a President still in office. In terms of civil rights, he said last week, President Reagan is at ''the bottom'' of United States Presidents.

title: Daily News and a Key Union Reach Pact With No '87 Raise
description: After months of deliberation, negotiators for the Daily News and its largest union agreed yesterday on a proposed three-year contract that would save the financially troubled paper $18 million and give the drivers no raise in pay this year.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: LEARNING TO MAKE QUALITY CONSUMER GOODS;
Fashion Gives Life to Soviet Reforms
description: LEAD: FOR many years the Soviet Union has borne the brunt of American jokes about the poor quality of its consumer goods. A 1985 Wendy's commercial ridiculed Soviet fashions by featuring a matronly Soviet woman dressed in a drab, potato sack-like dress. Cynics claim that Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to internationalize the Soviet economy are doomed because of the Russians' inability to produce world-class consumer goods.

title: NEW AID FOR REBELS IS PROPOSED BY SHULTZ
description: The Reagan Administration presented its proposal last week for $270 million in new aid over the next 18 months for the Nicaraguan rebels, provoking criticism from leading Congressional Democrats that the move could damage peace negotiations in Central America and warnings that it would be rejected by Congress. This early, sharply negative reaction came as Secretary of State George P. Shultz advocated the proposal Thursday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. He contended that unless the United States continued to support the insurgents, or contras, the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua would have little incentive to adhere to the provisions of a peace-process accord signed last month in Guatemala by the presidents of five Central American countries, including Nicaragua. The accord, which calls for cease-fires, amnesties and a restoration of democratic rights, is to take effect beginning Nov. 7. Opponents of the aid say that the Administration is supporting the violent overthrow of a government with which it still has diplomatic relations and that new contra funds would undercut the peace process.

We would feast outdoors on local, seasonal bounty as we looked out on the vineyards and Mont Ventoux. It turned out to be one of those rare weekends when everything that could have gone right went right, and sometimes even better than right.

title: Equal Opportunities
description: More than half the players in the National Football League are black, many of them among the game's most accomplished stars, but when their playing careers are over, blacks are rarely hired as N.F.L. coaches and front-office personnel. According to N.F.L. figures, while 55 percent of the players are black, there are no black head coaches on the 28 teams and members of minority groups account for only 41 of the 284 assistant coaches (14 percent) and 170 of the 1,400 nonplaying personnel (12 percent).

description: The fierce political battle over Judge Robert H. Bork, now moving toward contentious Senate hearings, has been marked by sharply contrasting images of what he really stands for and what he would do if confirmed for the Supreme Court.

title: CATCHING DUMPERS AT SEA IS DIFFICULT
description: ALTHOUGH Congress can pass stringent laws affecting illegal ocean dumpers -such as those who left a 50-mile swath of trash and medical waste off the New Jersey coast last month - there is little the Government can do to catch them, the Coast Guard says.

title: The Milan Forecast
description: NO MATTER WHAT THE ECONOMIC CLIMATE, the Italians can always be relied upon for invention and for style. Especially at the annual Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the world's most influential furniture fair, which opens in Milan Wednesday and runs through Sept. 21. Celebrated architects and designers - as well as young unknowns - exhibit their latest creations for the thousands of furniture buyers who shop the acres of showrooms hoping to spot new design trends and to stock their stores with fresh merchandise (which can appear in department and specialty stores in the United States as early as next spring). Some pieces are innovative, intended to make a social statement about what furniture should be; others are simply well-designed objects crafted from such traditional materials as sumptuous leathers, beautiful woods or more modern chrome, glass and steel.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SINGING ON THE TITANIC. By Perry Glasser. (University of Illinois, $11.95.) As the Titanic sank, the passengers on board sang hymns - surely an affirmative act in the face of impossible odds. And in almost all the stories in Perry Glasser's second collection the characters respond with the same optimism, their actions colored by the experience of loss or by the precariousness of their inner balance. At no time, however, do Mr. Glasser's characters sink. In ''Mexico,'' for instance, Doralee Jackson, a simple young woman from Iowa, has hooked herself up with the wrong man and driven to Mexico; she sings, or at least swaggers, when I wouldn't have thought it possible, and the author's sure prose and humanitarian spirit guide her out of a tight spot. Somewhat bleaker are ''Away Out and Over'' and ''What Doesn't Kill Me.'' Written from the point of view of desperate women, these pieces leave lasting impressions of bitterness; it is as if the author feels compelled to show some dark vision but must restrain his natural buoyancy to do so. Mr. Glasser does better with male narrators, as in ''Steering Clear,'' in which a father struggles to comfort his small daughters and himself when they are brought up short by another person's unhappiness. However, the writing can be uneven, occasionally forced, as in the title story: ''Eventually I had ten chocolate bars of varying degrees of nuttiness, six sandwiches of which only one had to be liverwurst. . . . Carrying all of it in my jacket, I felt like a shoplifting kangaroo.'' But the perceptions are usually acute. I only wish the author had been more playful, more daring -he's got the sense of story down, and of character; he just needs to let it all fly.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ST. JOHN DE CREVECOEUR: The Life of an American Farmer. By Gay Wilson Allen and Roger Asselineau. (Viking, $19.95.) From Tocqueville and Chateaubriand to Romain Gary and Jean-Francois Revel, French writers have paid celebratory and caustic attention to America. Two distinguished students of American culture have now collaborated on an agreeably written study of an 18th-century Frenchman, Michel-Guillaume Saint-Jean de Crevecoeur, who is the most interesting precursor of the better-known commentators who came after him. Crevecoeur came to North America as an officer in his king's army during the Seven Years' War, and after leaving military service under murky circumstances, settled in the Hudson Valley. He became, and proclaimed himself in a series of letters published to wide acclaim, an ''American farmer.'' The letters are a remarkable record of the mind of a member of the lesser European nobility - restless within both the prescribed limits and privileges of his rank - as he encounters the frontier experience in its idyllic and brutal aspects. The lacunae in Crevecoeur's written recollections of his life make it difficult for the authors to answer some of the more intriguing questions: why did he choose the uncertainty of farming in a remote country over the comfort of his inheritance in Normandy? Why did his early Anglophilia give way to a preference for upstart American republicans? The book also situates Crevecoeur less firmly than it might within the currents of contemporary French thought on the American phenomenon: how, for instance, did he judge the theory of Volney and Buffon that the climate and terrain of the American continent could never support an advanced civilization? Despite its limits, mostly enforced by the paucity of documents, this is a deft and unpretentious work; it gives a sense of the boisterous young nation through the eyes of a fascinated visitor who became an American himself.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'FOR USE AND DELIGHT' Several decades ago in Boston the Herb Society of America was formed by ''some very erudite ladies,'' said K. Doreen Willox, chairman of the Herb Fair to be held by the New York State unit from 11 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Thursday at the Old Race Track on Baxter Road in North Salem. During the brief hours that this unusual event takes place, visitors may purchase products grown or made by some of the 85 members. ''It's not like a rose society where you can join by paying dues,'' said Mrs. Willox, chairman of the fair. ''You have to be invited, and while you don't need to have your own herb garden, you must be knowledgable about herbs, attend at least three meetings a year and be willing to work on the fair.'' The society's motto is ''for use and delight,'' referring to the medicinal, culinary and aromatic properties of various herbs. Perennial herbs that may be purchased and planted at this time of year include sage, chives, wormwood (which Mrs. Willox noted was the base for absinthe and made a potent punch), thyme, lemon balm, sorrel and salvia, which she explained was one of 700 varieties and was in the sage family. Annuals, such as rosemary and some of the basils will be available in pots to keep indoors. A selection of herb breads, vinegars, mustards, jams, relishes and jellies will be for sale, along with dried arrangements, books, fragrances, crafts and such mementos as napkins, aprons and tote bags bearing the Herb Society logo. An educational exhibit and a raffle for tickets to a Broadway show, an Elizabeth yellow magnolia or a stone statue are additional features of the fair. For lunch, the members will serve hot soup, sandwiches, dessert and beverages. Because everything is under cover, the fair will be held rain or shine. To reach the site take I-684 to Exit 7, Purdys, then Route 116 east to North Salem Center and follow the signs. Parking and admission are free. For a copy of the Herb Society's unusual recipe book, send $10 to The Herb Society of America, 2 Independence Court, Concord, Mass. 07042.

title: 'No Bunk About Bogie'
description: Katharine Hepburn's unmistakable voice is in every word of THE MAKING OF THE AFRICAN QUEEN: Or, How I Went to Africa With Bogart, Bacall and Huston and Almost Lost My Mind (Knopf, $15.95). This slim memoir is as spirited, appealing and shrewdly elusive as its author. Writing in a talkative style full of detours and oh dear's, she looks back 36 years and recalls weeks in the former Belgian Congo, where her hut had straw matting over a mud floor and she was thrilled to have a better view than the Bogarts. ''Don't pretend. I know what you're wanting to know. Bogie. What was he like,'' she says. ''He liked to drink. He drank. . . . There was no bunk about Bogie.'' More often, we hear a jungle story of fire ants and polluted water. The richest memories sneak up on the reader -perhaps on the writer. Her friendship with John Huston - who died two weeks ago - was slow starting. She complained about the script; he showed off his riding boots to distract her. In time, though, they went elephant hunting together. This is the Hepburn we know: the woman who leaves ''Betty Bogart'' behind to fix the crew's lunch while she tracks elephants, who has the wit to see herself in a ''sort of white planter's suit,'' looking like a ''freckled female impersonator.'' The 45 black-and-white photographs include some of her in that suit and many nostalgic movie-set views. But the best are less familiar off-the-set shots. Bogart and Lauren Bacall eat breakfast in their robes, Hepburn and Huston ride a bike, in poses that suit the memoir's tone: artfully casual and happy.

title: Changing Stories
description: The public does not pay close attention to the stories behind Supreme Court cases, but Norma McCorvey of Dallas, better known as ''Jane Roe,'' decided to straighten things out anyway. When she filed a challenge to Texas's abortion law, which was to turn into the historic Roe v. Wade decision of 1973, she told reporters her pregnancy resulted from a gang-rape. But in a recent interview with the columnist Carl T. Rowan, Ms. McCorvey said it wasn't true. She was not raped at all, she said, but was so frustrated and bitter at being denied an abortion that she made up a compelling circumstance. A 21-year-old waitress at the time, too poor to go to a state with more liberal abortion laws, she gave birth and put her baby up for adoption. She never made the rape allegation in her suit, which led to the legalization of abortion in all 50 states. Her lawyer, Sarah Weddington, noted last week that the issue of rape was irrelevant to the Texas law, which made abortion illegal for everybody.

title: GLOSSARY OF A SCANDAL
description: It is rare that one finds inspired figures of speech ascribed to such ponderous speakers as our forthright Secretary of State, yet William Safire credits George P. Shultz with a ''creative oxymoron'' in the Secretary's description of Elliot Abrams's testimony as ''a combative apology.'' Mr. Shultz was apparently using the word ''apology'' in its original sense of justification or excuse, and not as expressive of regret; Shultz's phrase was more accurate than colorful. In fact, the artful oxymoron was conspicuously absent from the Iran-contra hearings, unless, of course, one counts that deafeningly silent one: military intelligence. GREGORY J. SEGRETI Annapolis, Md.

title: OUR ORCHESTRAS ARE SPLINTERING

There was Schoenberg's invention of the 12-tone method in the 1920's and, before that, Cipriano de Rore's rediscovery in the 16th century of the ancient Greek practice of letting words govern music, a notion that eventually gave birth to opera. I'm sure a case could be made for one or two other such events. However, most of the musical revolutions we read about every few years are actually little more than tics on the face of history.

The latest death, of Stephen Germershausen, 28 years old, occurred late Thursday in the Southern District, where a similar incident occurred Aug. 22. The other incident occurred in the Southeastern District lockup on Aug. 31.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Oxford Valley, Pa.: On the Way: Stores Galore
description: LEAD: A COMMERCIAL transformation is under way in Bucks County, the populous suburban region just north of Philadelphia and west of Princeton, N.J. Most of it appears to be focused on this bustling community in the county's southeastern corner.

title:
DINING OUT;
Something Jersey City Could Use
description: LEAD: IF THERE is one thing that burgeoning Jersey City would welcome for its influx of upwardly mobile young residents, it is a first-rate restaurant or two. And although early word of interesting food at the handsome new Henderson Town House was promising, recent samplings have found that its could use a little upward mobility itself, especially with main-course prices averaging about $18.

title: R.E.M. CONJURES DARK TIMES ON 'DOCUMENT'
description: ''THERE'S ENOUGH MEDIA and there's enough music that presents itself to you as 100 percent complete,'' said Michael Stipe, R.E.M.'s singer and lyricist. ''We've been trained to accept that and not question that. If you're blasted into the public eye, you're supposed to be one-dimensional. But I'm pretty big on people contributing to things that they take in - not just accepting them on face value.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-25

title: Tibet's First Monastery
description: An hour or so west of the cement block Tibetan town of Zedang, the boatmen on the Zangbo River tie up their flat-bottomed craft, slinging frayed lines over discarded logs. Here nomads in sheepskin coats, or peasant women in banded aprons, or monks in maroon robes gather to wait for the next boat to cross the river on the way to Samye, where Tibet's oldest monastery was founded in the eighth century, now one of the most significant historic sites in Tibet.

title: TROUBLESHOOTING FLUORESCENT LIGHTS
description: FLUORESCENT lights work differently from incandescent ones. As a result, tubes last much longer than ordinary light bulbs and are far less likely to be the cause of trouble - even when the lights won't work at all - than some of a fixture's other components.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
How to Get Nuclear Plants Built
description: LEAD: Delays in commissioning nuclear power stations could be drastically reduced if the stations doubled as mausoleums for important politicians in return for their support for stations built during their lifetimes.

title: My Week With Oleg 1: Writers, Detectives and the Caviar Mafia
description: ''BEWARE of hack writers!'' said the dour-faced young man, a representative of the Union of Soviet Writers. In June, I sat on the stage of a Yalta movie theater with 22 other members of the executive committee of the International Association of Crime Writers, listening to a speech (delivered, it turned out, by a sportswriter) warning a large audience of eager Soviet citizens that their new-found interest in crime fiction contained potential dangers. ''Only the most serious political detective stories merit our attention,'' he continued sternly. My translator leaned over and I was afraid I was about to hear a quote from that bane of our genre, Edmund Wilson's ''Who Cares Who Killed Roger Ackroyd?,'' when Julian Semyonov, a remarkable Hemingwayesque bear of a man, rumored to be a K.G.B. colonel, president of our organization and the biggest-selling author in his country, stepped forward and in the timeworn tradition of a genial master of ceremonies, asked the audience, ''How many of you love crime stories?'' Two thousand enthusiastic hands shot into the air; a burst of spontaneous applause followed.

title: A DIFFERENT KIND OF LETTER FROM MY GRANDMOTHER
description: I COULD tell the pain on my mother's face was real; it was the first time I had seen her cry. I was 15.

title: Liverpool
description: To the Editor: The author gave short shrift to one of Liverpool's greatest exports, the Beatles. In the past few years the Merseyside County Council has refurbished several Beatle-related landmarks, and organized guided tours. They have attracted many Beatle fans from all over the world.

title: A HOMETOWN SHOW IN LARCHMONT
description: LEAD: IN a tribute to the town she lives in and a Bruce Springsteen song she loves, Nina Anastos has taken a series of photographs of Larchmont and made them into an exhibit entitled ''Signs of My Hometown.''

title: Photography
description: It's axiomatic that parents love to take pictures of their children. But very few parents would want to go as far as Sally Mann, whose photographs of her three youngsters trespass the conventions of family snapshooting in several intriguing ways. For starters, Mann uses an 8-by-10-inch view camera, which is an awkward instrument for snapshots but just the thing for rendering skin and other textures with great fidelity. For another, her prints are in black and white, and at 20 by 24 inches they are much too large to slip into a family album.

title: Six 'Steel Magnolias' Are Blooming Onstage
description: IN ROBERT HARLING'S ''STEEL MAGNOLIAS,'' the magnolias are named M'Lynn, Shelby, Clairee, Ouiser, Annelle and Truvy - six strong women, portrayed by six actresses who work together as an ensemble of equals. Creating such an ensemble, the actresses and director agree, was not easy.

title: OTHER GROUPS, TOO, MARK MILESTONES
description: EVERYBODY loves a birthday party, and several of our top cultural organizations are celebrating round-number anniversaries this season: it is the fifth for the New Orchestra of Westchester, the 10th for the Philharmonia Virtuosi, Year 15 at the Emelin Theater and a proud 40th jubilee for the Sleepy Hollow Concert Association.

title: THOMAS B. HUBBARD
description: Thomas Bassett Hubbard, chairman and chief executive of the Thinc. Consulting Group International, an executive placement concern, died at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center after a brief illness on Sept. 5. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: M.T.A. FORUM SET ON SMOKING BAN
description: A PUBLIC forum Tuesday on Metro-North's smoking policies is expected to draw a large number of county commuters determined to preserve their right to smoke on the train.

title: FEDERAL HELP AVERTS FALL OF TEXAS BANK
description: In the early 1980's, Houston's First Bancorporation was an engine of the boom in Texas, aggressively lending money to oil concerns and investing heavily in the real estate market.

title: New Look at Old West Through Eyes of Prince
description: In May 1832, a Prussian prince with an extraordinary eye for detail boarded a sailing ship bound for Boston. Now, a century and a half later, scholars are completing a translation into English of his comprehensive and long-overlooked field notes that provide an important window into the Western frontier of the 19th century.

title: ALMOST EVERYBODY IS SOMEBODY
description: LEAD: SCENES FROM THE FASHIONABLE WORLD By Kennedy Fraser. 204 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: THE IMPACT OF AIDS ON THE ARTISTIC COMMUNITY
description: LEAD: 1. The Impact of AIDS on the Artistic Community is that when a 36-year-old writer is asked on a network news show about the Impact of AIDS on the Artistic Community particularly in regard to the Well-Known Preponderance of Homosexuals in the Arts she replies that if you removed all of the homosexuals and homosexual influence from what is generally regarded as American culture you would be pretty much left with ''Let's Make a Deal.

title: THE BLOCKBUSTERING OF LEE IACOCCA
description: ''I WAS sitting around one Friday afternoon with our president, Alberto Vitale, discussing this hard-cover venture we had just embarked upon,'' Stuart Applebaum, Bantam Books' vice president for publicity, reminisced. ''It was a summer afternoon; nothing was going on. I observed that business books seemed to sell well in hard cover - this was even before 'In Search of Excellence' - and Alberto said he had always admired the business philosophy of Lee Iacocca. So I said we should get him to write his autobiography. So we got an appointment to see him and flew to Detroit, joined by Jack Romanos [ then Bantam's sales chief ] , and as we walk in the door, Lee looks at us warily and announces that he doesn't want to write a book, he has no time to write a book, and what did we want to see him about anyway?'' Applebaum to the rescue. ''I said that I thought he could write a book that students would read to understand how the business world really works. He really responded to that.''

title: B.F. SKINNER INSISTS IT'S JUST MATTER OVER MIND
description: FROM the 1930's through the 1960's, American psychology was dominated by behaviorism, whose more extreme proponents held that the mind is but a convenient fiction. Primitive tribes imagined that invisible spirits were responsible for wind, rain and other mysteries. And so, the behaviorists argued, we try to explain the complexities of human behavior by positing the existence of a mental ectoplasm that inexplicably dwells in our heads. This ghost in the machine is the root of the philosophers' mind-body problem: How does the brain generate mind and how does something without substance exert control over the body?

title: SOONERS ROLL, 28-0; HOLIEWAY SCORES 4
description: Jamelle Holieway ran for 170 yards and 4 touchdowns today as Oklahoma routed North Carolina, 28-0. The victory came despite a school-record 19 penalties against the Sooners (2-0).

title: Opener vs. Bills Looms as Shootout
description: For the eighth time since the teams were created in 1960, the Jets and the Bills will meet in the season's opener Sunday.

title: Loophole Mentalities
description: ''You know the rule: no sugary snacks before dinner.''

title:
GARDENING;
Dig and Divide Crowded Perennials
description: LEAD: MY perennial border was glorious in 1981, when it was new. By the next year, the plants had grown wider and taller and the border was even lovelier.

title: FROM THE PAST, DELIGHTS FOR THE MIND AND EYE
description: ALTHOUGH DANCE IS ONE OF THE oldest of the arts, dance history is a comparatively new field of study. Of course, there have always existed dance lovers fond of research. But, now, the number of researchers is increasing enormously. So are the opportunities for making the results of research available to the public.

title: SPIKE LEE'S STEREOTYPES
description: Film director Spike Lee opposes the film establishment's portrayal of black society in a ''shallow,'' ''misleading'' manner (''Spike Lee's Gotta Have It,'' by Stuart Mieher, Aug. 9). He then projects a black society made up of well-to-do, light-complexioned people and poorer, darker people. He uses two terms, ''wannabees'' and ''jigaboos,'' to describe these stereotypes, which, if they had been used by a white film director, would have caused the black community to picket this movie as a sociological outrage.

title: For Callers Message Is Medium
description: THE voice sounds conspiratorial.

title: Manhattan Couple Are Killed On Taconic as Car Hits Tree
description: A Manhattan couple were killed this morning when their car went out of control on the Taconic State Parkway and struck a tree, the authorities said.

title: The '68 Version of the Bork Debate
description: What's truly extraordinary about the battle over Robert H. Bork's nomination to the United States Supreme Court is the attempt to cut off debate about his legal, social and political philosophy.

title: Articulate Friend of Deaf Is Recalled
description: In affectionate speech and eloquent sign language, friends and relatives of Tanya Zolotoroff Nash yesterday recalled the pioneering work and pixieish personality of the former executive director of the New York Society for the Deaf, who died July 10 at age 89.

title: Woes Persist As Schools Open Today
description: When Brooklyn Technical, one of New York City's showcase high schools in science, opens for the first day of school today, the students will find a new principal - a man whose specialty is physical education. The former principal, a highly respected mathematician and administrator, left after three years to take a better-paying job in a Long Island suburb.

title: Cone Finds The Rain Relaxing
description: The game, David Cone said, was the biggest he had ever been asked to start. ''A must game,'' he called it. A rookie, Cone naturally could have been expected to approach it nervously. But the seemingly ceaseless rain washed away his nervousness.

title: Bowery Bank Theft Arrest
description: A former senior vice president at the Bowery Savings Bank has been arrested and charged with stealing more than $750,000 from the bank over a four-year period, according to the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: Siamese Twins Begin To Wake From Coma And Breathe Alone
description: The infant twins who were separated last week in a 22-hour operation began to emerge today from the drug-induced comas in which they were placed for the surgery, a hospital official said.

title: In Texas Town, an Inlet Becomes a Dividing Line
description: A narrow inlet off the Gulf intracoastal waterway here has become the dividing line for residents in this beachfront community of about 1,000 people over whether the area should remain incorporated.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Chosen By Benckiser Consumer
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, New York, has been selected over Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, New York, as the United States agency for Benckiser Consumer Products of Greenwich, Conn. The budget is in the range of $16 million to $20 million.

title: INSIDE
description: Rainy Day in Flushing The rain put off the men's final at the United States Open between Mats Wilander and Ivan Lendl until today, but the Mets waited it out and finally salvaged a victory over the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-2. The Jets went to sunny Buffalo to open the National Football League season and defeated the Bills, 31-28. SportsMonday, page C1. New Political Mecca Central America is the destination of choice this summer for members of Congress, Presidential contenders and other frequent political fliers.

description: The Notes on Fashion column on the Style page on Tuesday incorrectly characterized the showing of American fashions in the Soviet Union.

description: Susan Debra Klugman, a fourth-year student at the New York University Medical School, and David Gorobetz, the associate general counsel for the securities and investment banking concerns of Muller & Company and Philips, Appel & Walden, were married yesterday at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club. Rabbi H. Leonard Poller officiated.
