title: Who Stole the Syntax?
description: William L. DeAndrea, the author of 14 mystery novels with such titles as ''Azrael'' and ''The Lunatic Fringe,'' was approached a few weeks ago by Linda C. Exman, president of New York Is Book Country, to write what he described as a ''paper-chase scavenger hunt'' for this Sunday's festivalgoers. The Connecticut writer's 1,200-word opus, ''The Adventure of the Stolen Syntax,'' will be distributed to the first 10,000 people who request it at the Association of American Publishers booth, on Fifth Avenue between 51st and 52d Streets.

title: G. Heileman Rejects Offer
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company, the nation's fourth-largest brewer, rejected as inadequate a $1.2 billion takeover offer from Australia's Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., but it said it was willing to meet Bond's chairman, Alan Bond, for talks. Heileman shares rose $1.375 today, to close at $41.875, after the announcement. Bond began a hostile tender offer on Sept. 4 for $38 a share.

title: Reagan on Constitution: 'It Was in 1787 That the Revolution Truly Began'
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech today to participants in the celebration of the 200th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution:

title: Mortgage Issues' Rate Basis Varies
description: Morgan Stanley & Company is offering $500 million of collateralized mortgage obligations divided into fixed-rate and floating-rate issues.

title: At Yale Law, Choosing Sides Over a Not-So-Favorite Son
description: At the Yale Law School, where Robert H. Bork spent most of his career, the hearings on his nomination to the Supreme Court might be a time of great excitement.

title: Seeking a Press Secretary, Almost Desperately
description: For months one of Washington's most visible jobs has gone wanting: Vice President Bush has been operating without a press secretary since June, despite entreaties to journalists, public relations consultants and even to Congressional officials.

title: IRAN PANEL SAYING AIM OF CONTRA AID PUSHED ARMS DEAL
description: A preliminary report of the Congressional committees that investigated the Iran-contra affair concludes that the driving force behind the continued American arms sales to Iran was the desire of some officials to raise money for the rebels in Nicaragua, according to several members of the panels.

title: Film: Norman Mailer's 'Tough Guys Don't Dance'
description: ''I KEEP saying to myself,'' muses Tim Madden, ''death is a celebration.'' Tim (Ryan O'Neal), ex-con, ex-bartender and would-be writer, does a lot of rather portentous musing in ''Tough Guys Don't Dance,'' Norman Mailer's Cape Cod film noir that, with a body count of five murders and two suicides, turns out to be a fairly continuous celebration, though of what is not always apparent. Of mortality, perhaps. Maybe of movie making. Possibly of Provincetown, Mass., where the film was shot and which, no matter how hard Mr. Mailer tries, never seems more dangerous than a picturesque seafood restaurant that sells day-old lobsters.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Red for Shevardnadze
description: Selwa Roosevelt, chief of protocol for the State Department, sent a positive diplomatic signal when she wore a red dress to greet the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, upon his arrival Sunday at Andrews Air Force Base.

title: NEW YORK TO ADD PSYCHIATRIC BEDS IN EFFORT TO REDUCE OVERCROWING
description: In a move to ease overcrowding in psychiatric emergency rooms and inpatient units in New York City hospitals, a state health agency yesterday approved adding 171 psychiatric beds in five municipal and three private nonprofit hospitals.

title: Art: From Sherrie Levine, a Mini-Retrospective
description: SHERRIE LEVINE'S widely anticipated first exhibition at the Mary Boone Gallery is more a mini-retrospective than a presentation of new works. Although much of the work dates from this year, the all-over effect is familiar. The message seems to be that if the work hasn't been seen at the Mary Boone Gallery, it hasn't really been seen. To a certain extent this is true, a natural outcome of this gallery's prominence. But it also constitutes a hedging of the artistic bet.

title: Film: 'Lady Beware,' a Thriller
description: THE stars of ''Lady Beware'' find each other through a shared interest in shop-window dummies. Diane Lane is a window dresser for a Pittsburgh department store whose creativity takes kinky turns, like spritzing Reddi-Wip on a mannequin's limbs. Michael Woods is turned on by her displays, including the decolletage she reveals as she is setting them up.

title: 2 PROFESSORS WHO VANISHED IN '83 IN INDONESIA ARE DECLARED DEAD
description: Two English professors from the City University of New York who vanished in a remote jungle area on the Indonesian island of Sumatra more than four years ago have been declared legally dead by a judge in Manhattan.

title: RJR Nabisco Elects Unusual Chairman
description: In a highly unusual move yesterday, board members of RJR Nabisco Inc., the consumer products giant, elected Charles E. Hugel, president and chief executive of Combustion Engineering Inc., as non-executive chairman.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NEW YORK'S fall cultural season got a spectacular send-off this week. At town houses, in corporate suites, even at the Brooklyn Museum, lovers of art, dance and music hobnobbed with artists, dancers and musicians.

title: Market Place; Cigarette News Impresses Few
description: WHEN the RJR Reynolds Tobacco Company confirmed that it was developing a virtually smokeless cigarette, some Wall Street analysts cheered.

title: Jets Try to Think About the Game
description: With four days remaining before their home opener against New England, the Jets are talking about the need to concentrate on the task at hand.

title: JURY LIIKING AT 3 OTHER STATE SENATORS
description: The Manhattan grand jury that indicted the minority leader of the State Senate, Manfred Ohrenstein, and two other Democratic politicians will consider charges against three additional Democratic state senators, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Tale of the Senate
description: In Philadelphia, there were speeches and the ringing of bells.

title: INSIDE
description: Pope Stresses Forgiveness John Paul II's stress in San Francisco on forgiveness appeared aimed at homosexuals. Page A16. Boston-Moscow Exchange Sarah Caldwell of Opera Company of Boston plans an exchange emphasizing contemporary music. Page C19. Reagan Aide to Resign Beryl W. Sprinkel will resign today as senior economic Adviser, White House officials said. Page D1. Aquino Ousts Key Aide The Philippine President dismissed Joker Arroyo, her closest adviser, from her Cabinet. Page A3.

title: No Headline
description: At Sprague Field in Upper Montclair, N.J., last Saturday night, Tom Pugh, Wagner College's 235-pound fullback, ran inside 21 times for 180 yards behind an offensive line that averaged 262 pounds tackle to tackle.

title: On Rangers, Older Is Better
description: Michel Bergeron, the new Ranger coach, has insisted that he doesn't want to see too much other newness around the team this fall, and that inexperience will be kept to a minimum.

title: Union Bank Sale
description: The Union Bank of California, the state's fifth-largest bank, confirmed that it would be sold by its parent, Standard Chartered of London, to cover losses on its foreign debt. In a memo to the 4,500 employees, John F. Harrigan, the bank's chairman and chief executive, suggested that a buyer might be foreign. Union, based in Los Angeles, has 33 offices with $9.52 billion in assets as of Dec. 31, 1986. The company also owns United Bank of Arizona, the fourth-largest bank in that state.

title: Carter Signs Pact
description: Cris Carter, the wide receiver picked in the fourth round by the Philadelphia Eagles in a supplemental draft, signed four one-year contracts with the club yesterday. Carter, an all-American at Ohio State, was declared ineligible for college football after signing with agents. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.

title: PLAN TO RE-EQUIP B-52'S IS PROPOSED
description: The commander of the nation's long-range bombers said today that he had proposed a $3 billion plan to modify 150 B-52 bombers to carry conventional weapons to help defend Western Europe in the event nuclear missiles were banned.

title: EMERY L. VAN HORN
description: Emery L. Van Horn, the first manager of the Atomic Energy Commission's office at the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Severna Park, Md. He was 80 years old.

title: Tru Green Is Sold
description: Waste Management Inc. has acquired the Tru Green Corporation, the nation's second-largest lawn-care company, after being spurned in its bid for the industry leader, the Chemlawn Corporation of Columbus, Ohio. Tru Green, a privately held company based in suburban Atlanta, has 55 branches and had sales last year of $43 million. James Koenig, Waste Management's vice president and treasurer, said the deal was completed Aug. 31 after two months of talks. He said the price would not be disclosed. Tru Green includes a pest-control operation that Waste Management intends to expand through acquisitions, Mr. Koenig said.

title: Bridge: Event for Those 55 and Over Will Be Held in Manhattan
description: Almost two-thirds of the members of the American Contract Bridge League are 55 years of age or older. The average age has been steadily rising, a source of concern to those who worry about the future of the game in North America.

title: Booth-by-Booth Guide to the Fifth Ave. Book Fair
description: This is a booth-by-booth browser's guide to activities at the New York Is Book Country fair. The major displays of each booth are listed. Author appearances are subject to change. 1. Rizzoli Bookstores: Landscape and gardening books. ''The Old Fashioned Garden'' by Nancy Lynch; ''Traditional English Gardens'' by Arabella Lennox-Boyd. Free posters. 2. New York Botanical Garden:

title: Stomach Illness Fells Princeton Students
description: Health officials began investigating dining halls at Princeton University Wednesday after almost 90 students and faculty members fell ill.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Up Sharply
description: Hopes that Congress will soon agree on a plan to reduce Federal budget deficits helped lift Treasury bond prices sharply yesterday, with most of the gains coming in late afternoon trading.

title: Film: 'Amazon Women'
description: WHY tamper with perfection? The tinny, low-budget science-fiction epics that turn up on late-night television have the kind of innocence and silliness that don't grow on trees, so the idea of duplicating these classics seems doomed from the very start. But the makers of ''Amazon Women on the Moon,'' which opens today at Loews New York Twin and other theaters, knew no fear. Nor did they know much about taste, concentration, restraint or any of the other virtues that might have bogged them down.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Carlos Ward, First on First, First Street at First Avenue (473-9826). John Coltrane hired Carlos Ward soon after the young alto saxophonist arrived in New York City from Panama, in the mid-1960's. Mr. Ward subsequently formed lasting associations with Carla Bley, the funk band B. T. Express and Abdullah Ibrahim, a South African pianist. Don Cherry's quartet featured Mr. Ward's evocative, rhythmically stimulating compositions as well as his alto at the Village Vanguard recently, whetting one's appetite for this one-night appearance with his own band. Shows are tomorrow at 10:30 P.M. and midnight; admission is $7.

title: KEY RATES
HARRY G. NEWMAN
description: Harry G. Newman, a former vice president of Helmsley-Spear Inc., the real-estate concern, died of cancer Tuesday in St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 94 years old and lived in White Plains Mr. Newman was a partner in Ames, Cunehand & Newman, the real-estate brokers, until the firm merged with the Helmsley organization. He worked for Helmsley-Spear until he retired in 1972.

title: T. MICHAEL REED
description: T. Michael Reed, a dancer in such Broadway musicals as ''Seesaw'' and ''The Magic Show,'' died of complications from acquired immune deficiency syndrome Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 42 years old.

title: Rebels Kill 14, Salvador Says
description: Fourteen armed security workers of the state electrical company were killed and 14 wounded in a guerrilla attack 13 miles north of San Salvador, the army information office said today.

title: At a Gala Benefit at Saks, A Fall Fashion Preview
description: The annual SFA/USA party has been a success for nine consecutive years, a long time on the promotional charity-cum-fashion circuit. This time it exploded in a burst of red, in both clothes and decor, which established a gala setting for the evening.

title: Film: Belushi in 'Principal'
description: IF you think New York's public schools have problems, you haven't been to Brandel High, the locale of ''The Principal,'' which opens today at the Criterion Center and other theaters. This joint makes the Blackboard Jungle look like Rye County Day. Since most of the inmates, who pass their time imbibing reefer smoke and loud noises from their boom boxes, necking, negotiating drug sales and beating up on one another, have been kicked out of other schools, expulsion holds no fears. Also, they lack a healthy self-image. As one says, ''Garbage never leaves the dump.''

title: Doctor in AIDS Case Finds Parents Split On Risk to Children
description: A pediatrician who carries the AIDS virus is worried that he will be forced from his practice by angry parents, but other parents are rallying to his support.

title: Leave the Dollar Alone
description: With the merchandise trade deficit having hit an all-time high of $16.5 billion in July, common sense would seem to dictate either that the dollar will have to drop some more or that we will need some tough new import restrictions to even things out. But here common sense is wrong.

title: Old Foes Plan To Talk Over Missile Crisis
description: With the 25th anniversary of the Cuban missile crisis approaching, American and Soviet officials, including some who were closely involved as the crisis unfolded in 1962, plan to meet to discuss the event.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Harness Racing Consecutive Victories in Brown Jug: In a rare double for owners, Jaguar Spur followed Barberry Spur's 1986 victory by winning the $412,330 Little Brown Jug before 44,932 fans at the Delaware County Fairgrounds in Ohio yesterday. It was only the second time that owners had enjoyed consecutive victories in the 42 runnings of the second leg of pacing's triple crown. Yacht Racing Jobson Takes Lead: Gary Jobson of Annapolis, Md., the defending skipper in the Liberty Cup match-racing series, led seven other world-class sailors here yesterday in the first day of the 1987 regatta. A 5-to-6-knot southwesterly wind and light rain set a slow pace for the start of the four-day series in New York Harbor.

title: Broadway
description: New Book for 'Legs'

title: Mattel Receivables Back Unit's Preferred Stock
description: The Mattel Funding Corporation is offering $62.5 million of money market preferred stock backed by trade receivables of its corporate parent, the toy manufacturer.

title: In Hindsight, Biden's Law Teacher Sees Offense as Minor
description: The instructor who alerted the faculty about possible plagiarism in Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s law paper said tonight that ''the incident doesn't look half as bad now as I thought it did then'' and that he did not think it ''reflects on what Joseph Biden is today.''

title: Hafts Offer $6 Billion For Dayton
description: The Haft family of Washington offered yesterday to pay $6 billion for the 95 percent of the Dayton Hudson Corporation it does not yet own.

title: Baxter Names New President
description: Wilbur Gantz has been named president of Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., the company said. He replaces Vernon R. Loucks Jr., who remains as chairman and chief executive.

title: Senators Question the Sincerity of Bork's New Views
description: The sincerity of Judge Robert H. Bork's new views emerged as a central issue today in hearings on his nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: Restaurant Tender
description: A management-led buyout group said today that it had begun an $18-a-share tender offer for Restaurant Associates Industries, even as Anwar S. Soliman raised his competing offer. The management bid was valued at $99 million; Mr. Soliman's bid, at $20 a share, was valued at about $115 million. The bidding contest pits Mr. Soliman, chairman of the American Restaurant Group of Irvine, Calif., against a group led by Martin Brody, the chairman of the New York-based restaurant and newsstand company.

title: Manila Retired From Racing
description: Manila, who won the Arlington Million 12 days ago to reaffirm his place as the nation's leading grass horse, has been retired from racing because of a hairline fracture discovered yesterday morning in his left cannon bone.

title: Banker Cites Africa's Woes
description: Falling commodity prices, rising debt, undependable weather conditions and political tensions make Africa ''the economic crisis of our planet,'' a top World Bank official said today.

title: Housing Starts Fell By 1.5% in August
description: Housing construction edged down 1.5 percent in August, the fifth decline in six months, as rising mortgage rates continued to dampen demand for new homes, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Explosion Risk At Nuclear Site Is Reported High
description: Tanks containing millions of gallons of deadly radioactive wastes at a nuclear weapon facility in South Carolina are at substantial risk of exploding and contaminating the surrounding area, according to a report released today by an environmental group.

title: Rather Takes a Ribbing
description: Dan Rather's six minutes of ''black air'' one week ago has brought the CBS News anchor six days of intense attention of the most unwelcome sort.

title: McClatchy Plans Public Stock Sale
description: McClatchy Newspapers Inc., which operates The Sacramento Bee and 11 other newspapers in California, Washington state and Alaska, said it had filed a registration statement for a proposed initial public offering of 2.4 million shares of its Class A common stock. Goldman, Sachs & Company, Morgan Stanley & Company and Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. have been named co-managers of the underwriting group.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Major obstacles to an arms treaty to eliminate medium-range missiles were overcome, and Washington and Moscow agreed tentatively to hold a summit meeting later this year, Administration officials said. Page A1

title: If All Reporters Got Kicked Out of South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: A STREET FAIR FOR SLEUTHS AND BIBLIOPHILES ON FIFTH AVENUE
description: EARLY this week I met a distinguished visitor.

title: British Jobless Rate Dips
description: Britain's unemployment rate fell to a seasonally adjusted 10.2 percent in August, from 10.4 percent in July, the Department of Employment said today. The August figure was down from 11.6 percent in August 1986.

title: ALBANY CHIEFS CHALLENGE INDICTMENTS
description: One day after two state senators were formally accused of using public funds to pay political campaign workers, leaders of the Legislature sharply challenged the basis of the indictments, saying the distinction between politics and government was a matter for the Legislature itself to decide.

title: LAWYERS PRESENT LAST ARGUMENTS TO BIAGGI JURORS
description: The Federal bribery and conspiracy case of Representative Mario Biaggi and Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, is to go to the jury today, after the defense and the prosecution concluded their arguments yesterday at a court session that ended at 8:20 P.M.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 396 money market mutual funds increased $466.2 million, to $245.57 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 103 institutional funds were up $77.3 million, to $64.65 billion. Assets of the 200 general-purpose funds were up $151.8 million, to $72.53 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds increased $237.1 million, to $108.39 billion.

title: Advertising; Ricochet: New Arts Magazine
description: BACK in the 1920's, an international cultural magazine called Der Querschnitt appeared in Germany and published Ernest Hemingway and James Joyce, among others. William J. McTighe came across the magazine in an art gallery in Berlin in 1979 and decided that there might be a niche for a similar publication.

title: Biden's Waterloo? Too Soon to Tell
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s Presidential candidacy has been badly hurt by disclosures that he committed plagiarism in a law school essay and in speeches this year. But politicians in both parties and political consultants say it is not clear whether he retains a chance to win the Democratic nomination in 1988.

title: Phillips Plans Debt Offering
description: In its first effort to raise money in the securities market since a restructuring in 1985, the Phillips Petroleum Company said today that it had filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $400 million debt offering.

title: Mets Held to Four Hits By Expos in 4-1 Defeat
description: The Mets ran into one of those mysteries of human performance tonight, the kind that seem to surface in pennant races, and they did not survive.

title: Crownx Ends Bid for Units
description: A takeover of the financial services concern Mercantile House Holdings P.L.C. neared completion after a Canadian company that had made a last-minute bid for part of Mercantile decided instead to sell its holding.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Giants Meet on Labor Dispute
description: Although Coach Bill Parcells said today that the threat of a strike had not been a factor in the Giants' preparations for the Cowboys this week, his players apparently believe otherwise.

title: Con Brio Ensemble
description: The Con Brio Ensemble - Joyce Hammann, violinist; Victor Battipaglia, clarinetist, and Diana Mittler, pianist - will perform music by Mozart, Khachaturian, Bach and William Ryden, Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Queens Botanical Garden, 43-50 Main Street in Flushing. The concert is free. Information: (718) 886-3800.

title: We Need A Coordinated National Drug Policy; Together We Can Win
description: To the Editor:

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday TRISHA BROWN, CONTINUED

title: The Papal Visit; Nun Still Keeps the Faith On Larger Women's Role
description: Eight years ago, in one of the most dramatic moments of Pope John Paul II's first papal visit to the United States, a nun stood up before him in a Washington cathedral and urged in a respectful but firm tone that he consider ''the possibility of women being included in all ministries of the church.''

title: Sir Rudolf Bing and Wife Are Found in Scotland
description: The police said today that they traced Sir Rudolf Bing, former head of New York's Metropolitan Opera, and his wife to a Scottish hotel, after friends said the couple had not been seen for more than three weeks.

title: Bells and Talks Mark Celebration
description: Hundreds of New York City schoolchildren scurried in ordered confusion, each taking an assigned place in the columned rotunda of Federal Hall National Memorial in lower Manhattan.

title: Reorganization At TV Retailer
description: Home Shopping Network Inc. said today that it planned a major reorganization that would make it a diversified holding company. Home Shopping's chairman, Roy M. Speer, said the company's main business would be the retailing of consumer products and services, ''as well as many other diversified products and services through television, direct mail and telemarketing media.''

title: UNCLE TESTIFIES THAT HE HEARD OF ABUSE BY GIRL
description: In a dramatic, surprise appearance, an uncle of Cheryl Pierson took the stand here today and said Miss Pierson's mother, Cathleen, had confided to him that she knew her husband was taking their daughter into bed with him at night but that there was nothing she could do about it.

title: Film: 'Mozart Brothers,' a Comedy
description: ''I DON'T like singing and I hate opera,'' says the intense, beady-eyed Walter to the astonished members of the company he's about to direct in a new production of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni.''

title: South Africa Panel Urges Multiracial Areas
description: A presidential advisory committee has recommended the partial dismantling of an apartheid law that enforces racially segregated residential living.

title: The Computer as Couturier
description: It's that daily debate: what to wear. You could stare into the closet, plow through every drawer, go back to bed. Or you could turn on the computer. ''Looking Your Best - A Computer Guide to Your Ideal Clothing Choices'' is a program for women that suggests how to fashion your wardrobe to fit your physique. If your thighs are full and your legs long, ''Looking Your Best'' suggests harem pants or a wrap skirt. If your face is angular the program advises necklaces and scarfs to add fullness, and earrings to fill in the jaw line.

title: Film: 'Maurice' in Style Of Ivory and Merchant
description: STATELY and tasteful, supremely confident, proud of its Anglophilia and shameless in its devotion to the upper crust, the Merchant-Ivory style of literary adaptation by now owes at least as much to Ralph Lauren as to E. M. Forster or Henry James. That's no small part of its appeal. The Merchant-Ivory ''Maurice,'' based on Forster's long-unpublished novel about a young man's coming to terms with his homosexuality, further perfects the approach that has worked better and better with each new film, particularly ''The Bostonians'' and ''A Room With a View.'' Seriousness and intelligence are certainly part of these successes, but a keen sense of the exquisite also goes into making Merchant-Ivory magic.

title: Film: 'Orphans,' Based on the Play
description: IN the lively precredit sequence of ''Orphans,'' Alan J. Pakula's screen version of Lyle Kessler's one-set play, a skinny young man with a manic bounce to his walk approaches a suit-and-vest type sitting on a bench in Central Park. Treat (Matthew Modine), the intruder, sits down beside the suit-and-vest and immediately asks if the fellow has any pictures of his family. The mind inhabiting the suit and vest does some split-second calculations:

title: At the Movies
description: A Chinese Film First

title: Alfonsin Appoints 5 to Serve As Ministers in New Cabinet
description: Ten days after his party lost heavily in nationwide elections, President Raul Alfonsin has named five new ministers to his eight-member Cabinet and promised a ''new era'' for the debt-ridden nation.

title: The Stage: 'Bouncers,' Drama
description: THE English playwrights in widest currency among New York theatergoers these days - Tom Stoppard, Simon Gray, Michael Frayn, Peter Shaffer - are highly educated and middle aged. They're not the sort of fellows to get down to the street level of Margaret Thatcher's high-unemployment England, where alienated, semilingual youths lurk about in search of a pint or a fight. If rebellious teen-agers surface in a play by Mr. Stoppard (''The Real Thing'') or Mr. Gray (''Melon''), chances are they'll be in articulate revolt against Mommy and Daddy. It's up to new-wave English films (''My Beautiful Laundrette'') and younger, punkier playwrights to chart the travails of modern post-adolescent English rebels without a cause.

title: N.H.L. Toughens Fighting Penalties
description: In its strongest effort to crack down on bench-clearing brawls, the National Hockey League Board of Governors voted today to hand out stiffer penalties to coaches, players and clubs -including lengthier suspensions - in order to stop such infractions.

title: Jay Hoggard
description: Jay Hoggard, a vibraphonist, is to lead a quartet - with Benny Green on piano, Anthony Cox on bass and Victor Lewis on drums - tonight and tomorrow at Jazztrack, 27 Barrow Street, east of Seventh Avenue South (645-2387). Admission is $10.

title: Taxing Our Brains
description: To the Editor:

title: HOMELESS IN SUBURBS: A SLAYING
description: In his last two weeks in this town of stately homes and smart shops, Richard Elliott lived in his wheelchair in a covered passageway just off Main Street.

title: Film: 'Fatal Attraction' With Douglas and Close
description: YEARS hence, it will be possible to pinpoint the exact moment that produced ''Fatal Attraction,'' Adrian Lyne's new romantic thriller, and the precise circumstances that made it a hit. It arrived at the tail end of the having-it-all age, just before the impact of AIDS on movie morality was really felt. At the same time, it was a powerful cautionary tale. And it played skillfully upon a growing societal emphasis on marriage and family, shrewdly offering something for everyone: the desperation of an unmarried career woman, the recklessness of a supposedly satisfied husband, the worries of a betrayed wife. What's more, it was made with the slick, seductive professionalism that was a hallmark of the day.

title: Strikeout Helps Yanks Win
description: Ernie Whitt sat at one end of the club house, trying to finish his postgame meal. But the thing that ate at him was a call in the eighth inning last night that doomed the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: 3 Chess Prodigies Show Their Stuff
description: Jessica and John played chess, and Susan, serious Susan, watched without any expression on her face. John chattered away during the fast game. Jessica kidded around also. The game was a draw, and there was a brief analysis. ''Suppose,'' Jessica said, ''I pushed pawn to b6?'' Said John: ''Wouldn't work, because . . .'' and he showed why. That is the way world chess champions talk.

title: Film: 'Hey Babu Riba,' Belgrade in '53
description: ''Hey Babu Riba'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films Series. Here are excerpts from Walter Goodman's review, which appeared in The New York Times March 15. The film opens today at the Embassy 72d Street 2, at Broadway.

title: Art of Bel Canto
description: Carmela Altamura, a soprano, will present the first in a series of three recitals exploring the art of bel canto singing tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at Weill Recital Hall. Tickets are $15, $10 for the elderly and students. Information: 247-7800.

title: Little Jimmy Scott
description: Little Jimmy Scott, a singer, will perform tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum. Tonight's first set will be broadcast by WKCR, 89.9 FM.

title: Replacing Mrs. Dole
description: A highly placed Reagan Administration official says the leading candidates to succeed Elizabeth Hanford Dole as Secretary of Transportation are Wendy Lee Gramm, who currently heads the regulatory affairs section of the Office of Management and Budget, and Jaime Oaxaca, a vice president of the Northrop Corporation.

title: 39 Die at China Building Site
description: Thirty-nine laborers died when a three-story building they were constructing collapsed at Yuan Jiang in China's central province of Hunan, the state radio and television news said today. The building toppled into a river beside the construction site while the men were asleep at midnight Monday, and the sole survivor was found clinging to a log floating in the water.

title: Senate Defeats Proposal to Advance White House's 'Star Wars' Initiative
description: The Democratic-controlled Senate approved a proposal today to prohibit the advanced testing and quickened development of a space-based missile defense system as envisioned under President Reagan's plan.

title: Group to Seek Crazy Eddie
description: Entertainment Marketing Inc. said today that it had formed a partnership to wage a proxy fight for control of Crazy Eddie Inc., the New York-based electronics retailer. The group now controls more than 11 percent of Crazy Eddie.

title: Sara Lee in Talks To Buy Dutch Unit
description: The Sara Lee Corporation is in final negotiations to buy the food and consumer products business of the Dutch company Akzo N.V. for $600 million, the Chicago-based concern said today.

title: About Real Estate; A Boom in Lower-Cost Orange County
description: ''We are becoming the suburbs of the suburbs,'' said Richard DeTurk, deputy commissioner for the Orange County Planning Department.

title: Guinness Agrees to Buy Schenley From Riklis
description: Guinness P.L.C. announced today that it would buy Schenley Industries, a New York-based spirits distributor, for $480 million to strengthen the British company's control over its brands in the United States.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ST. JOHN DE CREVECOEUR: The Life of an American Farmer. By Gay Wilson Allen and Roger Asselineau. Illustrated. 266 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Italian-American Gala
description: The annual gala weekend of the National Italian American Foundation, one of the biggest social events of the year in the capital, will have a show business glow this year.

title: Trial for Richardson
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, the first player in the National Basketball Association to be banned for drug use, will stand trial on theft and forgery charges in New Jersey because he used cocaine while in a court program to rehabilitate first-time offenders, according to authorities. The 32-year-old former Knick and Net guard broke program rules this summer when a urine test came up positive for cocaine. Gina Marino, the assistant Bergen County prosecutor, said that Richardson had also failed to meet weekly with program administrators, and that if he had completed the six-month program, he would have avoided prosecution. He has been charged with theft by deception and forgery for reportedly cashing a $9,748 insurance check meant to pay an auto shop for repair work.

title: Sprinkel Expected to Quit Today
description: Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, plans to announce his resignation Friday, according to White House officials.

title: APPEALS OF FRIEDMAN AND 3 OTHERS ARE ARGUED
description: Defense lawyers urged a Federal appeals court yesterday to overturn the conviction of Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, and three others found guilty of corrupting the New York City Parking Violations Bureau.

title: Modern Masters and Neophytes In Photo Shows
description: FOR followers of photography, the exhibition season has begun with all the intensity of last month's New Age celebration of ''harmonic convergence.'' At museums and galleries this weekend, a wealth and variety of shows waits to be seen, including ones devoted to such 20th-century masters as Henri-Cartier Bresson (at the Museum of Modern Art), Edward Weston (at the Metropolitan Museum of Art) and Andre Kertesz (at the International Center of Photography-Midtown Gallery).

title: Lebanese Suspect in '85 Hijacking Arrested by the F.B.I. While at Sea
description: A Lebanese man was arrested in international waters in the Mediterranean Sea and flown to the United States to face charges of hijacking a Jordanian airliner in 1985, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announced today.

title: A Reputed Mobster Is Found Murdered
description: A reputed associate of the Colombo organized-crime family was found shot to death in a stolen car in Brooklyn early yesterday, the police said. It was the fifth gangland-style slaying in the city in the last two weeks.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Bagel as Second Language
description: Autumn in New York City is the season of first nights and second languages. With the end of long summer evenings, adult education enlists prospective students with promises that periodic conversations on West 12th Street or weekend immersions in the Shawangunk Mountains will produce fluency in French or Hebrew or Basque. All too soon, enrollees discover that language is the hard way to assimilate a new culture. Eating it seems easier; and some abandon grammar for bagels.

title: Honda Expansion: U.S. Exports a Goal
description: The Honda Motor Company today announced a four-year plan to expand its American production to the point where it could export about 50,000 cars to Japan each year.

title: Biden Admits Plagiarism in School But Says It Was Not 'Malevolent'
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., fighting to salvage his Presidential campaign, today acknowledged ''a mistake'' in his youth, when he plagiarized a law review article for a paper he wrote in his first year at law school.

title: A World Of Music In Queens
description: GEOGRAPHY aside, four continents will meet tomorrow at a beer garden in Queens.

title: House and Senate Conferees Agree on a Budget-Cutting Plan
description: A majority of House and Senate conferees agreed today on a new method of enforcing spending cuts to reduce the deficit. But one key Republican withheld his support for the plan, casting some doubt about its chance of passage in the Senate.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1987
description: Companies

title: Biko Memorial
description: A memorial concert for the South African activist Steven Biko will take place tomorrow from noon to 7 P.M. at St. Mary's Park, at 147th Street and St. Anne's Street in the South Bronx (589-5819). The performers will include Pablo Moses and his reggae band; Trouble Funk from Washington; the Sons of Hoodoo, a jazz-funk group led by Steve Coleman, on saxophone; Melle Mel, a rapper; the South African Student Organization Choir, and others. Admission is free.

title: U.S. Serviceman Wounded By Russian in East Germany
description: An American serviceman was wounded today in East Germany when a Soviet soldier fired at a United States liaison team touring the Communist country, the Defense Department said tonight.

title: Sharpening Skills in Archery
description: With the archery seasons for deer opening Sept. 26 in New Jersey and Sept. 27 in New York State's northern zone, those who prefer this more difficult form of hunting may wish to attend a bow-hunter jamboree at the Garden State Archery Range in Jacobstown, N.J., Sept. 20.

title: Hard Facts Behind the Aviation Fog
description: Two facts finally emerge from the oratorical fog enveloping the troubles of civil aviation. First, despite improvements, there's an enormous need for basic facilities - runways, terminals and even whole new airports. The second is that receipts from current aviation taxes are inadequate to meet the need.

title: Where They Stand: N.F.L. Issues
description: The National Football League Players Association has said that in the absence of a settlement it will go on strike after the Jets' game Monday night against New England. Following are the key issues dividing the players and the owners. Free Agency

title: Settlement Is Reached In Detroit School Strike
description: Negotiators for the school system and the Michigan Federation of Teachers reached tentative agreement on a three-year contract here tonight, after a 17-day strike that had kept 11,500 teachers and 193,000 students out of classrooms.

title: U.S. Orders Eastern Airlines To Stop Flying Damaged Jet
description: An Eastern Airlines jetliner was removed from service by Government order Wednesday because of severe damage apparently caused by a hard landing two flights earlier.

title: F.B.I. in New York Asks Librarians' Aid In Reporting on Spies
description: F.B.I. agents have asked librarians in New York City to watch for and report on library users who might be diplomats of hostile powers recruiting intelligence agents or gathering information potentially harmful to United States security.

title: NASA HAILS RESULT OF SHUTTLE TEST
description: The first full-scale test of the redesigned booster rocket for the space shuttle was successful, keeping the space agency on schedule to resume flights next June, agency officials have told Congress.

title: Jaffa Journal; From America, Jews Spur Renewal of Arab Slum
description: The Ajami neighborhood of Jaffa looks more like an extension of downtown Beirut than of downtown Tel Aviv, which is just a few blocks away.

title: Dining Out Guide: Brunch
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE DES ARTISTES, #1 West 67th Street (877-3500) - * (May 30, 1986) Situated in a historic turn-of-the-century building off Central Park West is this gracious and romantic spot for weekend brunch with its dark burnished-wood walls and bucolic murals. Offerings include smoked salmon Benedict with poached eggs; sauteed French toast made with apricot marmelade and walnut filling; cold chicken cutlet with red onion, tomato and basil, and gravlax tartare. Brunch entrees $10 to $21.50. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Sundays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M. CHELSEA CENTRAL, #227 10th Avenue, near 24th Street (620-0230) -

title: Ranking Black Resigns From State Department
description: The highest-ranking black official in the State Department has resigned in an angry and public dispute that had racial overtones.

title: Brockway And Owens Near Link
description: Two of the nation's major glass-container producers, Owens-Illinois Inc. and Brockway Inc., said yesterday that they were negotiating a merger.

title: Raider Move Set Back
description: The Los Angeles Raiders' plan to move to the suburb of Irwindale has met a setback - the United States Army Corps of Engineers may order a lengthy environmental study on the stadium parking plan. The proposed parking lot for up to 20,000 cars is on a flood plain, it is home to several protected species, it is a candidate for a Federal preservation list, and an environmental study could take years, said John Rasco, a spokesman for the corps. If the Raiders refuse to extend the deadline or accept an alternative parking site, the $115 million deal that lured the team from the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum could be scuttled - and Irwindale could lose the $10 million in advance money it paid to the Raiders.

title: Dow Loses 2.29 More in Slow Day
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed narrowly lower yesterday in subdued trading as worry over the ultimate course of the dollar and the bond market continued to stifle equities.

title: IRAQ SAYS TROOPS REPELLED IRAN RAID
description: Iraq said its forces repulsed an Iranian attack in an 18-hour battle today, and Iran said it bombarded Iraqi cities in reprisal for Iraqi air strikes on shipping, oil centers and factories.

title: ABANDONED QUEENS FACTORY STUDIED FOR RADIATION
description: A small army of state and city officials with Geiger counters descended on a shut chemical plant in Woodside, Queens, yesterday, less than an hour after an upstate Assemblyman told a news conference that his office had discovered that old stocks of radium stored in the building were emitting excessive levels of radiation through a window.

title: Olympic Countdown: One Year to Go
description: As the International Olympic Committee began a one-year countdown to the 1988 Seoul Olympic Games today by sending invitations to the national Olympic committees of 167 countries, the I.O.C. president was intensifying efforts to resolve the issue of North Korea's participation in the games.

title: Aquino, Under Pressure, Removes Her Closest Adviser
description: President Corazon C. Aquino bowed to intense political pressure today and announced the removal of her closest adviser, Executive Secretary Joker Arroyo.

title: Ulster Soldier Killed
description: Gunmen killed a part-time soldier with the Ulster Defense Regiment today as his family watched, the police said. They said the victim was the 70th victim of sectarian strife in Northern Ireland this year.

title: Panel Just a Step To Bork Decision
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee's hearings on the nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court began Tuesday and are likely to last two or three weeks.

title: Mason Ruffner
description: Mason Ruffner will lead his blues-rock band Sunday at the Bottom Line, 14 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street (228-6300). Shows begin at 8 and 11 P.M.; tickets are $12.50.

title: WARD STUMBLES INTO WOMEN-DRIVERS ISSUE
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward has managed often to stir up disputes, whether he was predicting racial unrest this summer or calling one of his top aides stupid.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD IS SEEN ON SUMMIT AND MISSILE TREATY
description: Major obstacles to a Soviet-American treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles were cleared away today, and the two sides agreed tentatively to hold a summit meeting before the end of the year, senior Reagan Administration officials said tonight.

title: House Votes Payments to Japanese War Internees
description: The House today approved a formal national apology and restitution of $1.2 billion to more than 66,000 surviving Japanese-Americans who were forced from their homes and jobs in 1942 and held under armed guard in detention centers for three and a half years.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Marlboro Field Falls Short
description: The $750,000 Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park Sunday is likely to set several records, none of them encouraging.

title: The Guggenheim Needs Space, Not Pipe Dreams
description: To the Editor:

title: Wesray in Deal For RKO Studio
description: RKO Pictures, the legendary Hollywood studio once owned by the reclusive financier Howard Hughes, said it would be acquired by its managers and the Wesray Capital Corporation from its parent, Gencorp, for $31 million. The managers of the studio, based in Los Angeles, were unable to complete their own proposed buyout last spring, said Mary Begley Feurey, an RKO spokeswoman in New York.

title: FORD AND U.A.W. AGREE ON NEW PACT
description: The United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company today announced a new labor contract that both sides said would enhance the job security of 104,000 factory workers at Ford.

title: After 2 Centuries, Great Day for Constitution
description: In the climax of a yearlong celebration and re-examination of the nation's values and institutions, Philadelphia today led the United States in a rousing commemoration of the signing of the Constitution.

title: JOHN H.G. MUNSON
description: John H. G. Munson, an investment adviser with A. R. Schmeidler & Company, died of complications from cancer Sept. 10 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan and Mattapoisett, Mass.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Uncle Bonsai, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). The sophisticated singing and songwriting trio from Seattle writes delightfully fey folk-pop songs that suggest Gilbert and Sullivan filtered through the Roches, with a soupcon of Stephen Sondheim. Arni Adler, Ashley Kristen and Andrew Ratshin, the group's three carolers, are urbane hothouse flowers whose lyrics cheerfully twit everything from ''The Love Boat'' (''Isaac's Lament'') to Neanderthal yokels (''Send My Body Home''). The vocal blend of two sopranos and countertenor is as rarefied as their lyrical sensibility. Show times are tomorrow at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M., and tickets are $11.

title: Debaters Who Agree on Very Little
description: When they meet at Congressional hearings or the reception room of a television studio, they hail each other with a collegial ''Jim'' and ''Bookie.''

title: Pentagon Called Committed to Changes in Buying
description: The Pentagon remains committed to adopting improvements in the military's management that were initiated last year, despite internal arguments about how to organize for efficient weapons purchasing, Deputy Secretary William H. Taft 4th said today.

title: Restaurants
description: WITH all the ballyhoo over Tex-Mex, Southwestern and Mexican restaurants in recent years, the zesty cuisine of Cuba has been somewhat neglected. That's unfortunate, for Cuban food, when authentically prepared, offers a titillating array of flavors and textures - and at economical prices. The granddaddy of this tropical cuisine in New York is Victor del Corral, who opened the original Victor's Cafe 25 years ago on Columbus Avenue.

title: NEW YORK OFFICIALS VOTE TO END CONTRACT FOR MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: New York City hospital officials voted yesterday to end a $6 million-a-year contract for New York Medical College to provide medical and therapeutic services at Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island.

title: RESPONSE TIME CUT SIGNIFICANTLY FOR NEW YORK CITY AMBULANCES
description: New York City officials said yesterday that the average response time of municipal ambulances, which climbed to the highest level in six years last July, had been reduced significantly in August and early September.

title: SCHOOLS CHANCELLOR CANDIDATE ARRIVES TO MOUNT A CAMPAIGN
description: Dr. Bernard E. Gifford flew in from California this week and offered his candidacy for the biggest job vacancy in town. The only thing missing from what seemed to many guests to be a Gifford for schools chancellor cocktail party the other night was a campaign button on every lapel.

title: Economic Scene; Consistency: Crucial Factor
description: DESPITE all the worries on Wall Street, the American economy has been performing remarkably well - if, for the moment, you leave aside the big trade deficit, the budget deficit, the weak dollar and the growing dependence on foreign capital.

title: Advertising; First Y.&R. Ad For Pillsbury
description: The Pillsbury Doughboy will appear in a new ''Lovin' From the Oven'' campaign breaking tomorrow evening on NBC during its broadcast of the Miss America Pageant.

title: Standard Bank In Acquisition
description: In a move to expand its toehold in the Indiana region, the Standard Federal Bank said it had agreed to acquire the Tower Federal Savings Bank for $433.7 million.

title: Offbeat Antics From California Comedy Troupe
description: Regular viewers of the ABC news program ''Nightline'' should be familiar with the satirical sneer of Ian Shoales. The rapid-fire misanthropic social commentator whose face seems frozen in a permanent scowl was discovered by Ted Koppel on National Public Radio's ''All Things Considered'' and has been booked on ''Nightline'' 10 times. Mouthing off on just about any subject, Mr. Shoales, who is an alter-ego of the writer-actor Merle Kessler, always has a rancid train of thought ready to spew.

title: Jersey Hospitals Gain Rate Rise to Pay Nurses
description: State regulators granted hospitals in New Jersey a three-month, $35 million rate increase Wednesday to offset the cost of retaining experienced nurses and recruiting new ones.

title: Insurers Are Right On AIDS Testing
description: The insurance industry has filed suit to block a regulation proposed by the New York Insurance Department that would prohibit insurance companies from testing applicants for health insurance for exposure to the AIDS virus. The insurance industry has a valid point.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Duro-Test Corp., North Bergen, N.J., named Kevin Shanley president and chief executive, G. R. McGruther and J. M. Ross co-chairmen and William F. Shuck secretary-treasurer.

title: Columbia Looking for New Chief
description: David Puttnam, the former independent film maker who resigned Wednesday as chairman and chief executive of Columbia Pictures Industries, will leave the company by the end of the year. The departure, which surprised few in Hollywood, came just two weeks after the Coca-Cola Company, which owns Columbia, announced that it was merging its entertainment sector into Tri-Star Pictures Inc., the movie studio, in which it also held a stake.

title: In Iraq City, the Shells Fall Every Day
description: Personally, said Halid Jamir Bolus, an ice-cream maker, he had gotten used to it, living within a shell's drop of a front line.

title: Upshaw, Donlan Meet Today
description: The heads of the recalcitrant sides in the National Football League's contract talks agreed yesterday to meet face-to-face today in Washington to try to reach agreement on a new contract before the strike deadline Tuesday.

title: Guinness Peat
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell said he had increased his stake in Guinness Peat Group P.L.C., a takeover target of Equiticorp Holdings Ltd., to 6.38 percent from 2.57 percent. Mr. Maxwell, who did not declare his intentions, said he owned 20.1 million of Guinness Peat's 309.8 million shares outstanding. Meanwhile, Guinness Peat rejected Equiticorp's sweetened bid of 115 pence a share, or about $1.90, as inadequate.

title: Film: 'Pickup Artist,' From James Toback
description: WATCH the actors' lips as they deliver their lines in ''The Pickup Artist,'' which opens today at the Criterion Center and other theaters, and you'll sometimes see them mouthing words that didn't make it into the finished film. Something seems to have happened en route to the screen. ''The Pickup Artist'' is extremely brief -under 90 minutes - and a good deal tamer than the earlier works of James Toback, who wrote ''The Gambler'' and directed ''Fingers,'' ''Love and Money'' and ''Exposed,'' films not known for the kind of nice-guy romantic humor he displays this time. It's hard to know how ''The Pickup Artist'' started out, but there must have been more to it than now meets the eye.

title: Giants, a Pop Band
description: They Might Be Giants, a pop band, will perform tonight at 9 and midnight at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120), with the Ordinaires opening. Tickets are $10.

title: Diner's Journal
description: SIX-WEEK-OLD Chin Chin is the most visually striking Chinese restaurant since Auntie Yuan on First Avenue and 65th Street. That is no surprise, really, since James Chin, who owns this promising East 49th Street spot with his brother, Wally, spent five years as manager of Auntie Yuan. Moreover, some of Chin Chin's food, based on recent samplings, is equally arresting.

title: U.N. Council to Wait on Iran-Iraq Sanctions
description: The Security Council's 15 member nations believe that Iran may be seeking an end to its seven-year-old war with Iraq, Western diplomats said today.

title: When Fifth Avenue Becomes Book Lovers' Lane
description: WITH bibliomaniacal gleams in their eyes, a quarter of a million wordsmiths and bookworms are expected to take to the streets this weekend, rain or shine, for the annual orgy of erudition known as New York Is Book Country. This street fair devoted to the wonders of the printed word will transform a carfree, half-mile stretch of Fifth Avenue, from 48th to 57th Streets, and nearby blocks of 52d and 53d Streets, into a gigantic, outdoor literary emporium on Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Judge Bork at Senate Hearing: In Defense of Past Statements and Opinions
description: On the third day of hearings on the confirmation of Judge Robert H. Bork as a member of the Supreme Court, members of the Senate Judiciary Committee continued their questioning of Judge Bork. Following are excerpts, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Russian Tells of Easing Reactor Use
description: A top Soviet firefighting administrator said today that his country was gradually ending its heavy reliance on nuclear power reactors of the type destroyed in the nuclear accident at Chernobyl in April 1986.

title: Pirates Stop Cards After Rain Delays
description: Mike Dunne, traded away by St. Louis in April, allowed three hits over six innings tonight to beat his former club for the second time this season as Pittsburgh beat the Cardinals, 1-0, in a game delayed a total of 2 hours 39 minutes by rain.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Casey Stengel Lives
description: LEAD: This will provide scant consolation to New York fans watching the Yankees disappearing down the sinkhole and the Mets struggling to stay close to the Cardinals, but New York does have an oblique share of first place somewhere.

title: Boston and Soviet Plan Music Trade
description: Sarah Caldwell, the artistic director of the Opera Company of Boston, announced plans yesterday for a broad exchange between the artists and artistic institutions of Boston and Moscow, to begin with a three-week Festival of Soviet Music next March and April.

title: 1 Dead in Air Tanker Blast
description: A military air tanker parked on the tarmac at Barksdale Air Force Base exploded and burned today, killing one airman and injuring 16 other people, officials said. There was no immediate explanation for the blast and fire, which destroyed a KC-10A refueling tanker more than two hours after it had landed.

title: Clear Lake Journal; Oasis for Dance and Dream Endures
description: On the sweeping maple dance floor of the Surf Ballroom, love and memory mix magically, then linger like the swirling, cloudlike light patterns on the ceiling.

title: Leon Hirszman, 49, Is Dead; A Top Brazilian Film Director
description: Leon Hirszman, one of Brazil's best-known film directors, died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome Tuesday at the age of 49.

title: AUCTIONS
description: MERRY-GO-ROUNDS and carousel carvings -twirling for more than a century - have escalated sharply in value at auctions over the last decade. The upward price spiral is expected to continue next weekend in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., at a carousel and circus memorabilia sale organized by Guernsey's, a Manhattan auction concern specializing in extravaganza presentations of fairground art and other items.

title: Our Towns;

title: Boone Achieves Mark
description: When Bob Boone of the Angels crouched behind the plate Wednesday night against the Kansas City Royals in his 1,919th game as a catcher, he broke the record for major league games caught set by Al Lopez, who used to manage Boone's father, Ray, with the Cleveland Indians. ''I know him slightly, I spoke with him three or four times,'' Boone said of Lopez, a Hall of Fame member. ''I think what's special to me is the fact somewhere my name will be linked to Mickey Cochrane, Gabby Hartnett, Johnny Bench, Yogi Berra and Al Lopez. To me, I think that's something very special because I don't think of myself in the same category as those people.'' Boone, a .251 career hitter, explained his formula for success: ''The one thing I do best is just grind it out and go out there every day. You either do, or you can't. If you can't, get out. If you can, you can't let anybody else know about it.''

title: Haywood Dismissed

''I'm not interested in talking whys and wherefores,'' the Mariners' president, Chuck Armstrong, said. ''We just came to the reluctant conclusion that Bill Haywood will not be back as director of player development next year.'' Armstrong said his decision had ''absolutely nothing to do with the burnt-cork incident'' in June. Appearing as a guest speaker before about 25 members of the Northwest chapter of the Society for American Baseball Research, Haywood was asked about major league baseball's pledge to promote blacks for front-office jobs. ''I told my wife to get the burnt cork, because I'm probably going to have to wear a black face from here on out,'' he reportedly said. He never denied making the remark but he denied he was racist.

title: The Summit Record
description: September 1959 President Eisenhower and Nikita S. Khrushchev meet at Camp David, Md. Results: ''The Spirit of Camp David'' - a general feeling that scientific and cultural exchanges would be good and that disarmament was the world's main problem - but no concrete results. May 1960 Mr. Eisenhower and Mr. Khrushchev go to Paris, but the Russian uses the shooting down of the American U-2 spy plane over the Soviet Union to scotch the meeting. Results: Increased tensions. June 1961 Mr. Khrushchev and President Kennedy, in Vienna, have heated exchanges. Results: No formal agreements. A year later, the Soviet Union tries to put missiles in Cuba; the United States forces their removal. June 1967 President Johnson meets in Glassboro, N.J., with Aleksei N. Kosygin to discuss Middle East, the Vietnam War and nuclear arms. Results: No results on Vietnam; seeds sown for later arms talks. May 1972 President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, in Moscow, sign first treaties setting ceilings on strategic nuclear arms and limiting anti-ballistic missile systems. Results: They agree to keep negotiating on arms; regional issues still divide them. June 1973 Mr. Nixon and Mr. Brezhnev meet in Washington. Results: Agreement to try to complete a new arms treaty by 1974; agreements on practical issues. June-July 1974 Mr. Nixon and Mr. Brezhnev meet in Moscow and Yalta. Results: Treaty banning underground nuclear arms tests with yields exceeding 150 kilotons; 10-year economic pact. November 1974 President Ford and Mr. Brezhnev, in Vladivostok, reach tentative pact limiting missile launchers and bombers and lay base for second strategic arms treaty. Results: Treaty not completed before President Carter takes office; talks go back to starting point. June 1979 Mr. Carter and Mr. Brezhnev, in Vienna, sign the second treaty limiting strategic arms. Results: Though United States Senate never approves treaty, both sides agree to observe limits informally. November 1985 President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Geneva for wide-ranging talks on arms control and other subjects. Results: Cultural exchanges revived, air safety enhanced, but no arms control agreements achieved. October 1986 Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev meet in Reykjavik, Iceland, to provide momentum to arms control talks. Results: Two sides agreed to dramatic cuts in strategic arms and medium-range missiles, but accord fell through because of disagreements over American space defense plans and Moscow's insistence on putting all arms control issues in one package.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Yachting Two-Way Tie for Lead: Edward Warden Owen of Britain won all four of his match races in the Liberty Cup regatta yesterday to tie Gary Jobson of Annapolis, Md., for the lead in the second day of the series. Eight international sailing teams are competing in a four-day round of elimination races in New York Harbor. Rain was heavy at times yesterday along a two-mile course between Battery Park and Liberty Island, and winds were unstable and gusty. Jobson, who is the Liberty Cup defending champion, is competing against seven skippers. Each sails with a crew of four in an identical 30-foot sloop. A final match tomorrow between the two top boats will decide the winner. Overall scores for Jobson and Owen are 6-1. Tennis Smid Upsets Argentine: Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia upset fourth-seeded Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, 6-2, 7-6, yesterday to reach the semifinals of the $231,000 Geneva Open. The unseeded Smid put constant pressure on the backhand of Perez-Roldan, 17 years old. In the semifinals today, Smid will face top-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador, who defeated Thierry Tulasne of France, 7-6, 6-4. The other semifinal will match Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland and sixth-seeded Ulf Stenlund of Sweden. Mezzadri defeated a countryman, Roland Stadler, 6-4, 6-1; Stenlund rallied for a 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 victory over Horacio de la Pena of Argentina.(AP) Sabatini Advances: Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina overcame a slow start to beat Etsuko Inoue of Japan, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday in a quarterfinal match of the $300,000 Pan Pacific Women's Open in Tokyo. Inoue is Japan's No. 1 player and ranked 42d in the world. In other quarterfinals, second-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria overcame Marianne Werdel of the United States, 4-6, 7-5, 6-1; Katerina Maleeva, a younger sister of Manuela, trounced Dianne Balestrat of Australia, 6-2, 6-0, and Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden outlasted Barbara Potter of the United States 7-5, 5-7, 6-4.(AP) Golf Player and Moody in Tie: Gary Player and Orville Moody birdied five of the last seven holes yesterday and both shot 66 to share the opening-round lead at the $325,000 Crestar Seniors Classic in Richmond. The 51-year-old Player sank a 35-footer on the 18th hole to cap a run of four straight birdies. Player, who won last weekend's tournament at Charlotte, N.C., in a playoff, had six birdies and no bogeys on the par-72 Hermitage Country Club layout. Moody made eight birdies and two bogeys. One shot off the lead at 67 were Larry Mowry and Gene Littler.(AP) Two Share L.P.G.A. Lead: Missie Beteotti and Jan Stephenson shared the lead yesterday after two rounds of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Safeco Classic in Kent, Wash. Berteotti, in her second year on the tour, shot 69 and Stephenson had a 70. Their 36-hole totals of six-under-par 138 on the 6,222-yard Meridian Valley Country Club course left them two strokes ahead of Shirley Furlong, who carded a 68.

title: Journey to a Joint Understanding
description: June 9, 1977 NATO reports the Soviet Union has been deploying the SS-20, a three-warhead, intermediate-range ballistic missile, in its western regions. Oct. 28, 1977 In a speech in London on the dangers of an escalating arms race, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany expresses particular concern about the SS-20. Dec. 12, 1979 NATO's Council of Ministers adopts ''dual track'' approach: The U.S. will begin deployment of ground-launched cruise missiles and Pershing 2's in 1983; negotiations will be held between U.S. and Soviet Union on limiting medium-range arms. Nov. 18, 1981 President Reagan announces his ''zero-zero'' proposal, which cancels planned deployment of cruise missiles and Pershing 2's in Europe if Soviet dismantles its SS-20's, SS-4's and SS-5's. Included is freeze on shorter-range missiles. Does not include British and French nuclear forces or U.S. aircraft. February-March 1982 Russians reject ''zero-zero'' proposal, countering with call for phased reduction in NATO and Warsaw Pact medium-range missiles and nuclear-armed aircraft to 600 systems by 1985 and 300 by 1990. Leonid I. Brezhnev also announces moratorium on SS-20 deployment in Europe. Nov. 23, 1983 First Pershing 2's are delivered to Europe and Russians walk out of negotiations without setting date for resumption of talks. March 12, 1985 Medium-range arms talks resume as one part of negotiations in Geneva on nuclear and space arms. U.S. offers version of ''zero-zero'' proposal and Soviet calls for freeze of all new missile deployments, offering to reduce SS-20's in Europe in exchange for elimination of U.S. medium-range missiles. Jan. 15, 1986 Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposes to eliminate all U.S. and Soviet medium-range missiles in Europe over next five to seven years. British and French forces would not be allowed any buildup. Proposal is not linked to other Geneva arms talks. February 1986 U.S. responds with proposal that would eliminate medium-range missiles in Europe by 1990 along with proportional reductions in Soviet SS-20's in Asia. During reduction period, separate and equal limits would be set for warheads. Again, British and French forces are not included. U.S. proposal includes technical details for verification procedures, including on-site inspection, marked deployment areas and procedures for destruction of missiles. Oct. 11-12, 1986 At summit in Reykjavik, Iceland, both sides agree to elimination of all European-based medium-range missiles and equal limits of 100 on warheads outside European theater. Plan rejected because Soviet Union insists on making it part of overall arms deal. Feb. 28, 1987 Mr. Gorbachev announces Soviet willingness to sign ''without delay'' an agreement to eliminate Soviet and U.S. medium-range forces in Europe over next five years. Offer is first time since Reykjavik that Soviet Union has been willing to negotiate separately on medium-range missiles. Proposal identical to one on the table at Reykjavik. March 3, 1987 President Reagan directs U.S. arms negotiators to begin drafting treaty on medium-range missiles in response to Mr. Gorbachev's earlier announcement, and says he welcomes chance to have medium-range arms treaty separate from other arms talks in Geneva. July 22, 1987 Mr. Gorbachev accepts U.S. plan on worldwide elimination of all medium-range missiles, removing his previous requirement of dealing only with such missiles in Europe. Aug. 26, 1987 Chancellor Helmut Kohl announces West Germany will eliminate its 72 Pershing 1A's, with American-owned warheads, if Soviet Union and U.S. agree to plan to scrap all medium- and shorter-range missiles. Sept. 18, 1987 After three days of talks, U.S. and Soviet reach agreement in principle to conclude accord on global elimination of medium- and shorter-range missiles. Details of timing of elimination and verification procedures remain to be worked out. Source: Arms Control Association

Like the Affair itself, it raises issues that go far beyond the immediate acts of injustice that led to Alfred Dreyfus's conviction for high treason in 1894, and that upheld the original verdict at his second court-martial in 1899. It also features an extraordinary range of pictures, documents and memorabilia.

title: FOR ARCTIC INDIANS, A PAPAL PROMISE
description: Three years ago, while making a 12-day tour of Canada, Pope John Paul II was scheduled to celebrate a mass for Indians in a ceremonial tepee set up on a tribal meeting ground here beside the Mackenzie River. But the fog that often blankets this tiny community just 350 miles south of the Arctic Circle, prevented the Pope's aircraft from landing. The visit was called off, on a radioed promise by the Pope to return someday. Someday is Sunday. After completing his visit to the United States, the Pope plans to redeem that promise by diverting here on his return to Rome. The Canadian authorities, better prepared this time, have flown in modern radar equipment to assist in the landing of the chartered Boeing 737 that was to carry the Pope.

title: Picking The Winners

Hanley, whose bony features made him look younger than his 23 years, had driven from his office at the National City Bank.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: IRISH FESTIVAL A ''Day of Ireland'' in Morris County - with bagpipes, step dancing and singing - will begin at 9 A.M. next Sunday at the College of St. Elizabeth in Convent Station. At 11 A.M., the Very Rev. Frank Rodimer, Bishop of Paterson, will celebrate mass in the college's amphitheater, and at 1:30 P.M. Paddy Noonan's Irish Showband, with the singer Andy Cooney, will perform. Step dancers will vie for prizes, as will pipe and drum bands. The festival, sponsored by the Irish-American Association of Northwest Jersey, ends at 5:30 P.M. with the last event of the day: massed pipes and drums playing in unison. Refreshments and Irish products will be on sale throughout the day. Admission is $5 ($2 for the elderly and children 11 through 16). Children under 11 will be admitted free. The college is on Route 24 in Convent Station. Information: (201) 827-5347.

Her earlier, well-received ''The Book of Phoebe'' told the tale of a young girl's coming-of-age; in this novel, she details the careers of two women whose lives intertwine even as they follow different paths.

title: RACING FOR LIFE
description: THE CALL CAME at 11 A.M., three days before Christmas 1986. Marguerite Brown, the donor coordinator for Stanford University Medical Center's transplant program, took it at her desk in the cardiovascular research center. The St. Paul Red Cross had received news of a crib death in Fargo, N.D. The 4-month-old infant's heart had been successfully resuscitated, but the brain had not survived. The family of the infant had given permission for transplantation as long as anonymity was maintained. An official at the Red Cross had punched the blood type, weight and age of the infant donor into the national computer, and Stanford had come up on the screen.

title: CHRISTIE'S :VERDICT': ETHICAL MELODRAMA
description: DAME Agatha Christie's name is synonymous with the mystery thriller genre, and the term ''a good Christie'' refers to a tightly knit play or novel, filled with red herrings and psychological insights, often involving an extraordinarily clever detective. However, Dame Agatha occasionally exercised her writer's prerogative to stretch beyond the material with which she was most comfortable.

title: Hard Times for the Euromarkets
description: FOR the first time in years, experienced Eurobond dealers are looking for jobs - and not finding them. In one major sector of the Euromarkets, for floating-rate notes, roughly a quarter of the people have lost their jobs in the past year. Many banks and investment houses have quietly retreated from the most competitive areas, while a big British bank, Lloyds Bank P.L.C., announced three months ago that it was pulling out of the Euromarkets altogether. A new-found penchant for controlling costs is also in vogue. Suddenly, firms are getting stingier with their cornucopia of perks, from Concorde tickets to corporate taxi accounts.

To wit: ''Economists have the least influence on policy where they know the most and are most agreed; they have the most influence on policy where they know the least and disagree most.'' title: A Naturalists' Haven Off Canada
description: ''Albatross!'' At the skipper's cry, all eyes swept to starboard of the Darwin Sound II, a 71-foot ketch chartering in the Queen Charlotte Islands off Canada's Northwest coast. It took a moment or two for an untrained eye to pick up, a dark shadow gliding across the whitecaps of the heaving sea. After circling the yacht twice at a distance, it settled down gracefully amid a gaggle of smaller birds feasting on the breakfast of popcorn and pancakes cast overboard by the crew.

title: TWO VETERAN ROCK POETS WHO REFUSE TO COMPROMISE
description: NO ONE WHO HAS SEEN ''THE Last Waltz,'' Martin Scorsese's film of the Band's 1976 farewell concert in San Francisco, is likely to forget the cinematic close-ups of the guest stars Van Morrison and Neil Young. A puffy leprechaun with a wary, superstitious air, the Irish-born Mr. Morrison had already shed the last vestiges of any youthful pop-star glamour. And so had Mr. Young. Craggy-faced and glaring, the Canadian singer-songwriter projected the edgy, eccentric defiance of a crazy renegade farmer.

title: THE REGION: Battle Over Beaches; New Jersey Spoils for Scrap With Polluter
description: SWIMMERS throughout the region can tell sadly of tar balls on the sand and unspeakable floating objects, but in New Jersey it was an exceptional summer for beach closings. The State Environmental Protection Department counted more than a dozen episodes serious enough to call for closings, including a rise in fecal coliform bacteria off Atlantic City that closed beaches there for the first time in local memory.

title: Plays Considered During a Needed Intermission
description: WHILE WATCHING THE last rays of New York summer theater - ''Sherlock's Last Case,'' ''Henry IV, Part I'' and ''Bunker Reveries'' -it struck me (no revelation) that those of us who work in the critical profession spend entirely too much time viewing. Almost every evening and on occasional matinee days, we are in the dark looking at actors trying to inject life into sometimes inert objects. When there is an off night, a night away from the theater, a drama critic can often be found at the movies or the dance - in other words, seeing something in a related performance art. Actually my last summer theatrical experience was at a rock concert - David Bowie's final New York performance at Madison Square Garden, which, as some might say about experimental theater, was visually arresting although somewhat lacking in intellectual content.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BENEFITS FROM FRANCE Franco-American cultural relations in the 20th century are the subject of a six-part free lecture and film series beginning at 7:45 P.M. Tuesday in the Greenburgh Town Hall. ''In Westchester we have reminders of the French presence in street and town names, such as Huguenot Street in New Rochelle,'' said Madeleine Guttman, executive director of the Arts and Culture Committee of the Greenburgh Town Library. ''We may be aware of their historical, political and military significance, but it's important to remember how invigorated America has been by the artistic and intellectual exchanges.'' ''Reciprocities: Paris-New York'' will be led by six scholars who are acknowledged experts on the subject of the artists they will be lecturing about. Ulla E. Dydo, professor of English at City University of New York, will talk Tuesday about the difference between Gertrude Stein the writer and Gertrude Stein the flamboyant public personality. The film, ''Gertrude Stein: When You See This, Remember Me,'' produced in 1971 by Perry Miller Adato and containing filmed footage of Miss Stein and many of her celebrated contemporaries, will be shown. On Sept. 29 Arthur King Peters will discuss the unconventional works of Jean Cocteau in film, poetry, painting, design and music. A seldom-seen film based on an early Cocteau novel called ''Thomas the Imposter,'' produced in 1965, will be screened featuring Jean Marais, Cocteau's longtime companion, as narrator. Future programs are to focus on Jean-Louis Barrault, the distinguished actor, mime and director; Albert Camus, the novelist and member of the French resistance movement in World War II; Andre Malraux, the novelist, essayist and outspoken anti-Fascist, and Simone de Beauvoir, an early feminist and companion of the existential writer Jean-Paul Sartre. Leading these programs will be Muriel Balash, film producer, writer and director; Lionel Abel, professor emeritus of English at State University of New York at Buffalo; and Francoise Dorenlot and Rosette C. Lamont, Parisians who are on the staff of the graduate school at the City University of New York.

title: Key to City
description: IT will be awhile before he'll be free to play professional basketball, but David Robinson, the 7-foot-1-inch center who is fulfilling his obligations to the Navy, decided to take a look at San Antonio, the home of the Spurs, the team that made him its first choice in the National Basketball Association draft. Although team officials are barred from talking to Robinson because of the N.B.A. moratorium on contract negotiations, Robinson wasn't getting the silent treatment when he arrived by plane Friday. Some 350 fans were at the airport to greet him, and the schedule laid out by the Spurs included a golf tournament, a helicopter tour of the city, several dinner parties and a chat with Mayor Henry Cisneros.

For a moment, I thought I might be faced with another thinly disguised apologia for Iran-contra illegalities; but I quickly concluded that no one would think of linking Mr. Lincoln with a cabal of contra thugs, Argentine colonels and amateurish, free-enterprise cold-warriors.
