title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Yachting Protests at Liberty Cup: Protests in the Liberty Cup semifinals yesterday suspended advancement to today's finals by Gary Jobson of Annapolis, Md., and Peter Gilmour of Australia. Jobson beat Pelle Petterson of Sweden in the first two races of the two-of-three-race semifinal series, and Gilmour beat Edward Warden Owen in his first two match races. But protests were filed in all four races, leaving the results undecided until an international jury hears the cases today. Gilmour moved into a semifinal position by edging Chris Dickson of New Zealand over a protest earlier in the day, the third of the four-day regatta in New York Harbor. Eight international skippers have been competing, each with a crew of four, in identical 30-foot sloops. Tennis Sabatini and Maleeva in Final: Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina and second-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria will meet in the title after winning their semifinal matches yesterday in the $300,000 Pan Pacific women's tournament in Tokyo. Sabatini, who is ranked eighth in the world, needed a tiebreaker before defeating Katerina Maleeva, Manuela's younger sister, 7-6, 6-4. Manuela beat Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden 6-3, 3-6, 6-4.(AP) Gomez Upset by Smid: Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia upset top-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador, 7-6, 4-6, 6-0, yesterday in the semifinals of the $231,000 Geneva Open men's tournament. In today's final, Smid will face his doubles partner in this tourney, unseeded Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland. Mezzadri beat sixth-seeded Ulf Stenlund of Sweden, 6-2, 6-7, 7-6, in 3 hours 39 minutes in yesterday's other semifinal. Smid and Mezzadri have met in singles only once, and the Czechoslovak won.(AP) Track and Field Budd Wins Event: Zola Budd continued her comeback, running much faster than she had expected in winning the Kodak Classic 10-kilometer road race yesterday in Bangor, North Ireland. The 21-year-old naturalized Briton, who was sidelined for nearly a year with thigh and hip injuries, was timed in 32 minutes 17 seconds, easily beating a modest field of mainly Northern Irish runners.(AP) Golf Wrenn, Hallberg in Tie: Robert Wrenn and Gary Hallberg, who once were teammates at Wake Forest, moved into a first-place tie yesterday after three rounds of the rain-delayed $600,000 Greater Milwaukee Open. Despite a bogey on the final hole, Wrenn shot a 70 and was at 13-under-par 203 on the 7,030-yard, par-72 Tuckaway Country Club course. Hallberg had a 67. Larry Ziegler, the second-round leader, shot a par 72 and was tied at 204 with Wayne Levi, who had a 68. Fred Couples, who shot a 65, was next at 205, followed by Nick Price, Dan Pohl, Bill Kratzert and Mark Calcavecchia at 206.(AP) Hill, Berteotti in Tie: Cindy Hill shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to tie Missie Berteotti for the lead after three rounds of the $225,000 Safeco Classic in Kent, Wash. Berteotti, in her second year on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, shot a two-under-par 70. The two leaders had a total of eight-under-par 208 after 54 holes. One stroke back going into today's final round on the 6,222-yard Meridian Valley Country Club course was Jan Stephenson, who shared the second-round lead with Berteotti but fell back with a 71.(AP) Charles Ahead by 2 Shots: Bob Charles of New Zealand, a runner-up in each of his last two tournaments, fired a six-under-par 66 yesterday for a two-shot lead after two rounds of the $325,000 Crestar PGA Senior Golf Classic in Richmond. Charles had a 36-hole score of 10-under-par 134. The defending champion, Chi Chi Rodriguez; Dale Douglass and the Senior PGA Tour rookie, Larry Mowry, were next at 136. Rodriguez and Douglass each shot 68's, while Mowry had a 69. For his two rounds on the 6,644-yard Hermitage Country Club course, Charles has hit 34 of 36 greens and had only one bogey.(AP) Harness Racing Dexter Cup to Crowns Best: Crowns Best, a 3-year-old bay colt driven by John Campbell, overtook Crown Sweep midway through the stretch last night to win the 28th annual Dexter Cup at Roosevelt Raceway. Crowns Best covered the one-mile trot, which offered a purse of $167,962, in 2:00 3/5. In scoring a three-quarter length victory over J. R. Broline, driven by Mike La Chance, Crowns Best earned $83,981 to bring his season's earnings to $337,425. Sir Taurus, with Ben Webster driving, went off as a 9-5 favorite and finished third. Crowns Best, who has won 11 of 15 starts this year, paid $18 for $2 to win.

But it is wrong to conclude that terrorism has ended or even abated. And few people inside or outside Government doubt that large-scale attacks against American and Western European targets could resume at any time.

title: NONFICTION
description: I'M DYING LAUGHING: The Humourist. By Christina Stead. (Holt, $19.95.) Readers of Christina Stead's masterful chronicle of family life, ''The Man Who Loved Children,'' will immediately recognize the exuberance of style and imagination in the Australian novelist's last major work, left unfinished at her death in 1983 and now edited by R. G. Geering, her literary executor. Like ''The Man Who Loved Children,'' it was inspired by her 10-year residence in America. Caught in a tragic web of familial and political conflict, Emily and Stephen Howard embody what Stead calls the ''American dilemma'' - which is ''that you want to be free and break new ground, speak your mind, fear no man, have the neighbors acknowledge that you're a good man; and at the same time you want to be a success, make money, join the country club, get the votes and kick the other man in the teeth and off the ladder.'' Thus, they are members of both the Communist Party and Hollywood's ''fashionable leftist society''; they decry the rich, yet must depend on periodic handouts from Stephen's wealthy mother; and they have little trouble setting aside their high literary ideals when they discover Emily's gift for making money as a writer of domestic potboilers. ''I'm Dying Laughing'' forcefully portrays the poisonous betrayals of the McCarthy years and the way the most principled-seeming person, ground down by life's compromises, may yield to cynicism. These larger themes are obscured, however, by the attention given to the smallest details of the Howards' daily life, and by a rambling plot that follows the couple through three decades and across Europe and America. By turns fascinating and irritating, the novel is one of those loose and baggy monsters that can try one's patience even as it impresses itself in memory.

title: A BETTER MOUSETRAP
description: What a pleasure to read Gregg Levoy's article ''A Better Mousetrap'' (About Men, Aug. 23). I had just returned home after a day spent protesting at the National Trappers Convention, in Mansfield, Ohio, where a story such as Mr. Levoy's would have been met with boos and beer bottles. I had seen men who delighted in teaching young children how to trap, club and skin animals for fun and profit. Some contrast to a man who finds joy in sparing a life, even the smallest of God's creation. RITCHIE MARGARET ANDREW Columbus, Ohio

title: The Seasonal Pace Is Quickening
description: START planting bulbs as soon as first shipments arrive from nurseries or selections are purchased at garden centers. Set out the smallest bulbs first under trees, near shrubs or naturalize them in the lawn. If annuals and perennials are still in bloom, postpone any bulb planting until a hard frost. Continue rose care. Cut herbs for drying or freezing, but wash leaves and stems first. Last call to sow lettuce, radish and spinach seed for late vegetable crops. Keep up the transition and move any vacationing house plants indoors. Bees Love It

description: THE rumblings out of Africa about possible supply interruptions of strategic metals - the likes of chromium, cobalt and platinum upon which Western nations depend for industry and military uses - may raise the pulses of sophisticated traders in London, at least for an afternoon. But in the United States, the rumors have set phone lines ringing as high-pressure salesmen offer their wares - options, futures contracts, and variations on those instruments - to gullible investors.

title: Can Kirstie Alley Keep the 'Cheers' Bar Open?
description: KIRSTIE ALLEY SAT IN A COR-ner of Stage 25 Pararamount -the stage where ''Cheers'' has been filmed for the last five years. There were 10 cigarette butts standing on end, like a row of primitive soldiers, in front of her. ''When I'm nervous, I don't eat and I smoke cigarettes and line them up,'' she said. ''Walking around this set, I shake. For the first few days I was out of my mind. I felt like when I went to a new school in my new dress with my new pencil box.''

Even practical pulled-back styles allow for a sense of fun. Fringes poke out over the forehead, a tail falls down the back, or every strand is pulled into an oversize bun.

title: Bottom Line
description: WHEN Mikhail S. Gorbachev preaches ''perestroika,'' the Soviet leader apparently means business, at least for play, although ''restructuring'' hardly seems the word to describe the revolutionary transformation of the Dnepr soccer club of Dnepropetrovsk, Ukraine. According to Tass, the Soviet press agency, Dnepr, one of the 12 teams in the top-level league that plays in European competition, has become the first sports organization in the Soviet Union to give up its state subsidy and adopt a system of ''self-financing,'' in which all club expenses, including athletes' salaries, will be paid from ticket sales, fan donations, souvenir sales and, eventually perhaps, commercial advertising.

title: A SMITHSONIAN DIG RESULTS IN TWO MUSEUMS
description: THE SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION has had a curious architectural history. It began in a blaze of glory in 1857 with the completion of the lilting and sumptuous Gothic castle on the Mall by James Renwick, the Smithsonian's original home, but as this vast complex of museums has grown, its architecture has seemed more and more to sputter. There have been some decent buildings, like the Beaux-Arts Museum of Natural History, and quite a few wretched ones, like the banal modern box that is the Museum of American History or the round concrete bunker that is the Hirshhorn Museum. Throughout several generations of construction, however, one thing has remained clear: No work of architecture has come close to challenging Renwick's castle as this sprawling institution's best building.

title: FOOD TEAM PUTS TOGETHER NEW PRODUCT

The new contract provides wage increases of 18 percent to 28 percent over two years, depending on experience, said Ronald J. Del Mauro, president and chief executive of the hospital.

title: NONFICTION
description: KATHARINE THE GREAT: Katharine Graham and The Washington Post. By Deborah Davis. (National Press, 7508 Wisconsin Avenue, Bethesda, Md. 20814, $17.95.) Shortly after ''Katharine the Great'' was first published in 1979, its publisher, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, withdrew it and shredded thousands of copies after reviewing complaints regarding the book's accuracy from Katharine Graham, chairman of the Washington Post Company, and Benjamin C. Bradlee, executive editor of the newspaper. The book's author, Deborah Davis, filed suit against Harcourt Brace for breach of contract and received a $100,000 settlement in 1983. The new ''Katharine the Great,'' which is essentially the same as the original, is an unauthorized account of Mrs. Graham's life, including her marriage to the brilliant and mentally troubled Philip Graham, who committed suicide in 1963. At his death, Mrs. Graham took charge of The Washington Post, which had been acquired by her father in 1933, and the book tells of her transformation from a bright housewife into what Ms. Davis portrays as a powerful, sometimes ruthless, press mogul. The book offers detail, but it is weakened by an absence of footnotes, though some general sources are mentioned in an appendix. Ms. Davis takes a shot at identifying ''Deep Throat,'' the primary source of The Post's Watergate coverage. She says it was Richard Ober, a Harvard classmate of Mr. Bradlee and a former C.I.A. operative. One of Ms. Davis's central themes is that for many years the C.I.A. has manipulated The Washington Post, as well as other news organizations. For instance, she says that the Watergate scandal was essentially created by the C.I.A. to discredit President Nixon, who was, in turn, trying to discredit the agency. New to this edition is an appendix charging that Mr. Bradlee was part of what Ms. Davis characterizes as a C.I.A.-sponsored propaganda effort in the early 50's to bolster support for the espionage convictions of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. Mr. Bradlee was press attache at the United States Embassy in Paris at the time, and - in a letter to Ms. Davis included in the appendix - says that as ''the embassy's expert on the case'' he prepared ''a 30,000 word witness-by-witness account of the crime.'' In the same letter, he also says that all Ms. Davis's allegations about his association with the C.I.A. are false.

title: A WRITER AT HIS BEST
description: MAJOR events seem to happen to Reynolds Price on significant dates. In 1933, Price's mother went into protracted, nearly fatal, labor with him just hours after Hitler had become Chancellor of Germany. When Price reached manhood, when he was exactly 21 years and 21 days old, his father died. On the day in 1955 that he sailed for England to begin a Rhodes scholarship at Merton College, Oxford - his first trip out of the country, and the beginning of his adult life - James Dean, one of his heroes and the embodiment of troubled youth, died in a car accident.

One of these, glumly dressed in striped pajamas and cuddling a battered Winnie-the-Pooh, was unmistakably the British actor Freddie Jones. But the woman beside him was harder to identify, heavily camouflaged as she was in rouge and lipstick and gold bangles, spiraling coils and loops of off-blonde hair, and black chiffon twirling coyly and cutely down her torso. Everything about her was in the most impeccably awful taste. Surely it wasn't, it couldn't be, Vanessa Redgrave?

title: FICTION
description: MORTAL BELLADAYWIC. By Mark Christensen. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $16.95.) Mark Christensen's first novel is intended as a lampoon of political bureaucracy and universal corruption. Its hero is Bear Belladaywic, a perpetually soused fellow ''addicted to having things happen to him.'' This 34-year-old attorney from Portland, Ore., is a 6-foot-5 blond ex-athlete gone to epic bloated seed. He hasn't had an innocent client in his four years of practice. He is currently representing Joey Holtzman, the leader of a ''27-piece heavy metal marching band'' - a slack-jawed punk accused of gunning down two narcotics officers during a drug raid. Bear is infatuated with Joey's sister Cindy, a local emergency room nurse and the stoic mother of Bear's illegitimate son. As he researches Joey's case, Bear downs kegs of Blitz beer, seduces nubile receptionists and smashes and abandons luxury vehicles. At one point he maneuvers a Sherman tank, serves time in a country club-style penitentiary and samples Master Smack, a drug so potent it is destined to become ''number three on everybody's list. Right behind air and water.'' The novel peaks at Joey's trial, when Bear is set against his own father, a legendary Oregonian prosecutor and beloved Congressman, ''a Clarence Darrow from 1,500,000 B.C.'' Painted as a grand cartoon of slovenly New Wave machismo bent on both salvaging the planet and remaining drunkenly irresponsible, Bear becomes the center of the book's satirical thrust. The plotting of the novel, particularly in its political meanderings, unfortunately, becomes incoherent. A hero like Bear might have been better served by a less dizzyingly haywire framework.

We're starting a series of matinees for senior citizens, and we've rolled comedy, folk music and motion into one great new package called 'Fridays at 9.' ''

title: TV: Musical Women of the Calabash
description: ''THE black nation is in the dark because we have no representative in Parliament,'' reads a subtitle to a chant by the all-female percussion and vocal quartet Women of the Calabash. The group, which plays a variety of Afro-Caribbean percussion, including the shaken gourdlike instruments known as calabashes, is featured on this season's final episode of the popular avant-garde series ''Alive From Off Center,'' which is to be broadcast on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight. In the director Skip Blumberg's portrayal of the group, modern technological wizardry and primitive imagery are provocatively interwoven in ways that underscore the dichotomy between the harsh political realities of the present and seemingly timeless Afro-Caribbean rituals.

description: LEAD: DO you want to see a goose that has been laying golden eggs for the United States for several decades? Take a look at the World Bank. You will see that it is one of the sweetest international deals the United States has ever made.

title: POSTINGS: Mortgage Rates; Up Again
description: Mortgage rates, which have been rising since Aug. 28, reached a 21-month high last week, and economists expect more increases if capital market rates continue to go up. Nationally, and in the metropolitan area, 30-year-fixed mortgage rates increased by slightly over a half-pecentage point to 10.97 percent. Lenders, who prefer to write adjustable loans, kept increases on one-year adjustables to one-fifth of a percentage point, charging 7.88 percent for the first year, according to HSH Associates, a financial publisher. Cooperative loans increased by the same margins, to 11.65 percent for fixed loans and to 7.9 percent for adjustables. Just last March fixed-rates had fallen to a nine-year low of 9.09 percent.

title: Q and A
description: Sea Cloud Question: Travel agents tell me that E. F. Hutton's private yacht, the Sea Cloud, is available only to groups, not to individuals. How can I find out about the special-interest groups that are reserving the ship so that I can arrange to sail on it? - B. C., Burlingame, Calif. Answer: It is true that this 29-sail ship is not marketed through travel agents. Travel Dynamics, the company that has exclusive reservation rights for the vessel in the United States, arranges charters for groups from museums and educational institutions. However, it says it would be happy to help individual passengers either by directing them to institutions that have booked the Sea Cloud or by arranging to add them to the passenger list. Its address: 132 East 70th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021 (212-517-7555 or, out of state, 800-367-6766).

Would she accept the recommendations of a high-school graduate on the proper method for a complex dental procedure? I think not! Sometimes we held our breath as our keel scraped across a reef that, according to the charts, should have prevented us from entering one of the long, narrow fjords that are called canals in British Columbia.

title: Jazz: Marc Cohen, Pianist
description: THE piano style of Bill Evans lives on in the playing of Marc Cohen. Most pianists since the 1950's have been affected in some way by Evans's subtle, chromatic harmonies, but Mr. Cohen goes further. He has embraced the velvet-slippered Evans touch and, more difficult, the way Evans would develop solos, in introspective wisps and airy abstractions that left a song's chord changes far away. With Gary Peacock on bass and Jeff Hirschfield on drums Thursday at Fat Tuesday's, he also re-created the interplay of Evans trios - brushes and cymbals swishing as bass and piano tossed around melodies.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WOMEN IN ART The purpose of the ''American Women Artists'' exhibition opening today at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford is to bring more women artists into the mainstream, say its organizers. The traveling show, which is organized by the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington, is making its only stop in the Northeast at the Atheneum, where it will remain until Nov. 15. Most of the 118 works executed between 1830 and 1930 are portraits, ''reflecting the fact that women who painted nudes, climbed scaffolding, or traveled alone were socially unacceptable,'' according to the Atheneum's publicist, Claudia Bell. Eleanor Tufts, curator of the show, will give a free lecture at 3 P.M. today. Talks by the director of the National Museum of Women in the Arts, Anne-Imelda Radice, and by an art historian, William Gerdts, are scheduled on Oct. 11 and Nov. 8. A number of events related to the show include an original one-act play about Georgia O'Keeffe to be presented at the Hartford Stage Company, 8 P.M. Oct. 23 and 24, and 3 P.M. Oct. 25; a film series at 2 P.M. on four Saturdays in October about the lives of Mary Cassatt, Georgia O'Keeffe, Louise Nevelson and Helen Frankenthaler, and a special children's program on Nov. 14, at the Atheneum. Among other coordinated events and exhibitions around the state is ''American Women Artists of Old Lyme, 1900-40,'' on view Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and 1 to 5 P.M. Sundays through Nov. 29 at the Florence Griswold Museum, 96 Lyme Street, Old Lyme. American Women Composers' Concerts will be performed in Marlborough, Trumbull, New Haven, Middletown and New Britain from Oct. 4 through Nov. 22, and a series of lectures by female authors will take place at the Noah Webster House in West Hartford. The Atheneum exhibition may be seen from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Sunday. Admission is $3; students and the elderly pay $1.50, except on Thursdays and from 11 A.M. to 1 P.M. Saturdays when the public is admitted free. A complete list of events and exhibitions around the state may be obtained by calling the Atheneum, 278-2670.

title: Headliners; Moving Slowly

Mr. Gruss disclosed several months ago that he would contribute generously - ''over $30 million,'' said officials of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies - to Jewish religious education, but he did not say just when. In a surprise call last week, the 84-year-old philanthropist told U.J.A.-Federation officials that he was ready to sign the documents that would provide, among other things, salary and pension benefits for 4,500 teachers in Jewish schools. He said he took time to make sure the agreement was perfect. ''It is important that there be nothing wrong - not even a mosquito to slip through,'' he said.

description: IN 1965, when Congress was drafting legislation to create Medicare, the president of the American Medical Association testified against it, warning that there was ''no totally effective method'' to control its cost. Events bore out his warning: Despite many ingenious efforts to restrain the cost of the program, Medicare outlays continue to surge upward, raising serious questions about how the nation will pay for the health care that its elderly citizens want and need in the future. Medicare spending has climbed from $3.4 billion in 1967 to $75.9 billion in 1986, but on the average the elderly still pay a quarter of their medical expenses from their own pockets.

description: Coup de Torchon (Clean Slate) With Philippe Noiret, Isabelle Huppert, Jean-Pierre Marielle, Stephane Audran, Guy Marchand, Eddy Mitchell, Irene Skobline. Produced by Adolphe Viezzi. Directed by Bertrand Tavernier. 1981. Subtitled. Embassy Home Entertainment. 128 minutes. $29.95.

title: When on the Move
description: DIDN'T someone once say, ''The telephone always rings twice?'' Mine seems to, anyway. One day it was a friend suggesting that I do a column about photographing from a helicopter. The next day it was another friend who wanted to know how to take pictures while on a motorboat.

title: Bacterial Outbreak Spurs Medical Alert in Chicago
description: Health officials are alerting hospitals and nursing homes around the city to an unexplained bacterial outbreak linked to three deaths and to illnesses in 35 patients.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Jose, Calif.;
A Downtown Building Boom
description: LEAD: THIS booming capital of the high-tech industry 50 miles south of San Francisco has grown from under 250,000 people in 1960 to more than 700,000 today. Until recently, however, its downtown remained the sleepy little crossroads it was when farms and orchards rather than computer think tanks and microchip factories dominated the horizon.

title: When Teaching Isn't All Pay
description: FOR years, she was known as America's lowest-paid teacher, and that got her and her one-room schoolhouse national news coverage, even a letter from President Reagan praising her dedication. But last year, the school - in McLeod, N.D. -closed for a lack of pupils, and the teacher, Janice Herbranson, a 52-year-old widow earning $6,800 a year, lost her job.

title: NEW ROCHELLE GETS READY FOR AMTRAK
description: PARKING in the area of the New Rochelle Railroad Station could take on new dimensions next month when Amtrak begins long-awaited service here with an expanded facility that eliminates its stop in Rye.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Our wood-shingle roof was sprayed with a mixture of wood preservative and linseed oil last year and some of this spray drifted onto the windows - on the glass and the metal frames. I have tried all kinds of window cleaners, but when the cleaner dries the droplets seem to reappear. Have you any suggestions?

title: IN YONKERS, YOUNG DEMOCRATIC CHALLENGERS
description: LEAD: IN Yonkers, where Republicans hold three of four county legislative seats despite the city's heavily Democratic voter registration, the Democratic Party has turned to a group of young aspirants in its effort to unseat the incumbents.

title: JANE RASKIN WED TO LEROY BROWN
description: Jane Raskin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. H. Raskin of New York and Chilmark, Mass., and Leroy A. Brown, the son of Mrs. Henry Raymond of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Frank Brown, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the New York home of the bride's parents by Justice Stanley Parness of the Appellate Term of State Supreme Court.

title: SUSAN KARWOSKI IS THE BRIDE OF D. DAVID JONKER
description: Susan Karwoski, a daughter of Mrs. Eugene W. Karwoski of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mr. Karwoski, was married yesterday to D. David Jonker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Daniel Jonker of Maplewood, N.J. The Rev. Robert Valentine performed the ceremony at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford.

title: BATTLE LOOMING OVER WINE COOLER TAX
description: A BATTLE is brewing over the marketing of alcoholic ''coolers'' in New Jersey and, judging by what has happened in other states, the lobbying could become intense by the time it reaches the Legislature.

title: New York Probation Program Gets $100,000
description: Some of his best workers, says Albert A. Abney, an automotive parts rebuilder in Queens, were once convicted of crimes ranging from shoplifting to murder.

title: DATA BANK: September 20, 1987
Rock: The Radiators
description: FROM their native New Orleans to points far north, the Radiators have been packing clubs and dance floors for 10 years. It's easy to hear why; the Radiators command a groove that goes straight to the hips. Now, the band is about to go national, with an album, ''Law of the Fish,'' due for release Sept. 30 on Epic Records. As a preview, the Radiators played Thursday at the Ritz, stirring up dancers and a surprisingly high number of air-guitar players.

title: Suspect Held in Bronx Killings
description: A third suspect was arrested yesterday in connection with a drug-related shooting in the South Bronx last month that left three people dead and three seriously wounded, the police said.

title: Season to Show A Lot of Promise
description: Despite the fact that there will be no Metro Bowl game this year, matching the best from the New York City Public Schools against the best from the Catholic Schools, the high school football season continues to hold a lot of promise.

title: FOR DOORS, AN OPEN-AND-SHUT CASE
description: I TALK to doors. I interview them while taking their photographic portrait. Contrary to the old axiom ''. . . like talking to a door,'' it can be a very rewarding experience. I eschew sliding portals that provide passage from modern split-levels to wooden decks, or revolving entrances to marble lobbies guarded by gold-braided, top-hatted doormen. In order to qualify, my subjects must be venerably hoary with the patina of peeling paint. Hinges are essential accouterments, preferably solid brass and handmade, so I can exclaim: ''They don't make them like that anymore.''

title: THE GRACE OF OLD LOVERS
description: CROSSING TO SAFETY By Wallace Stegner. 277 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: ROBERT MAZZIOTTA, A DENTIST, IS WED TO DONNA CASSATA
description: Donna Cassata, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Cassata of Brooklyn, and Dr. Robert Mazziotta, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Mazziotta of White Plains, were married yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Frederick D. Hoesli performed the ceremony.

title: CHANGES POSSIBLE AFTER INDICTMENTS
description: The indictment of two New York State Senators and a Senate aide last week will increase pressure for public campaign financing and stricter controls on the Legislature, politicians and civic leaders predicted.

title: BOLSTERING YOUTH, BODY AND SOUL
description: LEAD: AT first, Joyce L. Vedral had trouble reconciling her several careers. After all, how many high school teachers with Ph.D.'s in English who write best-selling self-help books for teen-agers are also prominent in body-building circles?

title: New Issues Are Announced for the Month
description: THE United States Postal Service has issued one commemorative, two definitives and two postal cards in anticipation of October as National Stamp Collecting Month. Tomorrow a 22-cent commemorative will be released to honor the 100th anniversary of the United States accounting profession. It coincides with the opening of the centennial meeting of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants at New York City's Radio City Music Hall. It shows a pen point against an accounting ledger sheet and the letters ''CPA'' across the top with the words ''Certified Public Accountants'' along the left border.

title: Ford and U.A.W. Come to Terms
description: Ford and the U.A.W. agreed on a contract that gives the company's 104,000 factory workers an unusual level of job security. Ford is virtually prohibited from laying people off for reasons other than a decline in sales. Auto makers often lay off workers when they consolidate operations, retool plants or modernize with more automated equipment, and Ford, which has been the most profitable auto maker, now will be limited in those options. Although the first auto contract usually acts as the model for the others, G.M. said it manufactures so many of its own components, making its job requirements more flexible, that it needs different terms.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Offering Thresholds To the Past Trips to museums or exhibits in different cities, even other countries, are planned by organizations and museums as part of their educational programs. A group may ask that you become a member before you participate in a trip, but in return there can be savings in time and trouble through the planning the group provides. Additionally, there are often lower charges for accommodations and for bus transportation to a city and between sites.

title: FICTION
description: CUSTOMS VIOLATION. By Janice Weber. (Donald I. Fine, $17.95.) Sexual rancor can be extremely amusing, and luckily a few writers know it. Harold Pinter is one, and another is Janice Weber, who exploits the jolly mental state in her second novel, ''Customs Violation.'' Combatants in her tale of misogyny include customs officials operating out of northern New Jersey, the principals of a lingerie house, a feminist veterinarian, two testy Swiss nationals, and a dog that has undergone a sex change. Ms. Weber shakes them up and sets them loose in locations as various as mountain lakes, Carnegie Hall, Dumpsters and, eventually, an Alpine dining room as it is about to go up in flames. Behind it all is the novelist's interest in whether it is feasible for love actually to exist in a world where men and women find so many causes to dislike one another. Connecting the comic bile are Floyd, an overqualified customs agent on leave in Switzerland to learn how to make an exotic wurst, and (the partly eponymous?) Viola, a woman who only means to make men happy. The big question is whether Floyd and Viola will get together permanently. Ms. Weber supplies a surprising answer, as well as plenty of smiles, chuckles and belly laughs, although devout members of the women's movement may see no cause for guffawing, since her subliminal message seems to be that feminism is on the wane. Also, not all readers will survive the overabundance of forced similes; Ms. Weber's writing is too clever by at least a quarter. Not a big problem, but a problem nonetheless. Call it craft violation.

title: Stony Brook Fire Now a Bitter Issue
description: WHAT began as a small fire in a storeroom at the Javits Lecture Center at the State University of New York at Stony Brook last September has turned into a bitter dispute pitting environmentalists, students and faculty members against university officials.

title: THEY WILL HEAR SILVIO AYALA
description: IMAGINING ARGENTINA By Lawrence Thornton. 214 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $16.95.

title: New Uses, Old Wines
description: MANY PEOPLE STILL BELIEVE in the rigid rules of mating wine and food - that red wine goes with beef and white wine with chicken and fish. But just as red wine is now frequently served with fish, many chefs are pairing red-wine sauces with salmon, tuna and other fish, as well as with veal, chicken and eggs.

title: R. B. SIMPSON JR. WED TO SHARON LEE SCHULTZ
description: Sharon Lee Schultz, a vice president of Sotheby's and a specialist in Impressionist and modern paintings, was married yesterday to Roy Bertram Simpson Jr., a partner in the New York and Los Angeles law firm of Reavis & McGrath. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: ALEXANDER MAKES IT 7-0
description: Doyle Alexander, in the best tradition of the hired gun, has shot the Detroit Tigers to the top of the American League East.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Council Bluffs, Iowa;
Up for Auction: Shopping Mall
description: LEAD: ON Tuesday, the downtown Midlands Mall Shopping Center here will be sold at public auction in Chicago. The 11-year-old 300,000-square-foot property is the largest of its type ever offered in an open call auction, according to the broker handling the sale.

title: Rock's Walk on the Safe Side
description: ROCK USED TO BE THE life of the party. It would saunter in, holler ''Let the good times roll!,'' and goad people to dance and shout and run wild. Since the 1950's, rock has sketched fantasies of power, mobility and pleasure with no boundaries, no consequences. Every guy grabs a girl, everywhere around the world; honky-tonk women are ready and waiting; it's time for a walk on the wild side, and you can't catch me.

title: LANGUAGE A LA MODE
description: Anne Cox Chambers, former ambassador to Belgium, chairman of Atlanta Newspapers Inc. and co-owner of Cox Enterprises, is 35,000 feet over the Atlantic, but the familiar French voices in her ears make it seem as though she's already arrived in Paris. What's more, elle est branchee - she's plugged in.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In; Pelham
description: THE main thoroughfare in Pelham is Fifth Avenue, which might seem pretentious for a town of barely 13,000 people. But so many of its residents commute into Manhattan each morning that the parallel to New York City is indeed appropriate.

title: Kidnap-Murder of 5-Year-Old Shakes Japan
description: The kidnapping and murder of the 5-year-old son of a firefighter has transfixed Japan, stirring outrage and soul-searching in a society unaccustomed to much violent crime.

title: CAN THE GIANTS REPEAT AS CHAMPIONS?
description: Can they repeat as champions? They have to. I haven't seen my father as happy as he was last year. As a frustrated (aren't they all?) Giant fan spanning the decades, he grumbled every year during football season. His tickets were passed on to anyone who wanted to see them then. But last year, even being a daughter didn't help me get more than one game ticket.

title: Stage: Short Plays on Gay Themes
description: JOSEPH PINTAURO is one playwright who will never be accused of being too subtle. In ''Wild Blue,'' his evening of eight one-act plays with gay themes at the 47th Street Playhouse, such ticklish issues as homosexual incest and gay Roman Catholic priests are confronted in blunt melodramatic scenarios that get right to the heart of the matter.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE TAKING OF GETTY OIL: The Full Story of the Most Spectacular - & Catastrophic - Takeover of All Time. By Steve Coll. (Atheneum, $19.95.) This book, by the New York financial bureau chief of The Washington Post, could be read as a cautionary tale about what happens when a big deal goes bad. After all, giant Texaco was forced into bankruptcy by the $10.53 billion verdict levied against the company by a Houston jury. Remember, Pennzoil sued Texaco for buying Getty Oil just four days after Pennzoil thought it had its own agreement to acquire Getty. But despite the fact that much of Pennzoil's case rested on the lack of ethics on Wall Street, the mergers-and-acquisitions boom goes on at the same pace, with little or no regard for what the jury found. Companies take poison pills, targets get hugged by bears and the sharks are still looking for blood, to mix a few metaphors from the world of high and fast finance. Texaco's problems will probably end up as an interesting footnote in the history of the major corporate reorganization this country has undergone as a result of these giant mergers, and it will be a singularly well-annotated footnote. ''The Taking of Getty Oil'' is the second book to come out this summer on this messy financial and legal battle. The first book, ''Oil & Honor'' by Thomas Petzinger Jr., a Wall Street Journal reporter, used a fast-paced thriller style that kept the action moving through the complex legal issues. Steve Coll, while also making use of recollected and reconstructed dialogue to enliven the story, writes a less dramatic, but in many cases more clear, version of the deal. Both authors had great material to work with. Gordon Getty, the absent-minded composer who happened to end up with control of 40 percent of one billion barrels of oil, is an effective foil for some of the most aggressive deal makers in the financial world. Narrative nonfiction was originally used to tell stories of great crime, like Truman Capote's ''In Cold Blood.'' Now that writers are giving business the same treatment, the arcane world of finance is becoming more accessible to the rest of us. We may still gasp at the multimillion-dollar fees involved in investment banking, but now we know more about who is earning them and how.

title: Space Dwindling in Mobile Home Parks
description: A year ago, Frances and Lawrence Doyle of Cold Spring, N.Y., were ready to sell the mobile home they had lived in for five years and move in with their son. But the buyer backed out when the Brookside Mobile Home Park refused to allow the Doyle's 20-year-old residence to remain in the park.

title: Final Remarks: Interpret Law, Not Make It
description: After several hours of questioning yesterday, Judge Robert H. Bork offered a final statement.

title: Protect Privacy Of Players
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: POSTINGS: New Air-Conditioner Charges; The Cost of Cool Comfort
description: Keeping cool in a rent-regulated apartment in New York is complicated because so many variables affect surcharges for air conditioners. New guidelines take affect at the end of this month, and they are no simpler than the old ones.

title: Hungary Says Step Is Taken Toward Full Ties With Israel
description: Prime Minister Karoly Grosz said at a news conference Friday that Hungary's decision to resume a limited relationship with Israel was ''a very important measure on which we cannot go back.''

title: Ohio State Defeats Oregon by 24-14
description: Vince Workman rushed for 162 yards and a touchdown on 26 carries, and Tom Tupa passed for two touchdowns in a span of 1 minute 14 seconds of the third quarter today as Ohio State overcame Oregon, 24-14.

title: 3 Drown in Boating Accident
description: Three New York City men drowned yesterday morning when their motorboat capsized in rough waters off of Lloyd Harbor on Suffolk County's North Shore, the Suffolk police said.

title: BEING CATHOLIC IN AMERICA
description: Joseph Berger's article ''Being Catholic in America'' illustrates many interesting points about the condition of contemporary Roman Catholicism in this country, not the least of which is the intellectual sloppiness of the newly affluent and ''educated'' Catholics on whom he focuses.

title: Car Incentives
description: To the Editor: Carole Gould in ''The New Math of Car Incentive Plans'' (Personal Finance, Aug. 23) states that ''Some say the plans are a sham.'' There is no other rational interpretation!

title: A New Friend From the Old Country
description: Banners bearing the red and white colors of Poland fluttered overhead and signs proclaiming ''Solidarnosc'' were waved vigorously. This enclave in Detroit that bills itself as ''a touch of Europe in America'' welcomed Pope John Paul II today more as a local boy who made good than as a major religious figure.

title: CAN THE GIANTS REPEAT AS CHAMPIONS?
description: The Giants are as likely to repeat as Super Bowl champions as Ronald Reagan is to retain his Presidency in '88. It just can't be done. But unlike Reagan, there are no laws preventing the Giants from achieving this goal. They simply lack the maturity, discipline, and team cohesiveness to recapture the title. These behemoths in blue, so hollow of character, are too busy penning biographies, shooting commercials and basking in the eight-month-old limelight to fulfill their true potential. From juggernauts to jugheads, the Giants are not this decade's dynasty; they are only this season's overrated team. WARREN ETHEREDGE New York, N.Y.

title: VIEWS ON EDUCATING THE HANDICAPPED
description: In reply to the letter ''Education and the Handicapped,'' I say ''bravo'' to Jane Goldblatt.

title: Echoes of the Rustic Life From an Age of Opulence
description: BETWEEN THE CIVIL War and World War II, industrial tycoons and artists relaxed each summer in their luxurious hideaways in the Adirondacks, surrounded by log-framed, bark-veneered furniture embellished with split twigs.

title: SRI LANKA FIGHTING SETBACK FOR PACT
description: India's attempt to enforce the peace in neighboring Sri Lanka received a setback this week when fighting erupted among rival ethnic Tamil guerrilla groups in the eastern part of the island.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: The Environment; A PAct to Protect the Ozone
description: The agreement will probably not show results in the delegates' lifetimes, but there were congratulations all around when an international conference in Montreal last week produced an accord to protect the earth's ozone layer. The agreement requires the limitation and eventual reduction of chlorofluorcarbons and other chemicals that destroy ozone in the upper atmosphere, threatening radiation damage to the ecosphere and increased skin cancer among humans.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Our wood-shingle roof was sprayed with a mixture of wood preservative and linseed oil last year and some of this spray drifted onto the windows - on the glass and the metal frames. I have tried all kinds of window cleaners, but when the cleaner dries the droplets seem to reappear. Have you any suggestions?

title: Living and Learning Can Be Competitive Pursuits
description: AS the school year begins this month for the 440,000 students attending the 83 colleges and universities in New York City, many are being forced to scramble for housing because less than half the full-time undergraduates are able to find space in campus dormitories.

title: IRAN CAMPAIGNING TO BAR SANCTIONS
description: As the bloody conflict in the Persian Gulf enters its eighth year, Iran is moving to alt an effort to impose international sanctions if it does not heed the United Nations Security Council's call for a cease-fire with Iraq.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday on the marriage of Julie Herman and Thomas Paul Hirschfeld misidentified the bride's mother. She is Joy Goldfarb Herman.

title: IT'S TIME TO RECYCLE OUR WATER
description: IN Southern California is a city that shares a name with Nassau County's own Long Beach. The areas surrounding the two Long Beaches share more than a name; they share a problem. Some of the communities near Southern California's Long Beach are experiencing a critical water shortage similar to Nassau's.

title: CARING FOR AN AGED PARENT: A STRAINING REVERSAL OF ROLES
description: FOR years Virginia Borges has helped her 75-year-old, nearly blind mother cope with the details of life. Still, she tries to limit the visits, so she does not end up running her mother's life - and so her mother does not run hers. Maintaining such a balance is not easy.

title: Rematch Turns Into A Romp
description: The season-opening rematch yesterday between the finalists from last year's Public Schools Athletic League championship game produced a familiar outcome although the score turned out to be a bit one-sided. Susan Wagner of Staten Island romped to a 36-0 victory over Andrew Jackson in a chilly mist at the loser's field in Queens.

title: MISS L'ESPERANCE BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday, Laura Ann L'Esperance, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Anthony L'Esperance Jr. of Englewood, N.J., and Southampton, L.I., was married to Mark Richards Graham, the son of John A. Graham and Judith Richards Graham, both of Tulsa, Okla. The Rev. Henry Boyle officiated.

title: KATHLEEN REILLY WEDS
description: At St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church in Fairfax, Va., Kathleen Ann Reilly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Reilly of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Cooper Gates, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl S. Gates of Wilmington, Del. Darryl Dunn, a deacon of the church, performed the ceremony. The bride, who will retain her name professionally, is a figure skating coach and a choreographer at the Fairfax Ice Arena. Mr. Gates is a project engineer for the Pettibone & Johnson Construction Company in Annandale, Va.

title: 'Unanimity Hall'
description: At the time of the Constitutional Convention, 75 newspapers were being published in America, but not one got a scoop on what was happening behind closed doors and shuttered windows. The convention adopted a resolution ''that noth-ing spoken in the House be communicated with-out leave.'' Remarkably, nothing was. Well, almost nothing.

title: STATE SEEKS TO BECOME MICROCHIP RESEARCH CENTER
description: OVER the last year, leaders of the United States microchip industry have quietly planned a multimillion-dollar research consortium that could end up in Central New Jersey and provide hundreds of high-technology jobs there.

title: Temporary Services Booming
description: LEAD: WHEN 34-year-old January Fenamore moved from Sacramento, Calif., to Melville to be married last year, she decided to do temporary work as a word processor until she could find a permanent job. One year later, she is working full time, developing a data base at nearby NEC America, the electronics concern.

title: MICHAEL BERMAN WED TO JODY MAIDENBAUM
description: The wedding of Jody Maidenbaum to Michael J. Berman took place yesterday at the Muttontown (L.I.) Country Club. Rabbi Joseph Sternstein officiated.

description: Soviet Signs Read 'Slow'

title: VIRGINIA L. BLOOD
description: Virginia L. Blood, a former Republican state legislator in Connecticut, died of a stroke Thursday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: ROGER S. BARNES, DESIGN DIRECTOR, WEDS MS. GALPIN

Justice of the Peace John Atkin of Rowayton, Conn., performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Barnes of Southbury, Conn.

title: Reagan Suggests Separate Stopgap Spending Bills
description: President Reagan, taking what appeared to be a new tack in his budget battle with Congress, today suggested that lawmakers send him separate stopgap spending bills for specific areas of the Federal Government rather than the single stopgap measure that is now in the works.

title: Soviet Eye on the Sky: Questions of Trust

title: IRANIAN JEWS' REQUEST STIRS IRE IN GREAT NECK
description: WHEN they take sides tomorrow evening at the meeting of the Great Neck Village Zoning Board, they will divide up much as they did at the board's last session on Aug. 17. The residents of Steamboat Road, many of them in blue jeans and work clothes, will crowd the hall, loudly demanding to know what is to become of their block. The few elegantly dressed Iranian men whom they suspect of ''trying to put one over'' on them will gather quietly in the back of the room and allow their lawyer to do all the speechmaking.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Round Table From Purcell And Chausson
description: LEAD: GIVEN THAT MEDIEVAL LEG-ends of King Arthur and his Round Table knights have inspired poets and dramatists of virtually every age, from Sir Thomas Malory and Wolfram von Eschenbach through Tennyson, Swinburne and Edna St. Vincent Millay - not to mention our own Monty Python - it isn't surprising that the lyric stage has seen its share of adaptations.

title: CHINA EXECUTES CAR THIEF
description: A Hong Kong man convicted of stealing 18 minibuses and cars in the southern cities of Canton and Shenzhen was executed today, the New China News Agency reported.

title: FESTIVAL DRAMA: NOT ALWAYS ON THE SCREEN

title: TALKING: Co-ops; The Board Is Not Invincible
description: MAYBE the directors have voted to postpone repainting of the exterior for yet another year. Or perhaps they have refused to consider replacing a troublesome superintendent.

title: MUSIC
description: The week is full of desirable tickets that you probably can't get now if you haven't got them already - Bernstein and the Vienna Philharmonic, Domingo and Te Kanawa in ''Otello,'' and the Norman-Battle-Levine ''Ariadne,'' for instance. Unfortunately not much else at the opera houses looks especially recommendable, with two partial exceptions: the veteran tenor Carlo Bergonzi (in ''Elisir D'Amore'' at the Metropolitan on Thursday) still had, last I heard, a melting ''una furtiva lagrima'' in him. And ''Casanova'' (State Theater, 7 P.M. Sunday) is worth seeing at least once, especially in Timothy Nolen in the title role.

title: Film: A Horror Tale, Barker's 'Hellraiser'
description: CLIVE BARKER, England's answer to Stephen King as a best-selling author of horror tales, branches out into film direction with ''Hellraiser,'' a gooey horror movie in which the main monster, gelatinous anyway, seems to have been dunked in simple syrup. It oozes and drips without thought for what it does to the floors, possibly because it's supposed to be a boorish creature from the beyond.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

description: LEAD: Twenty-one years ago, ''Day in the Country'' was an equestrian event, featuring horseback riding demonstrations. A few years later, the yearly benefit for the Westchester Lighthouse, a division of the New York Association for the Blind, metamorphosed into an air show, with home-built planes and in-air demonstrations.

Its sole mission was to develop products from the new mix of chemistry and physics that had made superconductivity a practical industrial prospect.

description: ''WHEN it ticks, it bugs me,'' said Dennis Patrick, explaining why he stopped the Regulator pendulum clock his grandmother sent him when he became chairman of the Federal Communications Commission in April.

title: Dear Mutsy, With Love From Mousie
description: WHEN Carol Kulina could not find any cards that her 10-year-old daughter could send to say thank-you, the New Jersey woman started her own line. Today, Kards for Kids - with stick-figure illustrations on the front and ruled writing space inside - are sold nationwide.

title: Corrections
description: An item Aug. 30 in Q & A about bicycle tours in St. Kitts and Nevis gave an incorrect telephone number for Progressive Travels, the company that runs them. The number is 800-245-2229.

title: A NATION IN DECLINE
description: DECLINE OF A NATION OR a society is a provocative historical problem. In Rome, it is associated with external pressure from the barbarians and the inability of the empire's agricultural rim to offer firm resistance. In the ancient Greek cities of Asia Minor, it can be traced to the silting up of harbors, closing them to access by sea. In the Aztec empire of Mexico it was the invasion of ruthless Europeans. In China, it is a long story. In the United States, who knows? One certainly feels a deteriorating ethic in many spheres. Our Government is beset by incompetence; our officials display an inability to execute policy efficiently or within the law. The policy-making apparatus itself appears to have broken down, with the chain of command in the Government's executive branch reduced to a meaningless flow chart. Such incoherence and disarray in policy and its implementation result, in turn, from the public's unthinking acceptance of image over substance in its choice of Government officers.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: APPETITES. By Tom Murphy. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) Set in the world of first-class restaurants, ''Appetites,'' Tom Murphy's seventh book, might be called a greasy spoon of a novel. The heroine, Elise, is the daughter of Pierre Villeromain, the owner of Manhattan's world famous Le Palais-Royal. Upon his death, she and her stepmother inherit the restaurant.

Tanenbaum of the American Jewish Committee noted a surprisingly informal construction in the Catholic draft. The document referred to the president of the Commission for Religious Relations With the Jews as ''Cardinal John Willebrands.''

title: CRESSIDA MCKEAN, ECONOMIST, MARRIES
description: The marriage of Cressida Sargent McKean, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Q. A. Shaw McKean Jr. of Rumson, N.J., to Geoffrey Russell Borthwick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Borthwick of Gisborne, New Zealand, took place yesterday in Navesink, N.J. The Rev. Harry R. Sorensen performed the ceremony at All Saints' Memorial Episcopal Church. The bride, who will retain her name, is a development economist and an independent consultant for the Agency for International Development and other international agencies. A graduate of the Madeira School and Stanford University, she received a master's degree in international relations and economics from the London School of Economics and expects to receive a master's in development studies this year from the University of Sussex in England. Her father is an advisory managing director of Scudder, Stevens & Clark in New York.

title: Finding Furniture As Art In Paris
description: Some of the most elegant boutiques in Paris these days are the furniture showrooms of designers. Unlike New York, where avant-garde design is ''to the trade'' and closed to the public, showrooms in Paris are at street level, and anyone can go in and buy at essentially the same price (discounts to the design trade are only 10 percent). Meandering through these showrooms, which are clustered in a few places, can give visitors focal points for walks on both the Left and Right Banks.

title: New Money, Old Digs
description: THERE'S hardly a morning along the River Thames near Tower Bridge that doesn't have a Turneresque quality about it, with a weak sun filtering through the haze. It's the view the fishmongers of Billingsgate Market had each morning for more than a century, until 1982 when the trade was removed elsewhere. By this time next year, the era of fishmongering at Billingsgate will give way to an era of moneymongering when the old market, freshly renovated, will reopen as the new London headquarters of Citicorp Investment Bank.

title: BEING CATHOLIC IN AMERICA

I simply hope that readers of the article realize that being a chief executive officer, a dentist or a Ph.D, in itself has nothing to do with Roman Catholicism. Strong belief in Jesus Christ as the Son of God and founder of the Church does. REV. EDWARD F. DOHERTY Jackson Heights, Queens

title: A BETTER MOUSETRAP

Then I slide a piece of paper between glass pane and box, thus sealing the trap, take the contraption to the door and send the fly on its way. Will I come back as a fly? title: Pop: Frankie Valli and Four Tops Share Bill
description: POP music nostalgia can be a robust, openhearted celebration of younger days, but it can also be a cynical sour-spirited rehash of the past. At Radio City Music Hall on Friday evening, where the Four Tops, one of Motown's greatest 60's vocal groups, and Frankie Valli shared the bill, one saw both sides of the picture.

description: To the Editor:

title: INDIA SEIZES FOUR AFTER IMMOLATION
description: The father-in-law of a young Hindu woman who was burned to death when she placed herself or was placed on her husband's funeral pyre was arrested today pending charges of murder and abetting a suicide, the United News of India reported.

title: EMILY MILLER WEDS
description: Emily Carolyn Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward John Miller of Chicago, was married at Temple Sinai there last evening to Alexander Alan Friend, a son of Mrs. Burton Carr of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Howard Berman officiated. The bride graduated cum laude from Harvard College, as did the bridegroom. She is an account executive in the Image Group at Wells, Rich & Greene in New York. Mr. Friend, a principal of Venture Partners, a private investment firm in Newark, received an M.B.A. from Stanford University.

title: Fundamentalists' Trial a Concern to Tunisia
description: The trial of 90 Moslem fundamentalists who could face the death penalty is reaching its final stages here, and Arab and Western diplomats fear that a harsh verdict could shake northern Africa by creating some highly visible martyrs.

title: Fading Maine Town Finds a Future
description: For Walter Pietrowski, working as a lobsterman has been an elusive dream. He fished whenever he could, juggling his full-time job as a pipe welder and his responsibilities as a husband and father of two young girls.

title: KEVIN SMYLEY IS WED TO NORMA JEAN BRETON
description: Norma Jean Breton, a daughter of Mr. and Henry Breton of Plymouth, Mass., was married yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University to Kevin Tyrone Smyley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Newton Smyley of Hempstead, L.I. The Rev. Robert Springer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: THE MUSIC SEASON: REFLECTION OF CULTURE IN FLOWER
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY, Governor Kean said at a recent news conference, quoting a phrase that had appeared in a National Geographic magazine article, is ''a place of such stunning diversity that it is almost America in miniature.''

title: A New Father Frets Over College Tuition
description: I AM THE father of a 22-month-old girl, so, naturally, I spend a lot of time worrying about her college education. I'm not an extremist, mind you. I haven't enrolled her in any Baby Physics or Baby Comp. Lit. course at a local school, nor have I purchased a set of Financial Flashcards for her. (''This is a put option. This is a call. This is a straddle.'') But I do worry. And, like many people, one of my major concerns is financial. After all, it was recently reported that for the seventh year in a row, college tuition cost increases outpaced inflation. In the 1980's in fact, college tuition has risen at twice the inflation rate. Soon, a year at Bennington, the nation's priciest academic retreat, will cost more than a European luxury automobile.

title: THE NATION: Elizabeth Dole; From Cabinet to Campaign
description: ''It's sort of giving up one cause for another,'' Elizabeth Hanford Dole said last week about her resignation as Cabinet member to become a full-time candidate's wife, working in the Presidential campaign of her husband, Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican Senate leader. Leaving the office of Secretary of Transportation was a move Mrs. Dole had seemed to fight; it's ''curious,'' she had said, ''all the candidates can continue what they're doing. Wives are one step removed.'' But Mrs. Dole, a North Carolinian once called ''my Southern strategy'' by the Senator, is considered more than a geographic asset by his major supporters. Dole campaign officials note that when they appear together, Mrs. Dole ''softens the hard edges'' of Mr. Dole.

title: CYNTHIA P. BURR WED TO JERRY LARSON IN CALIFORNIA
description: Cynthia Parry Burr, the daughter of Donald D. Burr of East Hampton, L.I., and the late Jeanne Parry Burr, was married in Pacific Palisades, Calif., yesterday to Jerry Walker Larson, a son of Mrs. Robert C. Storey of Salmon, Idaho. The Rev. Turiyananda performed the ceremony at the Self Realization Fellowship.

title: Vice; Admiral
description: Former National Security Adviser John Poindexter, a two-star admiral, wants to retire from the Navy on Oct. 1 to secure his pension before possible indictment in the Iran-contra affair. Admiral Poindexter combines prudence with nerve: he would retire at the three-star rank of vice admiral he held at the White House before his sudden resignation last November.

ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
SCOUT MEMORIES
description: LEAD: NANCY RIEKERT, 38 years old, remembers the songs:

title: Columbia Is Still In Losing Mode
description: Judging by Columbia's first game of the 1987 college football season, this team looks as dismal as the ones that went without a victory the last three years.

title: MOCKINGBIRD HITS RIGHT NOTE, AND RIGHT ON KEY
description: THE Indians called him Cencontlatolly, or 400 tongues. His scientific name is

title: THE WORLD: Cheer at the U.N.; Rare Unity Brings Smile to a 'Toothless Tiger'
description: THE five major powers are making a fresh attempt at exerting their authority over the rest of the world through the United Nations.

title: The Dot and the Squiggle Make a Handsome Couple
description: THIS might just be the year when the squiggle comes into its own. Ditto the dot. They are two of the three patterns - the third is a floral abstract -in a group of silk coordinated separates that are the latest mix-and-match success.

title: Dance: Some Results Of Summer at the Yard
description: WHAT do choreographers do in summer? They frequently make dances, thanks to institutions like the Yard, a summer arts' colony which for the past 15 years has provided dancers and choreographers with rehearsal time and space at Chilmark on Martha's Vineyard.

title: VIEWS ON EDUCATING THE HANDICAPPED
description: Jane Goldblatt's letter to the editor [ ''Education and the Handicapped,'' Aug. 9 ] is laced with nesciences and distortions that can lead readers into making false conclusions. Her printed words could influence public thinking and even some elected decision makers. Vital and necessary services directed at handicapped persons might be damaged as a result.

title: Time Out For Tension
description: THE SCORE IS 11-ALL IN THE FIFTH and deciding game of a gritty, hard-fought match of squash racquets we are playing on the sixth floor of that Wall Streeters' mecca, the Downtown Athletic Club. George L. Ball, 48, chairman and chief executive officer of Prudential-Bache Securities, looks pressed but not tired. His reddish hair is moist and gathered into clumps; a wedge of sweat traces out his backbone. But his breathing is even and he still comes up on his toes to receive the serve.

title: Cassettes Rise Smartly to the Sonic Challenges
description: AT A TIME WHEN DIGITAL sound defines the growing edge of audio, less public attention is focused on older devices, such as cassettes. Yet cassettes remain by far the most popular medium for recorded music, and prerecorded cassettes outsell both CD's and LP's throughout the world. Moreover, since open-reel tape has virtually vanished from the audio scene, except for professional applications, the cassette is today the universal medium for home recording. Being so firmly entrenched, cassettes are perceived as a static medium with few current developments.

title: Music: Tibetan Bowls
description: ONE approaches music groups like the Tibetan Singing Bowl Ensemble with a certain suspicion. The personnel (there were eight players for their Asia Society Concert on Thursday) is mainly American and European; the instruments, however, come from Tibet, Japan, the Middle East and the Third World.

title: Music; Ruth Laredo's Difficult Cup of Tea
description: RUTH LAREDO CAME TO RACH-maninoff as we all should - in the first ardor of youth. She was a student at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia when she brought the Third Piano Concerto to her teacher, Rudolf Serkin. Mr. Serkin's distant, slightly pained expression was enough to send her back to Mozart and Beethoven.

title: RURAL TOWN WARY OF THE DEVELOPERS ON ITS DOORSTEP
description: WHEN Katherine Gilchrist arrived in Burlington some 40 years ago, she taught in a one-room schoolhouse. In those days, the town had five one-room schoolhouses. Within a few years, Burlington demolished the schoolhouse in which Mrs. Gilchrist taught and built a modern school, but it preserved one of the one-room schoolhouses, as well.

title: Baby M: Uncharted Waters
description: DURING the second half of its hearing on the Baby M case here last week, the State Supreme Court began exploring the ruling last March of Superior Court Judge Harvey R. Sorkow.

title: Must a Jury of One's Peers Be A Panel of One's Race?
description: RACE has been a central issue in the Howard Beach case since its inception, but until last week it appeared that the question of racial attitudes would apply mostly to the principals in the case, four white teen-agers who are accused of being part of a mob that set upon three black men and caused the death of one of them.

title: HARTFORD TO FEATURE 2 SIDES OF JUDY COLLINS
description: JUDY COLLINS first became known to many as a folk singer. Later she showed her vocal versatility with the Broadway show song ''Send In the Clowns.''

title: Inmate and Wife Seek Right to Conceive Child
description: A Federal prison inmate is suing the Government over its refusal to permit him and his wife to have a child through artificial insemination.

title: 22-CENT STATE STAMP IS PROVING POPULAR
description: THE New Jersey statehood stamp has been ''selling like wildfire'' since it was issued in Trenton on Sept. 11, according to Karen Tucker, manager of merchandising for the Postal Service's New Brunswick District.

title: A TRIBUTE TO CARSON MCCULLERS IN NYACK
description: WITH this summer's publication of the first one-volume anthology of Carson McCullers's short fiction, and a revival of her stage adaptation of her novella ''The Member of the Wedding'' coming up at off-Broadway's Roundabout Theater later this season, it appears that the literary reputation of the enigmatic, frail Southern writer is up for re-evaluation.

title: FULL DISCLOSURES
description: When it comes to full disclosure in annual reports, nobody yields to Warren E. Buffett, chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, his Omaha-based investment vehicle. He writes the reports himself.

title: DISPUTES CONTINUE ON WATCHDOG ROLE
description: LEAD: WHEN the General Assembly voted this year to abolish the year-old office of the State Inspector General, lawmakers hoped to bring an end to the controversy that had surrounded the post since before its creation.

title: Altitude
description: To the Editor: I am surprised that a person as perceptive as Katie Kelly (''When You'd Rather Keep a Low Profile,'' Travel, Aug. 16) did not ask a doctor about her altitude headaches.

description: Where to Call For Reports On Fall Foliage

title: JEFFREY W. RASER WED TO MARY P. SCHOWALTER
description: Mary Patricia Schowalter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William R. Schowalter of Princeton, N.J., and Jeffrey William Raser, a son of Thomas J. Raser of Princeton and the late Edith P. Raser, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. John Goerss performed the ceremony at the Miller Chapel of the Princeton Theological Seminary.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO PREVENT MAPLES FROM SPLITTING
description: LEAD: IF one were to take inventory of all the trees in most any neighborhood, maples would undoubtedly top the list in numbers. With the possible exception of flowering crab apples, they would also lead in the number of cultivars.

title: STATE NEARS DECISION ON FUTURE OF CONGESTED EXPRESSWAY
description: LEAD: BY the mid-1990's, the county's highly congested Route 287 - the Cross Westchester Expressway - may be expanded to eight standard-sized 12-foot lanes or have its current six lanes rebuilt and a seventh special high-occupancy-vehicle lane reserved for buses, car pools and van pools added.

title: DESPITE AID, CONCERN FOR HOMELESS
description: LEAD: LAST March, Elizabeth Shaw of the New Haven Christian Family Coalition urged lawmakers to provide enough aid to homeless families to get them out of welfare hotels and motels.

title: VAN TASSELL OUSTED IN SOMERS PRIMARY
description: LEAD: WILLIAM C. HARDING of Somers has discovered a sure way to improve his golf score - win the town's Republican nomination for supervisor in a hotly contested primary, as he did last Tuesday.

title: The AIDS Panel's Ill-Defined Mandate
description: PRESIDENT Reagan's advisory commission on AIDS has had a hard time since its creation last June. Critics say many of the 13 panel members are too uninformed about the disease or too committed to preconceived responses to a scourge that has already killed more than 23,000 Americans. Then, last week, the commission suffered another blow when its executive director, Linda D. Sheaffer, was abruptly forced to resign.

title: VIVIAN BETH LEVY MARRIED TO T. H. REUBEN, STUDENT
description: Last evening at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel, Vivian Beth Levy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Werner S. Levy of Forest Hills, Queens, was married to Todd Hayes Reuben, the son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Jesse Reuben of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Philmore Berger officiated.

title: Lost Among The Carnivores In Yugoslavia
description: Some people manage to travel in a totally carefree way. I don't. Where others happily contemplate crossing the Sahara with nothing more than a box of cookies, a light novel and equanimity, I assume there will be problems. Lots of them. Oh, not the sort of problems that would get my name in the papers, not tribal warfare or death from thirst, but little, everyday problems. In the matter of crossing the Sahara, my mind dwelled obsessively on how to avoid getting sand in my eye and what would I do if a camel bit me.

title: LINCOLN MEETS THE PRESS
description: In his hypothetical Lincoln press conference, William Safire has given us an insight into President Lincoln's views on several important topics of the times.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Signs Economic Pact at Meadowlands
description: Officials at the Meadowlands Sports Complex have signed an agreement with the N.A.A.C.P. to give members of minority groups broader opportunities in construction, sales and the promotion of executives.

title: FOUR-WHEELED FRIEND
description: I am the owner of a car that just celebrated its 18th birthday. To my son, who is now driving it, that is not something to be proud of. After all, his baby carriage used to occupy the back seat.

title: ATHLETICS TROUNCE ROYALS
description: Mark McGwire and Dwayne Murphy each knocked in three runs tonight to lead the Athletics to a 9-4 victory over the Royals.

title: LANDSCAPES AND VESSELS JOIN IN SOLO SHOW IN TRENTON
description: THE PERSISTENCE of landscape as a catalyst for artistic imagination is affirmed by its emergence in every medium.

title: LISA A. MEDNICK WED IN BROOKLYN
description: Lisa A. Mednick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Mednick of Los Angeles, and Steve C. Owen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Owen of New York and East Hampton, L.I., were married last evening at the Montauk Club in Brooklyn by Rabbi Lawrence Raphael.

title:
GARDENING;
It's Time to Plan For Spring Bloom
description: LEAD: AS fall approaches, thoughts turn to planting garden bulbs. Sometimes called fall bulbs, they are more accurately called spring-flowering bulbs.

title: IF IT'S NOT RUSSIAN, HE HATES IT
description: THE FRIGATE PALLADA By Ivan Aleksandrovich Goncharov. Translated by Klaus Goetze. 649 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $35.

title: A Horror Tale, Barker's 'Hellraiser'
description: CLIVE BARKER, England's answer to Stephen King as a best-selling author of horror tales, branches out into film direction with ''Hellraiser,'' a gooey horror movie in which the main monster, gelatinous anyway, seems to have been dunked in simple syrup. It oozes and drips without thought for what it does to the floors, possibly because it's supposed to be a boorish creature from the beyond.

title: BAYMEN HOPE TIDE IS TURNING
description: LEAD: AS he stood at the helm of his fishing vessel, Vincent Daley was sure he could see it in the distance. He could feel it coming. And he was sure that it would only be a matter of time before it would hurt him, his family and his fellow fishermen.

title: NEW LIMITS SOUGHT IN MEDICAL STUDIES
description: Medical students at New York State's teaching hospitals would be barred from performing clinical procedures without close supervision by a physician, under new rules being proposed by the State Health Department.

title: GEORGE HERMANN WED TO JULIE WEST
description: The First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Julie Noring West, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis J. West of Greenwich, to George Duncan Hermann, the son of Dr. and Mrs. George A. Hermann of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Avery C. Manchester, the pastor of the church, performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: Comings and Goings
description: HE thought long and hard before deciding against retirement at the start of training camp, but Brenard Wilson, the 32-year-old Philadelphia Eagle safety, no longer has any choice in the matter. Wilson, a nine-year veteran who played for Vanderbilt, was cut by the Eagles to make room on the roster for one of his best friends, Roynell Young, a cornerback who rejoined the club after a long contract dispute. . . . George Hauser, the endurance swimmer who has epilepsy, had to abandon his third effort to swim the English Channel when adverse tides blocked his way to the French coast after he had been swimming for 10 1/2 hours. . . . John McEnroe, the defending champion, has withdrawn from the Volvo-Los Angeles tournament this week so he can remain in New York with his wife, Tatum O'Neal, who is expecting the couple's second child. . . . Steve Ovett, the 1980 Olympic champion in the 800 meters, has entered the Mercedes Mile on Fifth Avenue next Saturday, along with Peter Elliott, the silver medalist in the 800 meters at the world championships in Rome. Newly entered in the women's division are Sandra Gasser of Switzerland, Diana Richburg of the United States and Elly Van Hulst of the Netherlands.

title: IN HIGGANUM, HERBAL GARDENS OF EDEN
description: LEAD: WHEN Ragna Tischler Goddard and her husband, Tom, restored their 18th-century barn house in Higganum, they decided to add gardens of the period. Three herb gardens were born, a barn reclaimed, and an herb business, the Sundial Herb Garden, created.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Our wood-shingle roof was sprayed with a mixture of wood preservative and linseed oil last year and some of this spray drifted onto the windows - on the glass and the metal frames. I have tried all kinds of window cleaners, but when the cleaner dries the droplets seem to reappear. Have you any suggestions?

title: WHEN THE WORLD WAS FLAT
description: THE HISTORY OF CARTOGRAPHY Volume One: Cartography in Prehistoric, Ancient, and Medieval Europe and the Mediterranean. Edited by J. B. Harley and David Woodward. Illustrated. 599 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $100.

title: Adjusting the Perspective on Pope's Visit
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope Condemns Abortion in U.S. As He Ends Visit
description: Pope John Paul II, ending his visit to the United States today, sternly condemned the practice of abortion in America, arguing that the nation must defend all human life if it wants to enjoy justice and freedom.

title: Restaurant Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 36 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: A GUITAR TRIBUTE TO SEGOVIA
description: AFTER more than a month of sporadic activity, the concert season has sprung back to life. There are six major attractions alone this afternoon.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN GREETING CARDS
description: IN the old days, people flocked to the card shop for birthdays, anniversaries, Christmas and Mother's Day, and a few big companies produced all the good cheer. Today more than 800 publishers vie for business in a $3.6 billion-a-year industry - and the noteworthy event might be a divorce or a promotion, the death of a dog or an unhappy 40th birthday.

title: NONFICTION
description: Color photos delineating ancient tribal ruins, rocks sculpted by the winds and striations in the Southwestern desert sands are juxtaposed in this book with pictures of ancient and contemporary coiled basketry, Navajo rugs and Pueblo pottery. Earth tones and textures reverberate from the land to the crafts in HARMONY BY HAND: Art of the Southwest Indians -Basketry, Weaving, Pottery (Chronicle Books, Cloth, $30; Paper, $16.95). The authors - Patrick Houlihan, Jerold L. Collings, Sarah Nestor and Jonathan Batkin, all experts on the culture of the American Southwest - use rare black-and-white portraits as well, many from the turn of the century, showing the artisans at work. The text is less enticing. Technology and the history of these tribal crafts are discussed in phrases that tend to be as dry as the desert winds. For centuries Indian craftsmen have believed in the spiritual qualities of the materials they employ; their designs can often be traced back to distant ancestors; and there is, among a few other oases in the book, an explanation of the spirit path, a broken line in the design that allows the artists' spirits to escape from their basketry, weaving or pottery. So it is hard to understand how the intricate patterning of men and beasts on a masterly basketry bowl could be dismissed here as designs that are ''merely decorative and have no particular symbolic significance.'' Perhaps the artists feared that sharing mystical secrets with museum experts would disturb the harmonies these talented hands created.

title: RUTGERS IN NEWARK GETS FIRST DORMITORY
