description: LEAD: RUTGERS UNIVERSITY has officially opened its first residence facility for students on its Newark campus, ending the school's history as strictly a commuter campus.

title: A Historic Agreement, And Suddenly the Mood Seems Much Brighter
description: SECRETARY of State George P. Shultz and his Soviet counterpart, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, decided last Wednesday, as Mr. Shevardnadze later reported, that it was ''time for us to bring in the harvest.'' That they did, and President Reagan displayed it for the nation and the world to see on Friday - an ''agreement in principle'' for the destruction of all of the two nations' short- and medium-range nuclear missiles, and a summit conference, probably in Washington, before year's end.

title: Jazz: Larry Carlton and Yellowjackets
description: WHEN jazz-fusion music was born in the late 1960's, it was a messy but adventurous blend of jazz improvisation and rock amplification, and its compositional formats suggested a sophisticated elaboration of arena rock set pieces. Twenty years later, mainstream jazz-fusion, like most of the rest of pop, has become smoothed-out, synthesizer-oriented and song-structured. Indeed, jazz-fusion, action-oriented television themes and the mood music known as New Age are becoming practically indistinguishable.

title: Karen L. Thorson Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., Karen List Thorson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Petr A. Thorson of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Lee Hunter Hallowell Jr., a son of Mr. Hallowell of Boston and Westport, N.Y., and Robin Welch Breed of New York and Washington. The Rev. Richard Dennis Visconti, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Forrest Kirkpatrick, performed the ceremony.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: PERFUME: The Story of a Murderer, by Patrick Suskind. Translated by John E. Woods. (Pocket, $4.50.) Blessed and cursed with an absurdly acute olfactory lobe, an 18th-century maker of perfumes named Jean-Baptiste Grenouille is both a vampire, who kills young women for their scents, and an artist, who creates invisible sculptures of smells. Translated from the German, this novel, a ''meditation on the nature of death, desire and decay'' is a ''remarkable debut,'' our reviewer, Peter Ackroyd, said last year. CADILLAC DESERT: The American West and Its Disappearing Water, by Marc Reisner. (Penguin, $8.95.) To the author, the American West is a vast, expensively maintained Disneyland - a synthetic fantasy world whose dependence on heroic feats of hydraulic engineering makes it as likely to endure as a flash flood in a desert arroyo. This ''revealing, absorbing, often amusing and alarming report . . . recounts how huge sums have been spent to benefit small numbers of influential people,'' Gladwin Hill said here in 1986, ''and suggests painful days of reckoning lie ahead.'' WHERE YOU'LL FIND ME: And Other Stories, by Ann Beattie. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) Ann Beattie's spare stories are peopled with survivors of the 60's and 70's who feel disconnected from one another and from reality itself, as they wait around for their real lives to begin. While a few of these stories ''pursue economy to the point of inconclusiveness,'' Thomas R. Edwards said here last year, ''most of them have the sensitive elegance one hopes for from this remarkably gifted writer.'' BIRD OF LIFE, BIRD OF DEATH: A Naturalist's Journey Through a Land of Political Turmoil, by Jonathan Evan Maslow. (Laurel/Dell, $6.95.) When the author, a naturalist whose previous book was ''The Owl Papers,'' set out in search of the sacred quetzal bird, he found not only a species endangered but a country as well. His portrait of Guatemala, where mountainous beauty clashes with human suffering, is ''wonderful,'' our reviewer, Graeme Gibson, said last year. ''His touch is sure.'' DESSA ROSE, by Sherley Anne Williams. (Berkley, $3.95.) The poet Sherley Anne Williams thought it was sad that two obscure historical figures - a pregnant black woman who led a slave revolt and a lonely white North Carolina woman who gave refuge to runaway slaves - had never met. She remedied the oversight in a novel that our reviewer, David Bradley, last year called ''an absorbing fusion that is both elegant poetry and powerful fiction.'' ON MODERN MARRIAGE: And Other Observations, by Isak Dinesen. Translated by Anne Born. (St. Martin's, $7.95.) After her husband had given her syphilis and she had begun her affair with Denys Finch Hatton, Karen Blixen wrote an essay comparing marriage (''mutual mental cannibalism'') and the virtues of free love. Written before the author took the name Isak Dinesen and produced her stories and memoirs of Africa, the book ''poignantly illuminates this adventurous woman's passionate refusal to be possessed or possessive,'' Susan Gubar wrote here in 1986. SAFE HOUSES, by Lynne Alexander. (Dell, $4.50.) Gerda, forced into prostitution by her father during World War II, does not know if her daughter, now living with her in a Brooklyn tenement, was fathered by a murderer, Adolf Eichmann, or a hero, Raoul Wallenberg. In 1985 our reviewer, Laurel Graeber, praised the novel for offering ''a stark and unsentimental view that is disturbing and often affecting.'' DESCARTES' DREAM: The World According to Mathematics, by Philip J. Davis and Reuben Hersh. (Houghton Mifflin, $12.95.) The technocrats' belief that nothing is real that can't be quantified is often traced to the 17th-century philosopher Rene Descartes, who dreamed of a world in which all questions could be answered computationally. In this book of essays, the authors of ''The Mathematical Experience'' offer ''an antidote to the Cartesian view that mathematical and scientific knowledge will suffice to solve the central problems of human existence,'' our reviewer, Daniel Gorenstein, said last year. SEVEN RIVERS WEST, by Edward Hoagland. (Penguin, $6.95.) In the 1880's, Cecil Roop, hoping to capture grizzly bears and train them to perform in vaudeville, leaves home to explore the West. Edward Hoagland, known for his essays on wildlife and wilderness, not only tells a good adventure story but also ''makes the reader grieve for the lost beauty he describes,'' our reviewer, John Irving, wrote in 1986. ''The book aches with melancholy for our past.'' MYTHS OF GENDER: Biological Theories About Women and Men, by Anne Fausto-Sterling. (Basic, $9.95.) Attributing differences between the sexes to biology is not only bad science but an attempt to shore up an oppressive status quo, argues the author, a developmental geneticist at Brown University. Save for an occasional dubious pronouncement, she has ''given us a temperate, judiciously argued book that makes its complicated subjects accessible in clear and uncomplicated prose,'' Daniel J. Kevles said here in 1985. THE WELL, by Elizabeth Jolley. (Penguin, $6.95.) Set in rural Australia, this novel tells of the idyllic relationship between a lonely, crippled spinster and a young orphan girl, and how it is brought to ruin when reality - in the form of a mysterious stranger - intrudes. Last year our reviewer, Robert Coover, criticized the author for being ''more witty than profound'' but admired the way her lines seem to ''radiate with the pleasure she'd had in writing them.''

title: U.S. Is Asked to Clarify Lebanese Man's Arrest
description: The Lebanese Government sent a note today to the United States Justice Department asking it to clarifiy its action in seizing a Lebanese citizen in the Mediterranean Sea and taking him to Washington for trial on hijacking charges.

title: Q and A
description: Checking on a Developer Question: I live in New York City but I am looking to buy a condominium in Sullivan County without a mortgage. It will be in a brand-new development. Lacking the advantage of the investigatory process of a bank or mortgage institution, how can I be sure of the sponsor's reliability? . . . S. H., Brooklyn Answer: The best way to protect yourself is to find a lawyer with a real-estate background who can take a knowledgable look at the sponsor's prospectus, a document required by the Attorney General's office.

title: In Un-Socratic Exchanges, Bork Delineates Several Selves
description: TWICE last week in the process of repackaging himself as a moderate, Judge Robert H. Bork, a hero to the right for thundering loud and long against ''the modern, activist, liberal Supreme Court,'' parsed a distinction for the senators of the Judiciary Committee, who are considering his nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: Reagan Alienates Koreans Needlessly
description: LEAD: President Reagan's meeting at the White House with Roh Tae Woo, chairman of South Korea's ruling Democratic Justice Party and a presidential candidate, is yet another example of the United States shooting itself in the foot in South Korea.

title: The Big Mac of Adult Education
description: ANY educational institution can offer a course in ethics. Apparently only one has ever taught ''How to Cheat on Your Spouse.'' ''The first thing the teacher said was: 'How many of you paid for this class with a credit card?' '' said William Zanker, the 33-year-old president and founder of The Learning Annex Inc., which offered the class. ''About three-quarters of the hands went up. Then she said: 'WRONG! How are you going to explain the credit card bill? Now think up some other class that you can claim you went to.' '' The apprentice cheaters had plenty of cover to choose from. In New York and more than a dozen other major cities, Mr. Zanker's company offers literally hundreds of courses every month with such titles as ''Hot Air Ballooning,'' ''How to Lose Your Regional/Foreign Accent,'' ''Stop Smoking Now!'' ''Your Own Greeting Card Business'' and ''Firewalking.''

title: DANCE
description: Sometimes, attending performances is like taking a journey. Dancegoers can travel backward into time at ''Concert Francais,'' an evening of French Baroque music and dance presented Sunday night at 8 at the New York University Theater by Concert Royal, a musical group directed by James Richman, and the New York Baroque Dance Company, directed by Catherine Turocy. The program's first half features reconstructions of dances by Louis Pecour and Francoise Prevost, two major Baroque choreographers. Then, after intermission, singers, dancers and musicians will join forces in Nicolas Bernier's ''Apollon, Comus et la Nuit,'' a fanciful divertissement commissioned in 1715 by the Duchesse de Maine, a celebrated insomniac who, to while away her sleepless nights, held all-night parties at her castle in Sceaux, where she staged musical and dance works as part of the festivities. The music for this divertissement will be performed on original instruments and the choreography, by Ms. Turocy, derives from 18th-century dance notation.

title: The Holy Landscape of Spain's Zurbaran By John Russell
description: IN LAVISHING TIME, SPACE, CARE and money on the paintings of Francisco de Zurbaran (1598-1664), the Metropolitan Museum has set itself to right an ancient wrong. Among the great Spanish painters, Zurbaran is to this day the least well known and the most difficult to study in depth. He has never before had what we call ''a one-man exhibition'' in the United States. In fact, his work had never been given a comprehensive exhibition on its own anywhere at all until first Granada, in 1953, and Madrid, in 1963, did their best to fill the gap. For anything comparable in size to the show that opens Tuesday at the Met we should have to go back to the Galerie Espagnole as it existed under the patronage of King Louis-Philippe in the Louvre from 1838 to 1848.

title: Poll Finds No Clear Democratic Choice; Bush Leading G.O.P.
description: There continues to be no clear front-runner in the race for the 1988 Democatic Presidential nomination, the latest Gallup Poll shows, but Vice President Bush is maintaining his lead over Senator Bob Dole in the Republican contest.

title: JEAN MINSKOFF IS WED TO F. C. GRANT 3D
description: Jean Barbara Minskoff, the daughter of Mrs. Jack Schleifer of New York, Harrison, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Henry H. Minskoff, was married yesterday at her mother's home in Harrison to Francis Clark Grant 3d, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Grant Jr. of Philadelphia, Palm Beach and Mount Desert Island, Me. Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner and the Rev. S. Burtner Ulrich, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Agency Seeks Fishing Boat Safety Rules
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, sharply differing with Reagan Administration policy, has called for sweeping regulations on fishermen and fishing vessels to reduce accidents and deaths at sea.

title: Data Update: September 20, 1987
For Once-Hated Killer Whales, Changing Attitudes Mean New Friends
description: For $20 you can adopt Mozart. Or Mata Hari. Or even Opus. But you won't be subsidizing a composer, a sexy spy or a comic strip penguin. You get a killer whale, maybe 25 feet long and weighing four tons. Awkward to hold in your lap.

title: How Is a Festival Measured?
description: WHEN HE FIRST COMES on the screen in Nikita Mikhalkov's ''Dark Eyes,'' Marcello Mastroianni appears to be exhausted and old. It seems as if success and the good life have at last caught up with this most talented, most engaging, most enduring of all European actors. In ''Dark Eyes,'' Mr. Mastroianni is initially seen as a rummy, garrulous wreck of a man, a once-promising architect who, near the turn of the century, had been picked up by the Italian haute bourgeoisie and then, after too many infidelities, had at last been abandoned by the wife and class that were never really his.

title: Sarah Henderson Becomes a Bride
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., Sarah Hedley Henderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warwick Peter Henderson of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to K. James Caviston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Caviston of Hampton Falls, N.H. The Rev. Robert T. Hollett performed the ceremony.

title: NEW FERRY SERVICE BEGUN
description: THE number of trans-Hudson commuter ferry runs continues to increase. The Arcorp Ferry Service is now offering weekday sailings betweeen its terminal at Pershing Road and 48th Street here to Slip 5, adjacent to the Staten Island Ferry terminal in Manhattan.

title: Playing the Odds On Air Refunds
description: Deep discount nonrefundable tickets did not disappear like Cinderella at midnight after all. They hung around, but the distinctions between them and their stepsisters have begun to be erased.

title: SUSANNA E. LAMB, DESIGNER, MARRIED TO FRANK R. BABBOTT, STUDENT, ON L.I.
description: St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Susanna Eyre Lamb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon E. Lamb of Cold Spring Harbor, to Frank Richardson Babbott, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Babbott of Burlington, Vt. The Rev. Robert A. Bryan, the Anglican Archdeacon of Quebec and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee, the rector of the church.

title: After the Great Leaps, Baryshnikov Moves On
description: THE TIME HAS COME TO STATE the obvious. A few months short of turning 40, after years of injuries and after performing less and less frequently with the American Ballet Theater in New York, Mikhail Baryshnikov is not the dancer we first saw here in 1974. But that is the image we all still carry in our minds. There is, however, a compelling, if different, Baryshnikov in our midst. The time has also come to recognize that the ballet superstar has entered a new phase in his career.

title: BASEBALL AT ITS BEST
description: IN the darkness before dawn Friday, the baseball fan stirred from his pillow.

title: REPLACING BROKEN WINDOW GLASS
description: REPLACING cracked or broken window glass is not difficult. Doing the job in an orderly fashion virtually guarantees good results even the first time.

title: SCULPTURE AS OUTDOOR EXPERIMENT
description: LEAD: THE Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, situated just west of the picturesque former whaling port, commands a delightful view of the harbor and bay, and boasts an eclectic mixture of buildings in styles ranging from gingerbread Victorian to the latest in postmodern formalism. This summer, the campus has been the site of an artistic experiment that parallels the work carried on in the laboratories and lecture halls.

title: POSTINGS: In Hamilton Heights; Walk-Up Condos
description: Two adjoining 80-year-old, five-story brick buildings at 441-443 West 151st Street in the Hamilton Heights neighborhood of northern Harlem have been converted into condominium apartments.

title: Last Call
description: THERE WAS NOTHING SPECIAL ABOUT the way Charlie Brown said, ''Can you step over to my office for a moment?'' Over the past 10 years I had picked up the telephone and heard those same words, in that same measured tone, hundreds, perhaps thousands, of times.

title: Firefighters Raise Voices for Charity
description: Jim McNulty, a firefighter with Squad 1 in Brooklyn, has no acting experience, but he did not worry about stage fright when he tried out for the chorus in a new production of ''South Pacific.''

title:
DINING OUT;
ECLECTICISM IN BUCKS COUNTY
description: LEAD: THE Cuban-born French chef Jacques Colmaire has developed an interesting and, for him, somewhat unusual restaurant in the Bucks County community of Doylestown, Pa. It is called Cafe Arielle.

title: Sports of The Times; Robinson Is Right at Home
description: HE was wearing a blue blazer and a blue tie and an off-white shirt and gray slacks with black shoes, and he carried a blue-and-red umbrella. He could have come directly from his summer job with Salomon Brothers rather than a football dressing room.

title: JANICE HYMAN IS ENGAGED TO DR. STEPHEN H. WOLPO
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abe Hyman of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter Janice Gail Hyman to Dr. Stephen Harris Wolpo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott L. Wolpo, also of Brooklyn.

title: Bork's Final Day: Trying to Discern Original Intent Behind the Constitution
description: On the fifth day of hearings on the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, members of the Senate Judiciary Committee continued their questioning of Judge Bork. Following are excerpts, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: The Interminable Term
description: THE THIRD WEEK OF September was always the nightmare week. All the excitement of going back to school was gone. The new pencil box was smashed, the crayons broken. The sole had come loose on one of your new back-to-school shoes, you suddenly had an enormous inkblot in your spelling book, and they were throwing the seven-times table at you.

title: SCHOOL-BUS RULES TIGHTENING
description: TO improve school bus safety, Nassau County is imposing additional standards on the operators of school buses throughout the county. A bill to license the buses, submitted this summer to the Board of Supervisors by a 12-member Task Force on School Bus Safety, is expected to be adopted at a Sept. 28 board meeting and would go into effect Oct. 15, making Nassau the second county in the state (after Yonkers) to implement such a law.

title: Tailoring Rhetoric of Others For Candidates' New Clothes
description: IF ever a campaign took inspiration from the New Testament lines, ''In the beginning was the word . . . and the word was made flesh,'' it is the campaign of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. It has been built on words - his own, spoken passionately, and those of a core of advisers who had a dream about how a candidate should run and what he should say before ever he started campaigning in the flesh.

title: ACCIDENTS REVIVE CALL FOR AIRPORT'S CLOSING
description: THE crash last month of a twin-engine, propeller-driven plane near Bader Field here has renewed anxiety over the airport's safety and its proximity to homes.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FOR CAR BUFFS Today's the day for car buffs to get off the road and onto display grounds to catch one or both of two shows. Those into the old might enjoy Old Westbury Gardens, where the Greater New York Region of the Antique Automobile Club of America holds its annual exhibition of recently restored custom, sports, classic, vintage and, yes, antique cars. From 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., the cars, and their proud owners, will dominate the rolling lawns of the lush estate. Admission, which entitles visitors to stroll the gardens at their leisure, is $3, or $2.50 for the elderly and $1 for children 6 through 12; tours of the mansion cost an additional $2 for adults or $1 for children. For information call 333-0048. In Hempstead, at Hofstra University, where Long Island Cars holds its Car Show and Swap Meet from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., the emphasis is on more contemporary, as well as collectible, models. Besides showing what devotion to wheels can achieve, the day's activities include judging of what's best in 50 categories, a car sale and a swap of car-related items. Admission is $1.50, with children under 12 free.

title: Owners Toughen Stance
description: The National Football League owners adopted a tougher stance yesterday, one designed to hit the wallets of players who go on strike. They also said they believed the only stumbling block remaining in the labor dispute was the issue of free agency, on which both sides remained far apart.

title: Headliners; Moving Up
description: Seldom has there been a more dramatic changing of the guard in Baltimore than occurred last week, when Kurt Schmoke defeated Mayor Clarence (Du) Burns for the Democratic mayoral nomination. Mr. Burns, 69 years old, learned politics by working his way up through the system, starting as a precinct volunteer 40 years ago, before Mr. Schmoke was born. Mr. Schmoke took degrees at Yale and Harvard, attended Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar, and then worked as a White House aide in the Carter Administration. Five years ago, at the age of 32, he was elected State's Attorney for Baltimore. With the Democratic nomination considered tantamount to election in Baltimore, Mr. Schmoke was virtually assured of becoming the first black to be elected Mayor.

title: Farm Issues Seen as Likely to Play Key Role in Shaping the 1988 Campaign
description: Relatively few American voters have a personal stake in farm prosperity or poverty, but a lot of those who do live in Iowa, where the first Presidential caucuses of 1988 will be held on Feb. 8, and in the 15 Southern or border states that will hold primaries or caucuses a month later.

title: N.F.L.'s Friendly Enemies
description: THEY glower at each other - the tightly wound, gray-haired, formally dressed lawyer representing the owners, and the sport-shirted, emotional, outsized leader of the workers.

title: MISS SCHAUS HAS WEDDING
description: St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church in Jamestown, R.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Wendell Walton Schaus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Schaus of Farmington, Conn., and Robert Otis Brown, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Brown of Providence, R.I. The Rev. William J. O'Neill performed the ceremony.

title: 'Mandela' Is Moving, But Oversimplified
description: ''MANDELA'' IS EARNEST, insistent and in its way sweet-tempered. Nelson Mandela, imprisoned in South Africa since 1962, is seen as a man sustained by the goodness of his own convictions. His life unrolls in a series of tableaux, some deeply moving, and all, as nearly as one can tell, reasonably consonant with the historical record, or at least some of its parts. Did Mr. Mandela say all the words that the Home Box Office presentation attributes to him? Did he walk, talk and smile with the same good humor and purpose? We don't know precisely, of course; Nelson Mandela, played here by Danny Glover, has been as much myth as man for years, and in real life his imprisonment serves a kind of saintly purpose. He is symbol and rallying point. As long as he remains in prison, it is clear that no black in South Africa is free.

title: On the Route Of Jefferson In France
description: Turning his thoughts back to France at the end of his life, Thomas Jefferson wrote of its ''preeminince of character among the nations of the earth.''

title: MAKING AND REMAKING THE LAW OF THE LAND
description: THE SUPREME COURT How It Was, How It Is. By William H. Rehnquist. Illustrated. 338 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: BIG RIVER, DANGEROUS GROUND
description: EAST ALONG THE EQUATOR A Journey Up the Congo and Into Zaire. By Helen Winternitz. 274 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. Paper, $7.95.

title: HOME SET UP FOR CHILDREN WITH AIDS
description: PEOPLE who look at 4-year-old Melissa's paintings on the walls at St. Clare's, a home for children here, find it hard to believe that the lively little girl, who likes to help in the kitchen and ride on swings, will probably be dead of AIDS before her sixth birthday.

title: Einar Gerhardsen Dies at 90; Led Norway as Welfare State
description: Einar Gerhardsen, a former Prime Minister of Norway who played a key role in the establishment of his nation's welfare state and its strong, pro-Western foreign policy in the decades after World War II, died Saturday at the age of 90, the Norwegian National News agency said.

title: WESTPORT TO SOLICIT BOATER DONATIONS
description: IN the next few weeks, boaters who have been aided by the police marine units in Westport will be asked to express their gratitude by sending in a $50 donation to the Marine Police Auxiliary.

title:
ART;
ISLIP SHOWS NEW WORKS
description: LEAD: FOR want of a better designation, the current exhibition at the Islip Art Museum in East Islip is simply called ''Untitled.'' This reflects that, unlike the museum's usual thematic group shows, this one, featuring five artists, has no particular theme.

title: ART
description: It is common ground among those who know his work well that Ferdinand Hodler (1853-1918) was one of the great European painters of his day. Yet in the United States he has almost no name at all. Rare in American museums, his work is rarer still in the dealers' galleries. The auction industry has yet to catch up with him. So has ''the literature,'' as it is often called.

title: Reflections on the Visit's End
description: Shortly after Pope John Paul II finished his speech on social justice and headed to the Silverdome to celebrate mass, the streets of downtown Detroit bore witness to the end of his 10-day visit to the United States.

title: NO QUICK FIX FOR 'VISIBLE BIGOTRY'
description: DESPITE the efforts of educators, the concerted attempts of law-enforcement agencies and special citizen human-interest groups, the problem of ''visible bigotry'' and the impact of bias crime on what are too often youthful victims, as well as youthful offenders, remains a problem that frustrates attempts at any ''quick fix.''

title: Outdoors; Diagnosis for Ailing Eelgrass
description: THE source of a disease that threatens eelgrass beds along the East Coast has been positively identified, giving cause for celebration. The villain - according to Dr. Frederick Short, senior research scientist at the University of New Hampshire's Jackson Estuarine Laboratory - is a single strain, or species, of Labyrinthula, a microscopic, primitive, parasitic fungus.

title: YONKERS MALL DRAWS AREA OPPOSITION
description: THE Yonkers City Council is the only governing body that can vote on whether to allow a 500,000-square-foot shopping mall with 75 to 100 stores into Yonkers - but five neighboring communities are opposing it anyway.

title: CAN THE GIANTS REPEAT AS CHAMPIONS?
description: Barring a strike . . . can the Giants repeat? Possibly. Will they? Unlikely.

title: 2 Kidney Transplants Linked to AIDS Virus
description: Two people became infected with the AIDS virus after receiving kidneys from an accident victim, officials said Friday, and it appears that routine pre-transplant tests for the virus were fooled because the donor's blood had been diluted by more than a dozen transfusions, officials said.

title: Vancouver's Seaside Towns, Rugged Wilds
description: Many travelers are familiar with the capital of Vancouver Island, the clean, pretty city of Victoria, with its British influences and traditions; fewer are aware of the rest of the 285-mile-long island off Canada's west coast. Seaside towns along the east coast contrast with the wilderness on its west; snow-capped mountains form the island's spine and clear lakes dot its body. Forests of centuries-old trees stand near rolling fertile farmlands.

title: 6 STAMFORD OFFICERS FIGHT RETIREMENT
description: FOR years, Patrolman Fred Genovese has directed traffic at what he calls the busiest intersection in downtown Stamford - at Atlantic, Broad and Bedford Streets.

title: THE NATION: Pat Robertson; Evangelist Joins Race in A Flourish of Petitions
description: Standing before heaps of petitions that he run, and boasting of ''clear-cut victories'' in early tests of organizational strength, the Rev. Pat Robertson said last week that he would seek the Republican nomination for President.

title: Mets Win on A Slam
description: Stride for stride, down the homestretch with two weeks to go, the Mets kept pace tonight in another close call.

title: For the Disabled
description: To the Editor: Dennis Hevesi's Practical Traveler column ''How Disabled People Clear Hurdles of Flying'' (Travel, Aug. 23) cited many precautions to take. Fine, do that, but be prepared to fend for yourself or a disabled traveling companion. During a recent trip, New York to Seattle, precautions went the way of the winds for myself and my husband, who needed a wheelchair.

title: LISA SCHNEIDER IS WED TO KEVIN E. THORNTON
description: Elizabeth Anne Schneider, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Arnold Schneider of Old Saybrook, Conn., was married yesterday to Kevin Edwin Thornton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Thornton of Hartsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Kirk Stevan Smith performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: City Makes It Official: Algonquin Is Landmark
description: The Algonquin Hotel, where literary figures of the 1920's held court at the Round Table, attained landmark status last week along with an apartment house overlooking Central Park.

title: A Warning
description: WITH the prospect of a professional football strike on the horizon, Bowie Kuhn, the former baseball commissioner, was asked about the 1981 baseball strike and came up with what might be regarded as a cautionary tale for National Football League owners. ''Ownership was too inflexible,'' he said, suggesting that baseball's owners ended up with a worse deal in 1981 than they would have gotten if they had been more willing to compromise with the players' union.

title: FOR MANY, ONE: PECULIAR NATIONAL STRENGTH
description: WHEN your family has been American for more than 300 years, as mine has, one tends to develop an intense, almost proprietary feeling toward our country. So it was with great interest that I observed the controversy surrounding passage of the Immigration Reform and Control Act, the so-called Alien Amnesty Bill.

title: OWNERS FIGHT PURCHASE PLAN
description: LEAD: WHEN an $8 million open-space-preservation bond act was approved last November by Town of Southampton voters, one of the intentions was to use the money to purchase land singled out for development. The attempted acquisition of four such parcels, totaling five and a half waterfront acres, has been encouraged by environmentalists.

title: Lure for Long Commute: Cheaper Homes
description: ON any workday Michael and Geraldine Ready leave their home in Matamoras, Pa., shortly after 5 A.M. to drive to the Metro North railroad station in Port Jervis, N.Y. From there, they travel via New Jersey Transit, PATH and the IND subway to their jobs in midtown Manhattan.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Speculation; Sensing the Path of Community Renewal
description: ''THE underlying principle,'' says Harry Skydell, ''is that at some given point all of Manhattan will be rehabilitated. It's the simple law of supply and demand.''

title: Hairpower
description: WHILE WOMEN HAVE been making it through the doors of such male bastions as the corporate board room and the private club, and into judges' chambers and operating rooms, men have been invading what has, until now, been exclusively a female province - the beauty salons of America.

title: Gray Matter, With Humor
description: SWIMMING TO CAMBODIA Performed and written by Spalding Gray. Directed by Jonathan Demme. 1987. Lorimar Home Video. 87 minutes. $79.95.

title: Donation Helps Create Housing for the Elderly
description: Carrying a shovel and wearing a white hard hat against the rain, Lawrence A. Wien, the real-estate investor known for his philanthropy, led participants at a ground-breaking ceremony Friday for a new 14-story building for elderly, low-income tenants in upper Manhattan.

title: Happy Birthday to Us
description: 'If our Constitution has endured, through times perilous as well as prosperour, it has not been simply as a plan of government, no matter how ingenious or inspired that might be. This document that we honor today has always been something more to us, filled us with a deeper feeling than one of simple admiration - a feeling, one might say, more of reverence.'

title: BLACK IS RED
description: Citizens for Reagan is urging its 100,000 members to boycott Home Box Office, the cable television service, in protest against an HBO program. So is the Rev. Jerry Falwell's Moral Majority.

title: A 1788 COMEDY IS UNEARTHED
description: HAVING unearthed a previously unproduced 1788 comedy, ''The Politician Out-Witted,'' which happens, ostensibly and tangentially, to be about the heated debate over ratification of the Constitution, the director Warren Kliewer had the play presented in a pair of ''concert readings'' in Rutherford last year.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Block Island, R.I.;
Island Saves Choice Land
description: LEAD: OPEN-SPACE preservation efforts are moving forward on this dollop of land off the Rhode Island coast.

title: NEW YORKERS Etc.
description: THERE'S nothing peculiar about a person walking along a Manhattan street, or any other street for that matter, eating an ice cream cone. It's the approach that's sometimes a little strange - ice-cream-cone-eating is not a cut-and-dried, standarized, routine matter. It is an accomplishment with infinite variety, ranging from methodical and workmanlike procedures to methods that are visions of delicacy and grace.

title: VIRGINIA FOWLER, A LAWYER, WED TO PETER M. KIMM JR.
description: Virginia Ann Fowler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude S. Fowler of Roanoke, Va., and Peter M. Kimm Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kimm of Potomac, Md., were married yesterday at the Arts Club in Washington by the Rev. Joseph M. Smith, a Baptist minister.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The trouble with a campaign is you have to sell yourself. I find it very distasteful. It is very hard to stand up and say, 'I'm a terrific person - select me, honor me, choose me, elect me.' That's very difficult psychologically for me. I don't like it, I don't like it.'' - Governor Cuomo. [ 1:4. ]

title: Reagan Names New Yorker
description: President Reagan nominated Alfred A. DelliBovi on Friday to be Administrator of the Urban Mass Transportation Administration, subject to approval by the Senate. Mr. DelliBovi has been Acting Administrator since May, when Ralph Stanley, the Administrator, returned to private business.

title: A TV Watch in France for Hostages
description: Twice each day, at the start of newscasts at 1 and 8 P.M., the same five snapshots of hostages flash onto the screen with their names and the number of days they have been held by terrorists: 910 for two French diplomats and 849, 559, and 249 for three French journalists.

title: Responding to Old-Age Creations
description: To the Editor:

title: Preservation Urged For Big Watershed
description: LEAD: THE 35,000-acre Newark Watershed is an irreplaceable reservoir of natural and cultural resources that should be preserved, a series of speakers contended at a symposium here last week.

title: 'SUBURBAN OFF BROADWAY' AND FAMILY FARE
description: WITH the advent of a new season, attention should be paid to a couple of emerging professional and as yet unheralded Fairfield County theaters - small in size, contrasting in vision.

title: KIWI ECONOMICS
description: In food, as in fashion, trend-setters create the fad, but the real dollars don't begin to roll in until it hits the mass market. Consider the kiwi.

title: Senator Trible of Virginia Announces Retirement, Citing Frustration
description: Senator Paul S. Trible Jr. of Virginia announced today that he would not seek a second term in the Senate next year, saying that ''much of the important work of the nation doesn't seem to get done'' in the Senate.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are giving Iran one more chance.'' - Prince Saud al-Faisal, Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia, as the Arab League announced a summit meeting. [ A9:3. ]

title: Nicaragua Lifts Restrictions From Opposition Newspaper
description: The opposition newspaper La Prensa, closed down by the Sandinista Government 15 months ago, has received permission to resume publication free of censorship, its publisher said today.

title: Michael Stewart Is Dead 63; Author of Broadway Musicals
description: Michael Stewart, who won Tony Awards as the author of the Broadway musical hits ''Bye Bye Birdie'' in 1961 and ''Hello, Dolly!'' in 1964, died of pneumonia early yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Advertising; Polaroid Revamps A Photo Magazine
description: The Polaroid Corporation has started a magazine called Instant, which will carry articles about instant photography accompanied by photos taken, for the most part, with instant cameras. The magazine, published by Polaroid and prepared by Hearst Professional Magazines, is actually a revamped, glossier version of the similarly named Instants, which was in circulation for three years before folding last spring.

title: Recital: Carmela Altamura
description: THERE may be precious little agreement about exactly what genuine bel canto singing sounds like, but even the most accommodating listener would be hard pressed to accept the version offered Saturday evening by Carmela Bucceri Altamura. The soprano gave the first of three scheduled recitals at Weill Hall, at Carnegie Hall, dedicated to this great and precious art.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: The Play's the Thing Everyone has opinions about everything connected with the stage. Today at Lincoln Center an actress, a director and a producer will voice theirs. The occasion is the opening program in Lincoln Center Offstage, a series of hour-long informal conversations on the performing arts, The participants in ''Actors/Directors'' will be the actress Viveca Lindfors; Deborah Shaefer, director of ''Fire on the Mountain,'' and John Goberman, producer of ''Live From Lincoln Center.'' Harlan Jacobson, editor of Film Comment magazine, will moderate. The talk will be preceded, from 5:30 to 6 P.M., by a wine-and-cheese reception. The site is Alice Tully Hall (362-1911), on Broadway at 65th Street. Admission, $12. The Writer Reads

title: Suzanne Leigh Lerner Weds Dr. Gary Hitzig
description: Suzanne Leigh Lerner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Lerner of Great Neck, L.I., and Dr. Gary Hitzig, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Hitzig of Deerfield Beach, Fla., were married yesterday at the Inn at Quogue, L.I., by Rabbi David Greenberg.

title: Intercontinental Hotels, In Split, Loses Leader
description: The Intercontinental Hotels Corporation has accepted the resignation of its chief executive, Hans G. Sternik, and plans to appoint a successor in the next week or so.

title: No Moon Collider
description: Moon Area L-5, the Energy Department announced Friday with a straight face, will not be the site of the Government's $4.4 billion super collider, the world's most powerful particle accelerator.

title: Bonni Benrubi Is Married To Dennis Harley Powers
description: Bonni Benrubi, a daughter of Harry Benrubi of Hackensack, N.J., and the late Salle Houseman Benrubi, and Dennis Harley Powers, a son of the late Dwight Powers of Los Angeles and the late Marion Powers of Santa Monica, Calif., were married yesterday. Judge Sandra Feuerstein of Nassau County District Court performed the ceremony at the Provence Restaurant in Manhattan.

title: BORK SWING VOTES REMAIN UNDECIDED
description: After five days of intense questioning of Judge Robert H. Bork, four members of the Senate Judiciary Committee say they are still undecided on whether to vote to confirm his nomination to the Supreme Court.

title:
AIDS AND DIVORCE: A NEW LEGAL ARENA;
When Illness Destroys a Marriage
description: LEAD: ''When a marriage breaks up because a man brings home AIDS, all the factors are at play,'' said Peter Bronstein, a New York matrimonial lawyer. He gave the following account of a case in which he represents the wife:

title: Foreign Banks in Australia: 15's a Crowd
description: Two and a half years after it was invited to apply for a banking license in Australia, Morgan Bank has still not taken up the offer.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A SOUTHERN FAMILY. By Gail Godwin. 540 pages. William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: Ex-Librarian of Congress To Be Doubleday Editor
description: Daniel J. Boorstin, the social historian who retired as the Librarian of Congress last week, will join Doubleday as editor-at-large. Dr. Boorstin will assume the specially created position on Oct. 1, and will work primarily out of his home in Washington.

title: Nancy Alison Bard Weds Donald Baer
description: At the Harmonie Club in New York, Nancy Alison Bard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Bard of New York and West Nyack, N.Y., and Donald Aaron Baer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ervin Baer of Fayetteville, N.C., were married yesterday by Rabbi Henry A. Sosland.

title: Advertising; Welch Foods Account Goes to Welch, Currier
description: Welch Foods Inc., producer of Welch's juices, jams, jellies and preserves, has asked Welch, Currier, Curry, Anderson to handle $2 million worth of its consumer and trade promotion budget. The agency will work chiefly on inserts for couponing, in-store displays and sales force materials. Levy, King & White in New York also handles some of the consumer and trade promotions, while Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, also in New York, continues as the agency for all consumer advertising.

title: What Makes the Right Gift?
description: For her 10th wedding anniversary, Catherine Fuller, a school teacher in New York City, received a tennis racquet from her husband, Bob.

title: Expos' Pitchers Best of A Crowd
description: ALL the names now fit on a piece of cardboard that once was the backing for a legal pad. The cardboard rests with the belongings of Buck Rodgers, the manager of the Montreal Expos. Before the start of this surprising season, when Rodgers sat in his spring training office at West Palm Beach, Fla., the names covered the wall opposite his desk.

title: Ideology Has Everything to Do With Bork Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Prant Married To Timothy I. Hooker
description: St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Episcopal Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y. was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Nancy Ellen Prant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Prant of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Timothy Ingram Hooker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Hooker of Nashville. The Rev. Edwin H. Cromey performed the ceremony.

title: A Message Ringing Loud: The Pope's Orthodoxy Will ReverberateFor Catholics in a Nation Proud of Dissent
description: When Pope John Paul II visited the United States in 1979, he was a new face on the world stage and his charm seemed to attract more notice than his words.

title: Britain's Thirst for Tea Wanes
description: ''Tea?'' mused Christopher Wheeler, a young British stockbroker. ''I never touch it.''

title: Boos and Strike Newsletters
description: WITH 6 seconds remaining, Raul Allegre's 46-yard field-goal attempt swerved wide of the goal post and the Giants lost to the Dallas Cowboys, 16-14. In their 0-2 start, they had lost as many games this season as they lost all last season in their ascent to the Super Bowl XXI throne. And now, on each of the wooden stools at their lockers, a slick one-page newsletter from the National Football League Management Council awaited the return of the Giants players from the boos that serenaded their departure yesterday from Giants Stadium.

title: 2 Sailors Killed Near France
description: Two sailors were killed when a Yugoslav ship and a Norwegian cargo vessel collided in thick fog in the English Channel today, the French coast guard said. The two unidentified sailors, aboard the Yugoslav ship, the Makedonija, died during a collision with the Norwegian ship, the Bajka, rescue officials said. No one was injured aboard the Norwegian ship, which was sailing toward the Ivory Coast from France.

title: Kingston Journal; From Fiery Man of Jamaica Politics, a Mea Culpa
description: Michael N. Manley, the fiery Jamaican leader who presided over a dramatic decline in his country's economy a decade ago and raised hackles in Washington with his anti-imperialist pronouncements, wants to be Prime Minister again. And he talks like a different man.

title: Advertising; BBDO Acquisition
description: BBDO Chicago has acquired Cohen & Greenbaum, a Chicago shop with $24 million in billings, for an undisclosed amount. The deal, effective in January, will bring the BBDO office's projected billings to $150 million next year. Michael Greenbaum, the former president of the agency that he founded in 1971, will become a senior executive vice president at BBDO.

title: Yankee Rookie Plays Give and Take
description: In a sense, the rookie pitcher showed more poise than the veteran hitter who is tied for the major league home run lead and has driven in more runs than anyone this season. In the end, though, it was the hitter's home run that started the pitcher on the way to his first major league loss.

title: Advertising; Sugar Account to Grey
description: Grey Advertising won the American advertising for the Sugar Association after a seven-way competition. The budget, close to $5 million, will include a consumer print and television campaign and is expected to break by the end of the year. The Washington-based association represents 24 major processors and producers of beet and cane sugar in this country. North Castle Partners, Greenwich, Conn., was the previous agency.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Metals Service Inc., Miami, which sells specialty metals to the aerospace industry, said Vincente Sanchez had resigned as president, but would continue as a director.

title: Was Biden an Echo
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. has been taking flak for speeches in which, without crediting the source, he echoed the words of Robert F. Kennedy and the British Labor Party leader, Neil Kinnock. He has also borrowed language (not to mention gestures) from John F. Kennedy's inaugural address.

title: 12,000 Free Miles for Pope
description: Will Pope John Paul II fly free on his next trip? Trans World Airlines, which is flying the Pope on his American tour, has announced it will award 12,000 free miles under its frequent flier program to all who complete the trip from Rome to California, Detroit, Canada and back to Rome. Attendants on the press plane distributed forms for the program, and one was returned with the name Karol Wojtyla, Apostolic Palace, Rome.

title: Opera: 'Traviata' New Cast
description: AT the New York State Theater Saturday evening, Gianna Rolandi suffered the disappointment of having to withdraw from her first local appearance in ''La Traviata'' after the first act. In the duets and exchanges of the opening scene she had sounded her usual self, and she reminded the City Opera audience of her extraordinarily distinct and easy handling of ornamental passages. But soon after she began the brilliant aria that closes the act, it was clear that she was not going to be able to handle the high notes. After the intermission, it was announced that she had been ill, and Marilyn Mims, whose debut as Violetta was reviewed earlier in the season, completed the performance.

title: Senator Biden's Drama
description: THERE was consensus on the talk shows yesterday: Senator Joseph M. Biden Jr. was hurting. The Delaware Democrat has ''very severe problems,'' David Brinkley said on ''This Week With David Brinkley.'' John McLaughlin, host of ''The McLaughlin Group,'' said, ''He's dead.'' On ''Washington Week in Review,'' Paul Duke, the most reasonable of moderators, asked, ''Who is the real Joe Biden?''

title: Jane Ann Wasserman Weds A. M. Neubardt
description: Jane Ann Wasserman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Wasserman of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Andrew Marc Neubardt, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Selig Neubardt of New Rochelle, N.Y., were married yesterday. Dr. Matthew Ies Spetter, a leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, and Rabbi Jack Bemporad performed the ceremony at the Neubardt home.

title: Mister Rogers Goes to Russia
description: The negotiations were dragging during the marathon bargaining session last week. The Soviet side had reacted stiffly to the American proposals. Then the chief American delegate turned to a furry, eight-inch-long puppet for help.

title: 1 of 3 Fail Drug Tests For Bus Jobs
description: Roughly one out of three applicants for entry-level jobs with the New York City Transit Authority fails the authority's mandatory drug tests, city officials said yesterday.

title: Question Box
description: How much above the .500 mark is Nolan Ryan's career won-lost record and what has been his overall record with each team for which he has pitched?

title: Seoul Is Urged To Bolster Won
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has urged the South Korean Government to accelerate the revaluation of the won against the dollar, the news agency Yonhap reported on Saturday.

title: Pope Ends Trip at Mass Beneath Arctic Rainbow
description: Pope John Paul II ended his 11-day tour of North America today by celebrating mass for 4,000 Indians at this old trading and missionary post in Canada's far north.

title: Apparel Makers Shift Tactics
description: Apparel manufacturers may have found an alternative to restrictive trade legislation to help them check the rising sales of imported apparel in the United States.

title: How Bork Recast Ideas In His Senate Testimony
description: One of the most remarkable aspects of Judge Robert H. Bork's five days of testimony last week was his recantation and qualification of some controversial views he has stated, forcefully and repeatedly, in the past, as long ago as 1971 and as recently as this year.

title: Captain Punished for Sexism
description: The captain of a Navy salvage ship has been stripped of his command, reprimanded and fined for participating in a sex party ashore and sexually harassing female crewmembers aboard his ship.

title: Oilers' Official Arrested in Fight
description: Ladd Herzeg, the general manager of the Houston Oilers, was arrested Saturday night on a misdemeanor assault charge after a fight with a man who was attending a wedding reception at the Oilers' hotel, the police reported.

title: Andrea Baumann Weds I. L. Lustig
description: Andrea Raymond Baumann, an associate with Booz, Allen & Hamilton, and Ivan Laurence Lustig, an associate in the corporate finance department of L. F. Rothschild & Company, were married yesterday at the Hampton, N.J., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Phillippe Emile Baumann. Rabbi Joseph I. Singer officiated.

title: New World's Stock Plan
description: New World Entertainment Ltd. said Friday that it plans to buy 750,000 of its own shares over the next six months on the open market, which would cost about $6.8 million at current prices. Shares in New World, a television, film and animation producer based in Los Angeles, rose 75 cents, to $9. The company is cash rich. New World raised $245.4 million in stock and debt offerings in 1986 and made several small buyouts, but failed this year in a $489 million bid for Kenner Parker Toys Inc., acquired this month by the Tonka Corporation.

title: Keeping Track of Doctors' Bills
description: The Reagan Administration's reported proposal to increase Medicare health insurance premiums 38.5 percent makes sense according to the actuaries: this is no callous effort to soak the aged. At the same time, however, it makes clearer than ever the need for new policies to hold down medical costs.

title: U.S. Tentatively Decides to Raze Most of New Embassy in Moscow
description: After months of discussion, the Reagan Administration has tentatively decided to raze and rebuild at least five floors of the new eight-story embassy building in Moscow at a cost of at least $92 million, according to senior Administration officials.

title: Chief Sees Growth For Hospital Corp.
description: Thomas F. Frist Jr. says he is excited about the future. The co-founder of the Hospital Corporation of America, one of the great growth companies until the Government changed the Medicare rules in 1983, believes the health-care provider is ready to grow again.

title: Bank Ties Savings Plan To Rise in College Costs
description: As a partner at Lazard Freres & Company, Peter Roberts was a bond market whiz who used sophisticated mathematics to squeeze profits out of small irregularities in the futures and options markets.

title: Australia Oversight Plan
description: Australia's Attorney General, Lionel Bowen, said Friday that federal and state governments would consider establishing a nationwide securities industry watchdog to replace state commissions. Business leaders have welcomed Mr. Bowen's proposal as more efficient, more accountable and more responsive to business needs than the individual state agencies.

title: Cut in U.S. Housing Aid Spurs a Private Search
description: The shortage of housing for low-income families is stimulating nationwide initiatives to attract such untapped private resources as corporations, foundations, local institutions like universities or hospitals, as well as wealthy individuals.

title: Ms. Roth Married To B. J. DiNardo
description: The marriage of Micheline Beth Roth to Bartholomew J. DiNardo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bartholomew A. DiNardo of Mamaroneck, N.Y., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Roth, parents of the bride, in Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Panni Products, a maker of potato dumpling mix and potato pancake mix, to Franznick & Cusatis

title: A Once-Proud Rotation Is Spinning Its Wheels
description: Dave Johnson remembers what it was like one year ago: he had a 19-game lead with two weeks to go, and he had five starting pitchers blitzing the National League in the youngest, healthiest and sharpest rotation in baseball. They started 148 of the 162 games the Mets played, and won 76 of them.

title: Respect the Arias Proposal
description: LEAD: The democratic presidents of Costa Rica, Honduras, El Salvador and Guatemala, along with the revolutionary President of Nicaragua, have knocked away the foundations of President Reagan's policy toward Central America: support for the contras and the fiction that Nicaragua menaces its neighbors.

title: Deaths in Building-Site Accidents In New York Found to Be Highest
description: Workers at New York City building sites have the highest rate of death from unsafe conditions among the nation's 35 largest cities, according to a city-by-city inquiry.

title: LINDESAY PARROTT, EX-TIMES REPORTER
description: Lindesay Parrott, a foreign correspondent for The New York Times who covered the Pacific theater in World War II and later the Korean War and served as Tokyo bureau chief for 10 years, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 86 years old.

title: Europeans Weighing an Expanded Role in Space
description: Western European nations are on the verge of making key decisions this fall that could set the course of their space enterprise well into the 21st century and give them increasing independence from the American and Soviet programs.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Market Place; Telex Outlook: Opinions Vary
description: WALL STREET is taking a show-me attitude toward the Telex Corporation, a leading producer of computer terminals and peripheral equipment whose seven-year string of rising profits now appears in jeopardy.

title: INSIDE
description: Republican Race Begins

title: Arab League Delays Sanctions on Iran
description: The foreign ministers of the Arab League held off today on ordering sanctions against Iran, but they announced a special Arab summit meeting that will focus on the Iran-Iraq war as well as the sanctions question.

title: Snack on Poppy Seed Bagel Lands Man Back in U.S. Jail
description: It was something as simple as a bagel with poppy seeds that sent Anthony Clarizio back to prison.

title: Double Defector in Moscow Says He Is Writing a Book
description: A Soviet diplomat who became a double defector was interviewed in a Soviet newspaper today and said he was writing a book.

title: Israeli Soldiers in Jerusalem Wound 2 Young Palestinians
description: Israeli soldiers shot and wounded two young Palestinians near the Damascus Gate of the Old City of Jerusalem today after one of the youths tried to grab a soldier's rifle, a police spokesman said.

title: Mexico Quake Victims Try to Forget
description: Two years after the earthquakes that devastated the Mexican capital, the damage to the city itself has largely been repaired. But thousands of city residents are still struggling, with varying degrees of success, to absorb the shock and rebuild their own lives.

title: Restiveness on Europe's East-West Border
description: To the Editor:

title: See That Googly? It's Cricket in the Bronx
description: Consider the arsenal faced by those at bat yesterday in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx: not fastballs, sliders and curves, but inswingers, offspinners and - the trickiest throw of all - the googly.

title: Flying Low
description: Joann Osterud says she knew she wanted to be a pilot when she was 2 years old. That was in 1948. The British Navy fighter plane that she took to this year's Reno National Air Races, which ended yesterday, traces its design back a bit farther, and was already a year old when the toddling Osterud first turned her face skyward.

title: 2 Issues Could Spell Trouble for Spain's Chief
description: Two major issues, wage negotiations and the education budget, carry the prospect of new protests against the Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez this fall.

title: Mets Falter In 14th
description: In what may have been their most ruinous performance of the season, the Mets went 14 innings today, lost the lead four times, eventually lost to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9-8, and fell two and a half games out of first place with only 13 to play.

title: Gap Response To Stock Loss
description: Gap Inc., responding to queries about a $8.625-a-share drop in its stock on Friday, to $47.25, said during the weekend that its third-quarter earnings could range between 40 and 55 cents a share, compared with 60 cents a share last year.

title: Dayton Talks With Citibank
description: Executives of the Dayton Hudson Corporation have approached Citibank about a possible restructuring of the big department store chain, executives close to the situation said yesterday.

title: Rangers Wonder About Their Speed
description: Under the watchful eye of their new coach, Michel Bergeron, a hodgepodge of Rangers barely survived the extra skating mileage demanded by an Olympic-sized rink to capture the first exhibition game of their season, 6-5, against the fleet United States Olympic team on Saturday night.

title: The Third Transition
description: Only a few years ago, this outpost of the West, deep within Communist East Germany, seemed a dying city, its boundaries fixed and its economy disintegrating. From 1970 to 1983, West Berlin lost 108,000 jobs from its manufacturing sector, and many of its skilled workers were moving out.

title: First Things First for the Jets
description: With the New England Patriots awaiting them Monday night, and with the prospect of a strike on Tuesday, the Jets concluded their practice today on an upbeat note. Preparing under overcast skies, amid swirling winds, the team was loose.

title: Piano: Richard Goode
description: TO judge by the first installment Sunday afternoon, Richard Goode's seven-concert cycle at the 92d Street Y of Beethoven's 32 piano sonatas will be among the season's most important and memorable events. Mr. Goode started his series with an overview of the terrain to be covered, offering two major early sonatas (Op. 2, No. 1 and Op. 7), a big middle-period work (''Tempest'') and an example of the late period (Op. 101).

title: Biden Assails New Report of Dishonesty
description: Declaring himself ''frustrated'' and ''angry as hell,'' Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. took the offensive tonight and denounced new reports that he had misrepresented his academic record in law school at a campaign appearance in New Hampshire.

title: On Lookout for the Earthquake in Japan
description: With its bank of computer terminals and a gigantic electronic display, it looks like a war room. Sooner or later, six men will rush to it in police cars, and many thousands of lives could depend on their subsequent deliberations.

title: Advertising; MCI Awards Account To Wells, Rich, Greene
description: MCI, the 20-year-old telecommunications company based in Washington, has awarded its $40 million account to the 21-year-old agency Wells, Rich, Greene. The three other New York agencies participating in the six-week competition were Ammirati & Puris; Scali, McCabe, Sloves, and Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, which was the runner-up.

title: G.N.P. Is Flat In Japan
description: Japan's gross national product showed no growth in the April-June period from the previous quarter, reflecting the harm to exports from the strong yen, the Economic Planning Agency said Friday.

title: Outdoors: Automatic Duck Adds Touch to Retrieving
description: WHEN waterfowlers daydream of their sport, they see birds wheeling through dark November skies or pitching down into decoys before a cattail-covered blind in a salt marsh. And a keen-eyed, ever-eager retriever, whether a Chesapeake or Labrador or some less-specialized breed, is always with them.

title: AIDS and Divorce: A New Legal Arena
description: Fear of AIDS is beginning to change and complicate the practice of divorce law in some states.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL President Reagan will meet with Prime Minister Nakasone in New York today at a time of strained relations between the U.S. and Japan. The leaders are expected to discuss a wide range of concerns, including Japanese fears about U.S. trade legislation. Officials said Mr. Nakasone might also raise the touchy subject of proposed import sanctions against Toshiba, but they denied rumors that he would make concessions on trade in exchange for a pledge by Mr. Reagan to oppose the Toshiba sanctions vigorously. [ D1. ] The yen is likely to rise further, some Japanese analysts say. Until recently, many experts argued that the currency had advanced too far, but some are now predicting a level of 100 to the dollar, compared with the current rate of about 142. [ D6. ] Foreign banks are scrambling for profits in Australia. An influx of 15 banks after deregulation heightened competition in a country that already had eight large national and regional banks. [ D6. ] A new A.T.&T. plan would restrict foreign surcharges on international calls. Under the program, overseas hotels would agree to limit their own telephone charges - which have amounted to as much as 300 percent - to no more than $1 a call. [ D7. ] THE ECONOMY Five securities firms will skip a large financing, rather than accept a ranking among the underwriters that they consider unbecoming. The protest stems from an increasingly common and contentious version of affirmative action on Wall Street. [ D1. ] A new form of C.D. is designed to finance college educations. A product of the College Savings Bank in Princeton, N.J., its interest rate changes annually to keep pace with rising college costs. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Apparel manufacturers hope to beat foreign competitors with sophisticated computer tactics. The ''quick response'' computers link retail outlets with apparel makers and textile mills. [ D5. ] There are signs of motion in the long-running controversy over Lilco and its Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island. [ B1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Changes are likely in the arbitration of disputes between stockbrokers and clients. Calls for reform come as a record number of cases go before arbitrators. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] . Wall Street is taking a show-me approach toward Telex, whose string of rising profits is in jeopardy. Market Place. [ D8. ] Key decisions on fiscal and monetary policy are expected this week from both Congress and the Federal Reserve. Credit. [ D9. ]

title: Reagan and Nakasone Meet Today
description: Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, in the United States to deliver a speech to the United Nations General Assembly, will meet with President Reagan in New York Monday to discuss a wide range of issues, including Japanese concerns about trade legislation pending in Congress.

title: Biden and the Annals of Raised Eyebrow7.2>
description: At Gettysburg, Pa., on Nov. 19, 1863, Abraham Lincoln spoke movingly of a ''government of the people, by the people, for the people.'' Someone in the audience that day may have recalled that on Jan. 26, 1830, Daniel Webster gave an address in which he talked of a ''people's government, made for the people, made by the people and answerable to the people.''

title: The Editorial Notebook: Sold!; For a Sensible Couple, Luxury Wheels
description: Television commercials flashed the hype: Toyota dealers were giving cars away. ''The '87's have got to go so the '88's can come in. It's our Summer Sale-a-bration!''

title: Martin L. Greenman Wed To Marianne Costantinou
description: The Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour in Rye, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Marianne Costantinou, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicolaos Costantinou of Astoria, Queens, to Martin Livingston Greenman, a son of Martin Allen Greenman of Youngstown, Ohio, and the late Mary Clare Gregory. The Rev. Theodore Baglaneas performed the ceremony.

title: Trapped at Thai Camps, Cambodians Despair
description: The demoralization and victimization of thousands of displaced Cambodians in this bleak border region has prompted fear that Cambodia's human misery has entered a new phase.

title: Unusual Tie Rule Broken In
description: Richmond 52, Massachusetts 51.

title: Great Fiscal Expectations
description: On Capitol Hill a lot should happen in September, the last month of the fiscal year.

title: Hasidim Ask Cuomo for Help on Soviet Visit
description: Governor Cuomo arrived today in the Soviet Union on his first diplomatic mission, the unexpected envoy of some travelers from Brooklyn.

title: Transit Officer Shoots A Youth in Times Sq.
description: A New York City Transit Authority police officer shot and wounded a teen-ager last night in Times Square after the youth ''went into a combat stance'' and fired at him, authorities said.

title: Giants Look Bad Again
description: The Giants played badly last Monday night and lost to the Chicago Bears in their season opener. Today, while they played somewhat better, they were still bad for much of the time, especially on offense, and lost to the Dallas Cowboys, 16-14.

title: Ambiguous Activism
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 21, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Further Rise Seen for Japanese Yen
description: With Japanese companies having adapted so well to the yen's huge appreciation against the dollar, the yen is likely to rise even further in the next year or so, many analysts here say.

title: Uncertainty on Treasury Financings
description: The schedule of Treasury financings this week is uncertain because Congress has not yet approved an increase in the Federal debt ceiling.

title: Little Rock Journal; A Leg in a Brace And White Hair, But Still a Tiger
description: When Lucille Babcock saw where the screams were coming from, she grabbed her cane -there was not time to fetch her rifle -loped down the stairs of her garage apartment and crossed the yard at a limping run.

title: Hecklers Taunt 200 in a March Against Racism
description: About 200 civil-rights demonstrators staged a candlelight march against racism last night in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, but their chants were drowned out by an even larger crowd of young white hecklers who moved alongside the marchers yelling ''Niggers go home!'' and ''White power!''

title: South Korea Is Walking a Fine Olympic Line
description: FOR South Korean Olympic officials, a nightmare vision of what could go wrong at the 1988 Seoul Olympics became a dark reality last June at the height of street protests that swept across the country.

title: Mister Rogers Goes to Russia
description: The negotiations were dragging during the marathon bargaining session last week. The Soviet side had reacted stiffly to the American proposals. Then the chief American delegate turned to a furry, eight-inch-long puppet for help.

title: Both Sides See Leeway on Free Agency
description: Both sides in the National Football League labor talks said yesterday -but not to each other - that they are willing to make concessions on the knotty question of free agency.

title: Bridge: First Senior Region Tourney Concludes in New York City
description: It is rather appropriate that the first Senior Regional Championships ever in New York City, just concluded, was at the Penta Hotel, at Seventh Avenue and 33d Street.

title: Advertising; GSD&M Wins Coors Beer Job
description: After a creative shootout among its three agencies in the last six weeks, the Coors beer account has been awarded to GSD&M Advertising of Austin, Tex., which has generally been known as a specialist in the Hispanic market.

title: Australians Gain Some Cup Revenge
description: When Peter Gilmour of Australia and Gary Jobson of the United States met yesterday in the final of the Liberty Cup match-racing series, it wasn't an America's Cup regatta, but it was close.

title: Pace Starts to Quicken in Fight Over Lilco
description: The complicated and lengthy fight over the Long Island Lighting Company and its Shoreham nuclear power plant is certainly far from over. But in the last week, there have been signs of motion on Long Island, on Wall Street and in Washington.

title: Music: Penny Leigh Luedtke
description: PENNY LEIGH LUEDTKE, a soprano from Wisconsin, came to Alice Tully Hall Saturday night with a coloratura technique that - though in no way triumphant - negotiated most of the stabs, leaps and flourishes the 18th century could throw at her. Indeed, one admired Miss Luedtke's defensive skills much as one would a harried baseball infielder chasing down the most difficult of chances, dominating none but making sure nothing eluded him altogether.

title: 5 Big Firms Shun Bond Syndicate
description: Rather than publicly accept a ranking that they deemed unbecoming, five of Wall Street's best-known securities firms have decided not to participate in this week's $2.4 billion financing for the Farmers Home Administration.

title: Stage: 'The Tightrope,' On Freedom in Spain
description: TWO metaphors vie in Fernando Arrabal's ''On the Tightrope'' - death below ground and freedom in the skies. Under the earth in the deserted mining town of Madrid, N.M., are the corpses of men and animals who perished after short lifetimes of exploitation. The only survivor is Wichita, once a tightrope walker, still an artist and a free man.

title: Judge for Howard Beach: Thomas A. Demakos
description: Thirteen years ago, Thomas A. Demakos was a prosecutor in Queens when a white police officer, Thomas Shea, was charged with murdering a 10-year-old black boy in South Jamaica, Queens.

title: TV Options: Pull the Plug or Play Along?
description: The possibility of a strike tomorrow by National Football League players has thrown the three major television networks into a scramble for substitute programs, with at least one network considering airing college games on Sundays.

title: Bosworth Defeats N.F.L.
description: Brian Bosworth, the Seattle Seahawks' flamboyant rookie linebacker, wore his old college number, 44, today against the Kansas City Chiefs, under a court order obtained against the National Football League. He had six tackles, including a sack, in the Seahawks' 43-14 victory.

title: New Member For F.A.S.B.
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the body that sets the standards for accountants, said Friday that it had named James J. Leisenring, 47 years old, as its newest member.

title: Foreign Foggy Bottom
description: The lengths the State Department will go to safeguard peace were extended during the visit of Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze last week to the point that Foggy Bottom declared itself ''a foreign mission.''

title: Morris Leads Cards in Rout
description: John Morris drove in a career-high four runs with two singles and an infield out, and Vince Coleman knocked in three runs to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 10-2 victory today over the Chicago Cubs.

title: In China, the Right Name Can Mean the Good Life
description: When Hong Kong's new British Governor, Sir David Wilson, arrived in the territory last January, people here approved of everything about him - except his name.

title: 'L.A. Law' and 'Golden Girls' Win Series Emmys
description: ''Promise,'' a stark drama about mental illness, won five awards at a four-hour-long Emmy ceremony today, while ''L.A. Law'' won four awards to help NBC dominate the presentation.

title: Washington Weighs Policy
description: Important decisions for fiscal and monetary policy are expected this week as Congress works on an agreement to reduce budget deficits in future years while Federal Reserve officials meet today and tomorrow to set the course for monetary policy.

title: Hutchinson Family
description: More than a century ago Frederick Douglass, a former slave who was a leader in the Abolitionist movement, declared: ''I especially have a reason to feel a grateful interest in the whole Hutchinson family - for you have sung the yokes from the necks and the fetters from the limbs of my race.'' He was referring to a remarkable musical family of the 19th century.

title: Metro Matters; Judging Judges: Court Discipline Under Scrutiny
description: In the entire United States, 12 judges were removed from office in 1985, eight of them in New York. Nationwide, 33 were publicly admonished or censured that year, the latest for which statistics are available. Ten of them were New Yorkers.

title: Weird Interception Helps Browns Win
description: A bizarre interception by Mike Johnson set up an 11-yard tiebreaking touchdown pass from Bernie Kosar to Gerald McNeil today as the Cleveland Browns defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers, 34-10.

title: Susan Maser, a Writer, Is Wed in Philadelphia
description: Susan Anne Maser, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin Maser of Philadelphia, was married at her parents' home there yesterday to Jack Howard Lechner, the son of Susan Schwartz Lechner of Arlington, Va., and Ira Lechner of Silver Spring, Md. Rabbi David S. Wice performed the ceremony.

title: Brewers' 5 Homers Overpower Tigers
description: Dale Sveum, Robin Yount and Paul Molitor hit home runs off Jack Morris as the Milwaukee Brewers had five homers to beat the Detroit Tigers, 11-4.

title: Anne Katz Is Married
description: Anne Rosalind Katz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford H. Katz of New City, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Wallner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Wallner of Harrisburg, S.D. Rabbi Jan Brahms performed the ceremony at the Gates of Heaven Synagogue in Madison, Wis. The bride, a graduate of Brandeis University, is the arts coordinator for the city of Madison. Mr. Wallner, a graduate of the University of Nebraska, teaches English and journalism at Stoughton (Wis.) High School and is a Madison City Councilman.

title: LEVITTOWN, L.I., AT 40: ONCE A SOLUTION, NOW A PROBLEM
description: Forty years ago, in the potato fields of Long Island, Levittown sprang into being.

title: Folk Music: Uncle Bonsai
description: NO other folk group has a vocal blend comparable to Uncle Bonsai, the Seattle-based trio that includes Andrew Ratshin, a countertenor and guitarist, and two sopranos, Arni Adler and Ashley Kristen. When the group sings its original rapid-fire patter songs in close, perfectly pitched three-part harmony, its sound begins to suggest mechanically sped-up munchkin-like singing. Of course, it is all done naturally.

title: A Comeback for Golf
description: Anyone familiar with the history of golf in China has reason to be surprised that the Chinese national golf team is on a tour of the United States. After all, golf never gained much of a toehold in China and what little it did have was dislodged after the Communists came to power in 1949. The few courses, which had catered primarily to the diplomatic community, were soon plowed under to make room for rice paddies. As a ''millionaire's game,'' golf had no place in a self-styled egalitarian society.

title: Injured Driver Showing Progres
description: Roberto Guerrero was able to breath without mechanical help today, the first time he has been able to do since a crash Sept. 10 at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, hospital officials said.

title: One-Person Subway Crew Risks Rider Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Personal Income and Consumption August Tuesday None Wednesday Consumer Price Index August Durable Goods August Thursday None Friday None

title: Jazz: Carlos Ward's Quartet
description: WHEN jazz musicians improvise on vernacular dance rhythms, their variations sometimes become diffuse, compromising the binding integrity of the groove. Saturday at First on First, a bar-restaurant in the East Village, Carlos Ward's quartet rang inventive and frequently surprising changes on the rhythmic vernacular of funk, without allowing the grooves to drift or fragment. Mr. Ward, an alto saxophonist, writes tunes with hard edges, clear-cut melodic definition and sturdy rhythmic backbones.

title: Times Mirror Cleans House
description: The criticism of Robert F. Erburu has always been that he led the Times Mirror Company astray during the last decade with acquisitions and diversification moves that dampened earnings growth and taxed an already-thin management corps.

title: Advertising; New Spots For Suzuki: 'Never Dull'
