description: WHEN you have an automobile that can variously be considered a subcompact, a small pickup truck or a sports-utility vehicle, how do you advertise it?

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 21, 1987: MONDAY Bunker Hill Inc Secs Jamesway Corp Horizon Bancorp NBD Bancorp TUESDAY Borg-Warner Corp JC Penney Co Centerior Energy Roper Corp Hydraulic Co Signet Banking Corp WEDNESDAY Brooklyn Union Gas Northern States Pwr MN EG & G Inc Piedmont Aviation Federal-Mogul Corp Raytheon Corp House of Fabrics Technitrol Inc Hunt Mfg US Air Corp Medtronic Inc THURSDAY Acme-Cleveland Corp Conagra Corp Boston Edison Knight-Ridder Inc Campbell Soup Michigan Energy Res Combustion Engineering Milton Roy Commonwealth Energy FRIDAY Aetna Life & Casualty Pueblo Corp CP National Ralston Purina Central Hudson G & E Rexham Corp Homestake Mining Southwestern Bell Pacific Telesis Group Texas Amer Bancshs SATURDAY Potlatch Corp Tektronix Inc SUNDAY Montana Power

title: SENATE COMMITTEE THREATENS DELAY OF NEW ARMS PACT
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee warned today that it might delay the ratification of the emerging arms agreement with the Soviet Union if the Reagan Administration holds to its interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title: Lotteries Offer Popular Entertainment With Full Accountability
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Wiesenthal Wed To Myles Alderman Jr.
description: Linda L. Wiesenthal, an associate at Robinson & Cole, and Myles H. Alderman Jr., an associate at Reid & Riege, both law firms in Hartford, were married yesterday at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbis Jack Stern and Robert Goldburg officiated.

title: Another Failure to Fix the Pentagon
description: Two of the Reagan Administration's highest priorities have been to force-feed the Pentagon with money, and to root out fraud, waste and abuse in the welfare system. It has ousted some cheats from the welfare rolls, and created a defense industry so greedy and mismanaged that serious reform seems impossible. The latest failure is signaled by Richard P. Godwin's departure. Appointed a year ago to help clean up the mess in Caspar Weinberger's Pentagon, he resigned last week, complaining ''I can't make anything stick.''

title: Local Talent
description: It's too early to tell whether Mark Jackson, the Knicks' top draft choice, will help revive the team's fortunes. But the 6-foot-3-inch point guard has already rekindled one venerable tradition.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL RISK SEEN IN DISMANTLING MISSILES
description: Nuclear-armed missiles are packed with dangerous substances, and dismantling of certain types as proposed under the emerging treaty on medium- and shorter-range arms poses potential environmental risks.

title: PRETORIA OFFERS LEGALITY TO FOES
description: If the outlawed African National Congress disavowed violence in its campaign against apartheid, the Government would be forced to legalize the group, a senior Government official has declared in an interview.

title: Israel Details New Sanctions On Trade With South Africa
description: The Israeli Cabinet today announced new restrictions on trade and cultural relations with South Africa, including a freeze on iron and steel imports at current levels, and bans on oil sales and visits by Government officials.

title: Business and the Law; Broker Cases: New Rules
description: ARBITRATION panels that resolve disputes between stockbrokers and their clients, burdened with an image that they favor the brokerage houses, are examining and changing some of their most significant rules.

title: New York and Vermont Get New Toll-Free Bridge
description: A new toll-free bridge across the northern end of Lake Champlain between New York and Vermont will be opened Tuesday to replace an old swing bridge that often caused massive tie-ups.

title: Misplaced Literalism
description: To the Editor:

title: City Ballet Names New Board Chairman
description: Theodore C. Rogers, former chairman and president of NL Industries Inc., a chemical and oil-field equipment concern, has been elected chairman of the board of the New York City Ballet. He succeeds Orville H. Schell, who was chairman emeritus at the time of his death June 17. Gillian Attfield will remain president of the ballet.

title: Nine Judges on Court
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Contestants Take Firm Lines on the Issues
description: After months of glancing exchanges, the Republican candidates for President have finally joined battle, setting forth the differences in style and philosophy that separate them not only from one another but also from President Reagan.

title: New Tensions With a Canadian City
description: There are Yankee footprints all over this southern Ontario town separated from Detroit by a river and a different flag.

title: RIGHTS BILL ON AIDS IS TO BE OPPOSED BY ADMINISTRATION
description: The Administration will announce its opposition on Monday to a bill that would ban discrimination against people infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Pen Is Proven Still Mighty At Fifth Avenue Book Fair
description: Defying both the weather forecasters who had predicted a deluge and those doom-sayers who contend that the printed word is dead, thousands of book-lovers turned out yesterday for the ninth annual New York Is Book Country street fair.

title: Cutting Back on Big Goal
description: Being host for the 1988 Summer Olympics is not South Korea's only driving ambition.

title: Truman Capote'S Life On 'American Masters'
description: TRUMAN CAPOTE, who was always a crafty manipulator of the media, is impaled on the media sword tonight at 10 on Channel 13's ''American Masters'' series. Produced by Andy Harries for RM Arts and London Weekend TV, in association with the American station, ''Unanswered Prayers: The Life and Times of Truman Capote'' fashions a biography largely out of comments from friends and from television clips in which the writer performed for a long succession of interviewers, including Johnny Carson, Barbara Walters and Stanley Siegal.

title: Chevrolet Sprint Is Top Rated In U.S. Gasoline Mileage Test
description: For the third year in a row, the three-cylinder Chevrolet Sprint has captured the top rating in the annual gasoline mileage tests of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: A Polish Bishop Issues a Plea for Free Unions
description: Tens of thousands of Polish workers gathered at a Roman Catholic shrine here today to hear an impassioned plea from a Roman Catholic bishop for the establishment of free and independent trade unions.

title: A.T.&T. Moves to Fight Big Surcharges Abroad
description: The thought of calling home from overseas makes Greg Carey cringe. Mr. Carey, an international advertising consultant, once called his wife in San Francisco from his hotel room in Paris. The actual cost of the call was about $25, but the charge on the hotel bill was $85.

title: Dr. Jane Weston, Surgeon, Is Bride of Dr. Jan K. Horn
description: Dr. Jane Sara Weston, a plastic and reconstructive surgeon with the Permanente Medical Group in San Jose, Calif., and Dr. Jan K. Horn, an assistant professor of surgery at the University of California Medical School at San Francisco, were married yesterday in Menlo Park, Calif. Rabbi Herbert Morris officiated at the Stanford Park Hotel.

title: Loss Is Seen At Rothschild
description: L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc. expects to lose money in the third quarter, based on its performance in recent weeks, according to Francois J. P. Mayer, the securities firm's co-chief executive.

title: Judge Bork vs. Himself: Evolution of His Views
description: Following are excerpts from some of Judge Robert H. Bork's prior writings and from his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee last week. Equality and Women

title: Java Gold Rallies To Win Marlboro
description: Java Gold dispelled any lingering doubt that he is the best horse in the country by rallying strongly from off a slow pace to score an impressive 2 1/4-length victory over Nostalgia's Star, Polish Navy and Gulch in the $750,000 Marlboro Cup Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Charles W. Nichols Jr., Ex-Corporate Official
description: Charles W. Nichols Jr., a retired engineering executive and prominent philanthropist, died at his home yesterday after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Power to Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Rock: Flipper, a Quartet
description: WILL SHATTER, who sings and plays bass for Flipper, announced back in 1981 that he had solved an age-old conundrum. ''Yes,'' he testified on the group's ''Generic Flipper'' album, ''I've found out what living is all about. It's Life! Life! Life is the only thing worth living for.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING Prost Edges Berger: Alain Prost of France scored a record 28th Formula One victory yesterday, winning the Portuguese Grand Prix at Estoril. Gerhard Berger of Austria was second, 20.493 seconds behind Prost. Prost had been tied with Jackie Stewart of Britain for the most Formula One victories. Prost's time was a record 1 hour 37 minutes 3.906 seconds.(AP) Michael Andretti Wins: Michael Andretti ran away with yesterday's Bosch Grand Prix at the refurbished Pennsylvania International Raceway in Nazareth. Andretti collected 20 championship points for the victory and 1 point for leading the most laps. Bobby Rahal, defending CART-PPG Indy-car champion, came away from the race leading Andretti, 162-137, with two races remaining.(AP) Tennis Sabatini Tops Maleeva: Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina survived the loss of five straight games in the second set to defeat second-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-4, 7-6, yesterday to win the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo. (AP) Mezzadri Upsets Smid: Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland defeated Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 7-5, yesterday to win the $231,000 Geneva Open. (AP) Connors Defaults: Andre Agassi beat Jimmy Connors yesterday when Connors retired because of exhaustion in the first set of the men's final at the duPont All-American Championship at Amelia Island, Fla. The match was played in temperatures over 100 degrees. In the women's final, Pam Shriver beat Stephanie Rehe, 1-6, 7-6, 6-0.(AP) MARATHON Petersen Takes Tune-Up: Pat Petersen of Ronkonkoma, L.I., won the 25-kilometer tune-up for the New York City Marathon yesterday, finishing the Central Park race in 1 hour 19 minutes 24 seconds. Nancy Adler of Irvington, N.Y., was the first woman to finish, in 1:40.09. GYMNASTICS Panova Completes Sweep: Bianka Panova of Bulgaria received perfect marks across the board yesterday to win four gold medals at the rhythmic gymnastics world championships in Varna, Bulgaria. The 17-year-old Panova, who won the gold medal in the overall individual competition Saturday, became the first person ever to win all gold medals in individual events at the championships. (AP) GOLF Mowry Wins in Richmond: Larry Mowry made a 25-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole yesterday for a five-under-par 67 and a one-stroke victory over Gary Player and Bob Charles in the Crestar Senior PGA Classic in Richmond. (AP) Stephenson Edges Lopez: Jan Stephenson beat Nancy Lopez by a stroke yesterday to win the $225,000 Safeco Classic in Kent, Wash., for her 15th victory in 14 years on the Ladies Professional Golf Aassociation tour.(AP) Rain Delay in Milwaukee: Rain delayed the finish of the $600,000 Greater Milwaukee Open yesterday.(AP)

title: Record for Payton As Bears Win, 20-3
description: Walter Payton scored two touchdowns today, setting a record in the process, to lead the Chicago Bears to a 20-3 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Bork's Worry: Southern Senators
description: LEAD: Southern Democrats in the Senate may hold the key to Judge Robert H. Bork's confirmation as a Supreme Court Justice. Although unlikely to be swayed by liberal arguments about judicial philosophy, they will weigh carefully his views on civil rights decisions that they have no desire to see reversed.

description: International A3-14, B12

description: b-Net loss and the 6 months' loss is after $401,000 of depreciation, depletion and amortization expense because of the limitation on capitalized costs of oil and gas properties.

title: World Leaders Open U.N. General Assembly
description: Leaders from around the world today hailed as historic the American-Soviet agreement to complete an accord banning medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles, and they called for further arms cuts in the near future.

title: Searching For Moose In New York
description: AFTER vanishing from the Adirondacks of upstate New York, moose are now reappearing there, and scientists have begun a major research program to study their behavior, health and habitat. They are asking New Yorkers to volunteer as moose spotters.

title: New Light Put on Old Products
description: THE two Martins at Shaw & Landey have decided that the way into the consumer consciousness in the age of advertising clutter is through the de-familiarization of products or services.

title: Mesa, Ariz., Bonds
description: Mesa, Ariz., is offering $86 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company, with yields ranging from 7.30 percent for bonds due in 1998 to 7.90 percent in 2003. Underwriters said the issue, rated A-1 by Moody's and AA by S.&P., was well received.

title: Listvyanka Journal; Lake of Lakes, and the Fight to Keep It Sparkling
description: One sixth of the world's fresh water stretches toward the horizon, a translucent jewel sparkling in the late afternoon sun.

Page A1 Sanctions against Iran should be adopted if the Iranian President does not ''clearly and unequivocally state'' if his country accepts a cease-fire resolution, President Reagan said at the United Nations. title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: Share earnings reflects a 2-for-1 stock split in March.

title: A Special House Awaits Officer Paralyzed by Bullet
description: At Thanksgiving a special homecoming awaits Steven McDonald, the New York City police officer who was paralyzed from the neck down by an assailant's bullet in the summer of 1986.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Syracuse dispatch last Friday about reaction at the Syracuse University law school to an act of plagiarism there by Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. in 1965, reported a comment by the Senator incorrectly. A paper written by him for a legal methods course carried one footnote, not none; the note credited an article in the Fordham Law Review that he used extensively.

title: U.S. REPORTS FIRING ON IRANIAN VESSEL SEEN LAYING MINES
description: The Reagan Administration said tonight that a United States helicopter gunship had fired on an Iranian vessel laying mines in the path of American ships in the Persian Gulf, setting the craft afire.

title: The Stage: Hamlet
description: THE first casualty of the Musical Theater Works production of ''Hamlet'' at the Abbey Theater is language.

title: MANAGEMENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $181,000.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The latest quarter share earnings showed a loss because of preferred dividend payments and other requirements.

title: Music: Religious Works by Kurt Weill at Festival
description: THROUGHOUT his career, Kurt Weill devoted considerable attention to religious and choral music, a sampling of which occupied the program Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall during an installment in the Kurt Weill Festival.

title: Ford Says Recall of Ambulances Is Taking Longer Than Expected
description: Ambulance operators and some safety advocates are complaining that a recall of up to 22,000 ambulances by the Ford Motor Company is taking months longer than expected, with some repair work scheduled as late as next March.

title: Ford Dismisses 3,200 Mexicans
description: The Ford Motor Company has dismissed 3,200 Mexican workers as part of a settlement ending a nine-week strike at one of its Mexico assembly plants, a company spokesman said today.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $653,000 and $1,375,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Boyfriend Testifies About His Role In Having L.I. Girl's Father Killed
description: In the finale to a hearing to determine whether Cheryl Pierson should be sent to prison, Miss Pierson's boyfriend took the stand here today and publicly described for the first time his role in planning her father's murder.

title: A Seabrook Owner Expects Large Write-Down
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire has estimated that it will write off $500 million of its $2.1 billion investment in the Seabrook nuclear plant.

title: Zenith to Cut Staff
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation, struggling against a flood of lower-priced imports, said it would try to cut costs in its consumer products operations by offering early retirement to about 650 employees. A spokesman for Zenith said the consumer products unit would therefore report an operating loss in the third quarter.

title: Software Eccentric's Big Step
description: Even in an industry known for its eccentric entrepreneurs, Philippe Kahn has stood out - for his loud Hawaiian shirts, for his impromptu saxophone solos at news conferences, and last, but certainly not least, for the success of the microcomputer software company he founded.

title: Police-Fire Feud Reflects Concern On Pay and Jobs
description: On the surface, the months of embarrassing feuding between New York City's police and fire agencies is a dispute over departmental jurisdiction at emergencies.

title: Managua's Bid to Censor Is Reported
description: The Sandinista authorities agreed to allow the opposition newspaper La Prensa to reopen without censorship only after the paper's publisher rejected a suggestion that it accept censorship, the publisher said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How do ointments and salves that have heating properties work? A. These products contain menthol and methyl salicylate, substances known as counter-irritants, according to Dr. Charles Bainbridge, a research pharmacist at the consumer products division of Pfizer which manufactures one such ointment, Ben-Gay.

title: Howard Beach Jury Challenges Are Held Biased
description: The judge in the Howard Beach murder trial ruled yesterday that the defense lawyers were seeking to exclude blacks from the jury and said he would curb the lawyers' challenges against prospective black jurors.

title: FULLER, H B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

title: Brussels Stock Changes

title: Kinugasa to Retire
description: Saying he had lost confidence in his ability to keep playing, Sachio Kinugasa, Japan's Lou Gehrig, announced yesterday that he would retire at the end of the season. Last June, Kinugasa, a third baseman for the Hiroshima Carp of Japan's Central League, broke Gehrig's record of 2,130 consecutive games played. He has continued his ''iron man'' performance, and had reached No. 2,192 last night as the Carp played the Yomiuri Giants. It was clear that Kinugasa, 40 years old and in his 23d season, had stayed on longer than he had wanted only because of the chance to surpass Gehrig. ''Retirement has been a big problem for me since the end of the 1984 season,'' he said at a news conference in Hiroshima. After a good start this year, he had slumped to a .246 batting average in 106 games with only 40 runs batted in. Even worse, he said, he worried about his fielding and about his level of endurance for next year. ''My confidence in continuing playing has collapsed,'' Kinugasa said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Hallberg Triumphs: Gary Hallberg birdied two of his last three holes yesterday to win the $108,000 first prize in the rain-delayed $600,000 Greater Milwaukee Open in Franklin, Wis. Hallberg moved out of a four-way tie for the lead by shooting birdies on the first two holes - the sixth and seventh - after play resumed from Sunday's rain delay. After additional birdies on the 16th and 17th holes, he ended the round with a par on No. 18 for a six-under-par 66 and a tournament total of 19-under 269. Tied for second at 17-under 271 were Wayne Levi, who finished with a five-under 67, and Robert Wrenn at 68. Larry Ziegler was fourth with a 272 total after shooting a 68. Hallberg, Levi and Wrenn had been tied with Bill Kratzert at 15 under when play resumed in overcast, drizzly conditions yesterday at the 7,030-yard Tuckaway Country Club course. Kratzert finished tied with Nick Price and Tom Byrum at 14-under.(AP) TENNIS Swede Advances in Spain: Jorgen Windhal of Sweden defeated Carl Limberger of Australia, 6-4, 7-5, in yesterday's first round of the 35th Count of Godo tournament a Nabisco Grand Prix event at the Royal Tennis Club of Barcelona. Ronald Agenor of Haiti, defeated Lawson Duncan of the United States, 6-2, 5-7, 6-2, and Horacio de la Pena of Argentina beat Damir Keretic of West Germany, 7-5, 6-3.(AP) Porwik Gains: Claudia Porwik of West Germany beat another West German, Martina Pawlik, 6-2, 7-5, to advance to the second round of the $150,000 Hamburg International Women's Tennis Tournament. Steffi Graf, Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, and Bettina Bunge had the day off. In other first-round play, Isabel Cueto of West Germany upset another West German, Tanja Weigl, 6-4, 6-1, and Wiltrud Probst of West Germany defeated Nicole Jagerman of the Netherlands, 6-4, 7-5.(AP)

title: Stage, 'Sarcophagus,' A Soviet Play, at Yale
description: The timing, while coincidental, could not be better. On the same weekend that the Soviet Union and the United States announced a tentative arms-control agreement, American theatergoers were treated to the premiere of ''Sarcophagus,'' a new Russian play about the nuclear peril. Written by Vladimir Gubaryev, the science editor of Pravda, ''Sarcophagus'' is a docudrama set immediately after the Chernobyl explosion in 1986. It is also the Soviet theater's prime export in the new age of glasnost. Following wide dissemination at home, ''Sarcophagus'' was mounted by the Royal Shakespeare Company in London this spring, where it was hailed for its surprisingly frank admissions of Soviet bureaucratic negligence. Now the play has opened simultaneously at the Yale Repertory Theater and the Los Angeles Theater Center. Tomorrow, the world?

title: Mormon's Widow Dies at 92
description: Camilla Eyring Kimball, widow of Spencer W. Kimball, the former president of the Morman Church, died Sunday night at her home, church officials said. She was 92 years old. Mrs. Kimball was born Dec. 7, 1894, in Colonia Juarez, Chihuahua, Mexico, and at 17, when revolutionaries in the Mexican civil war threatened Mormon colonies in Chihuahua she was sent to Provo, Utah, to live with an uncle. Her family loved from Mexico to Arizona, where she eventually joined them and met her future husband. He served as president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints from 1973 until his death in 1985.

Butcher Honored
description: Susan Butcher, a two-time winner of Alaska's Iditarod sled dog race, who finished in record-breaking time this year, was named yesterday as the professional sportswoman of the year by the Women's Sports Foundation. Jackie Joyner-Kersee, who captured gold medals in the heptathlon and the long jump at the recent world track and field championships in Rome, was honored as the McDonald's amateur sportswoman of the year. Ironically, Joyner-Kersee, the amateur - who also won the long jump gold medal at the Pan American Games in Indianapolis last month - probably will profit (in the form of money deposited in her trust fund) far more than Butcher, the professional. The 32-year-old Butcher was awarded $50,000 for her first-place finish at Nome on March 18. But until yesterday, she had received only half that amount. After leaving a news conference at the Plaza Hotel in Manhatten, she received a telegram saying the remaining $25,000 of her purse had been deposited in her bank account. Butcher, who lives with her husband and 150 sled dogs in the sub-zero Alaskan bush country, said she disdains money and the soft life. ''I'm totally dedicated to mushing dogs,'' she said. ''I don't care about anything else. I don't use a clock or a calendar and I don't see many people. I'm not dependent on anyone for anything. Even the threat of nuclear war doesn't frighten me. If society as we know it disappeared, I know I could survive.''

title: Opera: Domingo Sings 'Otello' In Opening of '87 Met Season
description: OPENING night at the Metropolitan Opera is generally not a time to collect golden memories. Recent tradition, at least, requires that the production be familiar and on the massive side. At least one or two of the singers must be identifiable at sight as certified semipopular celebrities, artistic considerations aside. And there should be seemingly endless intermissions during which the formally dressed opera lovers may parade about and guess at the cost of one another's outfits. Last evening's Metropolitan opening, a performance of ''Otello'' in Franco Zeffirelli's ponderous 1972 staging, fulfilled all those expectations. Happily, however, everything went off more smoothly, both vocally and as sheer theater, than might have been expected, even if the evening never came close to being the riveting experience that Verdi's masterly account of the Shakespearean drama can be in inspired hands, or throats.

With Mr. Alvin's brother Phil as lead singer, the Blasters looked back self-consciously on American roadhouse music, especially country, rockabilly and blues.

title: DINING ON CAMPUS: IT'S NOT ESCOFFIER, BUT...
description: LEAD: LUNCH time at Nostalgia U. Bound up the stairs, go through the doors, get in line, grab a tray, scoop up knife, fork and spoon, take a glass and then . . . the steam table: clouds billowing up around trays of mystery meat, ghosts of vegetables past and other indescribables. If you are lucky, the glass in front is fogged, sparing you the trauma of seeing the meal until it is on your plate.

title: Biaggi's Climb: A Mix Of Honor and Rumor
description: When 12 jurors found Representative Mario Biaggi guilty yesterday of accepting illegal gratuities from Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, they cast a harsh new light on the career of the much-decorated former policeman who won election to high office by stressing working-class values and law and order.

title: Fire Was Set Inside the Home in AIDS Case
description: The fire that destroyed the home of a family with three sons who have been infected with the AIDS virus was set from the inside, but family members are not suspects ''at this time,'' the sheriff said today.

title: A Hotel-Jail for Refugees
description: It's hard to imagine officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service as devotees of the French surrealist Jean-Paul Sartre. Yet a jail they have established in a luxury hotel at Kennedy Airport so closely resembles Sartre's vision of hell in his play ''No Exit'' - perpetual and unrelieved confinement in a small room with three strangers - that one is hard-pressed to avoid such a conclusion.

title: The World Stares at Iran
description: It was Iran's turn to speak yesterday before the green marble at the United Nations, and the world waited with unusual anticipation. Would Iran heed the U.N.'s call for a cease-fire in its war with Iraq? What would Iran say about its attack Monday on a British tanker? What could Iran say about its vessel caught by the U.S. Navy laying mines in the Persian Gulf?

title: Lawyers Back Aid in Suicide
description: California Bar Association delegates have approved a resolution supporting legislation that would allow physicians to give terminally ill patients a prescription for a lethal dose of drugs.

title: Seeing the Hearings
description: Lawyers are often accused of seeing things in terms of black and white, and there is some evidence in Washington these days to support that conclusion. To enable visitors to observe Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork, the Supreme Court law library has installed a portable television set on a desk near the entrance. But the Court did not feel it was necessary to spring for a color set, so the hearings are being presented in black and white.

description: Although there are robots that move around American factories on fixed tracks or computer-controlled vehicles, most are fixed firmly to the floor.

title: Met Opera: Te Kanawa And Domingo in 'Otello
description: OPENING night at the Metropolitan Opera is generally not a time to collect golden memories. Recent tradition, at least, requires that the production be familiar and on the massive side. At least one or two of the singers must be identifiable at sight as certified semipopular celebrities, artistic considerations aside. And there should be seemingly endless intermissions during which the formally dressed opera lovers may parade about and guess at the cost of one another's outfits. Monday evening's Metropolitan opening, a performance of ''Otello'' in Franco Zeffirelli's ponderous 1972 staging, fulfilled all those expectations. Happily, however, everything went off more smoothly, both vocally and as sheer theater, than might have been expected, even if the evening never came close to being the riveting experience that Verdi's masterly account of the Shakespearean drama can be in inspired hands, or throats.

title: Books of The Times
description: With two previous novels (''Water Music'' and ''Budding Prospects'') and two short-story collections (''Descent of Man,'' ''Greasy Lake and Other Stories''), T. Coraghessan Boyle has emerged as one of the most inventive and verbally exuberant writers of his generation. Rather than using his gifts to create polite mirrors of contemporary reality, he has chosen, like Robert Coover and Donald Barthelme, to mix up naturalism with large doses of hyperbole and metaphor to create storybook collages that comment on older forms of literature even as they reinvent essential American myths. In his latest novel, a vast and wordy epic that spans four centuries and more than 400 pages, he attempts not only to examine the implications of the American Dream, as he's done in earlier works, but also to tackle the complicated issues of freedom, class and race involved in the founding of our nation. <TD WIDTH=2

These pleasant diversions will now be followed on Wednesday nights by two of the new season's most innovative shows, ''Hooperman'' at 9 P.M. and ''The Slap Maxwell Story'' at 9:30. For the network struggling to get out of the ratings cellar, the new entries are little short of admirable as they explore ways to get out of the entrenched ruts common to most series. For starters, neither has a laugh track.

title: Optimism on Birdsong
description: Harry Weltman, the Nets' general manager, met for 90 minutes yesterday with Otis Birdsong, the guard who played in only seven games last season because of a series of injuries. Weltman, who called the meeting ''very productive,'' said that with Birdsong fully recovered, ''it puts us in good position at the big guard spot.'' A healthy Birdsong would allow the team to be more deliberate in bringing along top rookies like Dennis Hopson. Weltman said that his first priorty when the moratorium ends on Oct. 1 will be to sign Hopson, a 6-foot-5-inch guard from Ohio State who was the team's top draft choice and the third selection over all in the college draft last June. The National Basketball Association and its players' union have scheduled a ninth negotiating session for Monday to try to replace the basic agreement that expired last June 15. Unless some progress is made, this could be the final meeting before the end of the moratorium. The moratorium forbids teams from signing free agents or draft choices and from holding rookie or free-agent training camps until Oct. 1.

Released from buses or subways on weekday mornings, they plunge ahead, eyes forward, light on the balls of their feet. title: Laboring for Dole

The two Republicans developed a friendship in the Senate, where Mr. Brock, a Tennessean, served from 1970-76. In addition, both men had served as chairmen of the Republican National Committee. Thomas D. Bell Jr., a former aide to Mr. Brock, ran Mr. Dole's unsuccessful 1980 Presidential campaign. Mr. Brock is expected to reach a decision in December, when the switch could occur. Chriss Winston, a Labor Department spokesman, said the Secretary had told aides that he had no plans to leave the agency ''in the foreseeable future.''

description: The pro football strike began today with the Giants' players solid in their support and the Jets' players the same, with one or two exceptions.

title: Baseball Awaiting Remedies
description: With the players eagerly and the owners anxiously awaiting the arbitrator's second step in baseball's first free-agent conspiracy case, Thomas Roberts, the arbitrator, said yesterday that he was prepared to hear arguments in the remedy phase of the case as soon as the two sides were ready.

title: Philip Morris, Not Rail Union, Paid for Ads on Smoking Ban
description: Full-page newspaper advertisements yesterday that opposed a proposed smoking ban on the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North were signed by a transit union president, but secretly paid for by Philip Morris.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The jury convicted me of tipping. I'm not a waiter, I'm a Congressman and I'll continue to be a Congressman.'' - Representative Mario Biaggi. [ B4:3. ]

title: Schwab Offer Oversubscribed
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation's initial public offering was oversubscribed today on its first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 23, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Murdoch Lifts Stake In Pearson
description: Two flamboyant publisher-investors surprised the London financial district today. Rupert Murdoch announced that he had acquired a major stake in Pearson P.L.C., a media and financial services conglomerate, and Robert Maxwell declared that he was seeking to take over Guinness Peat Group P.L.C., a financial services company.

title: Keep Bankruptcy Judges on the Bench
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $103,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $504,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $4,004,096 and $4,448,764 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Graf Wins, but Bunge Is Upset: Top-seeded Steffi Graf moved into the third round of the women's $150,000 Virginia Slims tournament in Hamburg, West Germany, yesterday, but another West German, Bettina Bunge, was upset. Graf beat Louise Field of Australia by 6-1, 6-2 and had few problems in her quick victory. But Bunge, ranked 12th in the world, was eliminated by Leila Meskhi of the Soviet Union. Meskhi, ranked 175th, won by 6-3, 6-4. (AP) Arias Loses to Argentine: Christian Minuissi of Argentina defeated 11th-seeded Jimmy Arias of the United States, 7-5, 6-2, in the second round of the 35th Count of Godo tournament at the Royal Tennis Club of Barcelona yesterday. In other second-round matches, Luiz Mattar of Brazil beat 13th-seeded Tarik Benhabiles of France, 7-5, 6-0, and Sergio Casal of Spain beat Alberto Tous of Spain, 7-6, 6-0. (AP) GOLF Vershure Shoots 66 in Izod: Rick Vershure of Quaker Ridge shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday in the opening round of the Izod Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association championship that was suspended because of thunderstorms and lightning. The first round of the 54-hole tournament at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., is scheduled to be completed today, with the second and third rounds pushed back to tomorrow and Friday.

title: The Pop Life
description: U2 (Part 2)

title: Mozambique Leader Invited To Meet With Reagan Oct. 5
description: President Joaquim A. Chissano of Mozambique will hold talks with President Reagan at the White House on Oct. 5, American officials said today.

title: ROBERT HALF INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $276,000 for the quarter and income of $372,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $115,000 for the quarter and $300,000 for the 6 months.

title: Florida Ad Tax Repeal Gains
description: Two committees of the Florida Senate voted today to repeal the state's 5 percent tax on advertising and other services, but lawmakers in the House remained deadlocked over the measure's fate.

title: Serving PATH Rider Safety and Preserving a New York View
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL THOROUGHRED BREEDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CARDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the first quarter includes more than $1 million in unusual professional expenses arising from restructuring. The company recently changed its fiscal year-end to April 30 from Oct. 31. The quarter comparable to the latest first fiscal quarter is the third quarter ended July 31, 1986. In that quarter, the company reported a loss of $1,218,000 on sales of $58,726,100.

title: American League Jays Top the Orioles To Hold Off Tigers
description: George Bell drove in a winning run for the second consecutive game, singling in the eighth inning tonight to touch off a five-run rally as the Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 8-4.

title: Capitol Downhill
description: Members of Congress will be invited to take an early slide this morning on an artificial ski slope to be erected at the foot of Capitol Hill, courtesy of the Colorado ski industry and Busch beer, which are also providing equipment and instructors. Adventurous lawmakers will be able to swoop down a 40-foot ramp covered with slippery white artificial turf and then along a 150-foot strip of crushed ice.

title: Has Growth In Chips Hit 32-Bit Wall?
description: IN the semiconductor industry, relentless advances toward bigger, faster computer chips are the norm. Now, curiously, many industry experts believe that the current generation of new microprocessors -the logic chips that drive everything from desktop computers to automobile control systems - may have hit a silicon wall. They predict that the recently introduced 32-bit chips will dominate the microcomputer world into the late 1990's at least.

title: Christian Science Text's Copyright Is Ruled Illegal by Appeals Court
description: A 1971 law giving the Christian Science Church an extended copyright to its central theological text was declared unconstitutional today by a Federal appeals court.

title: BIAGGI, ESPOSITO CONVICTED ON GIFT BUT NOT ON BRIBE
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, and Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, were found guilty yesterday of Federal charges involving unlawful gratuities but were acquitted of a more serious charge of bribery and of conspiracy to commit bribery.

title: Telling Haig's Fortune
description: To the conventional techniques Presidential candidates use to get their messages across - television, radio, newspaper advertising, billboards, bumper stickers - add the Chinese fortune cookie. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the former Secretary of State and now a Republican Presidential hopeful, presented the Washington press corps yesterday with tissue-wrapped packs of fortune cookies.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Round-the-Clock Talks Planned
description: The parties in the National Football League strike that began yesterday will begin round-the-clock talks today in an effort to end the walkout in time to play on Sunday.

title: Reports of Racial Assaults Rise Significantly in New York City
description: Reports of incidents of racial assaults in which blacks and whites were injured in New York City in the first eight months of this year have already significantly exceeded the number of such assaults in all of 1986, according to police statistics.

title: Reagan's AIDS Battle Assailed as Inadequate
description: The $790 million proposed by the Reagan Administration to combat AIDS in the fiscal year 1988 will not cover the costs of needed research, education and testing, scientists and health workers said today.

title: Hurricane Nears Hispaniola; Is Held Unlikely to Hit U.S.
description: Hurricane Emily swept toward the island of Hispaniola today with 15-foot waves and winds of 120 miles and hour, forcing the Dominican Republic to close schools and cancel flights.

title: Steady Gains Achieved by Blacks On College Admission Test Scores
description: Black high school students across the country are making steady gains in the scores they achieve on standardized college admission tests, the two major testing agencies reported yesterday.

title: San Salvador Journal; With Guns at Hand, They Dance the Night Away
description: As Carlos Guirola gyrated to the beat of American rock songs at Mario's, he could easily have been a carefree 21-year-old at any popular disco in any major city. But at the door of this capital's glitziest nightclub, he showed the peculiarities of the city and how many residents have learned to live with war and terrorism.

title: Huge Rise in Jersey Prison Budget Is Seen
description: New Jersey, putting 135 more prisoners behind bars each month than it is releasing, could be spending more on its correction system by the year 2000 than on any other activity except education and Medicare, according to a state panel.

title: Rams' Soccer Thrives
description: Fordham's soccer team is off to its best start in the 19 years Frank Schnur has been the coach. Its victory over Hartwick College Saturday was the first time Fordham had ever beaten the powerhouse from upstate New York and it kept the Rams unbeaten in five games this season. The Rams have scored 24 goals and have allowed only 1, but the touhgest game may be this afternoon, when Columbia visits Fordham at Edwards Parade Ground in the Bronx. Although the Lions (1-1) are not as strong as in previous years, they still field a potent team. The squad includes Schnur's two sons, Frank and Peter, who are starters. In last year's game between the teams, Peter scored the only goal to defeat his father. Peter is Columbia's central striker and leading scorer. Frank is a defender. For the Rams, Jeff Knuth, the junior goalkeeper from Hicksville, L.I., leads the defense, and David Hausch, a freshman forward from Northport, L.I., leads in scoring with six goals.

title: 'Electronic Problem' Delays Nielsen Ratings
description: Electronic problems prevented the A. C. Nielsen company from releasing its weekly ranking of television programs yesterday. The ranking would have reflected the first week during which the company relied solely on its new audience-measuring method called ''people meters.''

title: Arrow's Leader Moves Toward $1 Billion Goal
description: John C. Waddell, chairman of Arrow Electronics Inc., had all the standard reasons for being pleased about the big acquisition deal he announced Monday. And then he had a few reasons that were special and intensely personal.

title: Newmont Rebuffs Pickens
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation appeared late yesterday to have won a major victory against T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who had made a hostile $6.3 billion takeover offer for Newmont.

title: Networks Try Scramble Play
description: The three major television networks will serve up baseball, a repeat of last year's Super Bowl and a ''Star Trek'' movie to replace the first National Football League games canceled by the players' strike.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1987
description: Markets

title: Prisoner of Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Phone Accord Fails
description: Two rival consortiums, which tried but failed to merge into a single entity to enter Japan's lucrative overseas telecommunicatins business, disclosed divergent business plans today.

title: The Bon Expected To Name President
description: Robert Mang, the 40-year-old president and chief executive of the Broadway-Southwest department stores based in Arizona, will soon be named president of the Bon stores in Seattle, a division of the Allied Stores Corporation, according to retail trade sources.

title: Women Behind the Scenery
description: As the insurrection begins in ''Les Miserables,'' the towering barricades slide onstage in front of the audience, a spectacle so impressive that when the barricade segments link into place the theatergoers often applaud. What the audience does not see is the young woman hidden inside the barricades - a tall blonde in a satin blouse and jeans who drives the enormous machinery like a tank.

title: Editor's Note
description: A front-page article yesterday about the National Football League labor dispute began with this sentence:

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
U.S. Stops Funding LTV Pension Plans
description: Contending that the LTV Corporation had abused Federal pension policy, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said today that it had stopped funding the company's three pension programs and had returned the responsibility of making the payments to the company.

title: Excerpts From the Address to the General Assembly by the President of Iran
description: Following are excerpts from the address to the United Nations General Assembly today by the Iranian President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, as translated by the Iranian Mission:

title: Corrections
description: The ''Business and the Law'' column in Business Day on Monday, about securities arbitration panels, misidentified a case that the Supreme Court decided in June. It was Shearson/American Express v. McMahon.

title: Ex-Intelsat Head Sentenced
description: The former head of the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization received a six-year prison term today for leading a bid-rigging and kickback scheme that defrauded the agency of $4.8 million.

title: More Gains For South Bronx
description: FOR the last few years, the Bathgate Industrial Park has stood as a hopeful sign of the rebirth of the South Bronx, a section of the city that has long symbolized urban blight.

title: Dan Rowan, 65, a Comedian And a 'Laugh-In' Host, Dies
description: Dan Rowan, co-host and co-producer of ''Rowan and Martin's Laugh-In,'' the nation's most popular television variety series in the late 1960's, died of lymphatic cancer yesterday at his home in Englewood, Fla. He was 65 years old.

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After application of net operating loss carryforwards. c-Includes a one-time extraordinary gain of $10 million resulting from a refinancing and restructuring of GA's financial position and a consequent $12 million elimination of GA's previous bank debt and interest for both the quarter and year. Year-ago quarter and year are not comparable because the quarter was shortened to two months as a result of a change in fiscal year-end to June 30. Year-ago quarter consisted of two months and year consisted of 11 months.

title: AMERICAN BARRICK REOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Nicaragua Is Central America's Agrarian Lab
description: To the Editor:

title: Manila Army: In the Bush, Go-Slow War
description: Almost half of the Philippine Army is engaged in the counterinsurgency campaign against Communist and Moslem rebels on the island of Mindanao, but its forces appear to be making little headway.

title: Many Theories On Macmillan
description: EVER since Sept. 10, when the Macmillan Company disclosed its purchase of a 6.6 percent stake in the Bell & Howell Company and said it might seek control, Wall Street has been waiting for the other shoe to drop.

title: Pentagon Procedures Criticized
description: Richard Godwin, who resigned last week as the Pentagon's acquisition chief, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that the Defense Department ''may have lost ground'' in the last year in its effort to buy weapons efficiently.

title: Guatemala Chief Asks Support for Peace Pact
description: President Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala, addressing the General Assembly, appealed today to the United States and other countries to ''respect'' the wishes of Central American leaders and support the peace accord signed in Guatemala last month.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: SO there I was on Saturday night, with my pencil, my paper and my pint of Fantastic Mash ice cream. ''Miss California is pretty,'' I called to my husband in the kitchen. ''Oh my God,'' he replied. ''Not this again.''

title: Robertson's Finances
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson's decision to announce his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination on Oct. 1 has aroused the suspicions of rival campaigns because of the tactical advantage it provides. Mr. Robertson says he has collected more than $9 million, but of the major contenders only he and the Rev. Jesse Jackson have not filed financial reports with the Government, insisting that they are still ''testing the waters.''

title: Film: 'Parting,' From Cuba
description: THE opening situation of ''Parting of the Ways'' is fraught with possibilities. A woman who fled Fidel Castro's Cuba returns after 10 years to visit the son she and her husband left behind. He was 16 years old, draft age, and so denied permission to emigrate with his family. Now, still occupying the old family apartment in Havana, he is married and comfortble with the regime. Here are the makings of a politically consequential drama, of special interest to a North American audience because it comes from Cuba.

title: An Abandoned Room 80 Is a Treasure Restored
description: It was known for generations as Room 80, but it was really the New York Public Library's greatest architectural surprise. Where the other public rooms of the library are sumptuous and formal interiors of marble, wood paneling and plaster carving, Room 80 has a spectacular, 30-foot-high elliptical dome of glass, supported on four leaping arches of cast iron.

title: Politicians Say Conviction Is Likely to End Career of Another Bronx Power
description: The conviction of Representative Mario Biaggi yesterday, the prospect of a trial on even more serious charges in the near future and his advanced age will very likely end his career as a Congressman and as a political power in the Bronx, Democratic politicians said yesterday.

title: GOULD INVESTORS LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 9-month includes gains from disposition of properties, mortgages and investments of $101,000, or 7 cents a share, and $246,000, or 18 cents a share, respectively. Results for the year-ago quarter and 9-month includes gains from disposition of properties, mortgages and investments of $1,516,000, or $1.07 a share, and $1,827,000, or $1.30 a share, respectively. The company said results for 1987 periods include a gain of $300,000 from the favorable settlement of condemnation proceedings. The company was reorganized into Gould Investors L.P. on May 13, 1986; year-ago figures before that date represent the operations of Gould Investors Trust.

title: Patrick Settles In as a Ranger
description: James Patrick, the only Ranger on the Canadian team that defeated the Soviet Union in the Canada Cup final last week, arrived at training camp this morning. But unlike his peers, Patrick was deemed not to need an immediate round of skating and competition, and wasn't scheduled to take to the practice ice until Wednesday to prepare for his return as a Ranger in the exhibition games this weekend against the Whalers.

title: Edelman Group Bids for Rexham
description: The Rexham Corporation said it had received an unsolicited offer to buy the company for $53 a share in cash from a group led by Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor. Rexham, a maker of packaging materials, said it would discuss the offer but would also explore alternatives.

title: MILLICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from equity in operations of joint ventures of $1.9 million in the quarter and $3 million in the 6 months, incurred in the development of Metagram Messenging Services in the U.S. c-Includes a gain of $3.5 million from the sale of about 3.9 million shares of Racal Electronics Plc. d-Net income and includes a $5,795,000 gain on the sale of certain celluar interests. The company said the results for the latest periods reflect the consolidation of Millicom Celluar (U.K.) Ltd., a Millicom subsidiary since March.

title: Squibb Lawsuit
description: The Squibb Corporation said it had filed a lawsuit against the Dainippon Pharmaceutical Company, contending that the Japanese company had infringed on Squibb's patent covering capoten, a medication for treating high blood pressure. Squibb said that it objected to Dainippon's testing of a heart medication called Allacepril and that it wanted the tests halted.

title: A Fateful Decision for Unesco
description: LEAD: Today's meeting of Unesco's executive board is without a doubt the most important in the agency's 41-year history. On the agenda: whom to recommend to the General Conference as the next Director General. The decision may make or break Unesco.

title: INSIDE
description: Biden Assessing Candidacy

title: National League; Coleman Leads Cards Over Phils
description: Vince Coleman singled and tripled and scored two runs tonight, leading St. Louis to a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies that extended the Cardinals' lead to three and a half games over the Mets in the National League East.

title: Archbishop Files Suit to Halt Novel
description: Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, the former head of the Vatican bank, has sued to halt publication of a novel that uses his real name, title and background and portrays him as having ordered the assassination of Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, in 1984.

title: Koch and Priest Trade Barbs in Battle for a Chelsea Building
description: A battle between Mayor Koch and a Roman Catholic priest over the ownership of a building in the Chelsea section of Manhattan intensified yesterday, with the priest vowing to oppose Mr. Koch's efforts to seize the building and the Mayor accusing the priest of attempting to steal it.

title: Chase Aim Is Eased Regulation
description: CHASE MANHATTAN BANK is beginning a gloom-and-doom ad campaign today aimed at getting Congress to soften the regulatory climate enough to let commercial banks get more deeply into the investment banking and securities businesses.

title: LEADER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Imperial Set to Sell More Stauffer Units
description: Britain's Imperial Chemical Industries said today that it would sell the basic chemicals businesses of its American subsidiary, the Stauffer Chemical Company, to Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France for $522 million.

title: CIDER OFFERS A TOAST TO THE SEASON
description: CERTAIN drinks ally themselves with a season. Lemonade and gin and tonic, for example, are most appealing during the long, hot, languorous days of summer. Cider belongs to fall, its burnished reddish-brown color in tune with the autumn foliage, its mellow and robust flavor a brace against the nip in the air.

title: Woman Charges Malpractice in Lawsuit on AIDS
description: A woman suffering from AIDS has testified that physicians insisted she was only in need of mental help when she first became concerned about symptoms of the fatal disease.

title: TRC COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $119,000, or 8 cents a share. The latest quarter results include a loss on marketable securities of $94,082.

title: A Star of Iran Finds Destiny Against Him
description: If Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei had his way, his first visit to the United States would have also been his first foray into international public relations. Using the United Nations for his pulpit, the Iranian President intended to portray his country as a victim of Iraqi aggression and to appeal to Americans' sense of fair play.

title: Jaco Pastorius, Jazz Bassist, Dies of Injuries in a Beating
description: John Francis (Jaco) Pastorius, an electric bassist whose brief career influenced jazz musicians worldwide, died Monday night at the Broward General Medical Center. He was 35 years old.

title: New Steps In Santa Fe Revamping
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, a holding company with railroad, energy and real estate interests, announced new steps yesterday in its broad restructuring, including an offer to buy back more than a third of its outstanding stock.

title: DOW RISES BY 75.23 FOR LARGEST GAIN IN A SINGLE SESSION
description: The stock market surged higher yesterday, propelling the Dow Jones industrial average to its biggest single-day point gain ever.

title: Dayton Hudson
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation yesterday denied reports that it had approached Citibank about a possible restructuring of the big Minneapolis-based department store chain. The reports, attributed to executives close to the situation, arose this week in the wake of a $6 billion hostile takeover attempt by the Haft family of Washington. Ann Barkelew, a spokeswoman for Dayton Hudson, said, ''We did not approach Citibank on any business transaction.''

title: Gorbachev Book Described as 'Cut and Paste' Job
description: At first glance, the proposal sounded irresistible: a book about world affairs written by the architect of glasnost, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. A closer examination, however, showed that the book being offered to American publishers was actually what one publisher called a ''cut and paste'' job of Mr. Gorbachev's speeches and writings. The book was put together by two Austrian journalists, who have apparently never met the Soviet leader, much less interviewed him.

title: Fundamentalists in 'Born Again'
description: ''BORN AGAIN'' doesn't flatter its subjects, and it doesn't much criticize them, either. It just looks at them. Who are these fundamentalist Christians, so sure in their belief? ''Born Again,'' on Channels 13 and 21 at 9 P.M., does not tell us exactly, although it may give us mixed feelings of skepticism and envy. The fundamentalists, it is clear, have found a warm universe.

title: In Search of the Sports Balance
description: With pro football on strike and big league baseball in shock over disputes that turn on free agency, players and owners would do well to study the healthy example set by pro basketball.

title: Live Broadcasts Set For Bork Hearings
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on the confirmation of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court will be televised live on Channel 13 and CNN beginning at 10 A.M. Other broadcast and cable channels may pre-empt or interrupt programming for live or taped coverage.

title: Borden Acquires Laura Scudder's
description: Borden Inc., bolstering its position as the nation's second-largest producer of snack foods, said it had acquired Laura Scudder's Inc., a maker of potato chips and peanut butter. Terms were not disclosed, but Borden said the deal exceeded the $55 million it paid last month for the Snacktime Company, which serves the Middle West.

title: RIVERBEND INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After income from minority interest in loss from subsidiaries of $292,000 for the quarter and $909,000 for the 9 months.

title: Foe Warns Bork Views Pose A Serious Risk to Freedoms
description: A leading academic opponent of Judge Robert H. Bork's elevation to the Supreme Court said today that the nominee's views, even as modified in his testimony last week, posed a ''serious risk'' to constitutional freedoms.

title: Phil Niekro to Braves
description: Phil Niekro is rejoining the Atlanta Braves and will pitch for them Sunday against the San Francisco Giants in the club's final home game. The 48-year-old Niekro had been considering whether to pitch again for the Braves after being released by the Toronto Blue Jays. He said last week he had decided against doing so after an Atlanta newspaper columnist and television sportscaster denounced the idea. Niekro spent most of his career with the Braves, who released him after the 1983 season.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WORLD'S END. By T. Coraghessan Boyle. 456 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: Writer's Memories Sting and Entertain
description: Mary McCarthy came out on the stage of the 92d Street Y Monday night looking like somebody's dear old grandmother in a pastel dress edged with ruffles. She then cheerfully threw poisoned darts at a great many people as she read from the unpublished manuscript of her continuing ''so-called intellectual autobiography.''

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1987. The latest quarter's results include the operations of a business purchased in October 1986.

title: U.S. Budget Deficit Eases
description: The Federal budget deficit eased to $21.73 billion in August from $22.21 billion in July, leaving the Government's shortfall between spending and income in the fiscal year so far much less than a year before, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Monterey Journal; Debate Lingers On a Missionary Of 18th Century
description: Pope John Paul II has come and gone, but a historical dispute on which he declined to commit himself on his visit -whether Junipero Serra was a saint or a sinner - has lingered behind him in this coastal city.

title: Economic Scene; Critical Puzzle For the I.M.F.
description: THE key issue facing the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which begin in Washington this weekend, is how to prevent the developing countries from defaulting on billions of dollars of public and private debt.

title: ST JOE GOLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Japanese Get Role On German Bonds
description: Japanese banks and investment houses will be allowed to lead underwriting syndicates for Eurobonds denominated in West German marks as of Oct. 1, a spokesman for the Bundesbank said today.

title: Sutcliffe Adds to Mets' Woes
description: Did the Mets come to the end of the trail today in old Wrigley Field? Could be.

title: Bar by Pentagon Is Seen On Plessey Bid to Harris
description: For the second time this year, the Pentagon is apparently discouraging an effort by a major foreign corporation to buy an American military contractor, contending that even the nation's closest allies should not control the manufacture of components that are critical to weapons production and intelligence gathering.

title: Appeals Panel Refuses to Upset Ruling on Bias
description: A New York State Appeals Court let stand yesterday a ruling by the judge in the Howard Beach murder trial that would curb the defense lawyers' challenges against prospective black jurors.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1987
description: International A3-15

title: ALTAI INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ELLIS KHOURI
description: Ellis Khouri, a top official of the Orthodox Antiochian Church, died Saturday. He was 87 years old.

title: Ten Little Candidates
description: ''Madam,'' said the butler just at cocktail time, ''I am afraid there is a corpse in the library.'' All of us knew what that meant. A tiresome weekend with a gumshoe saying, ''Nobody leaves this room.''

title: ADVERTISING
description: LEAD: * Anthony Shore was named senior vice president at Ally Gargano/MCA Advertising.

title: Mobile Telephones For All Occasions
description: When cellular mobile telephones were introduced four years ago, they were gadgets only of the rich and powerful. Now everyone from drug dealers in Miami to the taco vendor in Rockefeller Plaza has one.

title: Racing Group Official Named OTB Chairman
description: Howard P. Giordano, an executive with the New York Racing Association, was named yesterday by Mayor Koch as the new chairman of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation.

title: Walkout Impact: Variety For All
description: For the second time in five years, fans, players, bartenders, restaurateurs and stadium personnel were once again facing a fall weekend without professional football.

title: ICN Acquires La Roche Stake
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. said it had acquired 6.3 percent of the voting shares of F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Company, the Swiss pharmaceuticals and chemical giant. ICN disclosed the holding in a filing with the Federal Trade Commission, but the Costa Mesa, Calif., company declined further comment. ICN, which developed an antiviral drug as a possible AIDS treatment, has amassed nearly $400 million in cash, and has said it intends to buy other drug companies.

title: AERO SERVICES INTERNAIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the results for the latest periods include a $357,000 writedown on Aero Services' investment in its Kansas City operation and a writedown of $256,000, representing the difference between the carrying value of the company's investment in its Flightmatic Inc. subsidiary and the highest amount which may be realized in the proposed sale of Flightmatic.

title: Spinoff Is Set By Thomson
description: Thomson McKinnon Inc., a privately held mid-sized investment firm, said yesterday that it was spinning off part of its asset management subsidiary.

title: HARDING ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 23

FOOD & FITNESS;
A Quick Kitchen Friend
description: LEAD: THE microwave oven is more than the expensive water-boiler that its detractors say it is, and less than the kitchen miracle that the appliance industry and cookbook authors often proclaim.

title: Saatchi to List On Big Board
description: Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi Company, whose growth to No. 1 in worldwide advertising circles was fueled by its ability to raise money through the sale of stock, has been cleared to apply for listing on the New York Stock Exchange, Saatchi announced yesterday.

title: Continental Acts to Stem Long Storm of Complaints
description: Continental Airlines, in an effort to stanch a flow of complaints and negative publicity, announced a sweeping improvement program today, including setting aside some airliners as spares for emergencies.

title: Minerals May Sell Salomon Shares
description: The Minerals and Resources Corporation said that it is considering the sale of 21.3 million shares of Salomon Inc., the parent of Salomon Brothers, as part of a plan to shift its investment strategy. The shares, 14 percent of Salomon's outstanding common stock, would have a market value of about $663 million. Salomon's shares closed today at $31.125, up 87.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: About New York; Passion to Create: A Life Altered By Hellish Vision

''I was at the table of the Royal Court,'' he said. Mr. Turovsky had illustrated nearly 300 books. His paintings had been shown in 50 exhibitions in the Soviet Union and in more than 30 countries. He had the honor of painting the late Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

description: The Justice Department's antitrust division said today that it would oppose a proposal by the rival Detroit News and Detroit Free Press to merge their advertising, production and circulation departments.

description: Two-thirds of Americans favor a treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union on intermediate range missiles, even though almost as many believe the Soviet Union will cheat on such an agreement, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Sanchez Advances: Emilio Sanchez, the fourth-seeded player, defeated Franco Davin of Argentina, 7-5, 6-2, yesterday in the second round of the 35th Count of Godo tennis tournament at the Royal Tennis Club de Barcelona in Spain. In other matches, Sergio Casal of Spain beat Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 5-7, 6-4; Juan Aguilera of Spain defeated Thomas Muster of Australia, 6-4, 6-3; Martin Jaite of Argentina beat Cassio Mottar of Brazil, 7-6, 4-6, 6-1; and Ronald Agenor of Haiti downed Francisco Maciel of Mexico, 7-6, 2-6, 6-1. Also Claude Mezzadri of Switzerland topped Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 6-3; Marian Vadja of Czechoslovakia overcame Francisco Yunis of Argentina, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4; Guillermo Perez Roldan of Argentina beat Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 1-6, 8-6, and Tomas Carbonell of Spain swept Jan Gunnarson of Sweden, 6-3, 6-3.(AP) Lundgren Upset: Peter Lundgren, the third-seeded player, was eliminated yesterday in second-round play of the Volvo tournament in Los Angeles, while Marty Davis, who was unseeded, defeated sixth-seeded Kevin Curren. David Pate of Las Vegas, Nev., had four aces in the first set and 10 in the second set to beat Lundgren, 6-4, 6-4. Pate, unseeded in the tournament but ranked 19th in the world, needed 77 minutes to take the victory. Davis, a tournament qualifier from Harbor Bay Isle, Calif., beat Curren of Austin, Tex., 7-6, 6-7, 7-6.(AP) Golf Vershure Leads Met Tournament: Rick Vershure of Quaker Ridge in Scarsdale, N.Y., held the lead with a 66 after the the rain-delayed first round of the Izod Metropolitan P.G.A. championship was completed yesterday at the Fenway Golf Club, Scarsdale. A record field of 172, including the defending champion, Don Reese of Glen Oaks in Old Westbury, L.I., is entered in the 54-hole tournament. Tom Sutter of Engineers in Roslyn, L.I., trailed Vershure, who finished play Tuesday, with a 68. He was one stroke ahead of Mike Joyce of Huntington on Long Island and Roy Pace of Wee Burn in Darien, Conn. Soccer Fordham Beaten: Peter Schnur scored the first goal in Columbia's 3-0 victory over Fordham. The defeat was the first of the season for the Rams, who had won six straight under their coach, and Peter's father, Frank Schnur.

title: At Annual Milan Fair, Furniture That Surprises
description: At the 27th annual furniture fair that ended Monday in Milan, Italy, romantic revivalism took the lead as the strongest and most interesting trend, seducing modernists and traditionalists alike. The most important direction for the future seems to be the romance of the past. Although many modernists looked back, they looked in different directions. Among the references were 19th-century garden pieces, American Shaker designs, 18th-century French furniture and styles recalling the 50's and 60's. Even at Memphis, the quirky avant-garde movement founded by Ettore Sottsass six years ago, some designs were nostalgic. Hard-edge minimalism, always a staple at the fair, was well represented, too. description: Steve Horn, the well-known director of TV commercials and a photographer, will officially be installed in the Hall of Fame of the Art Directors Club at a banquet at the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 23. He will be one of four men so honored, the others being Tony Palladino, the graphic designer; Shigeo Fukuda, a Japanese graphic designer, and the late Willie Fleckhaus, a German magazine designer.

title: More Hearings Are Set on Newmont
description: A Delaware state court judge ruled yesterday that he would not undo a British company's $1.5 billion stampede to buy stock in the Newmont Mining Corporation, but he called a hearing for tomorrow to decide whether he would temporarily hold up payment to those who had sold shares.

title: Macy's New Units
description: R. H. Macy & Company, releasing details of a proposed specialty-store venture, said it would open three Aeropostale stores in November to sell private-label clothing and accessories for men and women. The stores, with 3,000 to 5,000 square feet each, will be in Hoboken and Short Hills, N.J., and in Pleasanton, Calif.

title: Ruth Attaway, Actress, Dies Of Injuries in Apartment Fire
description: Ruth Attaway, a theater and film actress, died Monday at New York Hospital of injuries resulting from an apartment fire. She was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: The House ethics committee today formally charged Representative Austin J. Murphy Jr., a Pennsylvania Democrat, with six counts of violating House rules involving misuse of public funds and allowing someone else to cast his votes in absences from the House floor.

title: Dumb Absence at the U.N.
description: As the President of Iran gave an offensive speech at the United Nations Tuesday, the U.S. delegation walked out. That carried on a tradition begun by the Soviet Union in 1946. In that instance, its delegation walked out to protest the Security Council's refusal to defer dealing with the continued presence of Soviet troops in Iran.

title: Ex-Boesky Aide to Help S.E.C.
description: A former senior executive of a company controlled by Ivan F. Boesky agreed yesterday to cooperate with the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle charges that he had committed bookkeeping violations.

title: PSYCHIATRIST SAYS PANEL CLEARED HIM
description: A psychiatrist who said on national television that he personally opposed drug and shock therapy for the mentally ill has been told by a state medical committee that it sees no basis for revoking his license, the doctor said today.

title: World Bank's Staff Upheaval
description: Despite continuing attacks from a World Bank staff shaken by the most far-reaching reorganization in 15 years, Barber B. Conable Jr. is expected to get a pat on the back from the industrial countries that are his major shareholders at next week's meeting of the 151-nation global lender.

description: When his fans and former colleagues gathered this week to celebrate the television career of Jackie Gleason, it was with mixed opinions on what ''The Great One'' would have thought of such a salute.

title: Guerrero Improves
description: The condition of Robert Guerrero, the Indy-car driver seriously injured in a crash while testing tires at Indianapolis Speedway on Sept. 10, was upgraded from serious to good yesterday at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis. The driver was moved from the critical-care unit to a private room.

title: E.P.A. Plan May Allow Delays in Clean Air Rule
description: An Environmental Protection Agency proposal would eliminate threats to cut Federal highway funds for Denver and other polluted cities by allowing delays in compliance with the Clean Air Act.

title: Janet Hart Sylvester, Federal Reserve Aide
description: Janet Hart Sylvester, the first woman to head a division of the Federal Reserve System, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Washington. She was 70 years old.

title: Biaggi, Back in Washington, Says He Is Confident
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, who was convicted by a Federal court jury in Brooklyn on Tuesday of accepting unlawful gratuities and obstructing justice, arrived here today exuding confidence about his future.

title: Voice of Doom
description: The Chicago Cubs' interim manager, Frank Lucchesi, thought he was in more hot water after Tuesday's game against the Mets. Lucchesi was serving the second day of a two-day suspension for bumping a plate umpire, Joe West, in St. Louis on Sunday when he ran onto the field to congratulate Rick Sutcliffe for pitching a 6-2 victory.

title: FACING A DAUNTING CHALLENGE: WARD'S THREE SENIOR AIDES
description: One is a pipe-smoking administrator whose idea of lunchtime exercise is a seven-mile run up the edge of the East River from Police Headquarters. Another is a suave sleuth, a silver-haired former Marine whose television presence is as polished as his shoes.

description: In his eloquent speech to Congress on Tuesday, the Costa Rican President, Oscar Arias Sanchez, called on all sides of the Central America conflict to ''restore faith in diologue and give peace a chance.'' The Reagan Administration, however, is up to the same old trick: claiming that it must aid the contras to bring about a negotiated settlement but using that same aid to block it.

title: Judge Cleared in Bribe Case

The Sham: Not Just in Nicaragua
description: What's ''phony'' democratization in Nicaragua? To hear President Reagan, any steps forward by the Sandinistas are a sham because they could march backward tomorrow. Thus Administration officials peevishly refuse even one affirmative word when Managua lifts a 15-month ban on the major opposition paper, La Prensa . . . or when Sandinistas say they are ending censorship and authorize the Catholic radio station to resume broadcasting after 19 months . . . or when they name their most outspoken critic, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, to head a reconciliation commission.

title: Cleveland-Cliffs Dissidents' Filing
description: An investor group led by David F. Bolger, an investment banker in Ridgewood, N.J., said it would consider taking Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. private if its proxy fight to gain control of the company were successful. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bolger group said it believed that Cleveland-Cliffs' financial problems could be aided by ''the increased flexibility inherent in private companies.''

title: Critic's Notebook; Opera and the Constitution
description: FELLOW operagoers, have the confirmation hearings for Judge Robert H. Bork filled you with a sense of deja vu? The reason is not far to seek: After 200 years of buildup, public debate on constitutional law has approached the sophistication of operatic disputes, and indeed has begun to recapitulate them. Dozens of hitherto unexamined issues unite the constitutional scholar and the musicologist in grave concern.

title: Foreign Stakes in Rolls
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. said today that foreign holdings of its stock had exceeded the 15 percent limit set by the Government when the maker of airplane engines was sold to the public in May. Shares were sold under a plan allowing two installment payments. Banks handling the second installment, due today, said foreigners now owned 16.6 percent of the company. ''Foreign shareholders will be identified on a chronological basis and those who paid the second installment after the 15 percent limit had been reached will receive a letter from the registrar requesting them to sell their shares within about three weeks,'' a Rolls-Royce spokesman said.

The Pump on the Well

The gap between rich and poor widened, since the poor had no land to benefit from irrigation. Finally, village women broke the pump, so they could gather again around the well that had been the center of their social lives.
