title: Pop: 'Hidden Fortress,' From Japan
description: A WEEKLONG series called ''The Hidden Fortress: New Music From Japan'' opened Tuesday at the Kitchen (512 West 19th Street) with a concert of Western pop transformed by Japanese traditions - or maybe vice versa. Two pianists and singers, Akiko Yano and Haruo Togashi, played solo sets using Western harmonies, words in Japanese and English, and melodies and dynamics that evoked both cultures.

title: Cabaret: Lonette McKee Sings at the Ballroom
description: LONETTE McKEE has been a bright, sharp presence on the stage (''Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill'') and in the movies (''The Cotton Club,'' '' 'Round Midnight''), playing pop-jazz singers who put an edge of steel into a torch song. But as her new cabaret act at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, reveals, the movies and the theater have only skimmed the surface of her protean talents.

title: SOVIET HAS PRAISE ON WEAPONS TALKS
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A Shevardnadze, told the United Nations General Assembly today that the emerging nuclear missile pact between the Soviet Union and the United States means ''the idea of nuclear disarmament is close to the beginning of its fulfillment.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: New Season

title: Coffey Suspended
description: Paul Coffey, the star defenseman for the Edmonton Oilers who helped Team Canada win the Canada Cup tournament, has been fined and suspended indefinitely for failing to report to the Oilers on schedule.

title: Yanks Can't Believe It's Over
description: At times, the manager sounded like a broken record, his voice skipping back to the same theme over and over. He kept talking about injuries, how they had cursed his team almost from the start, how they had undermined its resolve and its steady climb into first place in baseball's toughest division. No matter how he tried to dissect the season, Lou Piniella could not dismiss the injuries.

title: STAGE: NEW PLAYWRIGHTS
description: IN its previous five seasons, the Young Playwrights Festival has introduced a number of short plays by young writers with widely disparate abilities. Only two plays are given full production in this year's festival (at Playwrights Horizons), but each is an attempt at writing a longer and more ambitious work than those that have preceded it. Juliet Garson's ''Tiny Mommy'' promises; the other play, Noble Mason Smith's ''Sparks in the Park,'' delivers. As is customary in this valuable series, both are given highly professional performances.

title: Norman Luboff, Head Of Choir and Composer
description: Norman Luboff, a composer and arranger of popular choral pieces and best known as director of the Norman Luboff Choir, died of lung cancer Tuesday at his home in Bynum, N.C. He was 70 years old.

title: Panel Finds Gross Incompetence In Repair of New York's Schools
description: Executives in charge of the construction and repair of New York City school buildings are ''grossly incompetent'' and have shown a ''shocking degree of apathy and managerial ineptitude,'' a state panel asserted yesterday.

title: Advertising; Better Homes' New Tack
description: BETTER HOMES AND GARDENS, whose circulation of eight million makes it Meredith's flagship publication, is abandoning a two-year-old, highly successful contest promotion in favor of a trade advertising campaign.

title: Hints for Reglazing an Old Cabinet Door
description: LEAD: The difficulty of obtaining good-sized panes of glass did not stymie the makers of glazed doors for early 18th-century china cabinets or cases.

title: Commercial Credit To Buy Back Stake
description: Sanford I. Weill, the chairman and chief executive of the Commercial Credit Company, announced plans yesterday to fully consolidate his control of Commercial Credit by having the company buy back 9.5 million shares from its former owner, the Control Data Corporation.

title: Refund Plan for Tickets
description: The Giants and the Jets have said that because of the strike by the Natonal Football League Players Association refunds will be given to any ticket-holders for games affected by the walkout, either those scheduled games not played or those played by strike teams.

title: Japan Opens Door To British Concern
description: Japan will allow Britain's Cable and Wireless P.L.C. to try to break into its telecommunications market, ending a yearlong battle that threatened trade relations between the two countries. The Japanese Government invited the International Digital Communications consortium, in which Cable and Wireless has a 17 percent stake, to apply for permission to run an international telecommunications service in Japan.

title: TWINS PULL AWAY
description: Dan Gladden hit a two-run homer and a tie-breaking triple in the eighth inning tonight as the Minnesota Twins beat the Texas Rangers, 4-2, and cut their magic number for clinching the American League West to six.

title: U.S. Terms Managua Moves 'Cosmetic'
description: The Reagan Administration today dismissed the Nicaraguan Government's announcements that it would allow the reopening of opposition newspapers and radio stations, calling them ''cosmetic gestures of compliance'' with a Central American peace plan.

title: Alexander Goes 8-0 As Tigers Triumph
description: Doyle Alexander pitched a two-hitter for his eighth victory against no defeats tonight and the Detroit Tigers tuned up for their American League East showdown with Toronto by beating the Boston Red Sox, 4-0.

title: Lobbying for Baker
description: Meanwhile, the Treasury's legislative operation is certainly changing. Last year Mr. Baker's main goal was to push through Congress, over the opposition of some of the most influential lobbyists in town, an overhaul of the Federal income tax system.

title: Whither Obey?
description: Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin has decided not to run for chairman of the Budget Committee in the next Congress, conceding the post to a fellow Democrat, Representative Leon E. Panetta of California. Under the rules, the current chairman, resentative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania, must step down because he will have served two terms.

title: 3-VOTE WIN REVERSES RESULTS OF A PRIMARY
description: The New York City Board of Elections, reversing the results of a Democratic primary last week, has declared Stuart C. Cohen the winner by three votes of the Civil Court nomination in Manhattan's First District.

title: Iranian Says Arms Affair Guides U.S. Actions
description: Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, the President of Iran, asserted yesterday that the United States was deliberately ''dragging the Persian Gulf to war'' in response to domestic political pressures, including President Reagan's need ''to project himself as a powerful and decisive person'' after the Iran-contra affair.

title: Debt
description: Ford Motor Credit is issuing $200 million of 9 3/8 percent noncallable Eurobonds due 1990 at 101 1/4 through Union Bank of Switzerland (Securities) Ltd.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Includes a net charge of $1,866,000 from discontinuance of certain products and operations. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared yesterday and effective Oct. 5.

title: First Week Of 'People Meters'
description: A RERUN of ''The Cosby Show'' was the top-ranked television program last week, the first during which the A. C. Nielsen Company relied solely on the new audience-measuring method called ''people meters.''

title: Orders Down 3.1% For Durable Goods
description: Orders to the nation's factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods dropped in August, the first decline in seven months, as demand for military hardware and aircraft slumped.

title: 'TOUR OF DUTY,' IN VIETNAM
description: WITH the Korean War as a backdrop, ''M*A*S*H'' managed to bring to CBS a long-running, enormously successful weekly series. Now the network is obviously searching for more of the same in ''Tour of Duty,'' the new series getting under way at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: A TV Series on the Buildings of America
description: ''THIS isn't Lord Kenneth Clark telling you the high points of Western culture,'' explained Prof. Spiro Kostof, host of ''America By Design,'' a five-part series on architecture and design that begins Monday on the Public Broadcasting Service. ''This is just some guy simply helping you to see.''

title: Can Railroads Come Back at High Speed?
description: To the Editor:

title: California Cashes In On the Leisure Life
description: In New York, the seasonal collection openings that are commonly known as Fashion Week actually last two weeks. Here, California Collections Press Week lasts a mere three days. This ''week'' aptly symbolizes the California design scene's contribution to fashion: it's casual.

title: U.S. Alerts Americans To Chance of Attacks
description: American embassies and personnel in the Persian Gulf and throughout the Middle East were put on alert today for possible Iranian-sponsored terrorist attacks.

title: 10 Die in Dhaka Sinking
description: Seven children and three women drowned today when an overloaded ferry boat sank at Tongi near Dhaka, fire brigade officials said. The officials said the boat was carrying about 200 passengers, beyond its capacity of 100, when it sank in the Torag River 12 miles north of this capital.

title: ANITEC IMAGE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Koch No Longer Thinks Myerson Is a Friend of His
description: Mayor Koch, revising his view of his relationship with Bess Myerson, said yesterday that ''it would be hard'' to call her a friend any longer.

title: Union Vows To Continue NBC Strike
description: The union representing 2,000 NBC producers, writers and technicians today accused the network of trying ''to bust this union,'' and promised to continue its three-month-long strike as long as NBC stands by its final offer.

title: President Resigns At Dayton Hudson
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, which already has enough trouble with an unwanted merger bid, found itself compelled yesterday to announce that its No. 2 executive, Boake A. Sells, president and chief operating officer, had resigned.

title: Artifacts From Titanic Are Displayed in Paris
description: Artifacts from the ship Titanic that were hidden 75 years on the ocean floor were shown to the public for the first time Tuesday.

title: Kennedy Center Honors
description: The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts named Perry Como, Bette Davis, Sammy Davis Jr., Nathan Milstein and Alwin Nikolais today as recipients of this year's Kennedy Center Honors.

title: Crime-Busting Dog Ready to Bite Again
description: WEARING a trench coat with the collar up, he looks more like a candidate for Gentlemen's Quarterly than a canine cartoon character. But McGruff, the suave symbol of the National Crime Prevention Council in Washington, has become a watchdog for safety, urging children and their parents to ''Take a Bite Out of Crime'' in televised public-service announcements.

title: Let House Keep Itself
description: To The Home Section:

title: Spinning With Baker
description: ''Be patient! That's what I preach,'' Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said the other day as he spun, over and over, a pointer on a dial that listed a variety of economic alternatives available to the Reagan Administration. The dial, like those used in board games, sits on an end table in Mr. Baker's newly redecorated office. One option on the dial is ''Patience.'' But Mr. Baker's luck being what it is, the arrow kept pointing to other alternatives: ''Sell gold,'' ''Cut oil prices,'' ''Increase oil prices,'' ''Buy dollars,'' ''Buy American.''

title: Market Place; A Bond Sector Finds Favor
description: DESPITE six months of falling bond prices and forecasts of further declines, securities dealers are finding good demand for closed-end mutual funds investing in tax-exempt bonds, a category of mutual fund that did not even exist a year ago.

title: At Milan Fair, Furniture That Surprises
description: THE Salone del Mobile in Milan, Italy, is the design world's most prestigious forum for contemporary furniture. Although few of the designs presented here will end up in American living rooms, they will be as influential in the world market of design ideas as the French couture showings are in fashion. This year, visitors were surprised to see not only the usual purely contemporary designs but also nostalgic looks at the past. International talents, more than ever, brought diverse points of view to Milan. Here and on page C6 are the personalities and trends that played starring roles GRAND MASTER: GAETANO PESCE

title: Abused Women's Plea
description: Battered women who kill their abusive mates should be able to defend themselves in court on the grounds of psychological self-defense, according to a lawyer and psychologist who has studied 100 such women.

title: SKIPPER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
description: The year-ago 9 months' results reflect a pre-tax charge of $975,000 from a provision for a loss on restaurant closures.

title: Consumer Prices Spurt 0.5%
description: The Consumer Price Index spurted five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the biggest rise for the inflation rate since January, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Midland Bank
description: The chairman of Midland Bank P.L.C. said today that he was not concerned about a recent spate of takeover activity related to Britain's fourth-largest bank. ''Some people have been buying shares and that's fine; it shows their confidence in the way the share prices can go,'' Kit McMahon, the chairman, said. The large conglomerate, Hanson Trust P.L.C., said last week that it had taken a 6.1 percent stake in Midland and the bank recently rebuffed takeover overtures from the advertising group Saatchi & Saatchi PLC.

title: View From the Top
description: To The Home Section:

title: HEILEMAN ACCEPTS $40.75-A-SHARE OFFER BY BOND
description: After a short struggle, the G. Heileman Brewing Company agreed yesterday to be purchased by Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., a leading Australian brewer, for $40.75 a share, or more than $1.1 billion, in cash.

title: IOWA CONGRESSMAN
description: H. R. Gross, a United States Representative from Iowa for 26 years, died Tuesday night in the Veteran's Adminstration Hospital in Washington, D.C., of complications from Alzheimer's disease. He was 88 years old.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $1,532,000 for the quarter and $1,831,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary tax credit of $1,417,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

description: The striking Giants spent an hour in the Giants Stadium parking lots and pathways today meeting and picketing.

title: Music: Composers Alliance
description: FOUNDED by Aaron Copland, Wallingford Riegger, Virgil Thomson and others at a time when American composers were just beginning to establish themselves as important figures on the international music scene, the American Composers Alliance has through its 50 years sponsored concerts, radio broadcasts and recordings and made accessible unpublished scores by American composers.

title: Holding the Center
description: To the Editor:

title: Ames Stores Appoints A New Chief Executive
description: Peter B. Hollis, the 44-year-old president and chief operating officer of Ames Department Stores Inc., has also been elected chief executive, taking over those duties from Herbert Gilman. Mr. Gilman, who is 63 years old, said he would continue as chairman of Ames, whose 326 stores generated sales of $1.5 billion last year.

title: Contras Accused of Killing 84 in Raids
description: At least 84 people were killed as a result of guerrilla raids on state-supported farm cooperatives in this country between February and July, a church-sponsored research group reported today.

description: b-After a charge of $639,000 from severance and transition costs. c-Net loss Corrected from yesterday's editions.

Lena Hodges Is Dead at 96; Heroine of Big Ship Disaster
description: Lena Hodges, credited with saving many lives in 1934 in a fire aboard the luxury liner Morro Castle, died Sept. 15 in a nursing home. She was 96.

Dan Rowan's TV Generation
description: Dan Rowan, who died Tuesday at 65, symbolized an era of evolution in television. From 1968 to 1973 he and his longtime partner, Dick Martin, presided over ''Rowan and Martin's Laugh-In,'' a sterling demonstration of Marshall McLuhan's ideas about medium and message.

title: Gothic Church Is Hung With Shocking Paintings
description: The setting was one of Wroclaw's largest Gothic churches. The artists were outsiders to Poland's officially sanctioned artistic community. The works were displays of anger, fear, violence, but also fervid devotion.

title: Majority Favors Raid, Survey Says
description: More than three-quarters of Americans approve of the United States military attack that resulted in the seizure of an Iranian ship that was laying mines in the Persian Gulf, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Burlington Begins $1.7 Billion Offer
description: Underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company yesterday began offering $1.7 billion of high-yielding debt issued by Burlington Holdings.

title: Flint Journal; A Fallen Star Wants to Shine Again
description: As prosecuting attorney in Genesee County, Robert F. Leonard built a national reputation in the 1970's, developing widely imitated programs on consumer protection and white-collar crime.

title: Advertising; Millar Adds Post at Saatchi
description: Anthony Simonds-Gooding has resigned the chairmanship of the communications division of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. of Britain and is being replaced by Victor Millar, who will also continue as chairman and chief executive of the Saatchis' consulting division.

title: The Wrong Way to Turn Phone Service Into a Welfare Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Built America
description: At a gathering of liberals on Manhattan's Upper West Side last month, I heard an earnest Congressman outline his plan for returning the White House to Democratic control in 1988. Liberals in New York divide into many factions, but this particular group - myself included - comprised a subset of idealists that came as close as any I've known to George Wallace's famous caricature of ''pointy headed bureaucrats.''

title: Players Miss U.S.F.L. Option
description: It once was easy to get a huge raise in pro football - threaten to jump to another league.

title: Mid-September Car Sales Fell 36.2%
description: Mid-September sales of American-made passenger vehicles were down 36.2 percent on a daily rate basis from the comparable period last year, the seven domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Governing, a Magazine
description: Over the years, Congressional Quarterly, a weekly magazine that provides definitive reports on the Federal Government with a special emphasis on Congress, has proved an indispensable research tool to those whose livelihood depends on following activities in Washington.

title: ALFIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $8,805,000 and $14,618,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $651,000 for the quarter and $4,244,000 for the year. The company said the latest quarter and year results reflect the restructuring and subsequent discontinuance of its skin care operations, including the proceeds from the sale of the Irma Shorell operation and from the sale of the gylcel and birthright inventory. Alfin said that included in discontinued operations are pretax charges of approximately $20,652,000 representing the writeoff of the skin care division and operating expenses incurred during the fourth quarter restructuring program.

title: Options for Jackson
description: Bo Jackson, the Kansas City Royals' outfielder who also has a contract as a football running back with the Los Angeles Raiders, is not certain how he will be spending the fall season.

title: GASTINEAU EXPLAINS REASON FOR PLAYING
description: Mark Gastineau reported to work this morning, as promised, as the old and new Jets began their first full day of strike activities.

title: India Sending Hundreds More Troops to Sri Lanka as Tamils Feud
description: Indian officials said today that hundreds more Indian troops would be sent to Sri Lanka, where at least 120 people have been killed in the last week in fighting between ethnic Tamil groups.

title: Senate Panel Acts to Cut Rights Unit's Funds
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to reduce financing for the United States Civil Rights Commission and placed numerous restrictions on how the commission can spend its money.

title: M.T.A. BOARD REJECTS BAN ON SMOKING ON RAIL LINES
description: Despite the plea of its chairman, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority refused yesterday to ban smoking on the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North.

title: Photos of Rare Fish May Be Clue to Evolution
description: Primitive fish once believed to have died out long before the demise of the dinosaurs have been photographed in their deep ocean habitat for the first time.

title: 'Call . . . for . . . James D. Phelan'
description: Poor Philip Morris. The cigarette company that once was proud to be paged in radio commercials now dares not speak its name.

title: Tenneco Unit Sale To Castle & Cooke
description: In a move to broaden its line of foods and to bolster its holdings in California real estate, Castle & Cooke Inc. said it would acquire substantially all of the operations of Tenneco West Inc., a subsidiary of Tenneco Inc. of Houston, for $236 million in cash and debt.

title: Harris Denies Plessey Report
description: The Harris Corporation broke its silence yesterday about reports that Plessey P.L.C. was trying to acquire the Florida-based semiconductor and communications equipment company, denying that it had been engaged in any negotiations with the British electronics maker.

title: WHEN TO CALL THE DOCTOR
description: In his Shea Stadium office, Davey Johnson stared at the Mets schedule on the wall next to his desk. Ever since the National League schedule was announced last winter, baseball romantics have anticipated that the National League East title would be decided on the last weekend of the season - Mets at St. Louis on Oct. 2, 3, 4.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ECONOMICS IN PERSPECTIVE. A Critical History. By John Kenneth Galbraith. 324 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $19.95.

title: Dow Chemical To Get Lamaur
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that it had agreed to buy Lamaur Inc., the hair-care products company, for $28.50 a share, or about $174 million.

Music: Sister Carol, Jamaica Rap
description: TOASTING, the Jamaican equivalent of rapping, was a formative influence on American rap and hip-hop music. And Jamaican artists like Sister Carol, who was at S.O.B.'s on Tuesday evening, could still teach American rappers a thing or two about rhythmic fluidity and about combining chanted rhyming with the structured melodic ''hooks'' of pop music.

title: Moscow Joins the Helsinki Watch
description: What a switch: now it's the Soviet Union protesting human rights offenses in the United States! And it does so with such zeal that Governor Cuomo of New York, visiting Moscow, must struggle to extricate himself from endorsing a tricky Soviet proposal for a human rights conference.

title: Leo Polk, Donor Rated No. 1 By U.S. Blood Group, Is Dead
description: Leo Polk, the most prolific blood donor on record in the United States, died Tuesday of cancer. He was 79.

title: Cuomo and 22 Soviet Dissidents Celebrate Jewish New Year
description: Governor Cuomo of New York celebrated Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish new year, with 22 Soviet dissidents tonight, praising their courage and calling them a symbol of how much human rights need to be improved here.

title: L.I. Schools Revise Tests For Drugs
description: The Patchogue-Medford school district, whose drug-testing program for probationary teachers was struck down three months ago by the state's highest court, plans to test all new job applicants, including school volunteers.

title: Tremors Shake Ecuador City
description: Three tremors shook the Pacific port of Manta early today, awakening residents but causing no casualties or damage, witnesses said.

title: For Every Light, a Bulb
description: JUDI BROOKS'S grandfather owned an electrical-supply store in Manhattan, where he sold what Miss Brooks described as ''basic, boring bulbs.'' Miss Brooks's mother, Shirley, worked at the shop until she came up with the idea of a store that sold light bulbs only.

title: Canadians Walk Out At U.S. Trade Talks
description: Canadian trade negotiators walked out of talks with their American counterparts today, declaring that efforts to agree on a free-trade pact between the United States and Canada had reached an impasse.

title: Poll Finds Public Opposition to Bork Is Growing
description: A growing number of Americans are expressing an unfavorable opinion of Judge Robert H. Bork after his weeklong testimony at Senate hearings on his nomination to the Supreme Court, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Jordan Plans to Revive Its Relations With Libya
description: Jordan decided today to restore diplomatic relations with Libya, broken since crowds burned down the Jordanian Embassy in Tripoli in February 1984, the official press agency, Petra, reported.

title: HERBERT G. AHREND
description: Herbert G. Ahrend, president of Ahrend Associates, a direct-marketing advertising agency he founded 50 years ago, died of cancer last Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: House Speaker Reported to Receive Unusually High Book Royalty
description: House Speaker Jim Wright has received royalty payments of nearly 55 percent from the sale of his most recent book, a rate that is far higher than usual, an official close to the Speaker said today. The book was published by a company that was paid $265,000 for services to Mr. Wright's election campaign last year, the official added.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm angry at myself for having been put in the position -put myself in the position - of having to make this choice.'' Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. [ A1:1. ]

Talks Resume Negotiators for National Football League owners and the striking players met in Philadelphia in an effort to settle the walkout. Page B7.

title: Henry Ford on Dialysis
description: The condition of Henry Ford 2d, who is suffering from pneumonia, has been reclassified from serious to very serious, and he has been put on a kidney dialysis machine, Dr. Bruce Steinhauer, his family physician, said tonight. Mr. Ford, 70 years old, has been in the hospital more than two weeks.

title: Inflation Growth Hurts Bonds
description: Bond prices slipped a bit yesterday as credit market participants were disappointed by a larger-than-expected rise in consumer prices for August and a decline by the dollar against the yen.

title: HERS
description: LIFE is simpler when you think you have no choices. There are no big decisions, no risk of self-recrimination, no anguish over making a mistake. How can you be responsible for making a mistake when you have no choice?

title: Report Urges Goetz Receive No Jail Time
description: A defense attorney for Bernhard H. Goetz said yesterday that the New York City Department of Probation had recommended a sentence of no jail time for his client, who was convicted in June of a felony gun charge but cleared in the 1984 shooting of four teen-agers.

title: The Video Camera, A Useful Aid
description: CONSIDERING that in recent months I have come home from impulsive shopping trips with a second personal computer, a microwave oven, a VCR and a television whose screen dramatically dwarfs any I have owned previously, my wife may be right. The obsession with electronic gadgetry that marks the onset of middle age for many American men has me in its clutches. But I plan not to go overboard. I vowed the day I got the microwave never to be tempted by a talking bathroom scale - or a portable video camera.

title: CONGRESS CLEARS A NEW MECHANISM TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: The Senate today approved and sent to the White House a new enforcement mechanism for the budget-balancing law, setting the stage for a confrontation with President Reagan over proposed tax increases.

title: Traces of Dioxin Found in Range Of Paper Goods
description: Traces of the toxic chemical dioxin have been found in a wide range of paper products, industry officials said today.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: DRAFTY windows rob heat from homes. One cure is to seal them with weatherstripping, usually a quick and easy task. Often the most difficult part is choosing the right product from the array at the hardware store.

title: Baseball Notebook; PLAYOFF SCHEDULE IS PERFECT FOR THE TWINS
description: Fortunately for the Minnesota Twins, the American League playoff schedule gives the Western Division winner four games at home and only three on the road. If the schedule were reversed, the Twins would be in trouble.

title: Sickle Cell Defect Tied to Death Risk In Extreme Exercise
description: Healthy young men with the sickle cell trait face about 40 times the usual risk of dying in extreme physical exercise, a military study has concluded.

title: Stein Says City Has Bungled Foster-Care Program
description: City Council President Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday that New York City is mismanaging a new program to screen relatives who take in children eligible for foster care, depriving hundreds of families of foster-care stipends, Medicaid and other services.

title: TOP STATE COURT BARS AN APPEAL OF BIAS RULING
description: New York State's top court declined yesterday to interfere with a ruling by the judge in the Howard Beach murder trial that would restrict the defense lawyers' challenges against potential black jurors.

title: N.A.S.D. Plans Placement Net
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday that it would develop an automated system for private placements. Joseph R. Hardiman, the new president of the N.A.S.D., said such a system could be in operation by 1989.

description: When former Representative Bob Edgar appeared as a stand-in for Senator Paul Simon at a breakfast last month for Democratic Presidential hopefuls, some in the audience may have wondered who was the candidate.

description: The Devils have had the youngest group of goaltenders in the league since they moved to New Jersey six years ago, but this is the first year they have had a goaltending coach.

description: To all but the most dedicated participants and observers, the second week of hearings on Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court is passing in a bit of a blur.

title: Concert: Vienna Orchestra
description: THERE are not many composers around these days who can persuade the world's brand-name orchestras to play their works. Leonard Bernstein is among the fortunate few, a circumstance traceable to some extent to the fact that he is not only a writer of music but also one of the world's brand-name conductors. Mr. Bernstein, who in that respect stands in the great tradition of such composer-maestros as Liszt, Wagner and Mahler, led the Vienna Philharmonic last evening at Carnegie Hall in a splendid and all but convincing performance of his youthful Symphony No. 1, entitled ''Jeremiah.''

title: Cards Win on 2-Run 9th
description: Lance Johnson's bases-loaded force-play grounder scored Willie McGee with the second run of the ninth inning as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-2, tonight.

title: TV Weekend; 'Beauty and the Beast,' on CBS
description: DESCRIBED as a contemporary fable, the new weekly series ''Beauty and the Beast'' opens - tonight at 10 on CBS - with the line ''Once upon a time, in the city of New York . . .'' Loud groaning will no doubt be heard from legions of whimsy haters across the nation. But don't change that dial. As far as premiere episodes are concerned, ''Beauty and the Beast'' turns out to be the most fascinating show of the new season. Reverting to a classic ''transformation myth,'' the story actually manages to touch on some unsettling contemporary realities. In prime-time entertainment, that is not just rare, it's courageous.

title: AFG Canada Unit To Buy Ford Glass
description: AFG Industries, having failed in takeover bids for Lear Siegler Inc. and Gencorp Inc. in 1986, said its Canadian subsidiary, AFG Glass Inc., had signed a definitive agreement to buy Ford Glass Ltd. Ford Glass is a nonautomotive glass subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company.

title: Bob Fosse, a Stylish 'Original,' Is Remembered by His Peers
description: Bob Fosse, the choreographer and director who died of a heart attack Wednesday night in Washington, probably would not have been surprised at the way he was remembered by some of the people he'd worked with during more than three decades on Broadway and in Hollywood. He had, after all, painted a complex and not always flattering self-portrait in his 1979 film ''All That Jazz,'' and his own verdict was upheld yesterday by a court of his peers.

title: European Prices Up
description: Prices in the European Community rose slightly in the holiday months of July and August, which is typical for that time of year, the community's statistics office reported today. Prices rose by a modest one-tenth of 1 percent in July and by two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the office said. The annual inflation rate crept up to 3.4 percent in the two-month period, compared with 3.2 percent in June.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sanchez Advances: Fourth-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain defeated Luiz Mattar of Brazil, 6-1, 7-6, 7-5, yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the Count of Godo tournament at the Royal Tennis Club in Barcelona. In other matches, Tomas Carbonell of Spain defeated Claude Mezzadri of Switzerland, 6-4, 1-6, 9-7; Martin Jaite of Argentina beat Ricki Osterthun of West Germany, 6-3, 6-3, and Eduardo Bengoechea of Argentina defeated Marian Vajda of Czechoslovakia, 7-5, 6-3.(AP) Gilbert Gains: Second-seeded Brad Gilbert defeated Kelly Evernden, 6-3, 7-6, last night to move into the quarterfinals of the Volvo Tennis-Los Angeles tournament. Gilbert's victory came after Andre Agassi knocked fifth-seeded Guy Forget of France out of the tournament with a 6-3, 7-6 second-round victory. Tim Wilkison of Asheville, N.C., and Paul Annacone of Knoxville, Tenn., also moved into the quarterfinals with victories yesterday. Wilkison scored a 6-4, 6-4 victory over qualifier Gary Muller of South Africa, and Annacone overcame a slow start to down Derrick Rostago of Los Angeles, 6-2, 7-6. The tournament at the Los Angeles Tennis Center continues today with quarterfinal matches. Semifinals are scheduled for tomorrow with the final set for Sunday.(AP) GOLF Eastwood in Lead: Bob Eastwood, who said he came to Texas largely to hunt dove, shot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday to take a one-shot lead after the first round of the $400,000 Southwest Golf Classic in Abilene, Tex. ''Golf just gets in the way of my hunting,'' Eastwood said after his bogey-free round over the Fairway Oaks course, a 7,189-yard layout that is treacherous when the wind blows. Daily dove hunts are part of the Southwest Classic allure, along with a $72,000 top prize. Dan Forsman, Don Halldorson, Bob Lohr, Frank Connor and Bob Lunn shot 66. Lunn, 42 years old, a six-time winner who dropped off the PGA Tour in 1979 because he was playing so poorly, called his 66 the ''best competitive round I've had in years.''

title: Art: Objects and Fabric Paintings by Blinky Palermo
description: BLINKY PALERMO was a purist, but a liberated, freewheeling purist. The work of this West German painter, who died in 1977 at the age of 34, is intriguing for its suggestion that geometric abstraction can be made out of anything, provided it is properly considered and presented. One of the best paintings among the 14 to be seen at Sperone Westwater is from Mr. Palermo's ''Stoffbild'' (or material painting) series of the late 60's. Mr. Palermo made it by simply sewing together two widths of solid-colored fabric (a narrow band of aqua blue and a much wider one of true blue) and affixing the resulting square to stretcher bars whose thinness balanced that of the cloth. The blue against blue field suggests a thoroughly distilled Mediterranean landscape, but it is also, primarily, a glowing optical unit that is recognizably a painting but that does not disguise the everyday quality of its origins.

title: Matt Dillon in 'The Big Town'
description: IT'S the great American theme: a small-town boy seeks his fortune in the big city. In this case he's the best crapshooter at the local garage and he heads off to ''The Big Town'' of Chicago in 1957, where he makes a pile of money and has to choose between two women: a married stripper and an unmarried mother with a heart of gold. So it's not Horatio Alger. More to the point, this huge cliche of a movie isn't even a distant relation of films like ''The Color of Money,'' which can actually make you root for hustlers. ''The Big Town'' only proves we've gone back to the 1950's one time too many.

Clemson and Stanford last year received $900,000.50 each, a record payout to Gator Bowl teams. That was fifth among all bowls last season. Bell said the increase would make the Gator Bowl the highest-paying bowl game that is not played on New Years's Day.

description: AS this schizophrenic film begins, a dark-haired, intense New York actor, deeply entrenched in Robert De Niro worship, sits in an old movie theater watching ''Taxi Driver.'' Bronson Green (Jim Youngs) sees himself stepping into the De Niro role as the obsessed, violent Travis Bickle, and Mr. Youngs gets to live out every young actor's fantasy. He looks the camera in the eye and jeers, ''You talkin' to me? You talkin' to me?'' Let's just say Robert De Niro does it better.

title: Dayton Hudson
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation's board will meet within a week to consider a $6 billion takeover offer from the Dart Group Corporation, reports on Wall Street said. A spokesman for Dayton Hudson, a Minneapolis-based retailer, would not comment other than to say the board would meet ''in due course.'' Rumors of dissension among the company's managers about the $65-a-share bid circulated Wednesday when the president, Boake A. Sells, announced his resignation. Mr. Sells said he would join another retailer in which he would have an equity stake. Dayton Hudson's shares lost $1.375, to $57.875, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: Brighter Prospect
description: Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois signed legislation yesterday that clears the way for night baseball at Wrigley Field for World Series, National League championship and All-Star games. Wrigley Field, built in 1914 and home of the Chicago Cubs since 1916, is the only major league ball park without lights. A Chicago regulation barring night games at the ballpark remained in effect, but there wasn't any chance of postseason play there this year anyway since the Cubs were in last place in the National League East. ''My approval . . . removes the problem of meeting network television demands for nighttime playoff and All-Star games at Wrigley Field in the future,'' Thompson said. The bill, which will take effect immediately, exempts postseason and All-Star play from the Chicago Pollution Control Board rules banning lights at the park by amending the state's Environmental Protection Act.

title: Dillard Indicted
description: Norman (Skip) Dillard, a former star guard on the basketball team at DePaul University, was indicted yesterday on 15 counts of armed robbbery by a Cook County grand jury in Chicago. The 27-year-old Dillard, who averaged 12.6 points while playing for the Blue Demons from 1979 to 1982, is accused of robbing 15 filling stations in Chicago during July, August and September. The police say that Dillard was identified in lineups by several witnesses or robbery victims. Dillard, who is being held in Cook County Jail on $340,000 bond, was arrested at his home on Sept. 10 after a motorist followed his car there from the scene of a robbery. If convicted on all counts, Dillard could draw a sentence of 90 to 450 years in prison.

title: Dining Out Guide; Pre-Theater
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CHEZ NAPOLEON, #365 West 50th Street (265-6980) - *(Nov. 18, 1983) Just west of Eighth Avenue is this French bistro in two tiny pleasantly seedy dining rooms with a kitchen that offers some enjoyable bourgeois cooking. The best starters are the traditional ones: moules marinieres in a creamy, garlicky, slightly peppery sauce; well-seasoned chunky pate, and onion soup made with deep rich stock brimming over with onions and cheese. Main-dish choices include blood sausage; frogs' legs laced with garlic, and bouillabaisse made with four different fish, lobster, clams and mussels. Dinner entrees $10 to $18. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. JEZEBEL, #630 Ninth Avenue, at 45th Street (582-1045) - **(Aug. 28, 1987) The intriguing setting for this soul-food restaurant is a cross between a leafy nightclub and a vintage clothing boutique with assorted foliage, multicolored shawls hanging from ceiling pipes and a potpourri of Oriental rugs and vintage posters. There are two seatings nightly, and if you have theater tickets, they make a point of getting you out on time. To start, you might choose smothered garlic shrimp in a zesty red sauce; rib bits, which are morsels of sweetly coated pork ribs, or Charleston she-crab soup. Entrees are generous and include a fine fried chicken, succulent and mildly peppery with collard greens; chicken waffles, roasted chicken under pan-dripping gravy with golden waffles and butter, as well as curried goat in a brassy sauce with cayenne pepper with rice, beans and collard greens. Entrees $13.75 to $18.75. Fridays and Saturdays, 6 to 11:45 P.M.; closed Sundays. LATTANZI, #361 West 46th Street (315-0980) - *(Sept. 14, 1984) Exposed brick walls and small hanging varicolored lights provide the decor for this pleasant, simply decorated restaurant in the heart of the theater district. You might start with carciofo alla Giudea, which is baby artichoke in olive oil and garlic; tortellini, in appetizer portion, in a zesty tomato sauce, or cappellini primavera, with perfectly cooked vegetables. For a main dish, options include veal with mushrooms broiled with the flavor of sage; osso bucco, a special; scampi with garlic and wine, and browned nuggets of chicken in a creamy, lightly spiced tomato sauce. Entrees $13.95 to $21.95. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays, 5 P.M. to midnight; closed Sundays. RUSSIAN SAMOVAR, #256 West 52d Street (757-0168) - *(March 6, 1987) This understated and moderately priced restaurant in the theater district has well-spaced tables with long banquettes and walls covered with straw-colored fabric. The kitchen offers a standard repertory of Russian dishes, and if you are in the mood for a jolt of good vodka and perhaps a plate of grilled lamb or seafood, this is a good place to go. You might begin with eggplant Samovar, grilled eggplant sprinkled with coriander and ground walnuts, or spicy Georgian dried beef rubbed with hot paprika with cucumber-and-onion salad in yogurt. The best main dishes are karski shashlik, which is marinated lamb chops with cabbage salad; salmon shashlik, cubes of salmon in a light white wine sauce with dill potatoes and onions; grilled and deboned Cornish hen, and chicken Kiev. Pre-theater dinner $19.95; entrees $11.95 to 18.95. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 5 P.M. to midnight. What the stars mean, page C28.
