description: From the shore of this town west of Leningrad, a sand and earthen breakwater stretches across the Gulf of Finland to within a mile of the other side.

title: CUBA, 20 YEARS LATER
description: From a long-range historical viewpoint, the participants at the ''Class Reunion'' appear to have missed the lasting impact of the Cuban missile crisis. For the first time, the United States was bound not to militarily intervene in the affairs of a country in the Western Hemisphere. Considering United States military participation in Cuba on four previous occasions, this was a result of great significance. Given the United States propensity for military intervention in the region (in Nicaragua, for example, even prior to the present contra war), the resolution of the missile crisis represented a historic event for countries of this Hemisphere attempting to avoid Yankee domination. JONATHAN W. LUBELL New York, N.Y.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a cultured marble bathroom sink that has turned green all around the drain -apparently from the minerals in the water. I have tried everything I can think of to get this green stain off. What can you suggest?

description: LEAD: LONG ISLANDERS take back-to-school night about as casually as the British take a command performance.

title: Drug Smugglers Die in Iran
description: Ten drug smugglers have been executed in Iran, the Teheran radio reported today. The broadcast said four people were put to death in Teheran and six in other cities. It did not say what drug was involved or when the executions occurred.

title: IN ERITREA
description: ON THE WALL OF EVERY mud-brick clinic in Eritrea I saw the same poster. It shows two children, one suffering from starvation, the other from the protein-deficiency syndrome called kwashiorkor, which creates the characteristic pot-bellied look of the victim of famine. The writing on this ubiquitous poster was usually in Tigrinya or Tigre, the major languages of Eritrea, a land situated along the Red Sea coast of what is now Ethiopia. Throughout Eritrea there is a strong, even a biblical sense of famine waiting like a bandit in the next valley, or around the corner in the next erratic rainy season.

title: U.S. FUNDS FOR HOMELESS EXPECTED BY STATE
description: NEW JERSEY is expected to receive $10 million to $20 million in Federal funds for the homeless under a law that goes into effect Thursday. The law, the Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Act, was signed by President Reagan last month; it provides $550 million nationwide for dealing with problems related to homelessness.

title: Q AND A

Would the same rules apply for a loft with interim multiple-dwelling tenants? . . . S. He added, however, that they do have some flexibility in the matter.

title: Tips for Buying Indonesian Artwork
description: Indonesia consists of 13,677 islands scattered over equatorial seas. From east to west, the archipelago stretches 3,200 miles across trade routes once so important that the struggle for their possession shaped world history. North America was discovered by Columbus as he sought a westerly route to the spice islands, the Moluccas, just east of Java, Indonesia's principal island.

title: Newmont Faces Off Against Pickens
description: T. Boone Pickens and Newmont Mining locked horns and began a rough fight for control, with Newmont enlisting the help of its biggest shareholder, Gold Fields of London. In an attempt to thwart Mr. Pickens, Newmont announced a special $33-a-share dividend to current stockholders in hopes that they would not accept Mr. Pickens's $105-a-share tender offer. That will cost Newmont $2.2 billion, $220 million of which will go to Mr. Pickens, who holds about 10 percent of Newmont. But Newmont also gave permission for Gold Fields to buy up to 50 percent of the company. When Mr. Pickens sued to block the move, Gold Fields rushed to the market and spent $1.5 billion on Newmont stock - a record for the Big Board - before a judge could rule on Mr. Pickens's request. The judge refused to void the sale, but did bar Gold Fields from buying more than the 49.67 percent of Newmont that it already had. A Delaware court is considering whether to uphold those decisions, and if it does, a defeat of Mr. Pickens is a virtual certainty.

description: BY all the rules of economics, Donna Van Name should be back in the work force. In prospering Boston, jobs go begging, particularly the sort of clerical work that Ms. Van Name did for the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company until her second son, Michael, was born in 1985.

title: Braves Put Giants' Drive on Hold
description: Dion James started a six-run sixth inning with a base hit and capped it with a two-run single as the Atlanta Braves defeated San Francisco, 10-5, tonight and prevented the Giants from clinching a tie for the National League West title.

title: IN SHORT
description: REMINISCENCES ABOUT A GREAT PHYSICIST: Paul Adrien Maurice Dirac. Edited by Behram N. Kursunoglu and Eugene P. Wigner. (Cambridge University, $49.50.) This 23-piece festschrift has the home-movie quality sometimes found in collections of personal and professional hommage prepared by academics to honor colleagues. It is also full of tough equations. But it has plenty of lovely stories which project a picture of Paul Dirac and what one contributor calls his ''creative elegance.'' Convinced that there is symmetry between mathematics and nature, Dirac at the age of 28 to posited the existence of antimatter. His theory, which laid the foundation for quantum electrodynamics, won him the Nobel Prize in Physics five years later, in 1933.As to those lovely stories, most involve both Dirac's reticence - rooted, it is said, in his domineering father's insistence on being spoken to in French - and his quality of mind. One related by several contributors concerns dinner with E. M. Forster. Dirac asks Forster what really happened in the cave in Forster's novel, ''Passage to India'' and Forster's answer varies in different versions. In a chapter called ''Some thought Dirac odd,'' Rudolph Peierls of Oxford says Dirac asked: ''Could there not have been a third person in the cave?'' ''Absolutely not,'' Forster replied. ''As usual,'' says Mr. Peierls, ''Dirac had thought of an interesting possibility which had occured to nobody else.''

title: Kickoff Return Sets Up Rutgers Victory
description: A 94-yard kickoff return by Brian Cobb late in the third quarter tonight set up the winning touchdown for Rutgers, which defeated Kentucky, 19-18, at Giants Stadium.

title: MARYBETH MENK BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Mary Elizabeth Menk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Menk of Summit and Normandy Beach, N.J., was married yesterday to William Kenneth Mendenhall 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mendenhall Jr. of London. The Rev. John Halborg performed the ceremony.

title: A 'Festive' Center: Eyesore No More
description: The old A.&P. building at South Riverside Avenue and Maple Street in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., empty for several years, has returned as a shopping center under the name of Croton Commons.

title: 'FATAL ATTRACTION': SLICKNESS AS ART
description: WITHOUT SPOILING ANY OF the thrills in Adrian Lyne's new thriller, it's possible to discuss the sequence in ''Fatal Attraction'' that finds a mother suddenly separated from her child. The mother has reason to suspect that her daughter may be in jeopardy, and so she is seen searching frantically for the little girl. Now, this ought to be enough: the mother's anxiety is the foremost emotion on anyone's mind. But Mr. Lyne also intercuts glimpses of the little girl's whereabouts. In a different sort of film, those glimpses would destroy any possibility of suspense.

title:
INVESTING;
Little Help From Dr. Ruth
description: LEAD: TWO years ago, when Dr. Ruth Westheimer was winning fame as a television sex adviser, Monarch Avalon Inc., a small Baltimore company, enjoyed a few months of reflected glory in the stock market. On the strength of Dr. Ruth's Game of Good Sex, a microcomputer game for adults, Monarch Avalon's thinly traded shares surged to $13.50, from about $2, in over-the-counter trading.

description: Tie Me Vanderbilt Down The stars may soon be inside and outside the Vanderbilt Museum in Centerport. While the planetarium continues its heavenly shows, the mansion may soon be host to its own set of stars: the cast of ''Crocodile Dundee II.''

title: Horszowski's Quiet, Elegant Pianism
description: ALL THINGS COME TO THOSE WHO wait, and few have been more patient than Mieczyslaw Horszowski. Through his first half-century of concertizing - Mr. Horszowski made his debut in Vienna in 1902 - prevailing tastes favored flashier, more virtuosic performers, and he settled into a career just beyond the spotlight. Now that his quiet and elegant brand of playing has found more general favor, Mr. Horszowski is enjoying a late flowering of attention, marked most recently by the release of a recording featuring works by Mozart, Chopin, Debussy and Beethoven (Nonesuch 791600-2 CD). At the improbable, astonishing age of 95, the Polish-born pianist (who, incidentally, married for the first time six years ago) is achieving long-deserved recognition.

Wouldn't it be fun to follow the Arnold Trail, the route the traitor-to-be took through Maine on his expedition to Quebec?

title: American Architecture And How It Grew
description: AT THIS RATE, ARCHITECTURE may replace Monday night football on television. A year-and-a-half ago we had ''Pride of Place,'' the splashy, eight-part series about American buildings, and tomorrow evening begins ''America by Design,'' a completely new series that will consist of five one-hour shows on all phases of the American landscape. (It will be shown on Mondays at 11 P.M. on WNET/Channel 13, and at 8 P.M. on other PBS stations around the country.) Whatever else can be said about the new arrival, it further confirms what last year's series made clear - that the public no longer considers architecture an irrelevant or academic discipline, but a subject of wide appeal.

title: Kemp's Solution

Kemp, a New York Republican, was a founder of the players association in the old American Football League, and his son, Jeff, is a reserve quarterback for the Seattle Seahawks. Kemp, who played quarterback with the San Diego Chargers and the Buffalo Bills from 1960 to 1970, suggested that negotiators lock themselves in a room and not come out until they have a contract and can resume the season. ''They ought to do it in the family,'' he said, ''they shouldn't go to the Federal mediation service. I'm not speaking officially because I do not know all of the various aspects of it. With a 31-0 drubbing of hapless Irvington High School in its season opener today, Union was well on its way toward being a symbol of excellence in New Jersey again this year.

title: IN SHORT
description: THE URBAN NATURALIST. By Steven D. Garber. Illustrated by Jerome Lo. (John Wiley, Paper, $12.95.) The author, a biologist formerly with the New York City Parks Department, is struggling for survival with such tough established species as John Kieran's ''Natural History of New York City.'' No fear, there is a niche for ''The Urban Naturalist.'' As well as describing (with the help of Jerome Lo's rather sketchy illustrations) a lot of plants and animals that manage to inhabit American cities, Mr. Garber addresses the environmental pressures and opportunities that make them do so. Many of these cases are familiar; for instance the pigeon, which nests on the ledges of metropolitan cliffs and prospers on a diet of baked goods. Some are less so, like the snapping turtle, which survives in any kind of water and lays eggs near park ponds at night. Generous in his sympathies, Mr. Garber admires the unconquerable ailanthus: ''When in seed, some of these trees are absolutely stunning. . . . More power to them.'' There are mysteries in the urban ecology; we see that ''some plants thrive on disturbed soils when just a few miles out of town these species are virtually nonexistent.'' I am grateful to the author for his sections on lowly urban plants, too often neglected by city naturalists for noble creatures like the peregrine falcon. The common reed Phragmites and the purple loosestrife are moving in on us, with consequences to our soggier soils we cannot now guess. Fortunately the loosestrife is beautiful and the reed edible (Mr. Garber tells us how). I wish he had included the pokeweed, which abounds in these parts and furnishes fine salads in the spring. But I'm glad he omits fungi; the fewer people who know which New York City mushrooms to eat, the better for me.

title: JANE R. COXE, SECURITIES ANALYST, WED TO BERTRAM LIPPINCOTT 3D, A HISTORIAN
description: The marriage of Jane Redman Coxe, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Travis Coxe of West Chester Pa., and Jamestown, R.I., to Bertram Lippincott 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lippincott Jr. of New York and Jamestown, took place yesterday at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Jamestown. The Rev. Frederick J. Spulnik performed the ceremony.

title: HOT STUFF FROM PARIS
description: IT'S LIKE DEALING IN MARKED MONEY. BUT AT THIS price level, probably no one will care. Couture, or made-to-order, clothes cost a lot - $10,000 and up is the current range. Yet the leading Paris couturiers are having a good season this fall, and it's not by being sedate. Not only have they presented provokingly dramatic evening silhouettes, but they often have rendered them in opulent fabrics of startling hues. The results are pretty special. The privileged woman who springs for one of these knows she is purchasing something that is almost stamped Paris, fall 1987. But no matter. A beautiful dress is a beautiful dress forever - or at least as long as its fashion message holds out. And that's the real point of this colorful combustion from Paris. It will inspire designers and manufacturers in other places and in considerably lower - and lower still - price ranges to fuel up their future evening fashions with blasts of brilliant color, pushing basic black into a back place, at least for a while.

Feerick as the new chairman of his Commission on Government Integrity, it was clear that he had not exactly heeded suggestions that he find someone with the same name recognition and headline-generating capacity as his original choice, Joseph A. Califano Jr. The 51-year-old Mr. Feerick, the dean of Fordham University School of Law in Manhattan, is highly respected in legal circles, and has drawn praise as a labor arbitrator in many tense situations, including disputes at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.

The Canada geese have come again to feed in the thousands of acres of recently harvested cornfields, a rolling landscape of brown stubble. The little coves and back creeks and farm ponds are full of pintails and mallards and canvasback ducks.

title: THE WORM AND THE APPLE: Dirt and Delay; Environment for Trouble
description: New York City's Environmental Control Board collects fines on the half-million tickets issued each year by other city departments for quality-of-life offenses. They cover a range - air and noise pollution, littering, ignoring the pooper-scooper law. Since 1979, audits and investigations have exposed problems of management at the agency, and a disturbing study just released confirms them once again. Yet Mayor Koch continues to ignore the warnings. For that he deserves a worm.

description: ''There is a mystique that Fifth Avenue has had and always will have,'' said Neil H. Siderow, president of Murray Hill Properties, ''and there's no reason for it to stop at 42d Street.''

title: Accountants Try to Put a Little Kick in Their Image
description: LIKE many of his number-crunching brethren, Robert Mead of Louisville, Ky., was proud to be an accountant. Very proud. In fact, as one of eight candidates running for state treasurer in the Democratic primary this May, he wanted every voter to know he was a C.P.A. Unfortunately for him, all references to professional pedigrees are forbidden on the Kentucky ballot. So Mr. Mead changed his legal name to Robert Mead C.P.A. He - Mr. C.P.A., that is - won in a landslide. The electoral triumph is good news for C.P.A.'s, but it doesn't exactly establish a precedent many will follow. While pleased with their reputation for probity, some accountants around the nation are interested in changing other aspects of their stereotypical image. And they seized on the 100th anniversary of the founding of the American Institute for Certified Public Accountants (A.I.C.P.A.), celebrated in New York this week, as an occasion for making improvements.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Hockey Rangers Top Whalers: Brian Mullen scored twice, Tomas Sandstrom collected a goal and two assists and Steve Nemeth added three assists to spark New York's 5-3 exhibition victory over the Whalers last night in Hartford. Mullen's second goal at 1 minute 32 seconds snapped a 2-2 tie and began a three-goal run by New York in the second period. Sandstrom followed at 3:22 to give the Rangers a 4-2 lead and Stu Kulak connected off feeds from Nemeth and Walt Poddubny at 16:41 to make it 5-2.(AP) Islanders Win Penalty-Marred Game: Bryan Trottier registered three goals and one assist, his first points of the exhibition schedule, to lead the Islanders to an 8-1 rout of the Philadelphia Flyers last night at Nassau Coliseum. The game was marred by penalties as 149 minutes were charged to both teams, including 38 when they got involved in a brawl with one second to play in the second period. Five game misconduct penalties also were assessed as a result of the same melee. Golf Inkster Takes Lead: Juli Inkster, seeking her first LPGA victory of the year, fired a 5-under-par 67 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after two rounds of the $300,000 San Jose Classic. Inkster, a San Jose State graduate, who had five birdies and no bogeys. She was at 6-under 138 after 36 holes. She held a one-stroke lead over the first-round leader, Missie Berteotti, who had a 71. (AP) Edwards Moves Into First Place: David Edwards tamed the gusty, tricky Texas winds with a 7-under-par 65 yesterday to take the third-round lead in the $400,000 Southwest Golf Classic. The former Oklahoma State star came from five shots off the pace to take a 1-stroke edge with a 30-foot birdie putt on the final hole. His 65 gave him a 54-hole total of 202, 14 under par on the windswept Fairway Oaks Golf and Racquet Club. Edwards was a shot ahead of Hale Irwin, who also shot a 65, and Bob Eastwood, the first-round leader who had a 69.(AP) Tennis Wilander Reaches Final: Top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden defeated Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, 6-3, 6-0, yesterday to advance to the final of the $293,000 Count of Godo tournament at the Royal Tennis Club in Barcelona, Spain. Wilander will face Martin Jaite of Argentina, who beat a countryman, Eduardo Bengoechea, 6-2, 6-4, in the other semifinal. Wilander's consistent shots and accuracy seemed to frustrate the ninth-seeded Perez-Roldan.(AP) West German Women Advance: Top-seeded Steffi Graff and Isabel Cueto, both of West Germany, advanced yesterday to the singles final of a Virginia Slims tournament in Hamberg, West Germany. Graf beat Sandra Cecchini of Italy 6-0, 6-2 and Cueto downed American Kathy Horvath 6-4, 0-6, 6-2.(AP)

title: IN SHORT
description: NUCLEAR IMPERATIVES AND PUBLIC TRUST: Dealing With Radioactive Waste. By Luther J. Carter. (Resources for the Future/Johns Hopkins University, $25.) The problem of stemming the global flood of garbage is increasingly intractable. When the refuse in question consists of waste from nuclear reactors, it threatens the lives and welfare of our descendants millenniums hence. Luther J. Carter, a science reporter formerly with Science magazine, spent eight years in the investigation that led to this book. In spare, fact-laden prose, he traces the roots of the radioactive-waste dilemma and calls for an urgent halt to 30 years of governmental dithering. Not only does he outline solutions for the disposal of spent reactor fuel that seem practical and effective, but his treatment of the subject is refreshingly free of the partisanship that generally clouds public discussions of nuclear power. Even if the United States were never to build another reactor, he reports, this country will have accumulated 41,500 tons of high-level radioactive waste by the year 2000. Nuclear power will not disappear, at least not quickly, he says, so the real issue is to make it safer. He concludes that the best way to dispose of nuclear waste is by deep burial, and he believes that entombment within Yucca Mountain, Nevada, one of the sites under consideration by the Department of Energy, would present the fewest problems. Objections by people living near a disposal site should be met, he says, not only by stringent safeguards against accidents, but also by remuneration; China, he reports, offered three years ago to accept and bury reactor waste from West Germany on payment to Peking of $1,512 per kilogram - surely one of the highest garbage disposal fees ever levied. .

Stocks of the previous year's dried and frozen supply are running low. In northern New Mexico the chile harvest is an autumn ritual that is a link to the earth and to the past. It draws sons and daughters who have moved away to Las Cruces or Albuquerque or Colorado to visit family and friends in the small hill towns north of Santa Fe to taste the season's first salsas and sauces. There are peppers other places, of course - jalapenos and poblanos, serranos and sandias, and the milder, long smooth varieties that are grown in southern New Mexico for commercial processing -but to the natives of northern New Mexico, the local chile has no rival.

title: On the Couch
description: Bernhard H. Goetz, who was charged with the attempted murder of four teen-agers he shot on a subway but was convicted only of possessing a weapon illegally, needs psychiatric care more than incarceration, according to the New York City Probation Department. In a report that was leaked to the press last week, the agency recommended that Mr. Goetz, who was convicted in June and could be imprisoned for up to seven years, undergo intensive psychiatric counseling instead. In a case with racial overtones, Mr. Goetz, who is white, said he shot the youths, who are black, because he feared they were about to rob him. Probation agency recommendations are usually secret, and Justice Stephen G. Crane, who is to sentence Mr. Goetz Oct. 7, ordered an investigation into how the report became public.

What we don't know, and sometimes can barely read, are all those peculiar words in fine print that sound as if they came straight out of a chemistry textbook.

title: Age No Hindrance
description: BOBBY RIGGS, noted tennis hustler, was at it again yesterday, although neither big money nor bragging rights were at stake. Riggs, 69 years old, faced Althea Gibson, age 60 and twice a Wimbledon singles champion, to open the Senior Games of New Jersey before a small crowd at Union College. ''I am trying to show other seniors they should stay active, keep busy and play in the senior events,'' said Riggs. ''It doesn't have to be the big state event of the Senior Olympics. Everybody should stay busy and keep active, and the years just seem to peel away. You don't feel them at all.'' Riggs won the match, 8-5, with an assortment of junk shots. Gibson had tied the match at 5-5 but then tired. Riggs won the next three games for the match, scheduled to end when one player won eight games. ''I don't want to make any excuses,'' said Gibson. ''I don't like to make excuses. I am just getting over the flu, and I'm under medication now. I just couldn't move. Then the wind played a big factor, too.''

title: Opera: Carlo Bergonzi in Met's 'Elisir d'Amore'

As Mr. Bergonzi acknowledged the extended ovation following ''Una Furtiva Lagrima,'' it became all the more puzzling that the Met could have abandoned him in favor of the pedestrian tenors who took his place.

title: Taming the Wild Mushroom

title: Driver Is Conscious

John White, a spokesman for Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis, said yesterday that Guerrero was still mildly disoriented. ''We still can't speculate on any length of stay or a prognosis,'' White said. Guerrero was injured Sept. 10 while testing tires at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. His car hit a wall and a tire struck his helmet. Guerrero finished second in the Indianapolis 500 this year.

title: Rail Passes

This summer I purchased mine in a small Swiss railway station that does not ordinarily carry it - they simply phoned to Lucerne, and in the afternoon it was delivered. It is available right away in all major Swiss rail stations.

title: Stunning Streak

He's got catching duties, he's calling pitches and he's trying to throw out runners. That's what makes it so amazing.'' Santiago, 22 years old, hit a single to left-center field in the fifth inning on an 0-2 pitch by Bob Welch of the Dodgers. That extended the National League's longest batting streak this season and broke the major league record for a rookie set by James Williams of the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1899 and equaled by Santiago on Friday night. In that game, Santiago lined an opposite-field single to right in the first inning off Tim Belcher to break the modern record for a rookie set by Guy Curtright of the Chicago White Sox in 1943. Santiago is batting .345 during the streak (40 for 116) and has raised his season average to .298. ''It's really exciting,'' Santiago said after Friday night's game. ''I'm a rookie, and when I put those kind of numbers up, I have to feel great.''

I am in the Vucciria, the central market of Palermo, which stretches, octopus-like, along perhaps a dozen streets in the center of the Sicilian capital. And speaking of octopus, at a wider crossroads I see a large stand set up, spread with empty plates and a pile of lemon quarters. Behind the broad counter, the proprietor is tending a huge cauldron of boiling water. At the proper moment he dips in a slotted spoon and fishes up, yes, an octopus, or a giant squid. He slams it on the counter, in an empty space, and with a huge knife, deftly chops it into sections and serves it. Waiting customers take the plates, squeeze lemon on the bits of tentacle or head, and greedily consume this peculiar breakfast.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: JOHN BOY AS 'HAMLET' Richard Thomas has come a long way from playing John Boy in ''The Waltons'' television series to his current role of ''Hamlet'' in the new production opening at the Hartford Stage Company Saturday through Nov. 7. The 36-year-old actor has grown a beard for the occasion and will wear a contemporary costume - as will the rest of the cast. Mark Lamos, Hartford Stage's director, has put the King in a military uniform and the Queen in clothes that might suit Nancy Reagan or Margaret Thatcher. ''Rosenkrantz and Guildenstern will have a 'Miami Vice' look,'' said the company public-relations representative, Howard Sherman, ''or something equally trendy that young men are wearing today.'' This interpretation of Shakespeare's classic will have no ramparts, crenelated towers, thrones, portieres or weighty silver goblets. The stage will be the set, with scaffolding and various implements of construction as the only furnishings. ''It will be a 1930's theater in the process of renovation,'' said Mr. Sherman. ''Some ordinary chairs will be scattered around.'' But the text will remain inviolate. Monique Fowler has the role of Ophelia; Richard Poe is the King; Pamela Payton-Wright plays the Queen, and Polonius is Robert Gerringer. Mr. Thomas has distinguished himself on Broadway in ''Fifth of July'' and ''The Front Page.'' Mr. Lamos returns to ''Hamlet'' after staging it in 1980 at the California Shakespearean Festival. Performances are scheduled at 7:30 P.M. Tuesday through Thursday, 8 P.M. Friday and Saturday, 2:30 and 7:30 P.M. Sunday and a 2 P.M. matinee on Wednesdays. Tickets are $22 Friday and Saturday and $16.50 for all other performances. Tickets for preview performances Saturday through Oct. 8 cost $11. The box office number is 525-5601.

Several members of Congress have offered bills that would restrict discrimination and guarantee the confidentiality of the results of tests for infection with the virus. But Reagan Administration officials told a Congressional subcommittee hearing last week that a new Federal law was not needed at this time because the states already had or were moving to adopt the necessary protections. A breed apart from their burly, rough-hewn cousins, the new tweeds are supple and polished in a way that belies their homespun origins. title: A Painter's Insights Into Body and Soul
description: IN MOUNTING THE FIRST ever American museum exhibition of paintings by Lucian Freud this month, the Hirshhorn Museum has taken a glorious risk, and one that does it great credit. Now 64, and a naturalized British citizen since 1939, Freud was born and raised in Berlin. When Hitler came to power in 1933, the family went to London as refugees. Freud has always been a difficult, disconcerting and resolutely private artist. He has never had, nor sought, a large constituency, either in this country or anywhere else. But in England he has been unmistakably there, as a disquieting and often worrisome presence, ever since April 1940, when a self-portrait drawing of him was reproduced in the third issue of ''Horizon,'' a monthly magazine edited by Cyril Connolly. In the London of that day, in which World War II seemed likely to take an ever more terrible turn, Freud at 17 and 18 began to be spoken of as the equivalent of Tadzio in Thomas Mann's ''Death in Venice'' -the magnetic adolescent who, to his admirer, seemed by his very presence to keep the plague at bay. In a city that was necessarily drab and was soon to become even more so, much was expected of Freud.

title: IN SHORT
description: THE WORLD OF PHYSICS: A Small Library of the Literature of Physics From Antiquity to the Present. Three Volumes. By Jefferson Hane Weaver. (Simon & Schuster, $29.95 each; boxed set, $90.) It is not always impossible for general readers to understand physicists; in fact, they can often be read with pleasure, as you will find in many of the 182 pieces collected from writings of a gross of scientists in Jefferson Hane Weaver's compendium. (Its three volumes are subtitled ''The Aristotelian Cosmos and the Newtonian System,'' ''The Einstein Universe and the Bohr Atom'' and ''The Evolutionary Cosmos and the Limits of Science.'') Some essays resort in places to the mother tongue of physics, mathematics, and will baffle even the ''educated novice'' Mr. Weaver wants to read his book. Not surprisingly, some of the most lucid essays are by the giants, such as Max Planck and Einstein (there is, however, a howler in a Latin phrase in one of his). From Pythagoras to Newton to Richard Feynman, these physicists reveal a beautiful universe and an exciting science. Roger Penrose is concise, clear, even comic, about black holes in plain English. About the mother tongue of physics Eugene P. Wigner is quite witty in ''The Unreasonable Effectiveness of Mathematics in the Natural Sciences.'' Werner Heisenberg argues eloquently that there is no way to talk about atomic reality in ordinary language, but Gustav Bergmann offers an empiricist philosophy of physics which proves there are no atoms anyway - and thereby reveals how physicists, and philosophers, think. The mischievous John von Neumann's ''Self-Reproducing Automata'' may leave you wondering who you are, or whether, or how many. But turn to that quantum genius Erwin Schrodinger on ''What Is Life?'' and you will learn with the thrill of recognition how alive the physical universe is. There is much more to enchant the educated novice, or even the untutored amateur, with this strange world.

title: PEACE IS STILL A LONG SHOT IN EL SALVADOR
description: OF all the developments in El Salvador since the signing of the Central American peace accord Aug. 7, few have been more striking than this month's announcement by Ruben Zamora that he intends to end seven years of exile and become the first top leftist leader to return to the country since the civil war began in 1979.

title: KATHLEEN VOUTE WEDS A MARINE
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York, Kathleen Ann Voute and Lieut. Peter Anthony Gudmundsson, U.S.M.C., were married yesterday by the Rev. John Cregan. Carolyn Voute was maid of honor for her sister. Brian Gudmundsson was his brother's best man.

title: Political Notes; Unlikely Partners: Regan and Abrams Fault Lawyers' Fees
description: In an unusual bipartisan alliance, New York State's Attorney General, Robert Abrams, and its Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, are objecting to the size of the fees legislative leaders have agreed to pay two politically connected lawyers to advise them on investigations of the Legislature.

title: British Commercials at Modern Museum
description: A program of 90 award-winning British film and television commercials will be presented on five consecutive days at the Museum of Modern Art, beginning Thursday. Ridley Scott, Marek Kanievska and Paul Weiland, all directors of feature films, are among those whose work will be shown.

title: Correction
description: A review Aug. 16 of Eva Figes's ''Little Eden: A Child at War'' gave an incorrect year for the author's emigration from Germany. She left in 1939.

title: Study Finds Drop in Anemia in Poor Children
description: The rate of anemia among children in low-income families dropped by almost two-thirds from 1975 to 1985, researchers say. They cited Government nutrition programs and the increasing popularity of breast-feeding and iron-fortified foods as reasons for the improvement.

title: Codella Scores 2 for Hofstra
description: Mike Codella, who rushed 32 times for a career-high 195 yards, scored two touchdowns on runs of 30 and 4 yards to lead undefeated Hofstra to a 28-12 victory over C. W. Post yesterday at Hickox Field in Brookville, L.I.

title: MISS THOMSON IS WED TO PETER ALLAN RENNER
description: Mary Browning Thomson, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Andrew Thomson of Evanston, Ill., was married there yesterday to Peter Allan Renner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Renner of Hanover, N.H. The Rev. Edward Copland performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: HOSPITAL REGISTERS ITEMS FOR DISABLED
description: LEAD: A STATEWIDE Used Equipment Registry that lists equipment to be donated or sold to children and adults with disabilities is available through Newington Children's Hospital.

title: IN NFL STRIKE, IT'S THE PRINCIPLE AND THE MONEY
description: FREE AGENT. The words evoke images of someone without restrictions or allegiance, someone free to come or go or stay. In one sense, the notion of a free agent is as American as the right to liberty.

title: A FINDING OF RACIAL BIAS AS THE JURY IS SELECTED
description: AT least one race-related point of contention was settled last week in the Howard Beach murder trial, in which four white youths are charged with participating in a racially motivated attack on three blacks, causing the death of one of them.

title: Theater Crosses Borders in Ireland, Fueled by the Troubles and a Love of Language
description: THE IRISH ARE ACTING up again, here, there and everywhere - scoring a smash at the Edinburgh Arts Festival, doing some of the best-received small theater in London, and, most importantly of all, working here on the Field Day Theater Company's annual cross-border renewal of the dramatic urge that grips the people of this land. The Irish continue to make something lyrical from the language they were forced to learn, demonstrating the thesis of their current master playwright, Brian Friel, that ''it is not the literal past, the 'facts' of history, that shape us, but images of the past embodied in language.''

title: BICENTENNIAL EXHIBIT SHOWS ROLE OF STATE
description: A NEW bicentennial exhibition in the museum of the New Jersey Historical Society here is said by its sponsors to finally give the state proper credit by depicting it not only as a principal theater of operations during much of the Revolutionary War, but also as the most enthusiastic supporter of the Constitution.

title: 7 Key Nations Plan to Support A Stable Dollar
description: Top economic officials of the United States and six other industrial democracies reaffirmed their commitment today to keep the dollar at its current level and threatened ''further appropriate actions'' if the dollar starts to fall.

title: EDWARDS PUSHES POLLUTION INQUIRY
description: W. CARY EDWARDS, the state's Attorney General, has invited New York City officials to come to Trenton and view the harvest of trash collected from New Jersey beaches this summer, hoping to convince them that the debris came from the city's waste system.

title: MOMENTARY UPSETS AND GOOD MARRIAGES
description: I HAVE been studying the generation gap recently. My children have a way of catching each other's eye and then looking at me and laughing quietly when I think I am behaving absolutely normally. Their father bursts into song, and again I see them eye each other knowingly. Often our behavior seems oddly quaint to them, and they tease us about it by threatening to engrave on our tombstones our simplistic cures for everything They love us, but they are making their lists, which are titled, ''What I won't do when I am a parent,'' and ''Things the man (or woman) I will marry will NEVER do!'' I smile to myself as I remember the same list I made at their ages.

title: Home Remedies
description: WHEN BEN OLEWINE DECIDED to build a house in Fairfield County, Conn., he wanted to avoid using a material that, in his New York City apartment, had literally made him sick. ''My eyes were constantly irritated and I kept sneezing, getting congested and feeling nauseous,'' recalls Mr. Olewine, a marketing consultant. ''One guest ended up being sick for two weeks.''

title: AUTOMATED FLASH
description: IN terms of picture taking, we are living in a revolutionary age. When we look back at the 1980's and assess what changes have been wrought in cameras, there will be plenty to talk about. Auto focusing. Idiot-proof ''auto everything'' lens-shutter cameras. Electronic imaging.

title: LEGAL DUMPING STILL THE BIG FACTOR
description: ALTHOUGH illegal dumping at sea wrought noticeable environmental damage along the New Jersey coast this summer, such dumping was minor when compared with legal ocean dumping.

title: Five Jazz Elements, Together and Apart
description: TODAY BROOKLYN, TOMOR-row the world. Maybe sooner.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Boom Times for the Fax. . .

title: The Kennedy Complex
description: LEAD: The two Democratic Presidential contenders who have seen their campaigns fatally damaged in recent months have something in common. Both former Senator Gary Hart and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. partly understood the current political climate in the United States. But the incompleteness of their understanding of that climate led both into practices that they thought would take them to the White

title: Worthless Assets
description: To the Editor:

title: Seven Former Defense Chiefs See Peril and Promise for U.S.
description: Seven former Defense Secretaries who gathered here to compare notes on the nation's defense have concurred that the United States should conclude a prospective agreement with the Soviet Union to eliminate medium- and shorter-range nuclear arms.

title: Vietnam
description: To the Editor: American travelers to Vietnam should not assume that the United States Government or any foreign embassy located in Vietnam can provide consular services or protection during their stay. ''Vietnam for Visitors'' (Travel, Sept. 13) correctly notes that the United States does not maintain diplomatic ties with Vietnam and that usual consular services are not available. The author suggests, however, that embassies of ''friendly'' governments in Hanoi, such as Britain, France and Australia, can help in an emergency. To imply that services not available in Vietnam from the United States Government may be obtained from other embassies there encourages travelers to assume too much.

title: ELIZABETH KING LONGSWORTH, AN EDITOR, IS WED IN VIRGINIA TO ANDREW L. SHINN
description: Elizabeth King Longsworth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Longsworth of Williamsburg, Va., was married there yesterday at her parents' home, Coke-Garrett House, to Andrew Lee Shinn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. and George L. Shinn of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. John W. Turner, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Okay Kid, Smile - and Shoot
description: PICTURE it: There's Dad, on Christmas morning, using his new camcorder to film Junior - trying out his new camcorder. If Fisher-Price has its way, it could happen in your living room this December.

title: JULIA BORDEN WEDS
description: Julia Huntington Borden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Borden Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Nichols Dean Kennedy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Kennedy of Old Lyme, Conn. The ceremony at the Stony Brook Meetinghouse was conducted under the care of the Princeton Monthly Meeting of the Society of Friends.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: STAMFORD HARVEST

title:
THE TALK OF THE CLASS OF 1962;
THE LOST AND THE FOUND MEET AT A 25TH REUNION
description: LEAD: IT rained on June 25, 1962, causing a 24-hour postponement of New Rochelle High School's 67th graduation exercises. The downpour prevented 657 anxious seniors from leaving a place that had dominated their lives for three years and delayed their charge into the exciting challenges of adulthood.

title: TWO DEMOCRATS: STUDY IN CONTRASTS
description: DEMOCRATS are challenging Republican interim County Executives in Nassau and Suffolk. Both Democrats are rated as underdogs but the resemblance ends there.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday on the marriage of Lynn Rosenman and Merrick Brian Garland referred incorrectly to the bride's paternal grandmother.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: How to Think Absolutely Positively
description: IN RESPONSE TO A READER WHO AC-cuses all critics of accentuating the negative, I hurry to state that I agree wholeheartedly. It is deplorably true that most of us fail to heed the ancient maternal advice: if you can't say anything nice about somebody, don't say anything. It is no excuse to pretend that if we adhered to this gentle injunction there occasionally would be blank columns where the criticism would have run. Everyone knows that press releases and large pictures could easily be found to fill the space.

title: Correction
description: The Personal Finance column Sept. 6 misidentified the Internal Revenue Service form used to obtain an employer identification number. It is Form SS-4.

title: Zaccaro Trial to Offer Look at Manes
description: John A. Zaccaro goes on trial Monday on charges of attempted extortion in a case that is likely to provide further glimpses into the ambiguous and interwoven relationships that characterized the Queens political world of Donald R. Manes.

title: Streetscape: The Hotel Martinique; Grimy Grande Dame Housing The Homeless Off Herald Sq.
description: THE Hotel Martinique, at the northeast corner of 32d and Broadway, could be any once-elegant midtown hotel now fallen on hard times. Its French Renaissance facade is dabbed with colors as if by a giant paint brush - the colors of drying clothes on the window guards.

title: LUCY SHERRILL MARRIES R. R. FARR IN CHICAGO
description: Lucy Gray Sherrill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Newton Sherrill Jr. of Wichita Falls, Tex., was married in Chicago yesterday to Randolph Rue Farr, a son of Charles Sims Farr of New York and the late Mrs. Farr. The Rev. Jeffrey Doane performed the ceremony at the Lincoln Park Presbyterian Church.

title: Commercial Property: Subletting; Tenants With Surplus Space Becoming Landlords
description: MANHATTAN stands as the premier office market in the nation, but that does not stop Leon Schwarzbaum from sounding like a landlord devoid of hope.

title: POLLUTION AND CAMPAIGN FINANCES
description: POLL after poll shows the people of New Jersey valuing a clean environment as a top priority. With such strong support under a democratic system, one would suppose that any cause would be home free.

title: VILLIANS AND HEROES
description: To the Editor:

title: MT. VERNON RACE WARMING UP
description: LEAD: THERE may not have been a mayoral primary in Mount Vernon, but George C. Albano is determined that there be a race.

title: Downtown, Short Means Short
description: THE market for micro-miniskirts these days is going up, up, up, particularly in lower Manhattan's more avant-garde neighborhoods. On the streets of SoHo and Greenwich Village there has been a parade recently of long-legged women in short skirts -very short skirts.

title: Ballistics Tests Set in Slaying of 6
description: Residents here and the authorities were mystified today after a hard-working 14-year-old boy apparently killed six members of his family before he died in a struggle with his uncle. The uncle was wounded.

title: IN QUOTE
description: ''Japan is now becoming more worried about inflation. Germany has been worried about inflation all year long. So they're going to put more emphasis on controlling their domestic economies than on helping us out.'' - Michael K. Evans, economist

title: Correction
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on Sept. 13 about the photographers Edward Weston and Henri Cartier-Bresson misidentified the co-curator of the Weston exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He is James Enyeart, director of the Center for Creative Photography at the University of Arizona.

title: Lebanese Tells Brooklyn Group Of Peace Hopes
description: The President of war-ravaged Lebanon, Amin Gemayel, yesterday preached a message of peace to a Brooklyn Heights church whose members believed that they could also teach him a thing or two about coexistence.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: On a recent trip to a missile factory in Florida, Robert B. Costello, who has been nominated as Under Secretary of Defense for acquisition, was taken aback by the lack of attention to quality.

title: Two Directories for Women
description: Women are winning election to national, state and county offices in increasing numbers, and while that is no surprise, it is made tangible in the new edition of a directory listing the women who hold elective office. And another updated guide indicates that an increasingly broad range of college courses in women's studies are now available.

title: 'Cagney And Lacey' On Racism
description: THE new season of ''Cagney and Lacey,'' which starts tonight at 10 on CBS, wastes no time in plowing once again into controversial territory. This particular episode has already been cited by lawyers in the Howard Beach trial, which is resuming jury selection today, as possibly being prejudicial to the rights of the white defendants. The program itself provides little or nothing to support that contention.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Taxes - no. Revenues, user fees, that sort of thing, maybe asset sales - yes.'' Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, on balancing the budget. [ A1:5. ]

title: KERMIT MORRISSEY
description: Kermit Morrissey, a professor at the University of Massachusetts and a former president of Boston State College, died Saturday. He was 68 years old.

title: Mets Pass 3 Million
description: On their last home day of the season, the Mets became only the second team in baseball history to surpass 3 million in home attendance. The Los Angeles Dodgers reached that plateau seven times in the past nine years.

title: 'It's a Lie,' Casey's Widow Says
description: Sophia Casey, the widow of William J. Casey, yesterday denied an account in a new book that her husband acknowledged in a sickbed interview that he had known of the diversion to the Nicaraguan contras of profits from the sale of American arms to Iran.

title: Machine Tool Orders Fell 12.7% in August
description: New orders for American-made machine tools dropped 12.7 percent in August from the previous month's level, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: Allied-Signal Buyback Plan
description: The board of Allied-Signal Inc. has authorized an increase of 25 million shares in its stock repurchase plan, the company said yesterday. The company also plans a special program to buy back stock that is held in lots of less than 100 shares.

title: Erasmus High at 200: Fresh Paint, New Hope
description: There was a fresh coat of paint and a tentative sense of optimism this weekend at Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn, where officials and prominent alumni celebrated the 200th birthday of the school with pledges that they would work to reverse its terrible decline.

The program, a United States-supported effort to help the country's Government win support from peasants, is in sharp decline. The border crossing, opened for the first time in several years, drew 15,000 to 20,000 people. title: Banks Cool to Brazil Debt-for-Bond Plan
description: Banks in the United States and Europe appeared unlikely over the weekend to accept a key part of Brazil's latest proposal for managing its huge foreign debt.

title: Twenty Opposition Leaders Seized by Police in Paraguay
description: The police arrested 20 opposition leaders today on their way to a meeting in a remote village, the Roman Catholic radio station Caritas reported.

title: To Wriggle Out of Gaffegate, Offer a Total Mea Culpa
description: It's the call you've always dreaded. ''Senator, I think we have a problem,'' says the campaign manager of your Presidential bid, as your stomach reflexively tightens. He tells you of a major reporter calling for a comment about your marijuana bust at age 22, or the tax bill you were three years late in paying, or an affair you've nearly forgotten, or a private ethnic joke, now leaked, or a misconstrued metaphor that has insulted a key primary state or interest group. Welcome to Gaffegate. In the past, a candidate prevailed or failed based on primary wins and delegate totals; more recently, fund-raising and debates have become pre-primary litmus tests. Now, after Gary Hart's and Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s collapses, there is a new criterion, a new device for weeding out Presidential candidates: the self-immolating gaffe.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $250,000.

title: A Dedicated New Coach Has Difficult Role to Fill
description: Ask Keith Merriman, the new football coach at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, what it is like to replace a local legend and he'll tell you it's not so bad - especially when the legend is Moe Finkelstein and he's right there at practice almost every day.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MIAMI. By Joan Didion. 238 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Jordan to Buy More Wheat
description: Jordan's wheat harvest fell short of forecasts this year, which will result in higher grain imports from Saudi Arabia and the United States.

title: Window Is Smashed At Biaggi's Office
description: The front window of Representative Mario Biaggi's district office in the Bronx was found shattered early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: U.S. Looking to Wildflowers To Dress Up Federal Roads
description: Following the lead of Texas planners, the Federal Government plans to sow native wildflowers throughout the country along highways built with Federal aid.

title: It's in the Air
description: Passing has been so much a part of football for so long that it's easy to forget there was a time when passes were not allowed. After all, throwing the ball across the line of scrimmage has been legal since the 1906 college season, and there are few fans around these days whose memories go back that far.

title: Pearson's Lure for Raiders
description: Pearson P.L.C., the blue-chip British conglomerate with holdings ranging from The Financial Times to Madame Tussaud's wax museum, had caught the eye of corporate raiders long before the publisher Rupert Murdoch bought a major stake last week.

title: MASSACHUSETTS COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,390,000 and $2,680,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes tax credits of $25,000 for the quarter and $75,000 for the year.

title: Candidate and Family Dispute du Pont Will
description: Pete du Pont, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, and three of his cousins believe they are legally entitled to $1.5 million of an aunt's estate that has been awarded to four charities.

title: Victoria Kent, 90, Who Led Magazine Opposed to Franco
description: Victoria Kent, the first woman to become a lawyer in Spain and the founder and former editor of Iberica, a magazine that opposed both communism in Spain and the Government of Franco, died last Friday of a heart attack at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Wilander Upset in Spain: Eighth-seeded Martin Jaite of Argentina upset top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, 7-6, 6-4, 4-6, 0-6, 6-4, to win the 35th Count of Godo tournament at the Royal Tennis Club of Barcelona. A crowd of 5,000 watched the match, which lasted 4 hours 12 minutes. Jaite, 22 years old, earned $39,440 for his victory. The 23-year-old Wilander earned $19,720.(AP) An Easy Triumph for Graf: Top-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany defeated Isabel Cueto of West Germany, 6-2, 6-2, in the final of the $150,000 Virginia Slims tournament in Hamburg, West Germany. The 18-year-old Graf, ranked No. 1 in the world, said the triumph was the easiest of her nine tournament victories this year. (AP) Edberg Surprised by Pate: David Pate of Las Vegas, Nev., defeated the No. 2 player in the world, Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 6-4, 6-4, to capture the $315,000 Volvo tournament in Los Angeles. Pate, ranked 19th in the world, won his first title of the year and the second of his career, earning $50,000.(AP) Auto Racing Mansell Closes In on Piquet: Nigel Mansell kept alive his slim chance of catching Nelson Piquet of Brazil, his Williams-Honda teammate, for the Formula One driving title yesterday by cruising to victory in the Spanish Grand Prix at Jerez de la Frontera. Mansell's 22.225-second margin over Alain Prost of France gave the Briton his fifth victory of the season and the 12th of his career. He moved into second place in the drivers' standing with 52 points. Piquet, the leader with 70 points, gained 3 points for finishing fourth. With three races left, Mansell has a chance to pass Piquet. Only the 11 top finishes from the 16 Grand Prix races count in the standing, and Piquet already has three firsts, six seconds, a third and a fourth. Mansell has scored points in only eight races, so his finishes in the final three events will count fully, while Piquet must do better than fourth. (AP) Waltrip Breaks Losing Streak: Darrell Waltrip steered through a last-lap tangle involving Dale Earnhardt and Terry Labonte and scored his first victory of the season in the Goody's 500 Nascar Winston Cup race at Martinsville Speedway in Virginia. Waltrip broke a 27-race streak without a victory. He averaged 76.410 miles an hour and led five times in the race for a total of 138 laps, but the day seemed to belong to Earnhardt, who passed Waltrip on the outside on lap 381 and began building an enormous lead until a late caution bunched the field. Earnhardt, Labonte and Waltrip all made pit stops and came out bumper to bumper. Labonte, trying to take the lead, bumped with Earnhardt and scraped the wall on the backstretch. Going into the third turn on the last lap, Waltrip nudged the nose of his car inside the left rear of Labonte's. The cars made contact. Labonte spun out, and Earnhardt wavered, allowing Waltrip to speed by on the inside.(AP) Golf One-Stroke Victory for Pate: Steve Pate emerged from a tense fight with four other golfers with a five-under-par 67 yesterday and won the $400,000 Southwest Classic in Abilene, Tex., by one stroke. The 26-year-old Californian secured his first PGA Tour victory and the $72,000 top prize with a five-foot par putt on the final hole. His total of 15-under-par 273 gave him the edge over the third-round leader, David Edwards, and Bob Eastwood, Dan Halldorson and Mark O'Meara in the wind-swept finale.(AP) 2d Straight for Stephenson: Jan Stephenson fired a seven-under-par 65 yesterday to win the Konica San Jose Classic by five strokes with a record-setting 54-hole total of 11-under-par 205. The victory was the second straight for Stephenson on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour. She won the Safeco Classic last week. (AP) Barber Wins in Newport: Miller Barber sank a 13-foot birdie putt on the 14th hole to take the lead for good yesterday as he shot a seven-under-par 65 for a three-stroke victory over Bruce Crampton in the $200,000 Newport Cup. Barber finished the 54-hole tournament with a score of 14-under 202 on the 6,566-yard Newport (R.I.) Country Club course. He earned $30,000 for the victory, his 21st on the PGA Senior Tour. Crampton, who had a final-round 67, finished at 205, two strokes ahead of Bob Charles, whose final-round 64 was the best score of the tournament. Gary Player of South Africa, who shot 65 yesterday, finished fourth at 208. (AP) Dog Show Poodle Is Best: An elegant black standard poodle, Ch. Alekai Airy, was gaited to her 23d best-in-show award yesterday at the 45th Annual Westbury Kennel Association Fixture on the grounds of the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville, L.I. The bitch, who led a field of 1,506 dogs, is owned by Tatiana Nagro and was handled by Wendell Sammet. Ale Kai Alluring II, a white standard poodle owned by Nagro and Sammet, was high scorer in obedience with 199 points.

title: Save the Bagel
description: To the Editor:

title: Official Gloom on Third-World Debt
description: A sense of hopelessness appears to pervade a huge gathering here of the top economic officials of nearly every nation on earth as they search for some way out of the bind of poor-country debt that has been draining the economies of most nations for five years.

title: KEVLIN MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Baker's Unhappiness
description: Mr. Baker has said repeatedly that he has no interest in an appointment to the Court, but friends in his home state of Tennessee report that he is unhappy in his White House post and might be looking for a way out. They say he resents the fierce back-biting and guerrilla warfare that seem to plague the White House staff.

title: For Proxmire, the Fleece Goes On
description: On the opening of every Senate legislative day since 1967, Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin has risen to begin the session with a 600-word address.

title: Burger King's Choice Is Due
description: Be assured that the top managers at J. Walter Thompson, N. W. Ayer and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles will be sticking close to their office phones this morning. Burger King, with its $200 million advertising budget, told them last week that the winner of the account would be notified by phone before 11 this morning.

title: Europe Defeats U.S.
description: For the first time in the 60-year history of this competition, the United States lost the the Ryder Cup at home. A team of European professional golfers retained the trophy they won in 1985 in England, as they defeated a squad of Americans today , 15-13.

title: Ms. Michanowicz Wed to Architect
description: The marriage of Dawn Elaine Michanowicz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Michael Michanowicz of Hermitage, Tenn., to Jan Gleysteen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Culver Gleysteen of East Boothbay, Me., took place yesterday in New York. The Rev. Robert Cowperthwaite performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Chapel, Trinity Parish.

title: Stage: 'Hungers,' Computer Opera in Los Angeles
description: For those interested in truly new music, electronics has long seemed one of the most promising avenues into the future. Right now, an enormous amount of ingenuity, energy and money is being invested in the development of electronic and computer hardware and software, and the presence of a novelty-hungry rock music industry fuels that development and makes it affordable - even by penurious ''serious'' composers.

title: Police Chase Ends In Fatal Collision
description: A suspect in an attempted rape who was fleeing in his car from the police collided with another car at a Bronx intersection early yesterday, killing the driver of the second car, the police said.

title: Why Rig the Rules Against Imports?
description: What a difference a few sentences can make. While hardly anyone was looking, Ernest Hollings of South Carolina slipped a brief amendment into the Senate's thousand-page trade bill that could raise some import prices by 20 percent and invite retaliation against U.S. exports. If they act sensibly, Congressional conferees will quickly undo this protectionist mischief.

title: New Chances to Slow Proliferation
description: Soviet and American leaders suddenly are talking about almost every arms control topic except nuclear nonproliferation. There may well be opportunities, especially with Pakistan and India, for Washington and Moscow to spend some capital separately and together to curb the spread of nuclear arms.

title: How About a Real Solution to Third World Debt?
description: Tomorrow, as the third world drowns in debt, 3,000 of the world's financial managers will gather here for the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. A continent away from the consequences of the debt, they are likely to avoid facing the problem head-on and instead to engage in what the economist Martin Feldstein has aptly phrased ''creatively muddling through.'' The problem this time - with a number of debtor nations edging toward unilateral action - is that muddling may no longer be enough.

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 5 percent dividend paid in August 1987.

title: A Light, Not a Mission
description: Is there some missionary sense in which the United States has an obligation to spread democracy throughout the world? A lot of its citizens seem to think so, judging from the response to a recent column concerning Nicaragua.

title: Rangers Tie Whalers, 4-4
description: The Rangers, who have had trouble looking impressive on their home ice, staged a third-period comeback and tied the Hartford Whalers, 4-4, in an exhibition game last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: MILLS JENNINGS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Pop: Dionne Warwick
description: IN 1962, at a studio just three blocks from Radio City Music Hall, Dionne Warwick recorded her first hit single, ''Don't Make Me Over,'' with the songwriter-producers Burt Bacharach and Hal David. The making of that record, which began a historic three-way collaboration, was one of many recollections that Ms. Warwick and Mr. Bacharach shared at Thursday's opening night show of a three-night Radio City Music Hall engagement. The show was the first in which the composer and singer performed together on a New York stage.

title: 'THEME' FROM SOVIET
description: IF your heart sinks at the prospect of a movie about a writer in midlife crisis, take heart again. In ''The Theme,'' which plays tonight and tomorrow night at the Film Festival, Gleb Panfilov, the Soviet director, gives the old subject a shot of imagination that sends it skipping around like a kid.

title: Recital: Susan Gregory
description: SUSAN GREGORY'S impressive vocal recital Saturday evening at Merkin Concert Hall included an ambitious range of music, from Boismortier's ''Dian et Acteon'' to Bernstein's witty ''La Bonne Cuisine'' from 1949. Miss Gregory's elegant accounts made a strong case for moving a number of the evening's selections more squarely into the repertory.

title: Metro Matters; Good Intentions On Quirky Geyser Go Slightly Awry
description: For nearly two decades, the Delacorte geyser pumped a graceful plume of East River water hundreds of feet skyward from Roosevelt Island four times a day.

title: COSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $50,000 and $419,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and gains on the disposal of discontinued operations of $75,000 for the quarter and $605,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $48,000 for the quarter and $77,000 for the 9 months, and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $280,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: FIRECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Firecom said the sales increase resulted from the acquisition of Auth Co. in July 1986.

title: Long Island Baymen Fight To Replenish Scallop Crop
description: The cages, each containing about a thousand tiny scallops, left the boat with a rhythmic slide and splash - sounds that signaled the latest attempt by a group of baymen to replenish the bays and harbors of the East End.

title: CROP GENETICS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Philharmonic: Sir Colin Davis Conducts
description: THE Sixth Symphony of Ralph Vaughan Williams is a big, sinewy piece, sometimes harsh, sometimes - especially in the jazz-tinted parts near the start - rollicking in a rough way. This describes the first three movements; the last, suddenly, is a muted, directionless reverie, 10 minutes and more of unvarying pianissimo.

title: Federal Witness in 'Pizza' Case Recants Testimony on Mob Boss
description: A former underworld killer who became a protected Federal witness has come out of hiding to recant testimony that helped send a New York Mafia boss to prison for 45 years in the ''pizza connection'' case.

title: Soviet Radar Tour Defuses Cheating Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST BANCORP (NORTH CAROLINA) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'I Thought I Was Fired'
description: THE more Davey Johnson talked yesterday in trying to clarify his status as the Mets' manager, the more he clouded the situation. But in 24 hours, he had gone from being contentious to being contrite.

title: Music: Carnegie Hall vs. Fisher Hall
description: LAST week's visit of the Vienna Philharmonic offered an unusual opportunity to investigate one of the issues musicians talk about most in this town: acoustics. The orchestra played in both our main concert auditoriums, the recently renovated, long-acclaimed Carnegie Hall and the oft-doctored, long-maligned Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center. Moreover, one of the Carnegie programs -Thursday's bill of Mozart, Bernstein and Sibelius - was repeated verbatim Saturday afternoon at Fisher Hall. And to make things just that bit more interesting, the New York Philharmonic played the same Sibelius piece, the Fifth Symphony, in its current group of subscription concerts.

title: Albuquerque Journal; Hordes of Chili Addicts Stock Up for Long, Cold Winter
description: This is a special autumn for Joe Gutierrez. The 28-year-old mechanic-turned-farmer is harvesting his first green chili crop from a half-acre plot a little more than a two-hour drive north of here.

title: LESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Training for the Industry of Justice
description: New York City already has specialized high schools for science, performing arts, communications and finance. Starting next fall, if the Mayor and the Board of Education have their way, Martin Luther King Jr. High School will add an Institute for Law and Justice. The idea deserves support.

title: FARADYNE ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Managed Trade Takes the International Marbles
description: To the Editor:

title: Political World Of Ann Lewis
description: On the Democratic Party's new themes, announced a year ago: 'It's Maginot Line politics . . . focusing on the last battle and over-reacting to that.'' On reports that Gary Hart planned to resume his Presidential bid: ''What it would require is for everyone but Gary Hart to have amnesia.'' On Presidential politics: ''You're in a vacuum-sealed universe where everyday concerns no longer exist. It's easy to forget the rules of the real world.'' On a candidate's private life: ''We want our candidates and their families to play the role, and if the role slips, we claim to be shocked by the pretense.''

title: MICHIGAN ENERGY RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
From Bork to Hatch?
description: As part of their promotion of Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court, White House strategists are encouraging the idea that if Judge Bork loses, President Reagan might name Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah as his replacement.

title: Striking Workers Polled on NBC Offer
description: Members of the striking National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians in New York City, Chicago and Washington are conducting polls that might force the union to put a disputed contract proposal by NBC to a vote before the full membership, union officials said over the weekend.

title: Fewer Philippine Strikes
description: The number of strikes in the Philippines has fallen to less than half of last year's figure, the Labor Secretary, Franklin Drilon, told The Manila Bulletin. He said there had been 66,291 strikes so far this year, compared with 141,841 in the comparable period of 1986.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss The prior year results for the 9 months reflect a non-cash writedown of oil and gas property costs totaling $895,000.

title: Nancy E. Dince Wed To Richard S. Trostle
description: Nancy Ellen Dince and Richard Scott Trostle were married yesterday at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y., by Rabbi Charles Davidson.

title: Sports World Specials; Yale Far Afield
description: Not many Old Blues are aware that Yale graduates played a prominent role in the development of Hawaii, according to officials of the Association of Yale Alumni. For instance, they note that among the first American missionaries to visit the islands in 1820 was Asa Thurston, Yale Class of 1816, who devised an alphabet for what had been an unwritten Hawaiian language, and Abraham Blatchly, the second American physician to settle in Hawaii.

title: MacNamara Gets B&B And Sheds Keystone
description: MacNamara, Clapp & Klein has become agency for B&B, the liqueur, for which the Buckingham Wile Company is the new importer.

title: Tunisia Court Orders Death Sentences for 7 of 90 Moslem Militants
description: A Tunisian court ordered the death sentence for seven of 90 Islamic fundamentalist defendants today, and defense lawyers said Western criticisms of the trial helped produce a verdict that was milder than many Tunisians had expected.

title: Renewed Devotion Seen In Wake of Pope's Visit
description: Before Pope John Paul II visited this and eight other American cities earlier this month, Carolyn Tilden, a retired retail clerk in New Orleans, said she attended mass just once a week.

title: INSIDE
description: Pope Inspires Devotion Priests and laymen in three cities visited by Pope John Paul II on his American tour say he succeeded in encouraging Roman Catholics to renew their faith. Page B9. Cuomo View of the Kremlin Governor Cuomo, back from a week in the Soviet Union, said the Russians might agree to discuss reducing human-rights abuses. Page B8. U.S. and Canada in Talks Canadian and American cabinet officers meet today in Washington to explore the possibility of reviving talks on free trade. Page D1. Chinese Leader Hesitates Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang expressed reluctance to assume permanent leadership of China's Communist Party. Page A3. A Verdict in Tunis A Tunisian court ordered the death sentence for 7 of 90 Islamic militants, a milder decision than many Tunisians had expected. Page A10.

title: AMWEST INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment losses of $3,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $5,000 and $58,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Woman Rescued In Flaming Home
description: Firefighters dragged a semiconscious elderly woman from a flaming apartment in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday morning, and she was taken to the burn unit at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan in critical condition.

title: '10-YEAR LUNCH' AT THE ALGONQUIN
description: ALTHOUGH finished only this year, ''The 10-Year Lunch'' has the unmistakable look of a period piece, which is very much to its advantage. Produced by Aviva Slesin, the documentary, subtitled ''The Wit and Legend of the Algonquin Round Table,'' can be seen on ''American Masters'' tonight at 10 on Channel 13 and at 9 P.M. on Channel 49. Ms. Slesin previously contributed the first-rate ''Directed by William Wyler'' to the series.

title: Alysheba Rallies In Super Derby
description: Alysheba rallied in the stretch today to win the $1 million Super Derby at Louisiana Downs by a half-length.

title: Irving Seeks Advice on Bid
description: In the wake of Friday's surprise $1.4 billion takeover offer by the Bank of New York Company, the Irving Bank Corporation has asked its adviser, Goldman, Sachs & Company, to prepare a report for its directors.

title: CMS ENHANCEMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $70,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Concert: Philharmonic
description: THE success of Leonard Bernstein's second Carnegie Hall program with the Vienna Philharmonic requires no subtle explanations. Performers of great accomplishment, deep and apparent love for the music at hand, the confidence to let those qualities mesh - the elements are not obscure, but at the level evident in Mozart and Mahler on Friday evening, they are rare enough to make the concert memorable.

title: ETHIGEN CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company was formerly Praxis Pharmaceuticals Inc. The development-stage company said its revenue in both years was derived from the payment of interest.

title: Salsa and Heartthrobs: A Palace of Hispanic Life Returns
description: Ceci Aponte had tears in her eyes when the red curtains parted at the grand reopening of the Teatro Puerto Rico in the South Bronx.

title: Hannah Zackson, A Physician, Wed
description: Dr. Hannah Judith Zackson, a daughter of Dr. Isabel Zackson and Dr. Ephraim King Zackson of New Hyde Park, L.I., and Andrew Robert Wolk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Wolk of South Orange, N.J., were married yesterday. Cantor Martha Novick officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Home Games Fill Giants' Schedules
description: It was a lovely autumn Sunday, a perfect day for a pro football game. Except there were no National Football League games because of the players' strike that began last Tuesday, so the striking Giants had to find other things to do.

title: CERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cruise Lines Ride a High Tide
description: Every Saturday and Sunday afternoon, an armada of gleaming white cruise ships glides down the long, narrow channel of the Port of Miami and heads across the horizon toward the Bahamas and the Caribbean.

title: Dance: Moscow Ballet Makes Debut in U.S.
description: Led by Vyacheslav Gordeyev, a Bolshoi Ballet star who became an American favorite in the 1970's, a new Soviet touring ensemble named the Moscow Ballet made its United States debut here this weekend.

title: Business and the Law
description: IN the debate on the role of Federal and state laws governing corporate takeovers, the alliances being formed invert traditional political labels.

title: Jacoby Wins Case On Ouster From Bates
description: Robert E. Jacoby, ousted millonaire chairman and chief executive of Ted Bates Worldwide, has won his case in an arbitration against the agency and its new owners, Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: Limited Benefit in Deficit Plan
description: The bond market might be encouraged by the President's announcement during the weekend that he would sign legislation calling for a smaller Federal budget deficit next year and automatic spending cuts if Congress and the White House do not agree on a plan to achieve the target.

title: Celebrities of Summer Are Cashing In
description: They are all young and attractive - three women catapulted into the limelight because of their associations with three of the male heroes or villains of the summer of 1987. Yet, beyond these few superficial similarities, Donna Rice, Fawn Hall and Jessica Hahn have very little in common other than an apparent desire to cash in on their experiences, relationships and good looks in what has become the standard currency of celebrity: movie, book and television deals, commercials, magazine stories and television talk-show appearances.

title: Don't Send People Into Space Unnecessarily
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Webster Weds Richard Harwood
description: Jacqueline Park Webster, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Webster of Allendale, N.J., and Richard Charles Harwood, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Harwood of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi Jonathan Rubenstein performed the ceremony at Skylands Manor in Ringwood, N.J.

title: Susan Zimny Is Wed To Sheldon Sussman
description: Susan Laura Zimny, a vice president in the capital markets division of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, and Sheldon Lee Sussman, a vice president in the global markets division of the Bankers Trust Company, were married yesterday at Estherwood in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Rabbi Sandy Bogin officiated.

title: Land for Salvador's Poor: To Many, Bitter Victory
description: When Jose Eleutereo Cruz received a tiny plot of land just below the rocky spine of a mountain ridge here seven years ago, he fulfilled his lifelong dream to own the ground he works. But now that dream is little more than a nightmare and he is thinking of giving up and moving to another area.

title: 150 Argentine Officers Stay In Their Barracks in Protest
description: At least 150 army officers confined themselves to their barracks in suburban Buenos Aires late tonight to protest the transfer of their commanding officer.

title: Sand Castles: More Than Child's Play
description: It seemed a contradiction in terms -''serious sand castle building.''

title: Aide to Khomeini Heir Apparent Is Reported Executed in Teheran
description: An Iranian who was linked to the revelation of the American arms deals with Iran was executed today by firing squad in Teheran, the Iranian radio reported.

'Styro-Wars'
description: The environmental group Friends of the Earth is trying to spread the word on the chlorofluorocarbon, the chemical compound that appears to be damaging the world's ozone layer.
