description: In what has become almost routine in Presidential primaries, Democratic and Republican hopefuls are making a mess of foreign policy. The Republicans are for the most part playing to deep suspicion about arms control agreements with the Soviet Union. The Democrats, with exceptions, tend to rail against new weapons systems and condemn the use of force to back up diplomacy. It will not be easy for the next President to reclaim a middle ground laid waste by the battle.

title: Life in the 30's
description: THE monster under the bed finally arrived at our house the other night. I've been waiting for him to show up for four years.

title: Toll in Rain and Floods Hits 60 in South Africa
description: Officials said today that 60 people were known dead so far in torrential rains and flooding in Natal Province, described by state television as ''the worst in living memory.'' Scores more were reported missing.

title: Boxing Notebook; Rahway May Be Arena for a Return
description: When Tony Ayala, a former junior middleweight contender, was transferred from Trenton State Prison to Rahway State Prison in New Jersey earlier this month, it prompted talk that he might resume his boxing career behind bars. There is a precedent at Rahway.

title: Cover-Up Charges At U. of Tennessee
description: An article in the November issue of Sport magazine cites accusations that athletic officials at the University of Tennessee covered up improper payments to football players. The charges were denied today by Johnny Majors, the school's football coach, and by Doug Dickey, the athletic director.

title: INSIDE
description: Businessman Evaded Taxes Victor Posner, described as the nation's highest-paid executive in 1985, pleaded no contest to charges of evading income taxes. Page D1. Deer Crowd the Suburbs An increase in deer in the New York area poses problems for motorists, farmers and homeowners. Page B1. Mets Down, Mattingly Up The Mets lost on one hit and were on the edge of elimination as St. Louis won twice. The Yankees celebrated a record as Don Mattingly hit his sixth grand slam of the season. Page B7.

title: Rained Out: Work Rules Limit Duties of Firefighters
description: The work New York City's firefighters do each day depends partly on what the National Weather Service has to say.

title: How Ayer Got Burger King Job
description: UNLIKE the two other finalists for the $200 million Burger King account, N. W. Ayer, the winner, entered its final presentation with but a single ad campaign.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LEAD: DEAR DIARY:

title: Jail Term in Stabbing Of Chinese Comedian
description: A homeless man who stabbed a Chinese comedian on stage at Town Hall on New Year's Day was sentenced yesterday to 2 1/2 to 7 1/2 years in prison.

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for 12wks to Aug 20
description: b-Includes tax credits of $260,000. The 1987 share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid May 1.

title: Topics of the Times; Mayor Grudge
description: More than a month after winning a sharply divided Board of Estimate's approval for a homeless shelter plan, Mayor Koch continues his punishment of Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden, who opposed the controversial measure. Mr. Golden has been punished enough.

title: Woman Slain on Times Sq.
description: A woman in her mid-20's was fatally stabbed last night during an altercation near the cashier's window of a Times Square movie theater. Her assailant, who witnesses said was also in his mid-20's, fled as the victim staggered into the street. According to the police, the couple argued as they were about to enter the Big Apple Theater on Broadway near 42d Street at 7 P.M. The theater, at which four X-rated films were playing, was closed, and witnesses were taken inside for questioning. The victim, whose identity was not known, died at Bellevue Hospital.

title: France in Fall? Election Jitters and Seekers of Seers
description: It is perhaps by definition a season of uncertainty when the 100 most famous clairvoyants and soothsayers of France gather in an expensive Paris hotel for a congress. The publicity surrounding the Salon de la Voyance reveals that the rational France that gave birth to Descartes has lately produced as many seers as doctors.

title: Penney to Buy Back Up to 10% of Shares
description: The J. C. Penney Company plans to buy back up to 15 million shares, or 10 percent, of its stock outstanding, the company announced yesterday.

title: California Acts to Speed AIDS Drug Testing
description: California will be the first state to supervise testing of drugs for the treatment of AIDS and potentially to approve them without the involvement of the Federal Government under legislation signed by the Governor.

title: Why Are People Being Caught in Subway Doors?
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: VEIL: The Secret Wars of the CIA 1981-1987. By Bob Woodward. Illustrated. 543 pages. Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

title: Excerpt From Speech By Reagan to I.M.F.
description: Following is an excerpt from President Reagan's address today to the annual meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund:

title: The Pop Life
description: A Christmas on Record

title: Experts Say Women at Risk Are Well-Informed on AIDS
description: Inner-city women at high risk of AIDS infection are now well-informed of their risk, but few are changing their behavior as a result, according to experts here for a federally sponsored conference on AIDS and women.

title: REAGAN ASKS STEPS IN TOKYO AND BONN TO SPUR ECONOMIES
description: President Reagan, saying he was doing his part in signing a law to reduce the deficit, told Japan and West Germany today that they needed the ''gumption'' to take unpleasant economic medicine for the benefit of a debt-burdened and slow-growing world economy.

title: Film Festival; 'Barfly,' Doing the Best With the Worst of Life
description: BARBET SCHROEDER, the French producer best known for his association with Eric Rohmer, infrequently directs films, but when he does, they're worth the long intervals between. It could be that being a producer is Mr. Schroeder's protective cover.

title: ESPRIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $24,000 and $23,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively, from utilization of net operating loss carryforward.

title: Ballet: Balanchine Premiere in Tulsa
description: What can only be called a balletic miracle occurred Sunday afternoon in the Chapman Music Hall of the Tulsa Performing Arts Center. Tulsa Ballet Theater offered the first North American performance - and the first performance anywhere in more than 20 years - of George Balanchine's ''Mozart Violin Concerto,'' which was created in Buenos Aires in 1942 when Balanchine was guest choreographer for the Ballet of the Teatro Colon.

title: Israeli, at U.N., Outlines Plan For a Mideast Peace Parley
description: Israel's Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, today outlined an eight-point proposal for an international peace conference on the Middle East.

title: Salomon Reassured On Revlon
description: The First Boston Corporation assured Salomon Inc. yesterday that it would not help Revlon Inc. in what many think could develop into a hostile takeover bid for the nation's biggest investment banking house.

title: Runner Banned
description: Sandra Gasser of Switzerland, the runner who failed a test for steroids at the world track and field championships that ended early in September, has been barred from competing for two years, including next summer's Olympics, track's worldwide governing body said yesterday in London.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Top Avis Officer Holds A Post He Know Well
description: Joseph V. Vittoria, who was named chairman and chief executive of Avis Inc. this week, is in a post he knows well.

title: Equiticorp Wins Guinness Peat
description: The merchant bank Guinness Peat Group P.L.C. conceded that Equiticorp Holdings Ltd., a New Zealand-based financial services company, had won effective control of the bank. In a letter to shareholders, Guinness Peat said that while it still thought Equiticorp's per-share offer of 115 pence, or the equivalent of $1.87 a share, was inadequate, Equiticorp's 44.2 percent stake in the merchant bank gave it control.

title: New Book on the C.I.A. Stirs Questions of Ethics
description: Publication of excerpts from Bob Woodward's new book on the Central Intelligence Agency has produced headlines around the world, but it has also put Mr. Woodward and the newspaper he serves as a reporter and editor, The Washington Post, at the center of a complex debate over press ethics.

title: G.M. Chief Hints at Approval Of Contract Similar to Ford's
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation says his company could accept a contract like the one the United Automobile Workers negotiated with the Ford Motor Company if the pact was changed enough to suit G.M.'s operations.

title: Based on New Evidence, a Rape Suspect Is Freed
description: A Bronx man convicted of rape and robbery was ordered released from prison without bail yesterday after defense lawyers said they had uncovered evidence that proved the man was innocent. He will remain free pending a hearing on a new trial.

title: About New York; Monday Night And No Football: A Bar Survived
description: Lurking in America's autumn is a black hole - the absence of professional football as a result of the eight-day-old players' strike.

title: Unknown Disease Kills 14 Cranes at a Preserve
description: An unknown disease has killed 14 cranes, including three endangered whooping cranes, at the Patuxent Wildlife Research Center in Laurel, Md., the Fish and Wildlife Service announced today.

title: Brooklyn: A Sleeping Giant of Wine
description: MYSTERIOUSLY, the attention of connoisseurs has been captured by harvests in such unknown regions as Champagne, Tuscany and Rioja. But the real excitement is in Brooklyn, a wine zone I have long considered a sleeping giant.

title: NBC Strikers Might Vote on Offer
description: The negotiating committee of the union representing the 2,800 writers, editors and technicians on strike against NBC will confer today to discuss a proposal that may end the three-month-old walkout against the network, union and network officials said last night.

title: TV Reviews; 'New Image Teens' Offers Vignettes on Youth Issues
description: IT is deadly earnest, sometimes awkward and often plodding; no matter, the episode on ''New Image Teens,'' on Channel 13 at 6 o'clock tonight, is distinguished by its topic. The 30-minute program looks at ''date rape,'' a subject seldom talked about on television, but one with rich possibilities for discussion. The program, awkward or not, is saved by its own good intentions.

title: Study Backs View on Lack of Agent Orange Data
description: A Congressional agency has agreed that no large-scale study of the effects of Agent Orange on ground troops in Vietnam can be conducted because too few troops were actually exposed to the chemical.

title: ERNEST FLEISCHMAN
description: Ernest Fleischman, a lawyer who specialized in labor and immigration cases, died of heart failure Sunday at his home in San Francisco. He was 76 years old.

title: A NEW HISTORY OF THE CENTURY
description: A major encyclopedic work, ''Chronicle of the 20th Century,'' which has already appeared to acclaim in five West European countries, will be published in an American version tomorrow by Chronicle Publications of Mount Kisco, N.Y., a branch of Jacques Legrand International Publishing of Paris, which holds the world English rights.

title: New Giant Has a Professorial Stance
description: Danny Eugene DeRose resigned today as associate professor of economics and marketing at the University of Southern Colorado to play inside linebacker for the Giants.

title: New Ally in the Lost-Luggage Battle
description: Forget ''Star Wars,'' program trading and advanced manufacturing. How about applying computers to a more down-to-earth problem, such as the frustration and despair of losing luggage?

title: ARTS IN A CALENDAR CRUNCH
description: Arts institutions in the New York City region hereabouts are experiencing a culture crunch -a paucity of free dates on which to open major attractions.

title: CONGRESS DELAYS NEW PAKISTAN AID AMID NUCLEAR RIFT
description: Congress has suspended new American aid to Pakistan for six weeks while the Reagan Administration and legislators wrestle with the issue of Pakistan's nuclear development program.

title: Bridge: 2 Longtime Partners to Be Knockout Final Opponents
description: Two players who have played thousands of deals in partnership, Phillip Martin and John Lowenthal, both of Manhattan, will be opposing each other in the final of the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, tentatively scheduled for Sunday. For the first half of this decade they were the most successful partnership in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Philippine Economic Reform Must Go Faster
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stage: 'Sex in a Baggie'
description: IN Margaret Smith's move from comedian to performance artist, her new late-night show, ''Sex in a Baggie,'' at the Dance Theater Workshop, should be regarded as transitional.

title: Detente's First Victim
description: Summit-itis has both the White House and Foggy Bottom in its grip, and the Soviet Union has already begun to reap the fruits of detente.

title: Court Upholds Claim By Direction Seeker
description: Someone who is robbed and injured in his car while seeking directions is eligible for personal injury benefits from his automobile insurance company, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: Heat Names Inman
description: Stu Inman, who put together the Portland Trail Blazers when they entered the National Basketball Association in 1969 as an expansion team, has been named the director of player personnel of the Miami Heat, which will enter the league as an expansion team for the 1988-89 season. The 61-year-old Inman resigned from a similar position with the Milwaukee Bucks nine days ago. . . . The Chicago Bulls have rewarded Doug Collins, who took the team to the playoffs last season as a rookie coach, with a two-year contract extension that will run through the 1989-90 season.

title: Reagan May Consider Tax Changes to Cut Deficit
description: The Reagan Administration would consider making changes in the tax code as part of an effort to raise revenue and avoid an estimated $23 billion in automatic budget cuts this fall, James C. Miller 3d, the director of management and budget, said today.

title: Life Sentence Stands Despite Recantation
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that there was evidence showing a man serving a life sentence for the 1976 murder of a police officer might have been wrongfully convicted, but that the court was powerless to grant freedom or a new trial. The judge, H. Lee Sarokin, said in District Court here that the key witness against the convicted man, Vincent J. Landano, had recanted testimony identifying Mr. Landano as the man he had seen fleeing the scene of the shooting.

title: Weinberger Asks for Meeting With Chief of Soviet Defense
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he had invited the Soviet Defense Minister, General Dmitri T. Yazov, to Washington early next month for talks on arms control and other issues.

title: Intravenous Gains: A Trickle
description: THE nationwide effort to contain rising health care costs has stimulated demand for new devices for delivering intravenous drugs and nutrients to millions of patients. But the same campaign has hampered efforts by nutritionists and hospital supply companies to develop new intravenous solutions tailored to the individual patient's needs.

title: Official Says Coast Guard Lacks Resources to Fight Trash Dumping
description: The Coast Guard and the Interstate Sanitation Commission do not have the ability to pursue illegal ocean dumpers effectively, officials of the agencies told a joint hearing of state legislators from New Jersey and New York today.

title: GRIFFITH CONSUMERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and year-end results include a loss of $334,000 incurred from acquisition of a petroleum distributor on May 1.

title: Steady Line of Fans For Ticket Refunds
description: Ticket-holders for Sunday's Jet game against the Dallas Cowboys and Monday night's Giant game against the San Francisco 49ers gathered at Byrne Meadowlands Arena today to get their money back.

title: UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUACTURERS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $445,000 for the latest year and $197,000 for 1986. The latest year's results include the company's Brazilian operations through Sept. 30, 1986, and 1986's results include the company's Venezuelan and Brazilian operations which were subsequently sold.

title: Stock Prices Ebb on Modest Selloff
description: LEAD: The stock market retreated with a modest selloff yesterday, as traders and investors tried to evaluate seemingly conflicting signs from the currency and credit markets.

title: Garment Worker Talks Go On
description: Contract negotiations between the menswear industry and the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers union, under way for several weeks with little progress, were expected to continue around the clock tonight. The current agreement expires at midnight.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Analysis and Technology, a provider of submarine and anti-submarine warfare professional and technical services to the Navy, elected Thomas J. Will executive vice president and Larry D. Gilliland senior vice president.

title: Norway's Oil Strategy
description: Norway's oil minister, Arne Oeien, said today that he would visit Saudi Arabia next month to discuss the oil market. He also told reporters that Norway would probably extend its 7.5 percent production cut into next year to help the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries bolster prices.

title: Film Festival; 'Bad Blood,' From France
description: THE pictures are in charge in Leos Carax's ''Bad Blood,'' which plays at the New York Film Festival at 6:15 P.M. tonight and Friday. Most of the scenes seem to have been improvised in the interests of a striking shot, and the characters are in thrall to the camera. In this, his second feature, Mr. Carax lives up to his billing as ''the natural heir of Jean-Luc Godard,'' showing a taste for underground types and milieus, an inventive eye and a tolerance for tedium.

title: Yields 5.20%-8.35% On Illinois Bonds
description: A $100 million issue of Illinois general obligation bonds was offered yesteray through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: Topics of the Times; The Legacy of Henry II
description: Henry Ford 2d will surely be remembered best for his flamboyant self-indulgence, bitter divorces and autocratic management style - if not merely as the Ford who dismissed Lee Iacocca. Too easily forgotten is the fact that he was also the Ford who saved both the family name and company from ruin.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed Doug DeCinces, infielder, who was released Sept. 24 by the California Angels.

title: Celebrities Open Wallets to Fight Trump's Project
description: A group of West Side organizers raised more than $20,000 last night in a chic, celebrity-filled reception designed to rally opposition to Donald J. Trump's Television City project.

title: White Plains Orchestra Ceases Operations
description: The 25-year-old White Plains Symphony Orchestra has canceled its 1987-88 season and decided to cease operations because of a lack of money.

title: Tough on Show Biz
description: The recurrent suggestion that the press should have a bad conscience about forcing Gary Hart and Senator Biden out of the political competition is sentimental silliness. Somebody would have had to get them out eventually and for doing the job sooner rather than later the press ought to be commended.

title: Made in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE become increasingly fascinated with tuna. Until a few weeks ago I assumed that the only factor in selecting tuna was freshness. But while sharing a lunch of sushi with Japanese friends, I learned that the fat content is equally important.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Santiago Streak at 31
description: Benito Santiago of the Padres extended his record hitting streak for a rookie to 31 games tonight, but Francisco Melendez went 4 for 4, and Jesse Reid hit a home run in his time at bat in the major leagues to pace the San Francisco Giants to a 5-3 victory over San Diego.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error in some copies yesterday, a Washington dispatch about on a letter from 64 senators opposing an arms sale to Saudi Arabia misstated the number of votes needed in the Senate to override a veto. A two-thirds vote of those present is required - a total of 67 if all senators take part.

title: KEY RATES
AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After gains from the sale of assets of $1.2 million and $7 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: MATTHEW E. DANN
description: Matthew E. Dann, former headmaster of the Trinity School in Manhattan and the Trinity-Pawling School in Pawling, N.Y., died Aug. 4 at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital of injuries from an automobile accident. He was 84 years old and lived in Pawling.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
For Diets: KO the Mayo, But Pour on the Ketchup
description: LEAD: CONDIMENTS belong to one of the few classes of foods dieters can still dip into wholeheartedly. There is at least one major exception - mayonnaise - but things like tomato ketchup, mustard and horseradish are important flavor-bearers to souls on a diet.

title: BBDO Acquiring
description: BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, is planning to acquire Tycer-Fultz-Bellack, a 14-year-old agency in Palo Alto, Calif., that has billings from its advertising and public relations operations of $33.5 million. Plans call for the T.F.B. to continue under that name and with its current management.

title: CR-PL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $145,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Buying Wave in Japan Helps Dollar to Soar
description: The dollar surged to its highest levels in almost six weeks yesterday, propelled by a wave of Japanese buying and a continued rise in interest rates in the United States.

title: WINE TALK
description: COUNT it a lucky day if you come across the Piedmont wines that carry the Vietti label, which are made by Alfredo Currado. In fact, count it a lucky day if you come across the charming Mr. Currado.

title: Computers a Catalyst for Catalysts
description: IT took nearly a decade and 10,000 experiments for Fritz Haber, the German Nobel Prize-winning chemist, to discover in 1918 that a bit of iron oxide could accelerate the chemical reactions that produce ammonia out of nitrogen and hydrogen gas.

title: 3 Offerings Raise 'Junk Bond' Supply
description: The heavy supply of new ''junk bonds'' continued yesterday, as underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. offered three new issues with face amounts totaling $775 million.

title: Kincaid Furniture
description: Nortek Inc. intends to begin a $17-a-share tender offer for the 2.78 million shares of the Kincaid Furniture Company that it does not control, for an estimated price of $47.26 million. In a Securities and Exchange Commissison filing, Nortek said it had $195 million in existing credit agreements to finance the offer. Nortek told the S.E.C. that its bid was conditioned upon Kincaid's removing its shareholder rights plan, commonly known as a ''poison pill,'' and Nortek said it also plans to file suit in Federal court in Raleigh, N.C., to have the state's anti-takeover law declared unconstitutional. Kincaid, which made no comment on the offer, makes wood furniture. Nortek, of Providence, R.I., makes building materials.

title: Outlook Gloomy For New Talks
description: Labor leaders for the National Football League owners and striking players continued their meetings yesterday, the eighth day of the strike -but once again, not with each other. The Management Council executive committee gathered for a three-hour planning session in New York, and the union's executive director met with striking players in Atlanta and Elizabeth, N.J.

title: New York Panel Urges Widening Patients' Rights
description: Legislation that would give patients in New York the ironclad right to authorize other people to make life-and-death decisions about their medical treatment if they become incompetent was proposed yesterday by Governor Cuomo's Task Force on Life and the Law.

title: Mets, Almost Held Hitless, Are Left Almost Hopeless
description: On a night when their bats fell fatally silent, the Mets probably fell out of the pennant race tonight when they got just one infield single off Don Carman and lost to the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-0.

title: Schembechler Ailing
description: Bo Schembechler, whose Michigan Wolverines open their Big Ten football schedule at home against Wisconsin Saturday, was taken to St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., early yesterday. The 58-year-old coach, who has compiled a 209-58-7 won-lost-tied record in 24 years of college coaching (six at Miami of Ohio and 18 at Michigan) is suffering from a kidney stone problem. But according to Don Canham, Michigan athletic director, Schembechler probably will be released this morning and will coach Saturday.

title: ARTICLES ASSERT F.B.I. OFTEN WATCHED WRITERS
description: More than 50 American authors and dramatists - including such Nobel laureates in literature as Ernest Hemingway, Pearl S. Buck, Sinclair Lewis, John Steinbeck and William Faulkner - were the subjects of dossiers compiled by the F.B.I. and other government agencies during the last half century, according to an article in the Oct. 5 issue of The New Yorker magazine.

title: Senate Democrats Split Over Strategy on Bork
description: As Judge Robert H. Bork's confirmation hearing approached its 12th and final day, Senate Democrats were in open disagreement today over a strategy for handling the next phase in the battle over President Reagan's nominee to the Supreme Court.

title: Jays Lose, but Tigers Do, Too
description: The Blue Jays lost to the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-3, tonight and their lead over Detroit in the American League East slipped to one and a half games after the Tigers defeated Baltimore.

title: Europeans Weigh Bank's Fate
description: The six European banks that own the European American Bancorp -the former Franklin National Bank -are struggling with the future of the institution, and even considering changing its name back to Franklin National, according to bank analysts here with close ties to Europe.

title: Italy Drops Plan on Public-School Religion Classes
description: Facing discord within his Government and the prospect of a confrontation with the Roman Catholic Church, Prime Minister Giovanni Goria withdrew a plan today to make religion classes optional in public schools.

title: A Correction
description: The meaning of a sentence in a letter published Monday about the Soviet radar station at Krasnoyarsk by Allan S. Krass of the Union of Concerned Scientists was altered by editing. It should have read: ''What we see confirms what most informed United States analysts have concluded: the radar is not militarily threatening to the United States and cannot be seen as an attempt to break out of the ABM treaty.''

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $47,059,000. The net from discontinued operations in the latest 6 months comprises a gain from the sale of stock in Superdrug Plc., adjusted by loss reserves for the earlier disposal of Circus World Toy Stores Inc. and home health care operations.

title: Produce Grown to Order in Berkshires
description: AS Americans have shown more interest in fresh fruits and vegetables, farmers' markets that bring the grower and the buyer closer together have become more popular. The concept, though, has been taken much further by a group of people in South Egremont, Mass., who have set up an unusual system: instead of the farmers' planting crops and hoping to sell them, the consumers are paying them salaries to grow produce.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Pennsylvania is offering $152 million of its general obligation bonds through a group of underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

title: Plain Words About Food Win Renown For Shy Man
description: JOHN THORNE is a gruff, bespectacled bear of a man. He is shy enough to be a one-man advertisement for Powdermilk biscuits - the ones in the blue box that ''give shy people the strength to stand up and do what needs to be done.''

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
No Headline
description: ''While Khomeini is recklessly attacking Gulf shipping to stop the flow of everybody else's oil, we're buying a half billion dollars of his oil every year. We've had enough warning shots across the bow. Now it's time for action.'' Senator Bob Dole of Kansas. [ A1:1. ]

title: Sandinista Foes Are Dubious
description: Opposition leaders expressed doubt today that the Sandinista Government would live up to its obligations under the new Central American peace accord.

title: Group Assails Soviet on Inmates
description: Soviet political prisoners face harsh treatment and grueling labor in camps and jails despite social changes instituted under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the international human rights group Amnesty International said in a report issued today.

title: ADVANCE CIRCUITS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-After a gain of $1,737,000 from the refinancing of debt. c-Net loss

title: Expansion at Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said it would expand its paint and hardware store operations by opening 80 outlets by the end of 1988, bringing the total to more than 140. Michael Bozic, chairman and chief executive of Sears Merchandise Group, said a new national division would be responsible for day-to-day management of the stores.

title: BORK IS DISPUTED ABOUT WATERGATE
description: Two lawyers who formerly served on the Watergate prosecution force today challenged assertions by Robert H. Bork and his supporters that, as Acting Attorney General, he aggressively continued the investigation of the scandals after he dismissed Archibald Cox as special prosecutor.

title: Soviet Jews: A Litmus Test of Glasnost
description: LEAD: As glasnost unfolds, the Kremlin's treatment of Jews - the Soviet Union's most Westernized community -may well serve as an early indicator of its future policy toward the West.

title: No-Contest Plea Made By Posner
description: Victor Posner pleaded no contest today to charges of evading more than $1.2 million in Federal income taxes by inflating the value of land donated to a Miami Bible college.

title: Music: David Del Tredici
description: SINCE his ''Alice Symphony'' of 1969, David Del Tredici has mined ''Alice in Wonderland'' and other Lewis Carroll works with an obsessiveness that is hard to match in the history of musical composition. For nearly 20 years he has been turning out Carroll pieces, the count now standing at some two dozen works. Most recent to appear was ''Haddocks' Eyes,'' commissioned by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and first performed last year.

title: Becton Dickinson Names President
description: Becton Dickinson & Company said yesterday that its board had named Raymond V. Gilmartin president, putting him in line for the top post at the major maker of hospital and medical diagnostic supplies.

title: Philippine Economic Reform Must Go Faster; A Dangerous Time
description: To the Editor:

title: DEAN FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Gold Fields Pact Amended
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation, busy fighting off T. Boone Pickens, said today that it had changed an accord with its ally Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. so that the British mining company could tender its Newmont shares to a third party.

title: Financiers and Wallets
description: Some of the movers and shakers of international finance who descended on Washington this week for the annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund had gathered Monday night for an elegant dinner party given by the First Los Angeles Bank and Italy's Instituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino. A murmur of appreciation rose form the candlelit tables as the guests unwrapped their souvenir gifts - wallets of fine Italian leather. But one guest, G. William Miller, a former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and Treasury Secretary in the Carter Administration, appeared less than thrilled.

title: Donnell Anthony Segalas Wed to Suzanne Wilcock
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Suzanne Jill Wilcock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bray Wilcock of Short Hills, N.J., was married last Saturday to Donnell Anthony Segalas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hercules A. Segalas of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Polish Borders Affect Population Figures
description: To the Editor:

title: Mattingly Breaks Slam Mark
description: In each of his first three full seasons in the major leagues, Don Mattingly did something to distinguish himself. In 1984, he won the American League batting championship. In 1985, he led the league in runs batted in and was named the most valuable player. Last season, he led the league in five offensive categories and broke the Yankees' record for hits with 238.

title: Robertson Quits as a Baptist Minister
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson, who plans to announce his Presidential candidacy formally on Thursday, resigned today as a Southern Baptist minister and severed ties to the Christian Broadcast Network, which he founded and has led for 27 years.

title: Bush Tours Birkenau and Auschwitz
description: A grim-faced Vice President Bush toured bleak reminders of the Nazi death camps today and afterward, in a shaken voice, said there was ''no way to express'' his emotions.

title: Real Estate; New Tower on 56th St. At 5th Ave.
description: AFTER more than five years of planning and negotiating, the developers of the 56-story tower that is to rise on West 56th Street just off Fifth Avenue have started to build.

title: Revco's Chairman And His Son Leave
description: Less than a year after leading Revco D. S. Inc. in a $1.29 billion leveraged buyout, Sidney Dworkin, a founder and its chairman, abruptly resigned yesterday as head of the nation's largest drugstore chain, along with his son, Marc, an executive vice president.

title: Dalai Lama Receives Humanities Award
description: The Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, received the Albert Schweitzer Humanities Award Monday at the First Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn Heights.

title: Top New York Official Resigns From S.E.C.
description: Facing low morale in the New York office of the Securities and Exchange Commission and a threat of mass resignations, Kathleen A. Warwick, head of the office, resigned yesterday. She had been the agency's top regional official for less than a year.

title: Privacy Suit Dismissed Against New Yorker
description: A $10 million suit for defamation and invasion of privacy has been dismissed against The New Yorker magazine; Janet Malcolm, a staff writer for the magazine, and Alfred A. Knopf, the publisher, by Judge Eugene Lynch of Federal District Court in San Francisco.

title: 3 Indicted in Case Of Couple Set Afire
description: Three Brooklyn teen-agers, accused of setting fire to a young couple while hey slept in Prospect Park, were indicted yesterday on charges of attempted murder and assault, District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman said.

title: Lauren Fragrances To Wells, Rich, Greene
description: Warnaco, which has already assigned its Ralph Lauren fashion line to Wells, Rich, Greene's Image Group, has now given it its fragrances as well. They are the Polo, Lauren and Chaps brands that were formerly served by Geers, Gross Advertising, which continues with other Warnaco fragrances.

title: Gelco Holds Talks
description: The Gelco Corporation, a leasor of cars, trucks and tractor-trailers, said it was negotiating a possbile takeover with an unidentified suitor. ''Discussions are in a preliminary stage and no assurances can be given that an agreement will be reached,'' the company said in a statement. No details were given. Gelco's stock jumped sharply today, closing up $8, to $31 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Earlier this month, the company sold Gelco Express Ltd., its Canadian courier service, to Air Canada. It expects a $15 million gain in the first quarter because of the sale. It is also planning to sell its Transport International Pool Inc. and Design Space International Inc. The Minneapolis-based company earned $11.9 million on sales of $728.1 million in the year ended July 31.

title: Enjoying the Wild Abandon of Recipes From an 1822 Book
description: LEAD: THE other day I received a 1929 German cookbook and found it full of solid old recipes and great common sense. An omelet, one recipe states, has to be crisp outside and moist inside. ''And if you cannot muster that discipline,'' the cookbook continues, you will never understand ''what only five cooks out of a hundred know.

title: Dreyfus Seen Likely to Quit New York City
description: The Dreyfus Corporation is likely to move its headquarters and back-office operations, which employ 1,200 people, out of New York City, municipal officials said yesterday.

title: Chicago AIDS Benefit Draws Stars and 3,000
description: Peter Allen, Colleen Dewhurst and Angela Lansbury led a cast of celebrities in a $1 million benefit performance for AIDS victims Sunday.

title: KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
description: The drop in net reflects a loss in income resulting from accounting for the company's Wolf Creek nuclear power plant.

title: Inouye Seeks to Move Indian Museum to Capital
description: Weeks after New York officials reached an agreement aimed at keeping the Museum of the American Indian in New York City, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the chairman of the Select Senate Committee on Indian Affairs, has introduced a bill to move the museum to Washington.

title: New Primary Ordered In Race for Judgeship
description: A new Democratic primary for a Civil Court nomination on the Lower West Side of Manhattan was ordered yesterday by Justice Michael J. Dontzin of State Supreme Court. The special primary, on Oct. 20, will cost the city about $100,000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1987
description: International

title: Fairfax Affirms Ms. Acquisition
description: Selling the magazine division of John Fairfax Ltd. will not affect the Australian media company's agreement in principle to purchase Ms. magazine, according to officials of Fairfax's United States subsidiary.

title: Are Female Tears Saltier Than Male Tears?
description: She cried.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The results for this year include eight months of operations of Development Corp. of America, which was acquired by Lennar in December 1986.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: 10 Plays in One Night

title: 'The Water Hole,' A Wildlife Special
description: ''THE WATER HOLE'' is gorgeously filmed, bursting with life and put together with intelligence and imagination. Wild animals struggle, survive and perish in a national park in Namibia. As a wildlife film, ''The Water Hole,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, is choice.

title: From Friends and Associates, A Tribute to Michael Bennett
description: An overflow crowd gathered yesterday afternoon at the Shubert Theater to memorialize Michael Bennett, the director and choreographer who died of AIDS on July 2. They listened as Mr. Bennett's friends and colleagues recalled moments in a brief life, and as a palpable sadness enshrouded the theater.

title: Indonesia Satellite Shift
description: Indonesia said today that the European space consortium Arianespace would launch its next satellite because a United States bank would not finance the venture. France had offered a loan with attractive interest rates for the purchase of the Palapa B2-R satellite and its launching by an Ariane rocket in 1990, Indonesia said. The United States has put four Indonesian satellites into orbit since 1976.

title: Market Place; Colgate View Seems Bright
description: THE Colgate-Palmolive Company, with 48-year-old Reuben Mark at the helm as its chairman and chief executive, continues to speed through a restructuring plan that has erased its once stodgy image while raising long-range prospects of even better earnings growth and equity appreciation.

title: INQUIRY ON BOMBER FOCUSES ON BIRDS
description: The investigation into the crash of an Air Force B-1 bomber focused yesterday on whether the plane's encounter with a flock of birds should have been averted by existing systems for reporting bird migrations.

title: JACO ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fiji Plans to Quit Commonwealth
description: Col. Sitiveni Rabuka, the army commander who seized power in a coup last week, said today that he would formally abolish the 17-year-old Constitution, eliminating the post of Governor General and suspending the judiciary.

title: For Rest and for Work
description: 1.Slippers to Go Wrap your feet in these comfortable slippers made of padded French cotton. Printed with lavender flowers, they are lightweight, have leather soles and fold easily for travel. The price is $24 at La Boutique de Marie Claire, 831 Madison Avenue, between 69th and 70th Streets. 2.Flying Into Order The Orville Supply Plane will land on your desk with all sorts of useful items. Its wings, tail, propeller and body hold scissors, tape, glue, paper clips, an eraser, a pencil sharpener, a tape measure and a stapler. The plane, which comes in red with white wings or blue with red wings, costs $14.95 at Conran's, 160 East 54th Street, in the Citicorp Center, and 2-8 Astor Place, near Broadway. 3.Animal Cookies If the cookie jar was a high point of your childhood, this rabbit should revive fond memories. It costs $25 and is part of a menagerie of cookie jars. In That's Entertainment on the sixth floor at Bloomingdale's; also available at branch stores.

title: Stage: 'Mississippi Delta'
description: THE subtitle of ''From the Mississippi Delta'' identifies it as ''A dramatic biography of a young girl coming of age,'' but it is also the biography of the girl's mother, and, in fusing these two lives together, Dr. Endesha Ida Mae Holland has made her play -which is at least partly autobiographical - as forceful a statement about the lives of women as it is about black people.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Japan and West Germany must act to emulate America and they need the ''gumption'' to take unpleasant economic medicine for the benefit of a debt-burdened and slow-growing world economy, President Reagan told the annual meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Page A1 A ban on imports from Iran, most of which are oil, was voted by the Senate without dissent. The largely symbolic measure reflected frustration over the situation in the Persian Gulf. A1 New U.S. aid to Pakistan was halted by Congress until the Reagan Administration and legislators resolve the issue of Pakistan's nuclear development program. A waiver of a U.S. law that would have prohibited all aid expires today. A1 Mikhail S. Gorbachev quelled speculation about his physical and political health by reappearing at the Kremlin after a 52-day absence from public view. Mr. Gorbachev was shown on television looking tanned, rested and robust. A1 South Korea's opposition deadlocked as its two dominant leaders, Kim Young Sam and Kim Dae Jung, failed to show a willingness to compromise on which of them should be their party's presidential candidate. A3 Neil Kinnock urged the Labor Party in England to examine its Socialist economic principles in light of the new ''realities'' brought about by nine years of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's policies. A14 French fortunetellers are in demand to tell who will be the next President, reflecting a genuine uncertainty about the race. President Francois Mitterrand leads in the opinion polls. A14 Bush visits Nazi death camps A3 London journal A4 Group assails Soviet on inmates A8 U.S. admits error on mines A10 Pretoria change urged by Shultz A11 Peres outlines plan for peace A12 Italian catechism plan derailed A13 NATIONAL A15-28, B4, B28 A Senate disagreement over strategy for handling the next phase in Judge Robert H. Bork's confirmation has erupted, following the majority leader's a suggestion that the Senate vote without a recommendation from the Judiciary Committee. A1 Tax code changes to raise revenues would be considered by the Reagan Administration in an effort to avoid an estimated $23 billion in automatic budget cuts, said the director of management and budget, James C. Miller 3d. A28 Victor Posner pleaded no contest in Miami to charges of evading more than $1.2 million in Federal income taxes by inflating the value of land donated to a Miami Bible college. D1 The Rev. Pat Robertson will sever his ties to the religious broadcasting empire he has led for 27 years. Mr. Robertson, who plans to announce his candidacy for President, is also resigning as a Southern Baptist minister. A20 Women at high risk of AIDS infection are well-informed about the disease but few change their behavior, experts meeting in Maryland at a federally sponsored conference on AIDS and women said. A18 Adults are replacing children as the major consumers of comic books. Publishers are trying to satisfy adult tastes by marrying off some characters, aging others and offering slicker editions. A1 American chefs are endorsing products as diverse as cooking equipment and credit cards as they discover that culinary celebrity can be easily converted into the coin of the realm. C1 Study backs view on lack of Agent Orange data A15 Berkeley journal A18 California acts to speed output of AIDS drugs A18 Audubon Society to monitor acid rain A19 Judge's jurisdiction over Boston schools is limited A22 Bork's role in Watergate disputed A25 Ex-Pentagon aides say they were overruled on Wedtech B28 WASHINGTON TALK A26 New book on C.I.A. stirs questions of press ethics Politics: Are female tears saltier than male tears? REGIONAL B1-3 A law that would give patients in New York the ironclad right to authorize other people to make life-and-death decisions about their medical treatment was proposed by Governor Cuomo's Task Force on Life and the Law. A1 The region's deer have multiplied to their highest level in centuries, posing serious, as well as comical, problems for motorists, farmers and suburban homeowners. Wildlife officials say many deer are being killed by cars. B1 The Museum of the American Indian, which New York officials have worked to keep in New York City, would move to Washington under a bill proposed by Senator Daniel K. Inouye, chairman of the Select Committee on Indian Affairs. B3 A seminary has rejected a proposal to build a luxury condominium tower on its Morningside Heights campus. Financially pressed Union Theological Seminary opted instead to raise money by selling or leasing an off-campus residence hall. B1 Work rules for firefighters that prevent them from inspecting buildings in ''inclement weather'' are under attack by New York City officials in negotiations on a new contract with the firefighters' union. title: Fewer Games on Tape
description: Dispelling reports that the bulk of Knick and Ranger games televised on Channel 9 this season would be shown on a delayed basis, Madison Square Garden Network and WWOR announced yesterday that only 12 of the 45 broadcasts will be delayed, with only seven of the taped games beginning after 11 P.M.

title: Peru Is Closer To Bank Law
description: The Congress approved a bill today allowing the state to take control of private banks, opening the way for President Alan Garcia to sign the measure into law.

title: London Journal; After Dusting Cobwebs Of Victoriana, Goodbye
description: Sir Roy Strong, the pithy Englishman who made the mammoth Victoria and Albert Museum prance stylishly into the modern era of the ''leisure industry,'' is quitting as director, exhausted by his own forced evolution from Renaissance scholar to money-hungry ''cultural economist.''

title: After 52 Days and Many Rumors, Gorbachev Reappears at Kremlin
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev reappeared today at the Kremlin after a 52-day absence from public view that had generated speculation about his physical and political health.

title: Berkeley Journal; Swimming Against Tide: Sometimes It's Natural
description: Everybody knew Berkeley was not the typical American city even before Mayor Loni Hancock departed last Friday to deliver medical supplies to Nicaragua. The ''peace delegation'' also included Assemblyman Tom Bates, her husband, and the sous-chef of the Fourth Street Grill, among other Berkeley notables. Two days earlier, in a lonely heroic foray on the ozone front to defend the stratosphere for human posterity, the City Council voted to make Berkeley the first American city to ban fast-food containers made with chlorofluorocarbons.

title: Incinerators Held to Pose Ash Hazard
description: More than half the ash from waste-to-energy incinerators in New York tested by the state's Environmental Conservation Department exceeded Federal limits for hazardous waste, according to a report released today by the department.

title: ADVERTISING
description: * Richard H. Shahan has been named vice president, communications, of the Association of National Advertising.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Off Sharply
description: Treasury bond prices fell sharply yesterday, raising yields to the highest level since December 1985, as traders and investors were discouraged by a worldwide move to higher interest rates and a heavy supply of Government securities.

title: Tax Division Nominee
description: President Reagan will nominate William S. Rose Jr., a South Carolina lawyer, to be Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's tax division, the White House said today. If confirmed by the Senate, he would succeed Roger Olsen.

title: EMONS HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,485,839 from the extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year; a tax loss carryforward of $33,616 for the quarter, and the year includes an extraordinary charge of $2,050,176 and a tax credit of $35,714. c-Net loss and includes a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $250,440. The company was formerly Emons Industries.

title: CHEFS FIND FAME BUT NO FORTUNES IN ADS
description: AMERICAN chefs are discovering what athletes have long known: that celebrity can be easily transformed into the coin of the realm. From Wolfgang Puck and Alice Waters to Andre Soltner and Anne Rosenzweig, chefs are being courted to endorse not only food and cooking equipment but credit cards and telephone companies.

title: Kinnock Fights Copycat-Party Image
description: In the United States, Neil Kinnock may be known as the man who turned Senator Joseph R. Biden into a copycat orator. Here at the Labor Party's annual conference, he is trying to combat the more serious allegation that he wants to turn Labor into a copycat party.

title: CHALLENGER INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Canadiens 4, Islanders 3: Sergio Momesso and Kjell Dahlin scored second-period goals last night, leading the Canadiens past the Islanders in an exhibition game at Nassau Coliseum. The victory extended Montreal's exhibition record to 4-2-2, while the Islanders dropped to 3-3-0. Mikko Makela opened the scoring on a power play for the Islanders at 15 minutes 52 seconds of the first period. Brian Skrudland scored just 10 seconds later on a 60-foot slap shot past Billy Smith, the Islander goalie, to tie the game. Pat LaFontaine scored at 2:29 of the second period on another power play, putting the Islanders back in front, 2-1, before Momesso connected at 4:07 and Dahlin scored 10 minutes later. Bobby Smith scored Montreal's fourth goal at 9:58 of the third period. Denis Potvin scored the third power-play goal for the Islanders on a 45-foot slap shot.(AP) Tennis Curren Advances: Kevin Curren, seeded seventh, defeated Glenn Layendecker to move into the second round of the $293,400 Transamerica Open tournament yesterday in San Francisco. The South African who resides in Austin, Tex., won by 6-4, 6-2. In other first- round matches, Jay Berger, Todd Nelson and Jim Grabb advanced. Grabb won, 6-2, 6-2, from a former teammate, Patrick McEnroe, whose older brother John is sitting this tournament out for the first time in 11 years because of a 60-day suspension for his behavior at the United States Open.(AP)

title: FLORIDA ROCK & TANK LINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago results are pro forma, giving effect to certain assets and liabilities transferred from Florida Rock Industries to Florida Rock & Tank. The pro forma results also give effect to certain leasebacks entered into between the two companies under the spinoff of Florida Rock & Tank by Florida Rock Industries as if the transfers occurred Oct. 1, 1985.

title: ASTROSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Chairman of Joint Chiefs Admits U.S. Underestimated Mine Danger in Gulf; Channel Swept for Mines
description: Three newly arrived British minesweepers searched the most-traveled shipping channel off Dubai for at least three possible mines spotted Sunday night.

title: Grown-Ups Gather at the Comic Book Stand
description: Spiderman married. Clark Kent, alias Superman, became a yuppie. And some caped marvels have aged, developing paunches and mid-life crises.

title: U.S. Really Did Well in Physics Olympiad
description: To the Editor:

title: Cards Sitting Pretty After Two Shutouts
description: The St. Louis Cardinals' struggle to produce runs - the problem that produced hope in New York and Montreal for a race in the Eastern Division of the National League - continued for much of the evening. But the remarkable resourcefulness of the Cardinals all but ended the race and began a noisy celebration at Busch Stadium tonight.

title: An Age of Pretense
description: Before we finally say bye-bye to Senator Biden, we ought to give the guy half a break. At least he knew when to quit, and he reminded us that petty betrayals and mindless neglect sometimes have deplorable results.

title: Trial of Gambino Figures Starts With Depictions of Leaders
description: A Federal prosecutor described Joseph N. Gallo, the 76-year-old reputed consigliere of the Gambino crime family, yesterday as a high-echelon mobster who was the ''adviser to the boss and underboss'' and received a share of the illicit earnings of the family capos.

title: Union Seminary Rejects Proposal To Build Tower
description: The Union Theological Seminary has rejected a proposal to build a luxury condominium tower on its campus in Morningside Heights. Instead, the financially pressed school will raise money by selling or leasing an off-campus residence hall.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pat Petersen, America's fastest marathoner this year, announced yesterday that he would run in the New York City Marathon Nov. 1. His time of 2 hours 12 minutes 42 seconds while finishing 12th in the London Marathon last spring was the fastest in 1987 by an American, but ranks only 48th internationally. . . . Jim Spanarkel and Tim Bassett, former National Basketball Assocation players, were added yesterday to the radio broadcast crew of the Nets that will be headed this season by Howard Davis, the play-by-play announcer. . . . When Rob Murphy relieved in Cincinnati's 5-4 victory over Atlanta yesterday, it marked his 84th appearance of the season, breaking the mark for left-handed pitchers in the National League set last year by Craig Lefferts of San Diego. . . . Greg Clark, a senior linebacker at Arizona State, has been sentenced to 30 days in prison and three years' probation for assaulting a police officer outside a nightclub in Tempe, Ariz., last May 9. He will begin serving the term Dec. 18, after the fall semester, but before any bowl games the Sun Devils might be in.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Henry Ford 2d Is Dead at 70; Led Auto Maker's Recovery
description: Henry Ford 2d, who took over the ailing auto company founded by his grandfather and restored it as one of the world's industrial giants, died yesterday in Detroit of complications arising from pneumonia. He was 70 years old.

title: A Delicacy Scraped From Pacific Rocks
description: What looks like a carpenter's thumb, feels like a rubber hose and is sweeter and more tender than spiny lobster? Why, gooseneck barnacles.

title: SENATORS, 98 TO 0, BACK IMPORT BAN AGAINST TEHERAN
description: The Senate, venting frustration over the situation in the Persian Gulf, voted without dissent today for a ban on all imports from Iran, most of which are oil.

title: Topics of the Times; Brooklyn Celebrates Diversity
description: Only three blocks away, on Remsen Street, the special guest at Our Lady of Lebanon Cathedral could have testified to the hazards of social diversity. He was President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon, a country that has given new meaning to the word faction. Beset by political and tribal struggles, religious and class rivalry, his country has known no lasting peace for decades.

title: Council Explores New Path to Truce in Gulf
description: The Security Council is expected to ask Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar in the next few days to see if Iran and Iraq will accept a cease-fire linked to steps to determine which of them is responsible for their seven-year-old war, informed diplomats said today.

title: Billington Sent Down
description: The Devils made three personnel decisions yesterday, the biggest of which was deciding to go with Alain Chevrier and Bob Sauve in goal instead of Craig Billington, who was sent to the team's top affiliate in the minor leagues, the Utica Devils of the American Hockey League. Murray Brumwell, defenseman, and Chris Cichocki, forward, were also sent down.

title: Fund Chiefs Map Drive on Poverty
description: The new chiefs of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund met their government shareholders today and presented freshly minted strategy for coping with poverty and the world debt crisis.

title: MAKING WAY FOR 'MAHABHARATA'
description: Brace yourselves. That is the motto these days at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where every living soul seems to be gearing up for the imminent arrival of Peter Brook and Jean-Claude Carriere's nine-hour-long, Indian-inspired stage epic ''The Mahabharata.'' Loosely translated, the title means ''the great story of mankind,'' which has been boiled down from an ancient, holy and still universally used Sanskrit text 15 times longer than the Bible.

title: Skeptical Audubon Society Will Track Acid Rain
description: The National Audubon Society, one of the oldest environmental organizations, announced today that it was monitoring acid rain around the country because it was dissatisfied with Government efforts.

title: U.S. Aides Say They Lost Battle Against Wedtech
description: Two former Pentagon officials told a Senate panel today that they had strongly opposed the awarding of a major Navy contract to the Wedtech Corporation but were overruled for what appeared to be political reasons.

title: Anybody Here Seen 'Icebox'?
description: ''Hello, Personpower Unlimited? My name is Rozelle and I need a thousand temporary workers this weekend.

title: Schoolboy Caught Smoking Accused of Shooting Teacher
description: A 16-year-old student has been charged as an adult with attempted murder and unlawful use of a weapon in the shooting of a teacher who had caught him smoking.

title: U.S. Court Pares Judge's Control On Boston Schools in Rights Case
description: The Federal appeals court here has further limited a Federal district judge's control of Boston's schools in a 13-year-old case that led to busing to achieve desegregation. The ruling tentatively returns the assignment of students to school officials.

title: Canada Sees Major Snag in Stalled Trade Talks
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today that ''fundamental differences'' remained between Canada and the United States over their stalled free-trade negotiations despite more than seven hours of high-level talks in Washington on Monday.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 30, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee's Working Group on Migrant Workers' Rights - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Legal Committee - 10 A.M.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for 12mo Aug 31
description: Results for 1986 are restated for the effects of the implementations of FAS 90.

title: H. Bourke Weigel, 75, Dies; Coordinated Design of U.N.
description: H. Bourke Weigel, a New York architect for nearly half a century, who served as coordinator on the design of the United Nations headquarters, died of liver cancer Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Scarborough-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Dart Lifts Dayton Bid To $68
description: The Dart Group Corporation sweetened its bid for the Dayton Hudson Corporation by $3 a share yesterday, to $68.

title: J.P. Morgan Realty Venture
description: The J. P. Morgan Investment Management Company and Silverstein Properties have formed a limited partnership to invest in real estate in the New York area for tax-exempt pension funds, the companies announced yesterday.

title: California Judge Halts A Mountain Lion Hunt
description: Citing inadequate environmental studies, a judge has ordered California to postpone the first authorized hunt for mountain lions in 16 years.
